While it is unclear whether James will start on the right or left as Leeds aim to secure a first league win of the season, do not expect to see Liverpool’s Trent Alexander-Arnold in midfield. Interestingly, Jürgen Klopp has poured scorn on Gareth Southgate’s decision to deploy the right-back in that department for England against Andorra. Louise Taylor

Burnley were one of nine teams to leave Goodison Park with maximum points last season as Carlo Ancelotti’s side routinely faltered when trying to take the game to opponents. That has been the clear instruction from Rafael Benítez so far, however, and a more direct, positive approach has underpinned an encouraging start to his Everton reign. Salomón Rondón could profit following his deadline-day arrival from China while Sean Dyche is considering a first start for new £15m signing Maxwel Cornet as Burnley seek their first league win of the campaign. Andy Hunter

Brentford have already taken five points from Arsenal, Crystal Palace and Aston Villa but Thomas Frank feels Brighton will present their “toughest opponent so far”. Thehosts will certainly look in fine shape if they are still unbeaten come Saturday night but Graham Potter will hope to bring the form of their first two fixtures, which brought six points, rather than the home defeat to Everton. Victory for the away side would boost the notion that they can push for a top-half finish in the coming months. Nick Ames

It already looks like crunch time for both Arsenal and Norwich. If either team loses they will be pointless from their opening four games and fighting an uphill battle from here to achieve their respective ambitions. Thomas Partey’s return is a huge boost for Mikel Arteta, who may also give Ben White a home debut. The visitors’ head coach, Daniel Farke, will oversee his 200th match in charge and hopes to buck a trend: Norwich have failed to win any of their last 23 Premier League games in London. Nick Ames

Wolves have lost all three league games 1-0 this season despite deserving at least a point from each match. A lack of cutting edge has cost them dear but at least Raúl Jiménez is available after Mexico withdrew their objection to him playing. Watford could hand a debut to Ozan Tufan, the Turkish midfielder who has joined on loan from Fenerbahce. Alex Reid

A trio of shiny new West Ham signings could make their debuts at St Mary’s with Kurt Zouma, Nikola Vlasic and Alex Kral all cruising through the international break unscathed. Ralph Hasenhüttl has no such luxuries and will field a similar XI to the side which drew 2-2 at Newcastle – although one of his summer additions, the right-back Tino Livramento, has made a positive early impression. Keeping out Michail Antonio, who has started the season magnificently with four goals in three games, is key to a Southampton success. Alex Reid

Chelsea will expect to maintain their unbeaten start to the season when they host Aston Villa. Thomas Tuchel is without N’Golo Kanté and Christian Pulisic, but Saúl Ñíguez is in the squad after joining from Atlético Madrid and Romelu Lukaku has shaken off a minor thigh injury suffered on international duty. It will be tough for Aston Villa if Lukaku is in the mood on his home debut – especially as Emi Buendía and Emiliano Martínez are unavailable after going abroad to play for Argentina. Jacob Steinberg

Cristiano Ronaldo has already taken the shirt number off Edinson Cavani’s back and is likely to steal his starting spot for his first appearance for Manchester United since May 2009. Newcastle could be without their own, arguably slightly lower-wattage, star attacker as Callum Wilson is suffering with a thigh injury. Jonjo Shelvey and Ryan Fraser are also absent but Paraguayan playmaker Miguel Almirón is available to play. In non-Ronaldo news, Mason Greenwood is in red-hot form and, after his curious England omission, should be perfectly rested to torment Newcastle. Alex Reid

A pair of 5-0 wins in their last two outings suggests Manchester City are starting to find their form and will fancy their chances of avenging last month’s Community Shield defeat against Leicester. Brendan Rodgers’ side have done well to amass six points from their three matches so far despite stuttering performances, caused partly by injuries. If Jonny Evans is deemed fit enough to make his first start of the season, possibly alongside Jannik Vestergaard, he could bring renewed solidity to a defence that could otherwise be tormented by the visitors. Paul Doyle

Tottenham have been quietly going about their business playing very well under Nuno Espírito Santo and are the only team with a 100% winning record as a result. Travelling to Crystal Palace will likely be their biggest test yet with Son Heung-min’s fitness in doubt and the trio of Giovani Lo Celso, Cristian Romero and Davinson Sánchez all unavailable. Patrick Vieira should certainly be fired up against his former north London derby rivals, and will hope his side pick up from their creditable draw at West Ham to secure a first win. In the end, Harry Kane’s superiority could be all Tottenham need to continue their barnstorming start. Graham Searles
Subs from Klaesson, Struijk, Forshaw, Roberts, Costa, Rodrigo, Cresswell, Drameh, Summerville, Shackleton

For his 100th league game as Manchester United manager, Ole Gunnar Solskjær could deploy a style that has served him well so far. Counter-attacking has been one of the keys to United’s impressive away form during his reign and Wolves, who have become ultra-offensive under Bruno Lage, may play into their hands, a little like Leeds did on the opening day. On the flip side, Wolves intensity and audacity could stress United’s midfield and defence. If Wolves’ finishing is better than it was in their first two games, then this could be a landmark day for Lage, too, and Wolves’ first win of the season. Paul Doyle
Subs from Elliot, Ngakia, Deeney, Fletcher, Gray, Hughes, Quina, Success, Sierralta, Pollock, Baah, Hungbo, Perica, Hernández, King, Kucka

Norwich’s difficult start to the season continues with the tricky task of hosting Leicester. Brendan Rodgers’ side have been so-so thus far, though, with defenders missing and those that do play making uncharacteristic errors. Be that as it may, Leicester will see this as a get right game to try to continue Norwich’s misery as they target finally getting over the hump to qualify for the Champions League. Graham Searles

Arsenal fans have been somewhat divided over the strength of the side Mikel Arteta put out in the Carabao Cup second round this week. Some are glad he took it seriously enough to still be in the tournament; others wondering how has it come to this in a cup Arsène Wenger used to give talented youngsters first-team exposure. Either way the 6-0 shellacking of West Brom has at least put a little swagger into Arsenal’s stride as they travel to take on the champions without a league goal or point on the board. Manchester City recovered from their limp opening-day defeat at Tottenham by trouncing Norwich last week and even without Harry Kane or Cristiano Ronaldo they should have the attacking armoury to extend Arsenal’s poor start. Paul Chronnell

Another London derby for Crystal Palace, who are still waiting for their first league win under Patrick Vieira. It has been an underwhelming start for Vieira, desperately seeking attacking reinforcements before the transfer window shuts on Tuesday. Palace are yet to score a league goal this season and they have taken one point from two games before visiting West Ham, who are close to signing Kurt Zouma from Chelsea. Jacob Steinberg

At least one of the early 100% starts to the season must fall at Anfield, where the tactical battle between Jürgen Klopp and Thomas Tuchel, the personal duel between Virgil van Dijk and Romelu Lukaku and the outcome for two of the title favourites make for a compelling occasion. Liverpool have won two of their past 11 home games in all competitions against Chelsea, who were among those to capitalise on the mid-season malaise at Anfield earlier this year, but have started in clinical, resolute style. Neither team have conceded a goal in the Premier League this season. Andy Hunter

Dean Smith can take satisfaction from the fact that this is a Premier League match, since he played a role in the rise of both clubs. He did well during three seasons in charge of Brentford, during which he hired Thomas Frank as his assistant. Now Smith hopes Villa become the first team to score a league goal against Frank’s side this season. With Danny Ings having netted twice in two games so far, the hosts’ hopes will be high, even more so if Ollie Watkins is fit enough to make his first appearance of the season. Paul Doyle
Injured Veltman (fitness, Sep), Lamptey (hamstring, Sep), Welbeck (hamstring, Sep), Burn (knee, unknown), Scherpen (ankle, unknown)

A big day beckons for Adam Armstrong. Born and bred in Newcastle and part of his hometown club’s academy from the age of nine, the Southampton striker was devastated to be told he was not good enough to make the grade at St James’ Park. That was three years ago when Armstrong was sold to Blackburn in a transfer that would prove the making of him and preface this summer’s £15m switch to Southampton. Now he can show his former employer – and Steve Bruce’s side are not only winless so far this season but have scored just two goals in 270 minutes – precisely what they are missing. Louise Taylor

It will be cheers all around from the home fans as they welcome back Nuno Espírito Santo before watching the first match at Molineux under his replacement, Bruno Lage. Nuno is very familiar with the Wolves players but perhaps not with the new attacking style Lage is trying to embed. Given how many chances Wolves missed at Leicester on the opening day of the season, Lage no doubt spent much of this week working on finishing. Nuno, meanwhile, gave most of his team an opportunity to rest while he sent a second string into Europa League action. Paul Doyle

Manchester United have enjoyed kicking Leeds around at home since the latter’s promotion so Southampton could be a better test of where Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s side are at. The last time United won by more than a goal at St Mary’s was 2009. Jadon Sancho starting would also give an even better indication of the kind of damage United can inflict going forward if Paul Pogba and Bruno Fernandes continue their destructive form from last week. Southampton’s shoddy backline (only West Brom conceded more goals last season) could be in trouble after losing Ryan Bertrand and Jannik Vestergaard. The omens feel rather bleak for Ralph Hasenhüttl. Graham Searles

These sides will be hoping to kick on after challenging for Champions League qualification last season. They almost upset the established order – Leicester only missed out on the final day – and both have made winning starts to the new campaign. West Ham mounted a strong comeback at Newcastle after a poor first half and Leicester, who hope to have James Maddison available, beat Wolves thanks to a goal from the evergreen Jamie Vardy. It should be a tight game. Jacob Steinberg

What you really want when you have been badly beaten by a newly promoted side, lost four players to Covid-19 and generally started the season already in crisis is a visit from the European champions and their shiny £97.5m striker. However, Arsenal fans looking for straws to clutch in the ill August wind will be aware Mikel Arteta’s side followed up their FA Cup final win over Chelsea 12 months ago by doing the double over their London rivals last season. Thomas Tuchel was only in charge for the last of those three defeats but will know that an Emirates Stadium full for a league game for the first time in 17 months and the hosts having Bukayo Saka and captain Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang available again could present a genuine early test of Chelsea’s title credentials, against a Chelsea side without Christian Pulisic, who has tested positive. With Manchester City away next week, Arteta needs to get something on the board on Sunday or the first international break of the season might be a little uncomfortable. Paul Chronnell

What is worse than following up a battering from Liverpool with a visit to the champions at the Etihad? A visit to face Manchester City fresh from defeat on the opening day at Tottenham. Norwich have a huge task on their hands in avoiding defeat and could be forgiven for using the game as more of a training exercise to prepare for more important tests on the horizon. Pep Guardiola will be out to remove all doubt regarding his side’s credentials for another triumph by making sure his side get back on track in front of a full house. Kevin De Bruyne’s return, even if only from the bench, could make this a lot easier. Graham Searles

Can Patrick Vieira exact revenge for Arsenal? Crystal Palace’s manager will certainly hope he can after a debut in the dugout to forget against Chelsea. This is surely an early marker for Vieira to be judged by and Palace’s vociferous support, back in full voice at Selhurst Park, will surely want to see something to spoil Brentford’s party. Thomas Frank could not have hoped for a better start and, with Palace in transition, an important second win from two could be on the cards. Graham Searles

Burnley have fared well on their past two visits to Anfield – ending Liverpool’s club record run of 68 home games unbeaten last season and emerging as the only visitors to avoid defeat during the host’s title-winning campaign the season before. Both matches, however, were played behind closed doors and the first full capacity Anfield crowd in 17 months will be keen to make its presence felt once again. The game also marks the meeting of the two longest serving current managers in the Premier League. Andy Hunter

Elland Road is sold out as two of the finest coaches of their generation cross swords in English football for the first time. Marcelo Bielsa will be anxious to atone for last weekend’s 5-1 reverse at Manchester United but the return of Leeds supporters for the first time since the pandemic struck in March 2020 should offer his side a welcome adrenaline boost. Not that Bielsa is about to underestimate Rafael Benítez as Everton’s new manager plots a second straight Premier League win. “Benítez has been successful because he puts together compact teams and always gets the maximum from his players,” said Bielsa. “His teams are always hard to beat.” Louise Taylor

Brighton and Watford pulled out perfect starts against tricky opposition and will be keen to start an early hot streak at the Amex Stadium. Graham Potter’s sider appear the better bet to do so as they are on a strong run – a positive result against Watford will make them six games unbeaten at home and equal their Premier League record. Xisco Muñoz has an ace in the hole with Ismaïla Sarr, though. The winger wreaked havoc in the Championship last season and will likely cause Brighton significant stress in defence. Graham Searles

Aston Villa had a rough start after dominating possession but losing 3-2 against Watford. Dean Smith’s side should brush this off fairly easy and be quietly confident of a first victory when they host Newcastle. Douglas Luiz could return to bolster midfield and if Leon Bailey is given a first start the winger could add extra attacking impetus on the left. Steve Bruce’s new attacking intent, on display against West Ham, could also play into Villa’s hands, as it did for David Moyes’s side. The continued absences of Martin Dubravka and Karl Darlow are not ideal for Newcastle’s chances of a positive result, too. Graham Searles

When Newcastle emerged comfortable 2-0 winners from their first match of last season at the London Stadium, few imagined West Ham would end the campaign in sixth place. Or that, despite ultimately finishing a reasonably comfortable 12th, Steve Bruce’s team would look like relegation candidates for prolonged periods. Much here hinges on how Newcastle’s first large crowd – almost 50,000 are expected – since late February 2020 react to Bruce. Many fans still want him replaced but Joe Willock’s £25m arrival from Arsenal should help pacify dissent, while Allan Saint-Maximin, Callum Wilson and Miguel Almirón offer more than sufficient attacking flair to pose West Ham problems. Louise Taylor

Imagine that Harry Kane does get on against Manchester City, the club he is desperate to join. How would he feel about denting their title hopes? How would City’s defenders feel about denting him? On the other hand, Kane could be keen to remind Pep Guardiola of his scoring prowess. Then again, is he in any shape to excel? Even the sight of him would draw a reaction from the Spurs crowd. In a game of many subplots, one transcends them all. David Hytner

Round one of the new season could be a cracker with Manchester United hosting rivals Leeds. Received wisdom says Marcelo Bielsa’s attacking play should suit United’s love of the counter. But this is sport so the script may prove a little different. And do not expect a repeat of last term’s 6-2 rout from Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s side. Jamie Jackson

Rafael Benítez did not win any of his opening Premier League games in charge of Liverpool, Chelsea or Newcastle and needs to rectify that sequence in his first game as Everton manager at Goodison Park. There was audible dissent against Farhad Moshiri’s controversial appointment during the 4-0 pre-season friendly defeat at Manchester United last weekend and few allowances will be given for the mediocre squad, and the FFP constraints, that Benítez has inherited. Southampton have not won at Goodison since 1997, however, and faced their own disruptions this summer, with Danny Ings and Jannik Vestergaard leaving. Andy Hunter

There has been one goal in the past four meetings between Leicester and Wolves but Saturday’s encounter promises to be very different. Bruno Lage has been hired to turn Wolves into a vibrant attacking force and, with Leicester’s defence not at full strength, he will hope to start as he means to go on. But he may be concerned about his own defenders, too, as a lack of summer reinforcements raises questions about their ability to play the high-pressing style that Lage likes. Leicester are well equipped to profit from any transitional pains. Paul Doyle

To say Jürgen Klopp would be disappointed to leave Carrow Road without three points would be an understatement. Norwich have taken only two of the last 42 points on offer between the sides, conceding at least three goals in seven of their past nine meetings and a whopping five in three of the last eight. Still, Daniel Farke’s side will feel under less pressure to make an immediate impact and Liverpool’s midfield remains a relatively unknown quantity since Georginio Wijnaldum’s departure. The Kosovan international Milot Rashica is an exciting home addition and could give the Reds something to think about at left-back in the absence of Andy Robertson. Kostas Tsimikas will hope for a rare chance but with an embarrassment of riches at centre-back now fit and available following last season’s injury nightmares, Klopp does have the option of changing formation to start three of them. Stuart Goodwin

How lovely it is to see everyone’s favourite midfield marauder (except Manchester United fans, maybe), Patrick Vieira, back in the Premier League where he belongs and at the tiller of Crystal Palace. Vieira has quite the task on his hands in the short and long term. A trip to Champions League winners Chelsea is a very tough task for a first assignment and bettering Roy Hodgson’s consistency will be even tougher. The extra minutes played in the Super Cup might soften Thomas Tuchel’s side up a little but the quality the German has at his disposal should overpower Palace in the end. Graham Searles

Aston Villa will be keen to scale even greater heights this season and a trip to Watford could allow an easy road towards doing exactly that. Dean Smith’s rock-solid defence will be on hand to shut down attacking threats as per usual but with Jack Grealish gone, Leon Bailey isolating, Douglas Luiz not back from Olympic duty and Emi Buendía and Ollie Watkins doubtful, Villa look more than a little threadbare across the rest of the pitch. The evergreen but non-threatening Ashley Young’s presence on the wing says it all regarding what might prove a sluggish start at Vicarage Road. Graham Searles

Burnley suffered an alarming regression from a 54-point finish in 2020 to 39 in 2021. The squad looks almost identical to last season’s so it is tough to see where improvement will come from. Whether Brighton can capitalise and find the goals they have been sorely missing to climb higher is the key conundrum for Graham Potter. Both managers will be acutely aware they must do better as this season’s crop of newcomers look more likely to pose a threat than the dead wood that allowed both sides to coast to safety in May. Graham Searles

What may have been a nothing game against Manchester United now has huge significance for Wolves and those lucky to be attending Molineux. Nuno Espírito Santo is waving goodbye to Wolverhampton. Yes, its bye-bye Black Country, auf wiedersehen West Midlands. The M54 beckons to pastures that may be distinctly based in north London. But enough speculation, Nuno’s fine four seasons have completely transformed the club and brought a wonderful Portuguese flavour to Wolves. One that has made the club a force in the Premier League and the fans can only hope it lives on after he departs. Some ugly crying may be the required tonic over a Pastel de Nata or two when the dust finally settles. Graham Searles

Leicester must beat Tottenham and realistically hope Liverpool fail to beat Crystal Palace to qualify for the Champions League. A disappointing state of affairs after allowing Jürgen Klopp’s side to sneak ahead and, when compared to a first FA Cup finally sitting in the trophy cabinet, ending up in the Europa League will not sting at all. Spurs, meanwhile, will be desperate for a win of their own to avoid a classic St Totteringham’s Day if Arsenal beat Brighton. To slip below the Gunners would be particularly painful after leading them for the whole season and, indeed, the entire league for a minute earlier on. Graham Searles

Fulham welcome fans back to Craven Cottage, albeit only 2,000 thanks in part to their stadium redevelopment, but it will not be for the relegation showdown they had once anticipated. Scott Parker’s side are playing for pride and it is likely to be a farewell for several of their players, particularly the raft of loanees who have filled out their squad. “This team has never let anyone down through a lack of effort, pride or professionalism,” Parker said. He will hope they curb Joe Willock’s hot streak for Newcastle, who could yet finish as high as 12th. Nick Ames

Before 10,000 adoring fans at the Etihad Stadium, Manchester City will parade a Premier League trophy magnificently claimed in a most trying of seasons. Before this, though, comes the visit of Everton and Pep Guardiola will, of course, want his players to give the crowd a victory to shout about after another impressive season. Jamie Jackson

Marcelo Bielsa’s contract at Leeds is about to run out and he has said he will take “the delicate decision” as to whether to extend it after Sunday’s finale at home to West Brom. However, the Argentinian has stressed he has had “no alternative offers” and that “many coaches in the world” would covet the Elland Road job. Bielsa, whose side are finishing the season in excellent form, hopes to make it a miserable last day in the West Brom managerial tracksuit for Sam Allardyce. After keeping a clean sheet at Southampton in midweek Kiko Casilla will retain his place in the home goal for possibly his final appearance for Leeds. Louise Taylor

Brighton have taken four points from their last two visits to the Emirates so, given they are also buzzing from their comeback win over Manchester City, may not be ideal opponents for Arsenal’s bid to secure Europa Conference League football. Time will tell whether that is any kind of prize to cherish: for now Mikel Arteta must do without Hector Bellerín, who may have played his last game for the club, and waits on the definitely-departing David Luiz. The in-form Nicolas Pépé, with six goals in his past 10 matches, will hope to inflict further damage. Nick Ames

West Ham need only a draw against Southampton to end a remarkable season by finishing sixth and sealing qualification for the Europa League. David Moyes has done an outstanding job and will hope his side put on a show for the returning crowd at the London Stadium. However West Ham have a concern over Lukasz Fabianski. The goalkeeper is a doubt after suffering a knee injury before the midweek victory at West Brom. Jacob Steinberg

Jack Grealish’s return precipitated a fine win over Tottenham and now the Aston Villa faithful have a chance to see their man in action for the first time this year. But will it be the last? The talisman will surely have suitors this summer and, if he upstages Chelsea’s creative forces, interest could kick into a higher gear. Thomas Tuchel’s side cannot afford this to happen to avoid missing out on Champions League football next season. Win and they are in the hat again, lose and they face the possible ignominy of falling out of the top four and failing to qualify as potential beaten finalists in this year’s edition. Graham Searles

The 10,000 Liverpool fans who will be present at Anfield could not have envisaged the prize at stake when the ticket ballot opened just over two weeks ago. Nor could Jürgen Klopp, for that matter. But, after collecting 23 points from the last 27 available, his team will be in the Champions League next season with three more against an opponent they beat 7-0 five months ago. Klopp has won more Premier League games against Crystal Palace than any other team (9) and an Anfield crowd would take more satisfaction than most in ruining Roy Hodgson’s farewell to top-flight management. Andy Hunter

A grim season for Sheffield United looks like finishing with a great sense of hope for a strong Championship campaign after 17-year-old striker Daniel Jebbison struck down Everton last week. Fans will be eager to see how the Canadian fares against a naturally rugged Burnley side that has earned another season in the Premier League. Sean Dyche has shown he is a master of achieving a great deal with meagre resources once again. He may not be pretty but damn it, he gets results. Graham Searles

Aston Villa could have a problem in defence with Matty Cash ruled out and Tyrone Mings doubtful but they will have top scorer Ollie Watkins back from suspension. Villa struggled in front of goal in the 0-0 draw with Everton on Thursday so the return of Watkins, who was serving a one-match ban after his sending off against Leeds, will be a welcome one for Dean Smith. Palace could make changes to the side that lost 3-1 to Southampton on Tuesday but Christian Benteke, who has found goalscoring form towards the end of the campaign, is expected to retain his place in attack. A large proportion of Roy Hodgson’s squad are out of contract in the summer and, with Premier League safety secured, they have an opportunity to impress potential new employers. Rich Flower

Carlo Ancelotti insists Everton will fight until the final day to secure European qualification, and believes three more wins could yet clinch it, but a major improvement at Goodison Park is required to achieve that aim. His team have the worst home record of the top 14 clubs in the Premier League and, as another sterile display on Thursday at Aston Villa underlined, their lack of creativity without James Rodríguez is glaring. The Colombia international has a chance of featuring against the league’s bottom club, who have won only once on the road this season. Andy Hunter

While Jürgen Klopp started the season with far grander ambitions than scrapping for fourth place come May, the Liverpool manager will sense that a tortuous campaign can maybe end on a happy note after Thursday’s victory at Old Trafford reignited their top-four challenge. Given third- and fourth-placed Leicester and Chelsea meet on Tuesday, Klopp knows that three wins will probably be enough for his side to leapfrog one of them come the final Sunday and secure Champions League football. Given his side’s form this season that cannot be considered a foregone conclusion, yet there were signs in the 4-2 win over United of the departing champions being a potent attacking force again. West Brom, relegated by last Sunday’s defeat at Arsenal, have nothing but pride to play for but Sam Allardyce rarely turns down the opportunity to bloody the nose of one of the bigger clubs. Paul Chronnell

If you speak to any Tottenham fans, this is a time of much debate. Who will the next manager be? Will Harry Kane stay? And, most urgently: is there any way Spurs can manage to not finish seventh and therefore qualify for Uefa’s new Europa Conference League? The simple solution to that last question is to keep playing as badly as they did at Leeds last weekend and Everton, West Ham or (God forbid) even Arsenal could yet claim that dubious privilege. The answer to the first question is the most pressing, and may also provide the solution to Kane’s future. The man in the opposite dugout on Sunday, Wolves’ Nuno Espírito Santo, has been mentioned as a potential candidate. Then again, there have been already been a few of those. Ryan Mason is recovering from the considerable shock of being handed a Wembley cup final against the champions-elect as his first ever game in charge of a football team, but is clearly holding the fort until the summer. Just don’t finish seventh, Ryan, and you may even end up with the permanent gig. Paul Chronnell

Southampton may have had a wretched second half of the season – Tuesday’s win over Crystal Palace was only their third in 18 Premier League games – but they do have one thing Fulham would dearly like: another season in the top flight. Having won just three of their last 25 games and five in total Scott Parker and his side cannot really complain, but there are many neutrals who will be sad to see them go given their enterprising attacking game. Premier League scouts will be circling around the likes of André-Frank Zambo Anguissa and Tosin Adarabioyo but given the volume of players on loan Parker will want to hang on to his leading lights if he is to fashion an instant return. Danny Ings was on target in that midweek win and while the striker may not be a Southampton player for much longer, on Saturday he will again likely exhibit the kind of lethal finishing that Fulham, for all their good intent, could not muster this season. Paul Chronnell

After something of a meltdown at Molineux in their last game which saw Brighton blow a 1-0 lead, lose 2-1 and get two men sent off, Graham Potter would have been mightily relieved 24 hours later to see Fulham confirmed in the third and final relegation place. With a fifth consecutive season in the top flight to look forward to the shackles may be off for the hosts but West Ham arrive on the south coast with much to play for. Last week’s defeat to Everton was perhaps a fatal blow to their top-four hopes, but a Europa League or Europa Conference place is still very much in their grasp if they can win their final three games. A word of caution to David Moyes, however: West Ham have failed to beat Brighton in all seven previous top-flight meetings since the Seagulls came up in 2017. Paul Chronnell

Burnley’s ruthless win at Craven Cottage confirmed both their safety and Fulham’s relegation on Monday, but in truth the 4-0 win at Wolves a fortnight earlier had suggested Sean Dyche’s side were in the Premier League to stay once again. It is fair to say Turf Moor’s ‘ginger Mourinho’ has a rather different philosophy to the man in the opposite dugout on Saturday, Marcelo Bielsa, but there will certainly be mutual respect between the pair whose sides both play to their strengths and are united by a fierce work ethic. The way Leeds dismantled Tottenham at Elland Road last weekend showed that Bielsa’s hard-running style has, despite some doubts, lasted until May. A European place looks beyond Leeds, but a top-half finish will be just reward for their fine season. The only doubts now will be whether both managers will still be in situ come next season, or if they will be tempted away by suitors who would find their achievements on limited budgets hard to ignore. Paul Chronnell

Manchester United’s place in the Champions League next season is virtually guaranteed but a win against Aston Villa would still be another step to confirming their place. Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s side will be in high spirits after cruising into the Europa League final but the manager will implore his side to maintain their momentum as he eyes a first trophy since taking charge at Old Trafford. Dean Smith will want the exact the same after a great win against Everton while Villa’s Tyrone Mings, Ezri Konsa and Ollie Watkins will be eager to keep impressing Gareth Southgate to make England’s squad for the European Championship this summer. Graham Searles

West Ham remain in contention for Champions League qualification with four games left and David Moyes will be feeling even more optimistic if he beats his former side at the London Stadium. These are heady times for West Ham, who hope that Declan Rice is closing in on a return from his knee injury. However Everton are strong on the road and have not given up hope of qualifying for Europe themselves. Jacob Steinberg

Wolves gave rare starts to several young players in Monday’s draw with West Brom and their performances may convince Nuno Espírito Santo to send them into action again on Sunday. Vitinha made a particularly strong case for inclusion even though João Moutinho is available. Brighton, who need a win to guarantee survival, will be testing opponents. The past four meetings between these clubs have resulted in draws – it would be no surprise if Sunday’s did too. Paul Doyle

Fulham take their latest swig in the last chance saloon on Monday night. They have fallen agonisingly short when it counted in recent weeks and realistically require four successive wins to stay up after managing five all season. Not many stranger things have happened, in truth, but victory over Burnley would notionally keep some heat on Sean Dyche’s side and also maintain their slim chances of catching Newcastle. “I get that we may fail this year,” Scott Parker said in an otherwise positive press conference on Friday; he hopes to keep the dream alive for at least another few days. Nick Ames

It is unlikely to be the cheeriest of Sunday nights at the Emirates given both sides could be put out of their misery, whether in avoiding the drop or chasing the Europa League, by full time. Sam Allardyce will have West Brom fired up for one last go but Mikel Arteta must raise his troops after the disastrous aggregate defeat to Villarreal. Eddie Nketiah may be among the players who get a chance to convince their manager they still have a long-term future at Arsenal. Nick Ames

This promises to end as a day of celebration in Manchester’s blue half if City beat Chelsea and claim a third Premier League title in four years under Pep Guardiola. Take care of business and the manager can ease his players through the remaining four matches ahead of the Champion League final on 29 May. City’s opposition in Istanbul? Chelsea, of course. Jamie Jackson

As a Tottenham player Ryan Mason became accustomed to hearing his old manager, Mauricio Pochettino, sing Marcelo Bielsa’s praises. Back then Mason could hardly have envisaged leading Spurs against Bielsa’s Leeds at Elland Road in his capacity as the team’s 29-year-old interim manager. Or that Tottenham’s hopes of European qualification could rest on victory in West Yorkshire. Much may hinge on whether Harry Kane or Patrick Bamford triumphs in a much anticipated battle of two strikers whose importance to their respective teams simply cannot be underestimated. Bamford will be hoping to not only propel Leeds into the top 10 but secure himself a late place alongside Kane in England’s European Championship squad. Louise Taylor

When Liverpool and Southampton last met on 4 January Jürgen Klopp’s champions were top of the table with one defeat in 16 games. Danny Ings’ early goal at St Mary’s Stadium precipitated a collapse still being felt today, with eight defeats in the past 17 matches leaving Liverpool seven points adrift of Champions League qualification. With Chelsea visiting Manchester City, and having had two weeks to prepare as a result of the Old Trafford postponement, the hosts can not afford another Anfield slip-up against a team that has shipped more away goals – 38 – than any other Premier League side this season. Andy Hunter

The stakes are acutely low at Bramall Lane as Sheffield United prepare for the Championship against long-since safe Crystal Palace. United fans will be pleased to see Sander Berge back in the starting lineup but that is where the good feeling begins and ends. Paul Heckingbottom’s tenure has been poor (two goals scored with 17 conceded in seven matches) and Roy Hodgson will be confident Palace can capitalise to end their rough spell of three successive defeats. Graham Searles

When, little more than a month ago, Newcastle lost 3-0 at Brighton they seemed Championship bound and Steve Bruce looked set to be sacked. Instead, Mike Ashley opted to stick rather than twist and this apparent gamble on the part of the club’s owner has seen the team collect eight points from their last four games. Should an Arsenal side likely to have one eye on next week’s Europa League semi-final, second leg against Villarreal be beaten Newcastle will reach the 39-point mark and be virtually certain of avoiding relegation. Yet, while an attacking combination of Callum Wilson and Allan Saint-Maximin look set to stretch Mikel Arteta’s defence, the Tynesiders must cope without their recent super-sub, the unavailable Arsenal loanee Joe Willock. Louise Taylor

Successive defeats against Newcastle and Chelsea may have dented West Ham’s top-four hopes, but David Moyes and the club’s fans will know that qualifying for any European football next season would be a significant achievement. Injuries are starting to bite, however, with the loss of Declan Rice in central midfield the most significant although both he and Michail Antonio, scorer of the winning goal when these sides met in east London in January, have a chance of returning on Monday. Burnley have been buoyed by their magnificent and unlikely 4-0 win at Wolves which has mostly banished their relegation fears, but the arch-pragmatist Sean Dyche is unlikely to be letting his players think along those lines. Paul Chronnell

West Brom begin the weekend nine points adrift of safety after conceding an agonising late equaliser at Villa Park – and their survival prospects may be even bleaker by Monday. “We’d have liked to have given ourselves a better chance,” Allardyce admitted this week. This is an opportunity to keep hope alive against opponents they beat 3-2 at Molineux in January, and who slumped to a dismal 4-0 home defeat against Burnley last week. Nuno Espírito Santo has revealed his side have “many injury problems” going into the derby game but declined to go into details – “that would be an advantage to our opponent.” The Wolves manager will demand a reaction from his players to Sunday’s performance, which he succinctly described as “terrible”. Niall McVeigh

After Manchester United’s 6-2 shellacking of Roma in the Europa League semi-final, Liverpool will hardly fancy taking on a home team 13 points ahead of them with five games left to play. That amounts to a 46-point swing from last season: Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s side trailed home 33 points behind Jürgen Klopp’s champions last term. That is further encouragement for United, but do not count Liverpool out in what is traditionally a fiercely-contested game. Victory at Old Trafford would boost Liverpool’s fading top-four hopes – but could also end their reign and confirm Manchester City as champions. Jamie Jackson

Sheffield United’s last visit to Tottenham, in November 2019, ended in a 1-1 draw that sent the Blades fifth in the table and signalled the end of Mauricio Pochettino’s reign as Spurs manager. Plenty has changed for both sides since, and mostly for the worse. A home fixture against relegated opponents offers Spurs caretaker Ryan Mason the chance to shake off a dismal few weeks following Super League protests, Harry Kane hinting at his departure and a painful Wembley defeat. Fellow temporary appointment Paul Heckingbottom earned his first win at home to Brighton last weekend, and with it a place on United’s shortlist for the permanent role. Niall McVeigh

While Chelsea have been excellent in the big games under Thomas Tuchel, their record against struggling sides threatens their hopes of finishing in the top four. Tuchel’s team have wobbled at Stamford Bridge of late, drawing with Brighton and losing to West Brom, and need to sharpen up when they host Fulham. An upset could be on the cards if Chelsea, who are without Antonio Rüdiger and Mateo Kovacic, are thinking about their upcoming semi-final second leg against Real Madrid. Fulham, who are sliding closer to the Championship, will hope their neighbours have other things on their mind. Jacob Steinberg

Brighton missed an opportunity to ease their relegation concerns with the 1-0 defeat at Sheffield United and face a tricky run-in, starting against a Leeds side unbeaten in their last six. Graham Potter’s team won the return fixture at Elland Road thanks to an early goal from Neal Maupay, who will be desperate to atone for a shocking miss at Bramall Lane. Ben White is available to face his former club after suspension, while Leeds are still without the injured Raphinha. Rodrigo could return to the bench as Marcelo Bielsa’s team look to continue their late push for a Europa League spot. Niall McVeigh

In the midst of a Champions League semi-final battle with PSG, Pep Guardiola must be glad his City side have such a healthy lead as they head to Selhurst Park 10 points clear at the top and knowing victory could seal the title if Manchester United were then beaten by Liverpool at Old Trafford on Sunday. Guardiola will undoubtedly rotate his treble-chasing squad and his opposite number, Roy Hodgson, may be tempted to do likewise. Palace slipped to defeat after leading at Leicester on Monday and with only one win in seven are limping to the finish even if their relegation fears have all but dissipated. Paul Chronnell

Despite regularly failing to seize their opportunities at Goodison Park – where Everton have taken six points from a possible 27 this year – Carlo Ancelotti’s stubborn side remain in contention for European qualification courtesy of their contrasting results on the road. A first win at Arsenal in 25 years took Everton’s away haul to 33 points from a possible 48 this season and they will leapfrog Liverpool and Tottenham with a second home league win of 2021. Villa, who remain without Jack Grealish, have won only two of their last 11 Premier League games and last won at Goodison in 2008. Andy Hunter

In normal times Manchester United fans would be streaming east over the Pennines for this one. Instead there will be no scarves flapping from the windows of countless cars traversing the M62, no good-humoured queues at Hartshead Moor services and no intense hostility between home and away supporters at Elland Road. If ever a fixture highlighted what football has lost since necessarily being moved behind closed doors it is this one. “A classic game,” as Marcelo Bielsa put it. The Leeds manager will be keen to atone for his side’s 6-2 reverse at Old Trafford earlier in the season but must cope without the injured Raphinha and Rodrigo and the suspended Liam Cooper. Edinson Cavani will doubtless fancy his chances of scoring a goal or two for Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s side. Louise Taylor

Aston Villa’s season may be meandering before another round of off-season improvement but a chance to virtually destroy West Brom’s hopes of survival will be enticing. Another occasion where a crowd would have provided an electric amphitheatre of these West Midlands’ rivals. Not long to go now, hopefully, and the same goes for Sam Allardyce’s side who reverted to type in limp defeat to Leicester. Villa desperately miss Jack Grealish but should still have the quality in defence to handle everything Allardyce throws at them as he tries to save his precious title of having never been relegated. Graham Searles

Crystal Palace will have had over two weeks’ rest by the time they travel to Leicester on Monday so it will be interesting to see whether they are rusty or recharged against Brendan Rodgers’ side, who in that time followed up victory in the FA Cup semi-finals with an impressive dismantling of West Brom. Leicester appear to be back in their groove, with James Maddison making a successful return to action and Jamie Vardy and Kelechi Iheanacho continuing to thrive together up front. Sometimes this season Leicester have struggled to penetrate defences who sit deep at the King Power but there is good reason to believe they will find ways through Palace. Paul Doyle

Nuno Espírito Santo effectively ruled himself out of the running this week for the position of Tottenham’s next full-time manager, with the Portuguese indicating that there is still plenty he wants to achieve with Wolves. This has been a difficult season for them but they appear to be finding consistency at last and are looking to win three league games in succession for the first time in this campaign. That could be bad news for Burnley, who are still too close to the relegation zone for comfort. Paul Doyle

Steve Bruce welcomed the fact that “the big six have took a slapping” over their duplicitous attempts to get even richer at the expense of the football pyramid and would enjoy landing another on Liverpool as he looks to secure Newcastle’s safety. Back-to-back wins have bolstered those prospects but Newcastle have won only one Premier League game at Anfield – in April 1994 – and Liverpool have won more home games against them than any other club in the Premier League era. Now that Champions League qualification is presumably important again to Liverpool’s owners, they will be looking to Jürgen Klopp’s team to provide a timely distraction. Andy Hunter

West Ham and Chelsea duking it out for a place in the top four should easily be the game of the weekend (sorry Carabao Cup final) and could be one of the games of the season. The bigger picture of the European Super League fiasco is a grim one but small thanks should be paid to Chelsea for firing up their rivals as a win for West Ham would leapfrog them above the breakaway boys into fourth. Just thinking about the prospect raises a smile. The task for David Moyes is a tough one though without Declan Rice to martial a midfield loaded with quality on the other side of the ball. Jesse Lingard is in incredible form though and a goal or two from him could be enough with Chelsea scoring only once in their past three matches in all competitions. Graham Searles

Sheffield United face Brighton now officially relegated after appearing checked out on this campaign for some time. Graham Potter would surely still have been confident of a positive result if United were still fighting but now his side should have a very good chance of taking an important three points as they look to glide above a relegation dogfight. Never say never and all that but Brighton were brilliant in grinding a draw out of Chelsea and look set to improve next season if they can hold on to Potter. Graham Searles

Aleksandar Mitrovic gave his teammates a rousing pep talk in the wake of last week’s desolating setback against Wolves, and Fulham need to show it has sunk in. Defeat at the Emirates would be their fifth in a row and demand a miraculous run in order to escape relegation. Wins are required but Arsenal are of a similar mind and refuse to give up on making the European places: it is the start of a relatively kind run-in for Mikel Arteta’s side and, while he may rotate, the manager will not allow his players to focus solely on Europa League salvation. Nick Ames

Reports in Argentina claim Marcelo Bielsa is close to agreeing a new two-year deal with Leeds and, although he has countered that “the information is not real”, there is growing optimism at Elland Road that the manager will renew a contract set to expire in June. Bielsa’s meeting with Jürgen Klopp should be intriguing. How will Liverpool’s manager – not to mention players – respond after Wednesday night’s Champions League exit to Real Madrid? Can the champions salvage a trophy-less season by somehow finishing in the top four? Then there’s the question of whether there’s still time for the Leeds striker Patrick Bamford to gatecrash Gareth Southgate’s England squad in time for this summer’s Euros. Louise Taylor

Manchester United can cut the gap to Manchester City to eight points by beating Burnley but even then only six games will remain so Ole Gunnar Solskjær is right to rate as unrealistic the chance of a late surge for the title. But finishing second is an improvement on last year so there is an incentive against a Burnley team who will aim to be problematic for the home side. Jamie Jackson

In Steve Bruce’s mind David Moyes has already won the manager of the year award for steering West Ham into unlikely Champions League contention. That would have been hard to envisage when Newcastle won convincingly in east London at the start of the season. But back then few could have imagined that a Bruce ensemble propelled by the attacking skills of Callum Wilson and Allan Saint-Maximin would end up in a relegation skirmish. Injuries to that pair represent a big reason why Newcastle continue to look nervously over their shoulder but with the two forwards restored to full fitness they have reason for cautious optimism that they may have opened up a nine-point advantage on relegation rivals Fulham by the time the final whistle blows. Louise Taylor

Wolves ended a five-match winless streak thanks to Adama Traoré’s last-minute goal at Fulham last week but were struck by another two cruel blows in a luckless campaign. Pedro Neto has already undergone surgery for the knee injury suffered in that match, while Rúben Neves will miss this weekend’s game, at least, after testing positive for Covid-19. Sheffield United have an even longer absentee list but this might just be Paul Heckingbottom’s best chance of picking up a point during his time in temporary charge of the Blades. Paul Doyle

Manchester United’s place in the top four looks secure for the time being so a tepid draw – like many of those produced since being thrashed 6-1 by Tottenham – against José Mourinho’s side would suffice. Spurs on the other hand need a win to catch up and Mourinho will be eager to stick it to his former employers. A full complement of defenders will certainly help the endeavour after last week’s misfire against Newcastle. Graham Searles

If one result might kick West Brom into some high-flying, season-saving mania it is walloping Chelsea 5-2. Ignore Thiago Silva’s red card and focus on the task at hand – stacking up wins, starting with Southampton. Ralph Hasenhüttl’s side may have picked up a win of their own against Burnley but showed the brittleness that has plagued them all campaign by quickly going 2-0 down. The flipside, of course, was the marvellous comeback spearheaded by the returning Theo Walcott and Danny Ings. The pair could profit in the second half once again should Sam Allardyce resort to throwing the kitchen sink at a vital set of three points. Graham Searles

Aston Villa did Newcastle a huge favour after they slipped into the relegation zone briefly but now would be a good time for Steve Bruce’s side to make their own destiny and find a win after relying on Fulham failing so far. The last time Newcastle won, eight matches ago, was also when Callum Wilson tore his hamstring, so the striker’s return feels like a potential ray of light to help scrape survival. Burnley look to be just about safe and will be keen to draw a line under last week’s capitulation at Southampton from 2-0 up. Graham Searles

West Ham’s hopes of qualifying for the Champions League rest on how they cope without Michail Antonio and Declan Rice. Antonio has followed Rice into the treatment room after injuring a hamstring against Wolves last Monday and is unavailable against Leicester, who are four points above David Moyes’s side. Moyes must find a way to adjust in attack. Leicester will spy a chance to record a precious win. Jacob Steinberg

Arsenal’s season may be alive in the Europa League but they share an empty feeling with Sheffield United that their league campaign has become more of a box-ticking exercise at this point. Mikel Arteta’s side must fight through the disappointment to avoid going five games without victory in all competitions before the second leg against Slavia Prague. United will hope to recreate last season’s brilliant win over Arsenal. It was surprising then but would be much less so now regardless of their league position. Graham Searles

Everton need to regain their winning touch as time dwindles away for them to make a late surge to qualify for European competition next season. The Champions League remains in play but if they fail to beat Brighton and turn around a poor run of three without victory that glittering door could finally start to feel closed. Carlo Ancelotti’s side certainly don’t appear to be the same one that started the season so emphatically. Graham Potter will be hoping Brighton can compound Everton’s misery and take a step toward confirming their place in the Premier League for another season. Graham Searles

With a maximum 10 points required (because of goal difference) to be champions again, Manchester City welcome Marcelo Bielsa’s Leeds as they go hunting for the first three of these. Bielsa is a mentor of Pep Guardiola but until the 90 minutes is up the latter will only be intent on victory, improving on the 1-1 draw in the reverse fixture. Jamie Jackson

Chelsea have to get things right domestically before facing Porto on Tuesday after their shambolic thrashing at the hands of West Brom. Selhurst Park feels like one of the last places Thomas Tuchel would pick to do so but without the suspended Thiago Silva, Chelsea have a better chance of putting to bed an unfortunately timed week of turmoil. Palace have a defender enjoying the twilight of his career rather more in Gary Cahill. The former Chelsea stalwart can serve a reminder that he may have been let go a touch too soon and damage their prospects for Champions League qualification next season. Graham Searles

Jürgen Klopp said October’s 7-2 defeat at Villa Park will be on his mind as Liverpool look to end a damaging sequence of six successive losses at Anfield. “We have to put things right,” he said of Liverpool’s heaviest league defeat since 1963. Victory, which would be Liverpool’s 100th in all competitions at Anfield under Klopp, would not only enhance prospects of a top-four finish but improve confidence before next week’s Champions League return against Real Madrid. Aston Villa, however, can move to within two points of the champions with an eighth away win of the campaign. Only Manchester City and Chelsea have kept more clean sheets this term than the visitors’ 14. Andy Hunter

The international break may have come at a perfect time for Southampton. A pause to take the positives from their run to the FA Cup semi-finals and draw a line under their abject league form. Easier said than done when your first game back is against Burnley. Sean Dyche’s side sit level on points with them, seven above the relegation zone. On paper that feels like enough for both to remain in the Premier League but Burnley will surely believe they can take a big step towards making certain by winning this battle of wills. Saints’ soft centre is usually there for the taking. Graham Searles

José Mourinho’s mentor, Sir Bobby Robson, believed he should manage Newcastle one day and it is not beyond the bounds of possibility that the Special One could yet eventually end up at St James’ Park. Mourinho may not exactly be flavour of the month in north London at the moment but, compared with Steve Bruce, the Tottenham manager seems almost popular. There was widespread astonishment on Tyneside that Bruce was not sacked following the recent abysmal 3-0 defeat at Brighton and Newcastle’s manager desperately needs an improvement here. Much may hinge on whether Allan Saint-Maximin is fit to return for the home side. Louise Taylor

Fulham have their best chance yet of climbing out of trouble. If they beat Aston Villa and Newcastle, most likely, lose against Tottenham, then 17th place is theirs. Fulham may have preferred the challenge before the international break, though. Villa were in a rut without Jack Grealish but his return should provide the spark they have been sorely missing. Grealish in addition to John McGinn’s revitalised form (three thrilling goals in three for Scotland) and Ollie Watkins fresh from a first England goal is a much more daunting task than a couple of weeks ago. Graham Searles

Wolves were glad to learn that the head injury suffered by Rui Patrício against Liverpool two weeks ago was so much less serious than first feared that he could start against West Ham on Monday. At the other end of the pitch, William José’s adaptation to the Premier League has progressed since his arrival in January but the striker has yet to find the net and will be hoping to put that right as Wolves look to atone for the 4-0 beating sustained at the London Stadium in September. David Moyes will have their work cut out as they seek to get their push for Champions League qualification back on track after two disappointing performances. Paul Doyle

The title may never have been a realistic proposition but a win against Brighton would give a healthy boost to wrapping up a top-four finish early so Manchester United can focus on trying to win the Europa League and FA Cup. Graham Potter’s side begin a difficult run to the finish line with Everton and Chelsea following this and a final three games against West Ham, Manchester City and Arsenal. The omens begin poorly as Brighton have conceded three goals in each of their past four meetings with United, losing each time. The meat of the run-in sandwich against Sheffield United, Leeds and Wolves will be crucial to their hopes of survival. Then again Newcastle’s form is so poor it may matter very little.

Chelsea will be confident of maintaining their unbeaten record when they host West Brom, who look certain to drop into the Championship. Thomas Tuchel’s side are fourth before hosting Sam Allardyce’s strugglers and have improved since firing Frank Lampard in January. However, Chelsea will be without N’Golo Kanté, who suffered a hamstring injury on international duty. Jacob Steinberg

Defeat for Arsenal would leave their hopes of Europa League qualification hanging by a thread, even with eight games left. If Liverpool lose the same might be said for their hopes of Champions League football via the domestic route. The stakes are high, albeit in ways neither side would like, and Mikel Arteta will be particularly concerned about question marks over key players. Bukayo Saka, Emile Smith Rowe and the recently improved Willian are all doubtful and their absence would improve Jürgen Klopp’s hopes of a third straight away win. Nick Ames

Three successive defeats have ended Carlo Ancelotti’s hopes of capping his first full season at Everton with silverware while also jeopardising his aim of bringing European football back to Goodison Park. He is yet to find a solution to the team’s recurring problems at home, especially against opponents they are expected to control, but the return of James Rodríguez should inject the quality and creativity that has been absent of late. Uncertainty over Roy Hodgson’s future continues to cloud the picture at Crystal Palace, much to the former England manager’s irritation, but one defeat in their past five matches demonstrates his players remain unaffected. Andy Hunter

Before facing Erling Haaland in Tuesday’s Champions League quarter-final first leg, Manchester City’s defenders will have to find of a way of subduing one of the Premier League’s most dangerous strikers – Kelechi Iheanacho, who has suddenly emerged as a prolific goalscorer, especially alongside Jamie Vardy. It remains to be seen whether Brendan Rodgers will deploy that front two but, whichever formation Leicester use, Pep Guardiola will have to give particularly careful consideration to his defensive selections. The outcome will have little bearing on the title race but a home win would bring Leicester closer to a laudable top-four finish. Paul Doyle

It is just over three years since Paul Heckingbottom became the manager of Leeds. He lasted only four months before being replaced by Marcelo Bielsa but, outwardly at least, has no hard feelings. “It was the right club at the wrong time,” said Heckingbottom, as he prepared to return to Elland Road in interim charge of Sheffield United, seeking his first win since replacing Chris Wilder. At the start of the season who could have imagined the Blades would be Championship bound and grounds would still be empty by the time this Yorkshire derby took place? Louise Taylor

The return of Jesse Lingard should ensure that West Ham offer more in attack after last week’s disappointing defeat to Manchester United. Lingard has been outstanding since joining on loan from United and has regained his spot in the England squad. West Ham, who could draw level with fourth-placed Chelsea, will need the midfielder to shine against Arsenal, who have a short recovery time after beating Olympiakos on aggregate in the Europa League. Jacob Steinberg

Aston Villa will hope Jack Grealish returns to inspire their misfiring attack against Tottenham. Dean Smith will make a decision regarding their talisman’s fitness on Sunday morning. A mild irritation for the manager compared with the soul-shattering migraine José Mourinho is nursing. The Portuguese attacked his team’s attitude after humiliation in Zagreb while his goalkeepers have spoken out too. Hugo Lloris said “it was a disgrace” while Joe Hart said “job done”. An unfortunate flub from Hart’s social media team but not exactly what a team aiming to actually return to European competition next season need. Villa will hope the implosion continues. Graham Searles

Brighton will be feeling good after a much-needed win against Southampton but they must refocus as they face a relegation rival in Newcastle. Recent history, the form book and fitness point to Brighton clinching another crucial victory. Graham Potter’s side are unbeaten in seven matches against Newcastle since promotion, conceding one goal in three wins and four draws. Steve Bruce’s side have been insipid without their three best attackers but Miguel Almirón may be available to return. They need a spark as Fulham continue to creep closer. Graham Searles

Both sides can be expected to shuffle their packs for the north London derby given their Thursday night Europa League commitments, with Mikel Arteta especially concerned about the condition of his players following an eight-hour round trip to Athens. Arteta may opt to give a couple of attackers, perhaps a flagging Bukayo Saka, some rest although he will not want to take too many chances. While Tottenham need points for their Champions League challenge, it feels like the last chance for Arsenal to make any inroads towards the top end. Nick Ames

Brighton are in trouble following a third successive defeat and Fulham’s shock win at Anfield. Goal difference only separates them from the relegation zone. Fulham are unlikely to repeat the trick against Manchester City on Saturday so Graham Potter’s side have a great chance to claw back some breathing room and Southampton’s shambolic defending could give the gilt-edged chances needed for Brighton to find the goals they have been sorely missing this season. Graham Searles

A deflating season for Sheffield United reached a low on Friday with word of Chris Wilder’s departure as manager. With relegation looming, the players have to find something to fight for without the manager who has been driving them for the last five years. While the visitors’ sights are on impressing a new manager and, most likely, preparing for next season, Leicester are firmly focused on securing a place in the top four. Last week’s win at Brighton was a welcome boost and they will expect to build on that and record their first home win since beating Liverpool a month ago. Paul Doyle

As Milan’s late goal in Thursday’s Europa League draw illustrated yet again, Manchester United lack the defence to be true contenders, something David Moyes will surely instruct West Ham to prey on. The visitors are fifth going into the weekend but only six points behind second-placed United. A win at Old Trafford, then, would really blow the race for a top-four finish open. Jamie Jackson

Liverpool’s victory in mid-week over RB Leipzig enabled them to advance in the Champions League but if they are to qualify for next season’s tournament through the Premier League, they will need to beat a Wolves side who are hoping to finish their own difficult season on a high. Diogo Jota, having regained fitness, will be hoping to make an impact on his return to Molineux, where he is remembered with fondness. The man who has taken his place there, Pedro Neto, will be integral to Wolves’ efforts to ensure he leaves with no points. Paul Doyle

Where grooming and sartorial style are concerned, Pep Guardiola says he is willing to offer Scott Parker a draw. He will presumably not be as accommodating on Saturday although, on the back of a tremendous win at Anfield and six days off, Fulham should not be taken lightly. Parker’s side have achieved a formidably consistent level of performance and, should they deal another bloody nose here, could finally escape the bottom three. Given Manchester City put five past Southampton in midweek while largely below par, though, it would still take some effort. Nick Ames

Carlo Ancelotti was effusive in his praise of Sean Dyche’s work on Friday. “I was born with 4-4-2 with [Arrigo] Sacchi, and Burnley explain really well how you play 4-4-2,” he said. “They are not inventing new football. Football was already invented a long time ago.” And the Everton manager will have to get creative against well-drilled visitors who have drawn four of their past five games. The influential Abdoulaye Doucouré is out for at least two months, James Rodríguez remains sidelined and Gylfi Sigurdsson is doubtful. Burnley have their own problems, with Charlie Taylor and Jack Cork expected to join Ashley Barnes among the absentees. Andy Hunter

On Thursday, Marcelo Bielsa completed 1,000, largely transformative, days in charge of Leeds. “I don’t think I’ve triumphed in this job,” he said. “The word triumph is something evading me.” Granted his side remain inconsistent – and have won only one of their past five games – but no one would be overly surprise if Leeds ended Thomas Tuchel’s unbeaten start at Elland Road. Chelsea may have won eight of their 11 games under Tuchel but what price Raphinha and Stamford Bridge old boy Patrick Bamford asking some awkward questions the visiting defence cannot quite answer? Louise Taylor

Time continues to slip away for West Brom’s bid for survival as they sit nine points from the last safe spot so beating Crystal Palace is an absolute must. A glance at the form book suggests this is rather unlikely. Sam Allardyce’s side have scored two goals in their past six games and have won only once in 13 matches on the road this season. Talisman Wilfried Zaha’s return to fitness should give Palace the edge and ratchet up the pressure on Allardyce even further. Graham Searles

This is a pivotal match in the race to qualify for the Champions League. Chelsea climbed back into the top four with their impressive win at Liverpool on Thursday, but Everton are a point behind after three successive wins. Everton will be dangerous and Carlo Ancelotti will be keen to beat his old club after losing 4-0 at Stamford Bridge last season. Chelsea, though, remain unbeaten under Thomas Tuchel and could have an entire squad available. Jacob Steinberg

The stakes are astronomically high in this relegation dogfight. A win for Newcastle could give much-needed breathing room while victory for West Brom could allow Fulham to drop Steve Bruce’s side into clear and present danger should they in turn beat Liverpool at Anfield (not as laughable a premise as it once was). On form Newcastle are in rough shape with only two wins in their past 15 league games. They are in even rougher shape when injuries come into play. Bruce is missing Callum Wilson, Miguel Almirón and Allan Saint-Maximin, his only threatening players in attack. Sam Allardyce may not be supremely confident but his side should be favourites to get one over on his former employers. Graham Searles

It will be exactly 12 months on Sunday since Liverpool last played in front of a full house at Anfield and atmosphere is not the only thing to have evaporated around Jürgen Klopp’s team in that time. An unprecedented fifth successive home defeat, sustained against Chelsea on Thursday, was another demonstration of how confidence, intensity and authority has been stripped from the champions. The Premier League table suggests Fulham are an ideal candidate for a recovery but, as Scott Parker’s side showed at Everton recently, that would be a dangerous assumption. Andy Hunter

Even a win for Manchester United only cuts the deficit to Manchester City down to 11 points with 10 games left but try they must. Pep Guardiola’s team are aiming for a 22nd successive win: should Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s team stop them it will be one for fans to brag about but, surely, the title race is already over. Jamie Jackson

José Mourinho made it sound as though he envied his Crystal Palace counterpart, Roy Hodgson, who is “without any real pressure to do better than have a stable season”. Hodgson’s team, according to Mourinho, can “just go and play, if they win, great; if they lose, they don’t feel any pressure from media or fans”. Hodgson would surely take issue with the view but what is clear is that all the pressure is on Tottenham in this one. David Hytner

West Ham will want an immediate response after losing narrowly to Manchester City last week. David Moyes’ side remain in the hunt for Champions League qualification and have been strong at home this season. Leeds, though, are dangerous on their day. Moyes will need his players to be at their best and for Michail Antonio to maintain his impressive goalscoring form. Jacob Steinberg

Arsenal will be raring to sink their teeth into Burnley after a fantastic comeback victory against Leicester last week. The extras came to the fore in style, so with Bukayo Saka and Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang back in the fold Sean Dyche’s side look heavily outgunned. But that is nothing new. On paper Burnley always look undermatched and those cunning Clarets have already beaten Arsenal at the Emirates this season. Mikel Arteta’s side often stumble after a good display, Dyche will be counting on forcing a fall to keep the Burnley locomotive chugging for another Premier League season. Graham Searles

Sheffield United’s luck was in against Aston Villa as they showed the grit and determination that have been ever-present despite their struggling mightily this season. Another win against the Premier League’s worst side on form could lift them off the bottom if West Brom lose their relegation crunch match with Newcastle. Southampton will hope injuries in United’s defence take their toll and their touch-and-go starters will be ready in time. A morale-sapping ninth match without victory before facing Manchester City will have Saints looking over their shoulders. Graham Searles

Wolves will be happy Jack Grealish is unavailable for Aston Villa for a fourth successive game. They are much less threatening without the playmaker but goals were drying up shortly before his injury too. Five in their past seven compared with 33 in 18 matches preceding the lean spell should give Nuno Espírito Santo further confidence. Wolves have hardly been prolific themselves but a victory over their West Midlands rivals, also still missing the key defender Matty Cash, could be all the incentive they need. Villa’s impressive season could risk ending with a whimper if they struggle again. Graham Searles

The fitness gods are seriously testing Leicester. Brendan Rodgers has seven players missing as his side attempt to avoiding ceding further ground to the pack chasing a top-four finish. The ghosts of last season’s failure to qualify for the Champions League add even more pressure and Brighton will hope they can capitalise. Graham Potter’s side need a win. Climbing away from danger and a line through the agonising West Brom debacle last week are a must. Graham Searles

Fulham have put together an excellent run of eight points from four matches to move within striking distance of safety. Newcastle are three points ahead in 17th but face a resurgent Wolves side, so defeat could be on the cards. Goals are still at a premium for Scott Parker’s side, though, and Roy Hodgson will be scheming to keep it tight and hit Fulham on the counter as they go in search of another vital set of three points. Crystal Palace will also be looking for Jean-Philippe Mateta to build on his fine night’s work against Brighton on Monday. Graham Searles

Leicester have tended to recover well from the few disappointments they have suffered this season and will be hoping to put Thursday’s Europa League elimination behind them by continuing their strong Premier League form on Sunday. That will required showing much more intensity than they did against Slavia Prague and overcoming the loss of James Maddison, who joined the club’s long injury list when he limped out of last week’s win at Aston Villa. Arsenal enjoyed a happier night of European action on Thursday and will be aiming to take advantage of their hosts’ troubles. Paul Doyle

Liverpool have been all over the place recently and deserved to lose against Everton but Sheffield United present an open goal for Jürgen Klopp’s side to get back on track. Injuries are mounting for Chris Wilder much like the pressure of relegation as the drop looms ever larger. United will hope to exploit Liverpool’s patchwork defence but as the cliche states: attack is the best form of defence. Ping it up to Mohamed Salah and let him take care of Phil Jagielka. A possible victory of sorts over Everton as the former Blue is unlikely to still have the legs to hold off Liverpool’s athletic attacking unit. Graham Searles

Chelsea disappointed for the first time under Thomas Tuchel in last week’s draw with Southampton so all eyes will be on his side, scrutinising how they respond. Tuchel was particularly upset with Callum Hudson-Odoi, who received the ignominy of being a subbed substitute, so Reece James will be eager to continue impressing on the right flank. James will have to be working hard to help shut down Manchester United’s impressive attacking unit. Bruno Fernandes is easy to single out as key to United’s successes but Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s defence need to continue their improvement, since a shocker against Everton, if they are to best Chelsea. Graham Searles

Everton are feeling good following a first win at Anfield since 1999, planning permission for a new stadium and a new contract for Lucas Digne – all in the space of five days – but major improvement is required at Goodison Park to give it more foundation. Carlo Ancelotti’s team have lost four of their past five Premier League home games, including 2-0 defeats by Fulham and Newcastle, and Southampton offer another test of what the Italian suspects is complacency among his players when facing struggling sides. Ralph Hasenhüttl’s team are sliding towards trouble after eight league games without a win. Andy Hunter

Tottenham need to beat Burnley. A team with their talent should be higher than ninth and José Mourinho should be able to extract more than his side are currently giving him. Sean Dyche presents a nightmare for Mourinho. An expert at sitting back and stealing victories means Tottenham have to play on the front foot. Mourinho will be taking notes on Sunday if Burnley snatch a result. Any points picked up would be a boost to Burnley’s survival ambitions. Graham Searles

Pep Guardiola says Manchester City can lose when playing precisely the same way that has swept them to 19 consecutive victories. The point is taken but so good are his side that their average is a class at least above most opponents. Here, then is David Moyes’ challenge: to somehow convince his West Ham players they can do what no one has since West Brom in mid-December – stop the winning machine. Jamie Jackson

Late last week a giant banner was draped across an entrance to St James’ Park. In a clear message to Mike Ashley, it demanded that Newcastle’s owner “stop gambling with our club”. It follows the earlier warning – also via a banner outside the stadium – declaring: “Act late seal your fate.” No one need read very far between the lines to realise these are demands that Ashley sack Steve Bruce. After a run of 12 defeats in 16 games, Newcastle’s manager is under intense pressure and could do with victory against Wolves as his side embark on a potentially season-defining run of games also involving fixtures against West Brom, Aston Villa and Brighton. Louise Taylor

Leeds will be without the injured Kalvin Phillips and Aston Villa lack the similarly indisposed Jack Grealish. Only time will tell which talisman will prove the bigger miss but Villa may need to be mindful of their hosts penchant for so-called tactical fouling. After Marcelo Bielsa’s side beat Southampton 3-0 in midweek – a result that lifted Leeds to 10th – Ralph Hasenhüttl said Bielsa’s players were far more streetwise than his team. “They’re very clever,” Hasenhüttl said. “They always stopped our counterattacks with a simple foul in midfield. It stopped everything. They do it very smart.” Louise Taylor

West Brom need to beat Brighton as time ebbs away for them to save their season. Sam Allardyce appears to have finally shored up their defensive problems, only two goals conceded in West Brom’s past four games, with the introduction of Okay Yokuslu as a holding midfielder but Albion are 11 points from the last safe spot and are not scoring enough goals to win matches. Allardyce will hope Brighton are still bearing the scars of a gutting last-minute defeat to Crystal Palace. The incentive of not dropping further into danger should give Graham Potter ample motivation, though. Potter can flex his superior tactical knowledge and deliver a welcome win. Graham Searles

West Ham have emerged as unlikely contenders for Champions League qualification and will go nine points above Tottenham if they win. David Moyes has performed wonders this season, though he will hope that Michail Antonio has shaken off a hamstring problem.
