West Ham, who recovered from 3-0 down to draw with Spurs in October, will need their main striker available to face José Mourinho’s side, who were able to rest Harry Kane in their Europa League win over Wolfsberger on Thursday. Jacob Steinberg

Leicester look intent on qualifying for the Champions League. Three goals in seven minutes and a comeback win against Liverpool last weekend should boost their confidence about atoning for a last-minute defeat against Aston Villa at the King Power in October. Matty Cash is also missing this time for Villa, which could give Harvey Barnes room to work his magic on the left. Dean Smith will hope Leicester show some tiredness from Europa League duties as he looks to earn an impressive double over Brendan Rodgers on Villa’s own push for European football. Graham Searles

Manchester City have done perfectly well without Kevin De Bruyne and Sergio Agüero but it will hardly cheer Arsenal that both are pushing for starts after returning to the bench recently. Mikel Arteta will need his squad to feel fresh if they are to end City’s winning run and boost their European prospects, so he may rotate, given the same XI started against both Leeds and Benfica. Kieran Tierney should return at left-back but one or two of the front four could be rotated, with Nicolas Pépé and Alexandre Lacazette hoping for extended involvement. Nick Ames

When Manchester United fire they can blow opponents away, as Real Sociedad found out, so Newcastle will hardly relish this visit to Old Trafford after Thursday’s 4-0 demolition of the Spanish club. United are 10 points behind Manchester City so if Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s side are to retain any hope of a title challenge they have to start a long winning run. Jamie Jackson

The M23 non-derby derby is back to give armchair aficionados their latest chance to be told by commentators how good it would be to have them back from exile. Brighton, sadly, appear not to share the sentiment, as their record unbeaten run in the Premier League shows no signs of stopping. Graham Potter’s side look likely to extend their stay in the top flight for another season. Crystal Palace’s stay is unlikely to end too but if they record a third poor defeat in succession without Wilfried Zaha then Roy Hodgson might begin to feel a touch nervous of being drawn into a relegation battle. Graham Searles

Fulham can sense daylight in their bid to escape relegation, although plenty will depend on their ability to defeat the division’s bottom side. Four points from two away games over the past week was a fine haul but it is high time they won a home game, something they have not achieved since 2 November. Sheffield United’s revival has stalled in the past fortnight and this feels like something of a final throw of the dice for Chris Wilder’s side, who will surely lose any remaining hope if they cannot take the spoils on Saturday evening. Nick Ames

Only a month ago Jürgen Klopp harboured hopes of retaining the title, while Carlo Ancelotti had the games in hand to reach the top four. Both managers have had to lower their sights following a damaging run of three defeats in their past five Premier League games, although Liverpool’s morale will be improved by the Champions League win over RB Leipzig. Everton have an embarrassing record at Anfield, where they have not won for 22 years, while Klopp is unbeaten in 12 Merseyside derbies. Events at Goodison Park in October linger on. Andy Hunter

Burnley will hope to continue their vital knack of avoiding defeat against relegation rivals with another positive showing when West Brom come to town. Sam Allardyce’s side showed signs of life against Manchester United but will have to find further improvement to break down Burnley’s impressive defensive unit. West Brom’s need to attack could play right into Sean Dyche’s hands as they sit and try to hit their vulnerable opponents on the break. The pressure is mounting on Allardyce, who has picked up two points in six matches since beating Wolves in January. Graham Searles

Chelsea roll on under Thomas Tuchel, while Southampton’s alarming nosedive continues, so only one out come is surely on the cards. Timo Werner finally finding the net on Monday is ideal timing too as the German international will not be up against Kyle Walker-Peters, who has reinjured a hamstring. The only optimism to be found for Southampton is some complacency on Chelsea’s part. They face Atlético Madrid on Tuesday so might just be more concerned with getting through without picking up injuries so that they enter Diego Simeone’s bullring unscathed. Graham Searles

Sheffield United have a thing going, LWLWL is their recent run of form so a welcome win to aid their survival campaign is coming. Confidence will be flowing after making the quarters of the Cup and Michail Antonio’s touch-and-go status further boosts Chris Wilder’s good feeling. A win and a Fulham defeat would bring them one point behind 18th, not much in the grand scheme but any progress is welcome with more than enough games left to survive. David Moyes must have an eye on Europe, a win could even take West Ham above Liverpool. The former Everton manager might find a bit of extra motivation on Monday if Leicester are victorious on Saturday afternoon. Graham Searles

Chelsea are building again under Thomas Tuchel – four wins and a draw feels like more than new manager bounce. The introduction of experience back into the team, specifically César Azpilicueta, has strengthened their inconsistencies in defence. Newcastle will need Joe Willock and Miguel Almirón to shine once again, while Callum Wilson sits on the sidelines, to claim a positive result. Graham Searles

Arsenal go into battle without the services of Thomas Partey, who Mikel Arteta said is “devastated” to miss out with the injury he sustained at Aston Villa. Partey’s career at the Emirates has been frustratingly stop-start to date and there is a further headache in the form of Kieran Tierney’s continued absence. Arteta hopes to see a swift recovery from consecutive defeats that he feels Arsenal did not deserve; if Leeds miss their own midfield lynchpin, the doubtful Kalvin Phillips, their causemight receive a shot in the arm. Nick Ames

Carlo Ancelotti conceded his players “are not in the best condition” after a two hour shift against Tottenham on Wednesday but the same cannot be said of their confidence having prevailed in a classic FA Cup tie. With James Rodríguez and Andre Gomes recovered from injury, the Everton manager has more options to rotate and Josh King could make his debut in place of the injured Dominic Calvert-Lewin. An improvement on the last home league game against Newcastle is necessary. Fulham may be languishing third from bottom but have drawn their last three games on the road. Andy Hunter

Manchester United threw away the chance of three points against Everton last week but should find the going much smoother with a trip to the Hawthorns. West Brom look likely to finish bottom on current form and with United’s quality they will pick apart a defence that has conceded 19 in their past four home games with ease. Nothing has worked for Sam Allardyce so far but the introduction of Okay Yokuslu to midfield is worth a shot. Graham Searles

Southampton’s thin squad has been punished five successive times but, with players coming back from injury, they will seek to repeat their Cup win over Wolves on Thursday. Nuno Espírito Santo did play a weakened team though. With a full strength lineup, injuries aside, they will aim to copy Arsenal from earlier in the season by serving up a victory following exiting the Cup against Saints. A first goal of the season from Adama Traoré on his 23rd appearance would be very handy. Graham Searles

Can José Mourinho do what no manager has since Slaven Bilic with WestBrom and lead Tottenham to halt the Manchester City juggernaut? The draw on 15 December is the last time Pep Guardiola’s side failed to win, having since reeled off 15 successive victories. Yet what is also true is the last team to beat City were Spurs in November so Mourinho can draw on this as inspiration for his players on Saturday. Jamie Jackson

Brendan Rodgers has had three bites at besting his former club and so far has failed each time, including a 4-0 thrashing at the King Power last season. Naturally, Liverpool are no where near the side they were then so the fourth time just might be the charm for Leicester, especially with Jamie Vardy and Wilfred Ndidi returning. Jürgen Klopp’s side need to avoid a third successive defeat with Chelsea, West Ham and Everton all excellently placed to rise above them should they slip further. Fixtures and pressure continue to pile up for Klopp as Liverpool face RB Leizpig in Budapest on Tuesday. A quick Champions League exit could boost chances of another crack next season but morale could be damaged further in the process. Graham Searles

Six of Crystal Palace’s eight wins this season have been recorded against teams with fewer points than them so Roy Hodgson’s side, while expecting to beat Burnley, have a decent body of evidence to suggest they can bounce back from falling flat against Leeds. The obligatory – Wilfried Zaha missing out hurts Palace’s chances – message must be raised here. Burnley have the worst attack in the league with 14 goals but have conceded the same amount as Liverpool in fourth. Sean Dyche will sense an opportunity to add to the eight-point gap over Fulham in 18th. Graham Searles

Graham Potter is doing a great job with Brighton. His side are in the form of their Premier League lives with their finest sequence yet of five games unbeaten. But their most recent last-minute loss to Leicester in the Cup will have smarted so Aston Villa could try and snatch an early goal to give an early, damaging reminder of that sinking feeling. Dean Smith’s side can beat their points total from last season with a draw. We will get an incredible 16 more chances to see just how far Villa can surpass it. Graham Searles

Wolves returned to winning ways after eight games thanks to a large slice of David Luiz-shaped luck on Tuesday but face a much trickier task in trying to earn another victory against Leicester. Brendan Rodgers could welcome back Jamie Vardy and Wilfred Ndidi, arguably his two best players, to a squad already flush with talent, to continue his side’s push for a return to the Champions League. Leicester are in a strong position to qualify but this is a game they must win to avoid the bitter disappointment of missing out last season. Nuno Espírito Santo may be minded to hold his side back before a winnable FA Cup fifth round tie with Southampton. Graham Searles

Sam Allardyce’s arrival at West Brom has not led to better defending. They have conceded 26 goals in his nine league games (yielding only five points). So imagine the reaction if Tottenham cannot get back on track after three league defeats in a row. José Mourinho’s team have been dreadful during the sequence, creating precious little, as the manager obsesses over Harry Kane’s absence. Somebody else must step up. David Hytner

Liverpool have lost their aura at Anfield and their grip on the title will be severely weakened too should they fail to beat Manchester City. To do so, Jürgen Klopp requires dramatic improvement in a Liverpool team that have not scored in three successive home league games – the first time that has happened since October 1984 – and against opponents who could set a club record of seven successive clean sheets in the league. Pep Guardiola has never led Manchester City to victory at Anfield and the visitors have not won here since May 2003, but ending that barren sequence would have profound repercussions for both sides. Andy Hunter

Leeds looks as if relegation should not be a problem this season but would a mid-table finish be sufficient to satisfy Marcelo Bielsa? Well, possibly. “The most important thing is how we play,” said the Argentinian who evidently prizes principles above pragmatism. “If you finish 8th by not playing well, it’s worse than finishing 12th and playing well. But playing well usually makes it easier to finish higher up the table.” Roy Hodgson is less philosophical but Crystal Palace’s counter-attacking strategy is serving them well and, even with the injured Wilfried Zaha absent, his side – and Eberechi Eze especially – threaten to fully stretch Bielsa’s sometimes vulnerable defence. Louise Taylor

Sheffield United were unbeaten against Chelsea last season, even producing a magnificent 3-0 pasting at Bramall Lane. Now the pressure is on to find wins the going could be much tougher but Chris Wilder’s side are winning close games – five by a single goal in their past seven in all competitions – rather than the valiant losing streak from earlier this season. Thomas Tuchel will be hoping to build on his unbeaten streak since taking over at Chelsea but will need his side to perform better than they did against Tottenham to overcome the fiercely competitive Blades. Graham Searles

Brighton burst into life in the past week with fantastic 1-0 wins over Tottenham and Liverpool. Graham Potter will need to guard against any complacency against a Burnley side also very adept at upsetting the odds. Sean Dyche will expect his side to move on quickly from their usual limp defeat to Manchester City but, with the top half surely looking like a realistic prospect now, Brighton should be targeting a third successive win. Graham Searles

With Manchester City at Liverpool on Sunday this is a chance for Manchester United to draw level with City and hope they then slip up at Anfield. In November’s reverse fixture a Bernard goal gave Everton the lead before two from Bruno Fernandes and a Edinson Cavani finish won the matchbut as Carlo Ancelotti’s team remain firmly in the hunt for a Champions League place expect them to put up a stern challenge at Old Trafford. Jamie Jackson

Mikel Arteta saw Arsenal’s seven-game unbeaten league run end in disastrous fashion at Molineux on Tuesday but would do well to remember just how bleak things were looking for him six weeks ago when a dreadful run of form precipitated talk of his removal. The result that started it was delivered by Aston Villa, a chastening 3-0 loss at the Emirates in early November when all the attacking vibrancy Dean Smith’s side have exhibited this season was on display in the form of young English talent such as Ollie Watkins, Ross Barkley and Jack Grealish. Arteta’s homegrown English youngsters Emile Smith Rowe and Bukayo Saka have helped dig Arsenal out of that hole and they can climb above Villa with victory on Saturday, although will have to do so without the suspended pair of David Luiz and hitherto ever-present goalkeeper Bernd Leno. Villa were also beaten in midweek at home by West Ham and Smith will be keen to ensure their surprisingly good form in the first half of the season does not fall away. Paul Chronnell

Fulham are winless in their past 12 matches and that run feels likely to continue against a West Ham side pushing for European qualification. Jesse Lingard’s arrival provided instant success as David Moyes’ knocked off Aston Villa with ease thanks to two goals from the Manchester United loanee. The big problem for Scott Parker is lack of goals. A tally of 17 from 21 matches is poor. A debut for striker Josh Maja could be on the cards to address Fulham’s drought but West Ham should still be able to handle their business. Graham Searles

After presiding over one win in Newcastle’s past 14 games in all competitions – 12 in the Premier League – Steve Bruce is wary of a Southampton side anxious to atone for Tuesday night’s concession of nine goals against Manchester United. An injury induced defensive crisis is doing little to assuage the home manager’s nerves – even if Allan Saint-Maximin is finally fit to start in attack and the Arsenal loanee Joe Willock could make his debut in midfield. Newcastle’s new-look diamond formation has brought an increase in possession – an almost unprecedented 60% – during the midweek home defeat to Crystal Palace but as one of Bruce’s predecessors, Alan Pardew, said “possession can be overrated” if you are not winning. Louise Taylor

Liverpool looked more like the team of old when they beat Tottenham on Thursday. The champions were excellent as they won for the first time in five league games. Yet their problems at centre-back increased when Joël Matip went off with an ankle problem and their injuries in defence could make life difficult against West Ham, who are two points behind Liverpool in fourth place. West Ham, who could name Jesse Lingard in their squad, will feel confident if Michail Antonio is in the mood. Jacob Steinberg

Brighton will be relieved Harry Kane is unavailable after injuring both ankles in Tottenham’s defeat against Liverpool. Kane has not only provided 12 goals but has also been a driving creative force for José Mournho. The striker has the most assists in the league with 11. How Mourinho schemes to beat Brighton without his talisman will be interesting to see. A dream scenario for Graham Potter’s side would be snatching an early goal to dent Tottenham’s confidence even further. Heads will be harder to lift without Kane’s presence. Graham Searles

Chelsea will hope for more excitement in Thomas Tuchel’s second game in charge. The German’s side created little in their 0-0 draw with Wolves on Wednesday and need to be more incisive against Burnley, who were victorious at Anfield in their last away game. Chelsea’s underperforming attack is a problem for their manager to solve. Tuchel is still working his squad out and, with N’Golo Kanté hoping to return from a hamstring injury, he could make several changes from the Wolves stalemate. Jacob Steinberg

Leicester will have to make do without key players Jamie Vardy and Wilfred Ndidi against Leeds. A tough ask to find the latter’s dynamism in midfield from elsewhere in the squad and Vardy showed how brilliant he could be against Leeds, laying on two goals and scoring another when they beat Marcelo Bielsa’s side earlier in the season. Bielsa’s side always create chances but their finishing varies between world-class and the unable-to-hit-a-barn-door variety. Shooting boots will be required to beat Kasper Schmeichel and get their own back. Graham Searles

West Brom need to dig deep against Fulham and Sheffield United on Tuesday. Two wins would be huge in their bid to stay up but Sam Allardyce’s side have not shown any fluency yet and lady luck may have to play her part to beat Scott Parker’s draw-happy side. Not to mention the Blades, who appear to be much better than their league position dictates. A first win for Fulham since November could bring them to within touching distance of Brighton and Newcastle, who have very tricky fixtures in Tottenham and Everton, respectively. Graham Searles

Manchester United may have stumbled against Sheffield United but, nevertheless, this is a meeting of two faded powers whose prospects are brightening. Arsenal have five wins in six and a new-found glut of creative options now that Martin Ødegaard has arrived on loan. Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang’s participation is in doubt so Nicolas Pépé, who scored when Arsenal won this fixture last season and again in Tuesday’s win at Southampton, may get another chance to show he is an able deputy. Nick Ames

Manchester City are hoping for a 12th consecutive win in all competitions while Sheffield United will have confidence boosted by winning 2-1 at Manchester United on Wednesday. Pep Guardiola’s team were given a rough ride by Chris Wilder’s in their 1-0 win when they met in October but the leaders being beaten by the Blades at home would rate as even more of a shock than Manchester United’s defeat. Jamie Jackson

Roy Hodgson has a great opportunity against Wolves to guide Crystal Palace back into the winner’s enclosure after a dismal defeat in midweek. Wolves are winless in seven with their dive down the table coinciding with Raúl Jimenéz’s absence. The striker remains unavailable as he recovers from a head injury. Wolves have not been the same without him and Hodgson will be confident his side can improve markedly on the 1-0 defeat in the Cup. Willian José may be given a larger role to bring some experience into Wolves’ attack. Graham Searles

Successive home games against Leicester and Newcastle would go a long way to determining Everton’s top four prospects, Carlo Ancelotti admitted earlier this week, but Saturday’s stakes are far higher for Steve Bruce. Newcastle sat 11th in the table after a 2-1 win over Everton on 1 November but their season has since entered a tailspin. No wins in 11 matches in all competitions and two points from the last 27 available have raised the spectre of a relegation scrap and intensified pressure on the Newcastle manager, who has overseen seven successive away defeats. Andy Hunter

Southampton and Aston Villa will be looking to improve after both sides turned leading positions into defeats in midweek. Villa’s loss was all the more painful after going ahead twice before losing 3-2 at Burnley. Morgan Sanson is available to make his debut for Dean Smith’s side. Ralph Hasenhüttl bemoaned Southampton’s uncharacteristically weak defending against Arsenal and the manager will continue to miss his giant centre-back Jannik Vestergaard. Kyle Walker-Peters’ return is still doubtful. Graham Searles

Arsenal and Newcastle go again at the Emirates nine days after contesting a tight 120 minutes in the FA Cup third round. A similar affair looks likely unless the home side strike early: the Magpies are adept when asked to sit in but, as they showed at Sheffield United, a more proactive approach appears to be beyond them. Arsenal’s turgid draw with Crystal Palace showed their improved form has not cured everything; they will hope Kieran Tierney and Gabriel Martinelli, driving forces of late, are able to return from injuries on schedule. Nick Ames

Five days after reaching the Premier League summit comes the truest test of Manchester United’s ability to stay there. Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s side are unbeaten in 15 away league games since losing at Liverpool almost exactly one year ago and will go six points clear of them should they inflict a first home league defeat on the champions since April 2017. Liverpool have dipped in recent weeks but will have no better incentive to rediscover their verve than puncturing the optimism of their great rivals in Klopp’s 200th league game in charge of Liverpool. Andy Hunter

Manchester City have won four in succession but have drawn and lost the corresponding fixture with Crystal Palace in the past two seasons. Roy Hodgson’s visitors, who have won only once in their last seven outings in the competition, should focus on not conceding early against opponents whose goal count is surprisingly low. Do so and Palace may again prosper at the Etihad. Jamie Jackson

Sheffield United looked much more like their 2019-20 selves in claiming a first win of the league season against an admittedly dismal Newcastle in midweek and Chris Wilder will hope that continues on Sunday against a Tottenham side they took four points off last season. Spurs need to pull themselves out of a mini-slump – one win in six has stalled their Champions League push and they have not won away in the league since early November. John Ashdown

Leeds will come face to face with the one that got away when Ben White returns to Elland Road for Brighton. White excelled for Marcelo Bielsa’s side as they won promotion last season but Leeds failed to secure his services on a permanent basis and the centre-back is now an integral element of Brighton’s struggle to avoid relegation. Bielsa harbours immense respect for Potter and predicts a game of “considerable tactical diversity.” The Argentinian, still suffering from a central defensive injury crisis, can only reflect on what might have been had he retained White. Louise Taylor

This particular London derby will not catch Scott Parker by surprise, although he would not complain overly if Fulham carve out a similar result to the point at Tottenham. They have drawn five games in succession and another positive outcome is clearly not beyond them; Chelsea, for their part, have had a fortnight to stew on their chastening defeat by Manchester City and need to bounce back. Frank Lampard will hope Timo Werner’s goal against Morecambe might point the way towards better things for both his expensive signing and ailing side. Nick Ames

Burnley have caused West Ham problems in the past and won at the London Stadium last season. Sean Dyche’s side have improved in recent months, rising four points above the bottom three, and almost held Manchester United in midweek. They are not to be underestimated. However, West Ham are having a good campaign and, with Michail Antonio free from hamstring trouble, will be confident of continuing their good form. Jacob Steinberg

After beating Liverpool in their most recent league match, Southampton will travel with confidence to the King Power Stadium, where they gained sweet revenge last season for their infamous 9-0 defeat earlier in the campaign. Ralph Hassenhüttl’s side have lost only once on their travels this season and could climb above Leicester with a win. But with Danny Ings absent that seems an unlikely outcome even if Leicester have found the going curiously tough at home, winning only three of eight matches. Paul Doyle

The Black Country derby is back for the first time in nine years with local hero Sam Allardyce, a Wolves fan as a boy, at the helm of West Brom. Allardyce may fancy his chances of a first win since taking over against a Wolves side hampered severely by injuries. Nuno Espíritio Santo’s side have scored more than a single goal in a match only once in eight attempts since Raúl Jimenéz was sidelined. But Wolves still have the more exciting lineup and will likely create chances to test Allardyce’s stodgy backline. If West Brom do lose again and Sheffield United beat Tottenham they will suffer the ignominy of dropping to the foot of the table. Graham Searles

Jürgen Klopp says Liverpool’s position at the top of the table means nothing at this stage but after stuttering to a point at St James’ Park on Wednesday, a trip to Southampton offers the champions a chance to instantly put the record straight. Liverpool were held to a draw against West Bromwich Albion and off-colour against Newcastle but put seven goals past Crystal Palace before Christmas. Despite failing to win any of their past four matches, Southampton should provide more stubborn opposition and Danny Ings will be desperate to strike against his former club. Ralph Hasenhüttl will return to the Saints’ dugout following a period of self-isolation. Ben Fisher

This game was under threat due to an outbreak of Covid-19 in Manchester City’s squad that caused their trip to Everton to be postponed last Monday. As it stands, however, it is set to go ahead after City recorded no further positive tests. The challenge for Pep Guardiola will be coping with five players having to self-isolate. Frank Lampard, under pressure after a poor run, will sense a chance for Chelsea to capitalise. Jacob Steinberg

On 1 January 2020 Leicester travelled to St James’ Park and rather enjoyed themselves. Not content with winning 3-0, they controlled 77% of the possession and left Steve Bruce’s players looking distinctly second-best in almost every department. At a time when he remains under intense pressure from Newcastle supporters who would like nothing better than to see him replaced by his still-adored predecessor, Rafael Benítez, Bruce could do with avoiding a similar new year mauling at the hands of Brendan Rodgers’s high flyers. The home manager can only hope Callum Wilson will eclipse Leicester’s Jamie Vardy in the attacking department, while his side’s new abandonment of their hallmark “low block” and new tactic of pressing higher up the pitch – which produced a point when Liverpool visited Tyneside last Wednesday – will pay dividends. Louise Taylor

Back-to-back wins have relieved some of the pressure on the Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta and banished, at least for now, talk of fighting the unthinkable scenario of relegation from the top flight. Albion, meanwhile, are five points from safety and have the worst goal difference in the division so will have no doubts that they are involved in the struggle to avoid demotion to the Championship. Sam Allardyce’s first three games have seen a highly creditable point at Liverpool sandwiched by home humiliations at the hands of Aston Villa and Leeds. If the hosts can take anything from this match it will offer encouragement before the January transfer window opens and Allardyce can indulge in some much needed strengthening of the squad. Rich Flower

“I don’t play against Mr Bielsa, never,” José Mourinho said. For the Tottenham manager, it is not him against Marcelo Bielsa, rather his team against Bielsa’s Leeds. Yet it is hard to overlook the contrasting styles of the managers; how they frame an intriguing game. Under Bielsa, Leeds might now be a favourite of the neutral (what a rebrand!) and they will look to rush men forward. But can they avoid damage by going one-v-one at the back against Harry Kane and Son Heung-min? David Hytner

Sheffield United took six points off Roy Hodgson’s side last season courtesy of two 1-0 wins but things have been much more difficult for the Blades this time around. Chris Wilder will be hoping they can finally record a first victory of the campaign, although Palace managed to stem the tide of goals they have been conceding in their draw with Leicester last week and will be no pushovers. Ed Aarons

How Brighton and Wolves would love to start the new year with a bang. Graham Potter’s side have won none of their past seven matches and are hovering above the relegation zone, while Wolves have lost four of their six games since Raúl Jiménez fractured his skull in November and look flat in the final third. Wolves are ensconced in mid-table but Brighton appear on a slippery slope and Potter concedes this is the most challenging spell of his managerial career. “If you don’t win football matches, it’s harder to convince people that you are on the right path, and I can understand that,” he said. Ben Fisher

Burnley have taken four points from their past two games, good going since they were away to Arsenal and Aston Villa, and have not only climbed out of the bottom three but still have a game in hand on most of their rivals. Normality seems to be returning at Turf Moor, in other words, though no one should underestimate Wolves after their win against Chelsea on Tuesday. Losing Raúl Jiménez so soon after Diogo Jota was a blow, but one it appears Nuno Espírito Santo and his players can take in their stride. Paul Wilson

Leicester have been excellent away from home this season, hitting hard on quick counters to win five of their six league matches. It is how Tottenham like to play, too, which raises the prospect of a who-blinks-first duel. It will be interesting to see who has more of the ball and whether either team actually wants that. More likely it will be about quality not quantity; who is the most incisive and ruthless. David Hytner

Sam Allardyce is back in the big time. Christmas come early. It is what we have all been waiting for. West Brom fans may disagree but he does have a very particular set of skills. Skills that make him a nightmare for teams such as Aston Villa and that save sides from relegation. Dean Smith will hope Allardyce has not quite yet had time to impart them to his players. Graham Searles

More than 16 years have passed since a 1-1 draw at Elland Road and the last time Manchester United played Leeds United in the Premier League. Marcelo Bielsa’s side arrive in 13th, seven places and six points behind an Ole Gunnar Solskjær team that are unbeaten in six matches (five of these wins) and rising towards the top. Both managers like to play the expansive stuff so this may prove a festive cracker to warm the cockles. Jamie Jackson

Sheffield United lost by a single goal yet again on Thursday as they lost a nightmarish eighth match in succession. Maybe Brighton are the team they can finally topple to end that horrific run as Graham Potter’s side are struggling for goals, with two in their past four matches while failing to win any of them. Confidence will likely be in desperately short supply on the team bus to the Amex and Potter will be hoping to guide his side to a much-needed win to stay above danger before facing high-flying West Ham. Graham Searles

Frank Lampard will be desperate to halt a worrying run against his old club. Consecutive defeats at Wolves and Everton have hurt Chelsea’s title hopes, leaving them outside the top four, and they need to bounce back when West Ham visit Stamford Bridge. Yet it could be an awkward evening. West Ham are a point behind Chelsea, who lost to their London rivals twice last season, and have earned 13 points from their past six games. Jacob Steinberg

Scott Parker was once an integral part of Newcastle’s midfield but he returns to St James’ Park on a mission to ease Fulham’s relegation worries. Should Aleksandar Mitrovic, also returning, score against his old club, Steve Bruce will have reason to be worried. Although Newcastle look safe enough things remain fragile and Wednesday’s 5-2 thrashing at Leeds served as a reminder of their limitations. With festive fixtures at Manchester City and at home to Liverpool and Leicester looming, Bruce could do with a victory. Louise Taylor

Carlo Ancelotti and Mikel Arteta were both appointed to their current roles almost exactly one year ago, just before a goalless draw between Everton and Arsenal at Goodison Park in fact, but only the manager who has already delivered FA Cup success finds himself under pressure. The visitors have made their worst start to a top flight season for 46 years and not won in six games, while the hosts find themselves two points off second following back-to-back wins and clean sheets against Chelsea and Leicester. Allan’s absence with a hamstring injury could be a big loss for Everton. Andy Hunter

Manchester City and Southampton both picked up disappointing draws in midweek, although Pep Guardiola should be the more concerned considering his side continue to struggle to score despite having ridiculously talented players in attack. Much may rely on whether Sergio Agüero returns. The talisman has the power to dispel City’s funk but if he continues his absence Ralph Hasenhüttl has a full-strength squad that has lost only once in their past 11. Saints may have a great chance of repeating last season’s upset. Graham Searles

Liverpool are still getting it done despite their huge raft of injuries, even if they were a little lucky to beat Tottenham and snatch top spot from José Mourinho on Wednesday. Roy Hodgson will be hugely disappointed the former Liverpool striker Christian Benteke is suspended as he has started scoring again since returning to the lineup. Palace’s attack will pose much less of a threat to Jürgen Klopp’s second-string centre-backs without him. Liverpool will more than likely remain top on Christmas Day. Graham Searles

Tottenham are unbeaten since the opening day of the season and in all likelihood they will remain so against Crystal Palace. The 1-0 defeat against Everton in September feels like a lifetime ago for José Mourinho’s intimidating, league-leading side. That said, Roy Hodgson’s side are unlikely to be as easy to coast past as Arsenal were last week. Confidence will be high after decimating West Brom, especially for Christian Benteke who scored two goals in a game for the first time since April 2017. It is likely they will need a few goals again to snatch even a draw from Spurs. Graham Searles

Arsenal’s lack of goals is, in Mikel Arteta’s own words, “not sustainable”. If Burnley bring the abject defence that conceded five at Manchester City then perhaps the Gunners will be able to play themselves back into form, although before that Sean Dyche’s side had kept consecutive clean sheets on the road. Eddie Nketiah showed great hunger and composure in scoring against Dundalk on Thursday and could be handed a first top-flight start in two months as Arteta seeks a spark from somewhere. Nick Ames

Fulham welcome back fans to Craven Cottage and hope that will give them an edge for Liverpool’s visit. Scott Parker must decide whether to recall one of their favourites, Aleksandar Mitrovic, having benched him for the past three games. “His attitude and professionalism will get him back to that place where he needs to be,” the manager said. So might his ability to expose a depleted Liverpool defence that was barely tested against Wolves last weekend. Nick Ames

Sheffield United’s latest attempt to end their winless run of 15 matches in all competitions looks dubious against a Southampton side welcoming back Danny Ings to their starting lineup. Ralph Hasenhüttl’s talisman is intrinsic to their success as he demonstrated by coming off the bench last week to grab the winner and return Saints to the Champions League qualification trail. Chris Wilder’s side have not been blown away in any game this season other than 4-1 against Chelsea, in fact eight of 10 of their defeats have been by a single goal. The fight just needs to transform into incisiveness in front of goal. The nightmare-fuel goals-for column reads five, fewer than one goal every other game thus far. Graham Searles

Leicester have been curiously vulnerable at the King Power recently, losing three of their past four home matches in the league, and Brendan Rodgers will know they have to be at their best against Brighton who caused them plenty of problems during the 0-0 at this venue last season. That was a match Brighton could have got more from – a recurring theme that Potter needs to resolve if Brighton are to climb higher. Paul Doyle

Ole Gunnar Solskjær could really use a win in this 183rd Manchester derby after Tuesday’s Champions League exit. Yet Manchester United’s Premier League form is excellent, four successive wins and a home-and-away double over Manchester City in the league last season. But: Pep Guardiola’s side are performing formidably in Europe and domestically. So, as usual, this clash of storied neighbours could go either way. Jamie Jackson

Wolves did the double over their West Midlands rivals last season but are gripped by uncertainty as they prepare to host an Aston Villa side who have been strong away from home so far. Nuno Espírito Santo had been trying to develop his team’s style of play even before suffering the most unwelcome of complications, the loss of Raul Jiménez to injury. Villa, though deprived of Ross Barkley, are more settled and will aim to exploit and add to Wolves’ difficulties. Paul Doyle

Steve Bruce said Newcastle will be missing a “big chunk” of his squad owing to the Covid outbreak at the club and with that in mind West Brom could be a very difficult test. A severely weakened team is one thing but the emotional toll of colleagues and friends struggling could mean concentrating on a football match is rather difficult. Or it could drive Newcastle on to bring some joy to the club with a victory against a West Brom side potentially low on confidence after receiving a 5-1 thrashing last week. Graham Searles

Chelsea are gathering momentum and will go top of the Premier League, for 24 hours at least, with a first win at Goodison Park in four seasons. Last weekend’s 3-1 victory over Leeds, who had inflicted a second successive home defeat on Everton in their previous outing, underlined the impressive range of game-changing attacking options available to Frank Lampard. They will welcome a confrontation with Carlo Ancelotti’s porous defence. Since entering the October international break with a 100% record from seven matches Everton have emerged with only one win from their past seven league games. Andy Hunter

Wilfried Zaha’s return after testing positive for Covid-19 could be just the lift Crystal Palace need after two defeats without their talisman. West Brom will look for some consistency and a second win of the season to climb out of the relegation zone but they have only seven goals so far and Roy Hodgson’s side look the more likely to snatch three points. Graham Searles

Tottenham have the meanest defensive record in the division while Arsenal have seen the goals dry up – only the three teams in the relegation zone have scored fewer. José Mourinho has drilled down into a deep-sitting, counter-attacking style, particularly for the big games, and nobody could say with any certainty that he will try to make the running. Mikel Arteta, meanwhile, is mired on a dismal run and must dig in to get something. Nick Ames

The most awkward assignment awaits Nuno Espírito Santo as he adapts to the absence of Raul Jiménez, who had played 86 consecutive Premier League games before his head injury at Arsenal. Jürgen Klopp’s mood and defensive problems might indicate otherwise but Liverpool have kept five clean sheets in theirpast 10 games, taken 139 points from the last 147 available at Anfield and are the only team to score in every Premier League game this season. The impact of former Wolves forward Diogo Jota, with nine goals in 15 outings so far, will be an added concern. Andy Hunter

Sheffield United are still looking for their first win after 10 matches. Chris Wilder was honest about his side’s shortcoming after the defeat againstWest Brom last week, when chances were created but not converted. On paper Leicester should be strong enough to prevail at Bramall Lane, especially with key players ready to return from injury, but Brendan Rodgers’ side are proving inconsistent again and the Blades will take encouragement from their past two two underwhelming performances in the league. Paul Wilson

Southampton’s winless run has come to an end but the manner of the defeat will offer more encouragement to Brighton. Graham Potter cannot count on Saints rolling over again but his side showed tremendous resolve in their draw with Liverpool – fight they need to bring every week to stay above the danger zone. Danny Ings – their top scorer – and Nathan Redmond may make welcome returns to bolster Ralph Hasenhüttl’s attack. Graham Searles

Manchester City blew Burnley away last week and Fulham may be in for a similar experience against a side approaching their best form. Pep Guardiola’s team remain mid-table but have a game in hand. They have won their Champions League group with a match to spare and expect them now to start rising towards the top of the Premier League. Jamie Jackson

After a hot start Leeds have scored only three in their past four and goals are likely to be at a premium again coming up against Chelsea’s dominant defence. Frank Lampard’s once flimsy unit are transformed with eight clean sheets in 10 and Oliver Giroud could spearhead the attack after scoring four against Sevilla. Marcelo Bielsa’s side could struggle to cope. Graham Searles

West Ham are on a great run and Manchester United are hurting after losing to PSG in midweek, so what better time for David Moyes to hammer home a point to his former employers. Ole Gunnar Solskjær is unlikely to be fazed, though, with world class talent in Bruno Fernandes and Edinson Cavani to rely on. The pair were instrumental in United’s comeback win last week and the former cannot be left free to pick West Ham apart. Graham Searles

Burnley escaped from the bottom three with their first win of the season against Crystal Palace, only to be plunged back into the relegation zone when a heavy defeat at Manchester City was compounded by Fulham’s unexpected success at Leicester. Sean Dyche and his players will have to keep a wary eye on Fulham if they are going to make a habit of that sort of thing, but first they need to take something from Everton and show they are capable of restoring Turf Moor’s reputation as a difficult place to visit. Paul Wilson

Manchester United face a serious test of their return to form before a key Champions League group match against PSG. Southampton will hope Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s side lose focus and allow their seven match unbeaten run to continue. United’s form on the road has been impressive though with three wins from three. Saints may miss Danny Ings’s lethal finishing with Bruno Fernandes in red-hot form. Graham Searles

Crack the popcorn out and get comfortable for this one. Chelsea and Tottenham have been electric so far this season while there was more than a little spark between Frank Lampard and José Mourinho when these sides met in the League Cup in September. Spurs could make a serious title statement with following up a win against Manchester City with another success at Stamford Bridge. Lampard’s side meanwhile can leapfrog Mourinho if they hold firm at home. Édouard Mendy may have a huge part to play in the outcome as his seven clean sheets in 10 games have transformed Lampard’s leaky defence. Maybe Mendy is the man who can finally halt the relentless goalscoring machine of Harry Kane and Son Heung-min. Graham Searles

Exactly a year after Unai Emery was dismissed, his successor finds himself facing some familiar difficulties. How can Arsenal, so toothless in front of goal, find some spark and fluidity in attack? Reiss Nelson may be given a chance to provide it after a good Europa League display at Molde and all eyes will be on whether Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang gets another run at centre-forward. The striker at the other end of the pitch, Raul Jiménez, would appear to have many of the qualities Arsenal lack and will be confident of compounding their uncertainty with a third straight home defeat in the league. Nick Ames

Leicester will be aiming to ride the wave of good feeling after dramatically qualifying for the last 32 of the Europa League in Portgual on Thursday and follow it up with a win against Fulham. A disappointing defeat last time out will have smarted against an undermanned Liverpool. Fulham have shown more promise than those around them but that counts for little when you are in the relegation zone. More cutting edge needs to be found and crucially an end to Aleksandar Mitrovic’s alarming eight-match run without a goal. Graham Searles

David Moyes has a selection headache at striker to face Aston Villa. Does he stick with Sébastian Haller who found form with the Ivory Coast and scored the winner last week against Sheffield United or twist and throw Michail Antonio back into the mix? Riding the hot hand in Haller feels the right move especially if Antonio is still not quite match-fit. Villa had fun on their last visit to London, battering Arsenal, and will be keen to move on quickly from losing to Brighton. Ross Barkley missing out is a problem but Dean Smith will be more concerned with his side being able to win the midfield battle against Moyes’s tough unit. Graham Searles

Goals and excitement may be at a premium as West Brom and Sheffield United have scored 10 goals between them, sit 19th and last respectively and are the only teams still winless. It may not be so easy on the eye then but this is an important match for both to grab three points against a relegation rival. Chris Wilder’s side may have the edge if they can find some of last season’s magic at long last. Graham Searles

Goals are a problem for Manchester City due to only scoring 10 in eight Premier League matches. Yet a home match against Burnley, who arrive a point above the relegation zone and have only registered four themselves, is surely the ideal opportunity for Pep Guardiola’s team to become free-scoring again. Jamie Jackson

Lucas Digne was instrumental in Everton’s return to winning ways at Fulham last Sunday but an ankle injury that requires surgery on Monday, and will sideline the France international for up to three months, means Carlo Ancelotti will be without both first choice full-backs with Séamus Coleman also nursing a recurring hamstring problem. Marcelo Bielsa will seek to capitalise on absences that limit Everton in attack and defence. Leeds’ four away games this season have produced 16 goals in total and the first ever meeting between Bielsa and Ancelotti promises to be an open affair. Andy Hunter

I have a formal apology to make to Danny Welbeck and Adam Lallana after suggesting they might not be what Brighton need in attack to avoid relegation last week. The pair hooked up wonderfully with the latter providing the former with Brighton’s opener in their win against Aston Villa. Moving swiftly on, can they do it again against Liverpool? Well Lallana certainly knows Jürgen Klopp’s side well and will be hungry to show he was let go a touch too soon considering Liverpool’s mountain of injury problems. A big miss is Tariq Lamptey though and without the right wing-back’s industry Brighton may just fall short in stopping Klopp’s intimidating attack. It feels unlikely we will see back-to-back poor showings after defeat against Atalanta, too. Graham Searles

Southampton showed by beating Newcastle and stretching their unbeaten run to six games that they are a force to be reckoned with even without Danny Ings, who is expected to be missing for at latest another month after undergoing knee surgery. But the outcome against Wolves could be determined by the fitness of Ryan Bertrand and James Ward-Prowse, since Bertrand will need to be at his best to subdue their wide attackers, and Ward-Prowse has the set-piece prowess to exploit the weakness that Jacob Murphy capitalised on when Newcastle drew at Wolves in October – if it has not been addressed in training. Paul Doyle

Sheffield United have one point from eight games and have scored four goals. On the positive side, five of the seven defeats Chris Wilder’s side have suffered have been by a single goal, but unless the Blades sharpen their attacking efforts they will continue to prop up the Premier League table. While Rhian Brewster has the potential to be a future goalscoring solution he has not found it easy to adapt quickly to a step up in level, and may be taken out of the front line spotlight against West Ham. Paul Wilson

Burnley are still looking for their first win of the season and face a Crystal Palace side who could climb into the European positions with a victory at Turf Moor, if other results go their way. Reaching December without a win is not normally a tenable situation for clubs or their managers, and with Manchester City away next the pressure is building on Sean Dyche and his players. Burnley have coped in the past but this season they are still stumbling to find their usually resilient stride. Paul Wilson

Carlo Ancelotti says Everton, whose flying start has come off the rails with three straight defeats, need to show a reaction at Fulham. Those setbacks coincided with Richarlison’s suspension but the Brazilian is available again and that may spell bad news for Scott Parker, who knows Fulham’s improvement must translate into a measure of consistency. Ademola Lookman will be hungry to offer them the necessary cutting edge against the club that sold him 16 months ago. Nick Ames

To Leeds fans Kalvin Phillips is arguably the exception to the rule that no one is indispensable. Marcelo Bielsa’s key holding midfielder has missed Leeds’ past three games – featuring successive 4-1 defeats to Leicester and Crystal Palace – with a shoulder injury. To say the England international will be welcomed back against Arsenal is an understatement. “It’s probable Phillips will start,” said Bielsa. “Phillips is a player who usually plays and it’s always important to count on the players who play regularly. The evolution of Phillips is a constant one. He has a capacity to analyse and criticise himself and he finds what he needs to improve and correct his game and he does this by himself.” Louise Taylor

New club records are on offer to the champions at Anfield – namely 64 home league games unbeaten and scoring in 39 successive top flight league matches at home – but Jürgen Klopp is unlikely to have given them a second thought during a damaging international break. Joe Gomez’s knee injury, Jordan Henderson’s groin scare and Mohamed Salah’s positive Covid-19 tests have increased Liverpool’s selection problems before meeting a Leicester team enjoying the club’s best start to a top-flight season. It was Leicester, incidentally, who ended Liverpool’s 63-game unbeaten run at Anfield in 1981. Andy Hunter

Aston Villa will beat Brighton easily if they play as they did when embarrassing Arsenal at the Emirates before the break. Life has been a little tougher at Villa Park though – Liverpool demolition aside – and Dean Smith is likely to have warned his team against overconfidence. Graham Potter’s side have flashed in attack in spots this season but have struggled for creativity recently with three goals in their past four matches. The logic behind counting on a proven poor finisher in Danny Welbeck and an ageing Adam Lallana should be questioned. On the flip side Lewis Dunk’s return strengthens an already stout defence that could limit Villa’s relative potency. Potter has had enough to time to plot a much-needed win but does he have the talent to execute? Possibly not. Graham Searles

José Mourinho and Pep Guardiola meet for a 24th time as managers in what is sure to be a highlight of the weekend. Guardiola will be seriously nervous of a title-denting defeat after signing a contract extension at Manchester City, if Sergio Agüero and Raheem Sterling fail to make the starting lineup. Mourinho will be quietly confident his flying Tottenham can put serious pressure on a City’s brittle defence. Harry Kane and Son Heung-min have been unstoppable and it is unlikely the international break will allow any respite from their surgical precision. Graham Searles

Can Manchester United beat West Brom and string back-to-back wins together for a first time this season? Slaven Bilic’s side have only three points and are winless so if Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s men turn up and follow the usual script and lose expect the latest inquiry into their direction under the Norwegian. Jamie Jackson

Steve Bruce is keeping everything crossed his leading scorer, Callum Wilson, passes a late fitness test on a hamstring injury as both he and Frank Lampard wonder why they have been asked to kick off at 12.30pm on Saturday following an international break. “With the flexibility we’ve got now, let’s sort it [kick-off times] out,” said Bruce. “We went to Southampton on a Friday night and we knew we couldn’t get back after the game because the airports were closed so, in these Covid times, let’s have a little bit of common sense. These 12 and one o’clock kick-offs after international breaks, I agree with Frank, something needs to be done about them.” Louise Taylor

West Brom’s season darkened further after losing to fellow winless side Fulham on Monday and on recent form Tottenham should ease past Slaven Bilic’s side without breaking sweat. Bilic needs to fire up his side for a free hit, as losing here will not condemn their season. A shock result, however, could define it and turn the corner toward improved performances.Jake Livermore, the captain, will be surely be motivated to lead an upset against his former side Graham Searles

This is an intriguing game between two attacking sides who cancelled each other out last season, when they shared a pair of scoreless draws. Both Leicester and Wolves have evolved since then and found new ways to infiltrate opponents so, although they remain defensively strong, goals seem likely now. Leicester have the added incentive of knowing that victory would send them top, at least for a few hours. Paul Doyle

This is the showdown of the season so far, between the reigning champions and those of the two preceding campaigns. Manchester City are starting to hit form, with Ferran Torres appearing one of the buys of the summer. Liverpool, though, have had the measure of City in recent seasons and so will arrive in east Manchester as a decent shot to record what could prove a materially significant win. Jamie Jackson

Aston Villa’s defence has regressed to the levels that almost resulted in relegation last season but Emiliano Martínez may hold the key to renewed fortification. The former Arsenal keeper has the inside track on Mikel Arteta and will be licking his lips at the chance to show the club they made a mistake in cashing in. Motivation may be totally irrelevant, though, as Arsenal seem to have skewed too heavily toward preventing goals. Yes, conceding two against Manchester City, Leicester and Manchester United is an amazing upgrade but scoring one in that period feels far too meagre for long-term success. Spain’s own George Graham will be unconcerned with stats, though, and focused on driving his side to feed off the victory at Old Trafford. Graham Searles

Chelsea will not underestimate Sheffield United given that Chris Wilder’s side took four points from them last season. This could be tricky, especially as Christian Pulisic and Kai Havertz are unavailable. Yet Chelsea have won their past three games and have five successive clean sheets in all competitions. It would be a shock were United, who have one point from seven games, to end their wait for a first league win. Jacob Steinberg

Fulham are feeling good after beating West Brom. Scott Parker’s side are out of the bottom three after earning their first win and will sense an opportunity to generate momentum when they visit West Ham, who are still without the injured Michail Antonio in attack. However, David Moyes’s side have been in good form and were unlucky to lose to Liverpool last weekend. Jacob Steinberg

Nineteen months on from what was, at that point, the nadir of his Old Trafford reign Ole Gunnar Solskjær returns to Goodison Park still under pressure and with questions surrounding the commitment of the same core of players who folded in that 4-0 defeat to Marco Silva’s Everton. So much for change or improvement. Two poor away defeats in succession – both without Richarlison, who remains suspended – demonstrated that Everton, like United, flatter to deceive. Both managers require a reaction urgently. Andy Hunter

Leeds have a tough ask in taking on the experienced Roy Hodgson and Crystal Palace. Hodgson’s side give nothing away and will be well prepared to hold firm and launch counterattacks while the visitors, level on points with Palace, go through their death by a thousand passes routine. It has worked well for the equally experienced Marcelo Bielsa but last week’s defeat to Leicester was Leeds’ poorest showing so far. Avoiding a painful slump from an excellent comeback to the top flight would be ideal before the international break. Graham Searles

Harry Kane and Son Heung-min’s influence on results this season has been huge. José Mourinho paid the price for resting them against Antwerp but they will be back to face Brighton. Graham Potter’s task is simple but incredibly difficult. Shut them down. Potter would be wise to take a leaf from Burnley’s book last week and sit back to negate their explosive quick breaks forward. Unfortunately for Brighton there is little worse in this world than a Mourinho scorned. He will have his midfield at peak ferocity as Tottenham aim to cleanse their shock Europa League defeat. Graham Searles

After gripping and ripping through their first four games, Aston Villa came up well short against Leeds despite having the upper hand in the first half. Dean Smith’s side created chances but failed to apply the finishing touch. A surprising development considering the hammering sent via Asgard that Liverpool received at Villa Park. Southampton are arguably an even tougher test than Leeds as Danny Ings will score if given the same room to attack in as Patrick Bamford and co. On the other side Jack Grealish will want to flash his considerable technical and creative abilities for Gareth Southgate’s perusal before England’s upcoming internationals. The quality in both sides easily makes this a contender for game of the weekend. Graham Searles

Scott Parker thinks Fulham are “moving in the right direction” but that needs to start translating into results. Defeat to West Brom, themselves in need of a first win, would bode particularly ill and this already has the feel of one that could define their season. “I think this game has a little bit extra,” Parker said. West Brom are in decent nick after a draw at Brighton but Slaven Bilic’s relationship with his board remains tense after the controversial sale of Ahmed Hegazi. Nick Ames

As befits a stranger to indecision, Marcelo Bielsa usually decides his Leeds lineups well in advance of games but the competitiveness, and versatility, within his squad dictates a rare dilemma before Leicester’s visit. “I don’t know my team, any of 22 players could start,” said the Leeds manager. It would be more major bombshell than mere surprise were the suddenly free-scoring Patrick Bamford to be omitted – particularly in the wake of his hat-trick as Bielsa’s team prevailed 3-0 at Aston Villa. Louise Taylor

Ole Gunnar Solskjær wants Manchester United to be consistent and following the 6-1 humiliation by Tottenham they have been – defeating Newcastle, Paris Saint-Germain, and RB Leipzig, while drawing with Chelsea with an aggregate score of 11-2. For the same period Arsenal’s record shows Sheffield United, Dundalk and Rapid Vienna all beaten with a defeat at Leicester for a 7-4 record overall. Yet on Sunday it will be a month since Arsenal’s last Premier League win so the home side, surely, start as firm favourites. Jamie Jackson

Rafael Benítez paid £12m to sign Jacob Murphy for Newcastle from Norwich in 2017 but he experienced a slow start to life on Tyneside. Indeed, following loan stints at West Brom and Sheffield Wednesday, Murphy was expected to be sold to a Championship club this summer but instead was a surprise inclusion in Steve Bruce’s Premier League squad. It looked an excellent call when an apparently reborn Murphy shone at right-back before scoring a late equaliser as Newcastle drew at Wolves last week. Bruce now says he does not dare drop him against Everton. Maybe Benítez’s judgment was right after all. Louise Taylor

Some are already describing this fixture as the Blades verses the blunts, as Manchester City will be without both Sergio Agüero and Gabriel Jesus, meaning Raheem Sterling is likely to be the central attacker. City have too many quality players to be completely blunted, although it is true that the points might have been shared last season but for Agüero coming on from the bench to provide a late winner. Sheffield United badly need to add to their solitary point before the international break, and after City they are away at Chelsea next. Paul Wilson

Jürgen Klopp has major problems in central defence but whether David Moyes has the options to capitalise is debatable. West Ham arrive in good form after four league games unbeaten but without striker Michail Antonio following the hamstring injury he sustained against Manchester City. With Fabinho, Virgil van Dijk and probably Joël Matip all out, the Liverpool manager could hand a Premier League debut to Rhys Williams, Nathaniel Phillips or Billy Koumetio alongside Joe Gomez. Jordan Henderson is another alternative but doubts over the fitness of Thiago Alcântara and Naby Keïta may prevent that switch as Liverpool aim to equal a club record of 63 league game unbeaten at Anfield. Andy Hunter

Burnley were somewhat unlucky not to get something from Tottenham in their last game, they certainly made life difficult for José Mourinho’s side. Sean Dyche feels Burnley are coming back into form but Chelsea will be another tough challenge for a side in the bottom three. Everyone knows how Burnley play; Chelsea, like Tottenham, have a few more subtle variations, but anyone visiting Turf Moor needs to be up for a fight and, with a takeover looming, the home side need to climb away from the relegation positions. Paul Wilson

Everton are feeling good but the scars from last week’s fraught Merseyside derby – Richarlison’s red card and James Rodríguez sustaining an injury leaving him touch and go – mean Carlo Ancelotti’s free-scoring side head to Southampton short of their full armoury. Dominic Calvert-Lewin – the league’s joint-leading scorer – will be keen to continue his impressive form, while another England striker, Southampton’s Danny Ings, will be determined to ensure Jordan Pickford has another busy afternoon. Ben Fisher

Newcastle have an excellent recent record at Molineux, they are unbeaten there since 2003, and this might not be a bad time for another visit, since Wolves have yet to hit top gear. On the other hand, Nuno Espírito Santo’s side have shown signs of progress after winning their past two matches and facing a team who have looked defensively vulnerable could be the chance their attack needs to really click. Newcastle could find themselves leaving Wolverhampton on the back of a hiding. Paul Doyle

Tottenham should coast past winless Burnley on current form, providing José Mourinho has served up a reminder of his reputation after the three-goal collapse against West Ham. Rather continuing the break from said reputation, Tottenham are the Premier League’s top scorers with 15. Burnley have three. Mourinho also has a squad large enough to handle the stresses and strains of the Europa League. Burnley are always tough to beat but keeping a clean sheet against the incandescent partnership of Harry Kane and Heung-min Son feels an impossible task for any side. Graham Searles

Brighton have been up and down, much like West Brom, but their ceiling feels rather higher, especially in attack. Graham Potter’s side need a statement victory to arrest a run of three without three points. Always easier said than done when facing a side you are “supposed” to beat. Slaven Bilic will be happy switching to the rugged pairing of Branislav Ivanovic and Ahmed Hegazi in central defence garnered a clean sheet last time out for West Brom. Now he needs end product from Karlan Grant to back up their productivity. Graham Searles

Sixth meets fifth with Arsenal and Leicester both aiming to bounce back from narrow defeats. The home side need to be more creative and may find Leicester’s expansive approach more conducive to giving the relatively shot-shy Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang more chances. How heavily Arsenal are detained defensively may depend on whether Jamie Vardy passes a fitness test for Leicester, who have thrashed both Manchester City and West Brom on the road so far but are yet to find consistency. Nick Ames

Roy Hodgson returns to Craven Cottage and finds Fulham feeling confident their fortunes may be turning. Their performance at Sheffield United last week was a step in the right direction and suggested Scott Parker’s extensive transfer window dealings may yet bear fruit. They need wins, though, and Crystal Palace will be difficult to beat as always, even though Jordan Ayew and Jack Butland are self-isolating with Covid-19. What price a vital contribution from Ruben Loftus-Cheek, on loan at Fulham, against a previous temporary employer? Nick Ames

Manchester City have won all five of their London Stadium visits, scoring 22 goals. Pep Guardiola’s side could be boosted by the return of Kevin De Bruyne, so West Ham need to avoid the sauntering pace they started at against Tottenham. If they defend properly, though, David Moyes’ side have a chance which could be boosted by a first West Ham appearance for Saïd Benrahma. Jacob Steinberg

Following Wednesday’s win over Ajax Jürgen Klopp highlighted that Sheffield United had their feet up while Liverpool were battling in Amsterdam. A fair warning, but it would be disingenuous to suggest Liverpool have not benefitted from a welcome victory and clean sheet. Plus, as Klopp’s triple substitution of Mohamed Salah, Roberto Firmino and Sadio Mané demonstrated, he still has enviable resources available in some departments. Chris Wilder’s side are winless this season and have been toothless in attack, scoring twice in five matches. Former Liverpool hopeful Rhian Brewster will be itching for the opportunity to improve that statistic. Andy Hunter

When Manchester United were hammered 6-1 by Tottenham this game was one of a subsequent run of fixtures that made grim reading for Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s side. Yet after convincing victories over Newcastle and Paris Saint-Germain United have shrugged the pressure off as Chelsea arrive at Old Trafford after enduring their own wobble. They have won one of their past four league games. Jamie Jackson

Leicester thrashed Aston Villa 4-0 at the King Power in the last match before the Premier League shutdown in March but Villa have been transformed since then. Dean Smith will probably start with only four of the players who featured in March and will be hoping to see a performance more like the one that brought that sensational 7-2 victory over Liverpool in their last outing. Injury-ravaged Leicester will have to play much better than against West Ham to avoid a second successive home league defeat. Paul Doyle

At some point Raphinha is expected to make his debut for Leeds. Marcelo Bielsa is clearly delighted with the 23-year-old Brazilian winger, signed from Rennes for £17m earlier this month. “His adaptation has been very quick, instant,” said the Leeds manager. “He is a player who is very able to adapt to the style of play we have. He is fundamentally a winger who can play on the right or the left side but he can also play in the central offensive position.” It seems competition for places is heating up in West Yorkshire as Leeds look to extend their fine start against Wolves. Louise Taylor

Sheffield United are in danger of suffering from second season syndrome. The team that surprised everyone last time out are pointless after four games this season, as are Fulham, currently propping up the table by virtue of an inferior goal difference. Chris Wilder has worries about some of the players on international duty in midweek, but mostly he has worries about restoring missing confidence. Goals from Rhian Brewster would help, and against a defence like Fulham’s the new signing should surely play. Paul Wilson

How both Slaven Bilic and Sean Dyche crave three points to get their respective seasons at West Brom and Burnley up and running. Five weeks in, they share a solitary point between them. Bilic can call upon new £15m signing Karlan Grant, while the Chelsea loanee Conor Gallagher could make his Premier League debut. Burnley, meanwhile, failed to make any late signings but are boosted by Dwight McNeil extending his stay. West Brom were much improved after switching to three in midfield in defeat at Southampton and Bilic must be tempted to start on the front foot when Burnley visit. Ben Fisher

Crystal Palace and Brighton face each other off the back of losing their past two games and the spice usually involved in this fixture will hopefully not be dampened by the lack of a crowd. Neither side could claim to be in a rut before the break considering all of those defeats were to superior opponents, even if Manchester United definitely did not deserve their win over Brighton. Graham Potter may feel he has the slight edge as Neil Maupay looks to be the difference maker between the two sides on current form. Graham Searles

Tottenham and West Ham are both in fine form after surprise commanding victories over Manchester United and Leicester respectively. José Mourinho’s front three – Harry Kane, Gareth Bale and Son Heung-min – are sure to overmatch their opponents on paper. But the introduction of Bale could interrupt Son and Kane’s electric partnership. Giovanni Lo Celso’s presence will also be missed in midfield. A free hit approach for David Moyes could yield another shock if his own attacking trio continue to dazzle. Graham Searles

Chelsea will not underestimate Ralph Hasenhüttl’s side after losing this fixture last season. But Southampton will expect a tougher test this time. Chelsea have spent heavily on their attack and Hakim Ziyech is in line for his first start since joining from Ajax after recovering from a knee injury. However Southampton, who are dangerous on their travels, may fancy their chances given that Kepa Arrizabalaga is likely to deputise for the injured Edouard Mendy in goal. Jacob Steinberg

Manchester City were knocked out of the FA Cup semi-finals the last time Pep Guardiola’s side played Arsenal and Mikel Arteta’s team have started their league campaign as impressively. Arsenal have taken nine from 12 points while City have four from nine and, with Kevin De Bruyne out, this is another firm test of where the home side is at. Jamie Jackson

Arguably Steve Bruce’s best day at Newcastle came last autumn when Matty Longstaff’s debut goal secured a 1-0 home victory over Manchester United. Now he hopes Allan Saint-Maximin can undo them again. The 23-year-old Frenchman has signed an improved, six-year contract and Bruce says he can be the “new David Ginola”. Although Saint-Maximin is a different type of winger Bruce knows he possesses similar capacity to bewitch. “Can Allan be a David Ginola?” he mused. “He can be anything he wants to be. He’s got the ability. He does things which are just off the radar.” Louise Taylor

Ten years. That’s how long the past fortnight must have felt for Jürgen Klopp after the champions’ fine start to the season came to a humiliating halt at Aston Villa. Liverpool have not lost a derby since 17 October 2010 and have never lost back-to-back league games under Klopp. The return of Sadio Mané and Thiago Alcântara after positive Covid-19 tests should aid the reaction required after Villa but Everton, confident as they sit top of the Premier League with a 100% record, pose a greater threat than usual with Dominic Calvert-Lewin already in double figures for the season as a whole after his first for England. Andy Hunter

After adjusting his tactics last week to earn a remarkable win at Manchester City, Brendan Rodgers is likely to revert to a more familiar method as he tries to prolong Leicester’s strong start to the season. His attempt to dominate play may lead to a first start of the season for James Maddison, whose performance off the bench last week suggested he has regained all his sharpness. West Ham also go into this game on the back of an excellent result thanks to last week’s 4-0 victory over Wolves. But Leicester should edge this fixture between two teams in form. Paul Doyle

The last edition of this fixture in December ended in a 2-1 Manchester United win that had Mason Greenwood at centre-forward for the first time and José Mourinho handed a first defeat as Tottenham manager. Victory eased pressure on Ole Gunnar Solskjær who had just overseen an insipid draw with Aston Villa. Now the manager is being asked to explain why only Donny van de Beek has been signed in the window. Another victory would go some way to fading out the noise – for the moment, at least. Jamie Jackson

Aston Villa have continued their excellent form post lockdown and look a different team than the one that almost exited the league. John McGinn and Jack Grealish were sublime as Dean Smith’s side demolished Fulham so a hard-fought battle like last season’s narrow defeat against Liverpool should be on the cards. Jürgen Klopp’s side have started with similar venom but, agonisingly for the rest of the league, still appear to not yet be in top gear. Smith’s revolutionised defence is in for a serious test to stop Liverpool racking up a fourth win in four. Graham Searles

Ralph Hasenhüttl swapped Jack Stephens for Jan Vestergaard against struggling Burnley and it did the trick as Southampton recovered from conceding five with a clean sheet. West Brom, after scoring three against Chelsea, look to pose a bigger threat. However Slaven Bilic’s side are still winless. Will they bring confidence from the first half last week or still be riddled with anxiety after failing to take a huge scalp? Graham Searles

There is no panic at Wolves over their streak of three consecutive defeats in all competitions. But that may change if they flop against Fulham, who were so bad in Monday’s defeat to Aston Villa that their chairman apologised to fans and vowed to keep looking for new players. Morale among the Londoners was flattened further by Thursday’s thrashing in the Carabao Cup by Brentford. Nuno Espírito Santo is trying to turn Wolves into a more dominant side this season and, despite injury concerns, this looks like a good opportunity to start. Paul Doyle

One of Arsenal’s repeated failures last season was in neglecting to put away supposedly inferior opponents once their noses were in front. Sheffield United’s last visit to the Emirates, in January, was a case in point; John Fleck scored a just-about-deserved leveller and the hosts’ problems loomed large. They look better now but Mikel Arteta believes Sunday’s opponents have “deserved much more” than three straight defeats. With both squads in a state of suspended animation before the transfer deadline, it could be a cagey afternoon. Nick Ames

Marcelo Bielsa says he is not Pep Guardiola’s lodestar as the pair meet for the first time in the Premier League. “I do not feel like a mentor to Guardiola. It’s not just how I feel, it has been evidenced to not being the case,” said the ever pedantic Leeds manager who must trust Patrick Bamford to maintain his one goal per game Premier League scoring record. “If there’s a manager who is independent in his own ideas, that is Guardiola. It’s not just because I say it is, it’s because his teams play like no other team.” Guardiola has repeatedly described Bielsa as the best coach in the world after their friendship was cemented in 2006 when the Spaniard travelled to meet the former Argentina coach on his ranch near Rosario. Louise Taylor

Steve Bruce has called for patience and balance after Newcastle fans criticised poor recent performances. Although results have been perhaps better than Bruce’s team deserved – they have lost only one of the last six games – the mood is increasingly hostile. “We all need time,” he said. “And I’m trying to change us from a team with a deep sitting back five to a more forward thinking side with a back four. You expect criticism but you hope it would be balanced.” Given that Sean Dyche and Burnley have troubles of their own Bruce could do with winning this one. Louise Taylor

This is a dangerous game for Chelsea, who remain a work in progress despite spending more than £200m on their squad. Crystal Palace are set up to hurt teams on the break and, having already won at Manchester United, they could cause Chelsea a few problems. It promises to be an awkward test for Frank Lampard’s side after their defeat to Tottenham in the Carabao Cup, although they have been boosted by Christian Pulisic’s return from injury. The winger could be in the squad for the first time this season. Jacob Steinberg

Everton have started wonderfully but injuries have hit Carlo Ancelotti’s side already. Midfielders Allan and André Gomes definitely miss out while Richarlison is doubtful. Carlo Ancelotti would love to grab a fourth win from four to keep his side’s 100% record and regroup following the international break. That may not be much of a worry though if Dominic Calvert-Lewin continues his incredible run of form. Brighton were desperately unlucky not to beat Manchester United let alone draw.
