They are capable of an upset if Graham Potter can target any familiarity and fluency problems Everton may have. Graham Searles

Sheffield United have failed to make the solid start to their second season in the Premier League their form last term suggested, in fact they have now lost their last six league games in a row, which is a worry going into the first top-flight edition of this particular Yorkshire derby for 26 years. The Blades will also have to do without defender John Egan, sent off last time out against Aston Villa, and will be aware Leeds have scored seven times in their opening two fixtures. That said, they have conceded seven times as well, and Marcelo Bielsa has admitted work needs to be done on the defence. Paul Wilson

José Mourinho wants to generate momentum and, after three wins in three in all competitions, the signs are encouraging, particularly with Harry Kane and Son Heung-min combining well. The challenge for them will be to make the running against a Newcastle team that will most likely be compact and look to strike on the counter. There have been times under Mourinho when this has been beyond them. Newcastle have won four of their last six in the league at Tottenham. David Hytner

Despite a long injury list Manchester City were sharp in their opening game and this meeting with the early leaders, Leicester, should be a cracker. Here are two sides who love to attack quick and fast so there would be some surprise if this ends as a dour goalless draw. Jamie Jackson

Two defeats to Mikel Arteta’s Arsenal – the last on penalties in the Community Shield – have left the champions “wanting to strike back” when they meet on Monday according to Jürgen Klopp. It will be the first of two opportunities to do so, with Anfield also hosting their Carabao Cup fourth-round meeting on Thursday. With Jordan Henderson unavailable and Fabinho potentially required in central defence, there could be a first start for the new signing Thiago Alcântara. Arteta admits his team will have to be at their absolute best to end Liverpool’s 60-game unbeaten run at Anfield. Andy Hunter

It has been another odd week at West Ham, whose win over Hull in the Carabao Cup was dominated by David Moyes, Josh Cullen and Issa Diop returning positive tests for Covid-19 shortly before kick-off. Moyes will be managing remotely against Wolves, with Alan Irvine standing in on the touchline, and needs a win losing his first two league games. West Ham’s co-owner David Sullivan did not ease the pressure when he warned that there might be no signings before the transfer window shuts. Jacob Steinberg

A must-win game for Fulham? Not that drastic, according to Scott Parker, but the consequences of a long early run of losses need little spelling out. Defeat at Leeds was far from ideal but the manner of their recovery, pulling back to 4-3 and coming close to completing the job, ensured they did not depart with confidence sapped. Villa have seen their new expensive new signings – Ollie Watkins, Emiliano Martínez and Bertrand Traoré – all make immediate impacts and will be confident of a different outcome from a skeleton side’s 2-1 reverse in the FA Cup third round nine months ago. Nick Ames

Brighton lost 3-0 in the corresponding fixture in June and since then United have added the £35m Netherlands international Donny van de Beek to their squad. Joël Veltman, at £0.9m Brighton’s costliest signing of the transfer window thus far, is also a Dutch international and a former Ajax teammate of Van de Beek. Neither of the former colleagues are likely to start on Saturday, though, but if Tariq Lamptey fails a fitness test on a groin strain, Veltman may slot in at right wing-back for Graham Potter’s side. Rich Flower

Two 100% records collide at Selhurst Park, with Everton hoping to record a third straight win to start a new season for the first time since 1993. Palace haven’t achieved that feat since 2006 in the Championship and will be looking to pick up only their second win over the Merseysiders in the Premier League in 12 attempts. Be warned, however: the last two meetings of these sides at Selhurst Park failed to produce a single goal. Ed Aarons

Frank Lampard will decide whether to hand Édouard Mendy his debut following a £22m move from Rennes but the Chelsea manager is unlikely to persist with Kepa Arrizabalaga, who is set to be dropped after a high-profile error in defeat to Liverpool last weekend. Willy Caballero started in goal as a much-changed side romped past Barnsley in the Carabao Cup in midweek, a game in which Thiago Silva made his Chelsea debut. Conor Gallagher is ineligible to face his parent club but Branislav Ivanovic could feature against the team where he won three Premier League titles after making his Albion debut in the Carabao Cup exit to Brentford in midweek. Ben Fisher

Both Burnley and Southampton are looking for their first points of the season and both will be looking to take something from this game to show they are capable of moving up the table. With two games played Southampton’s disappointing return has been the more surprising, but though Burnley showed characteristic feistiness in going down 4-2 at Leicester last week Sean Dyche’s repeated warnings about the shallowness of the squad seem to be coming to pass. Even though Ashley Barnes is on the verge of a return, Burnley cannot afford any more injuries. Paul Wilson

A fairytale return to where it all started will come too soon for Gareth Bale but the subplots do not stop there. This week Tottenham had an approach for Danny Ings, who scored the winner in this fixture last season, swiftly rebuffed by Southampton, with Ralph Hasenhüttl adamant the striker, whom he labelled “one of the best in Europe”, has zero interest in playing second fiddle to Harry Kane. Pierre-Emile Højbjerg, the former Southampton captain, and Kyle Walker-Peters, who joined Tottenham aged 10, are set to face their former clubs as Spurs travel to St Mary’s for the first of three games in five days. Ben Fisher

If Manchester City are to mount a better title challenge this season then this is the kind of match where they must show improvement. Wolves beat City home and away last season and kicked off their own campaign with a fine win at Sheffield United last week before slipping up in the Carabao Cup against Stoke. Adama Traoré did plenty of damage to City last season so one of Pep Guardiola’s new signings, Ferran Torres, could be in for a heck of a baptism while the other, Nathan Aké, may be handed the equally difficult task of trying to suppress Raul Jiménez. As ever, City will be counting on their attack to offset any defensive problems. Paul Doyle

Brendan Rodgers’ big decision is whether to start James Maddison, who returned from injury as a substitute in last weekend’s win at West Brom. Owing to other absences Leicester are likely to have to continue using Wilfred Ndidi in central defence – he coped fine at the Hawthorns but this Sunday he will face Chris Wood, who scored twice against Leicester last season, and who represents an altogether different challenge for a midfielder playing out of position. Paul Doyle

Aston Villa will be raring to go against Sheffield United after beating the drop against the odds last season. Dean Smith has reason to hope for better now after upgrading his improving defence with right-back Matty Cash and goalkeeper Emiliano Martínez. Martínez is unlikely to get off to a worse start than Sheffield United’s goalkeeper Aaron Ramsdale, who conceded twice within six minutes on his debut last week. The Blades need a sharper performance to keep out Ollie Watkins. He scored on his debut in the EFL Cup and was lethal for Brentford last term. Graham Searles

This is the first big test for Chelsea after their summer spend. While Liverpool’s defence looked shaky in last weekend’s 4-3 win over Leeds, the champions remain the team to beat. Liverpool have the benefit of stability and have boosted the mood around Anfield after signing Thiago Alcântara from Bayern Munich. But Chelsea flashed in victory over Brighton on Monday, with Timo Werner impressing on his debut, and Frank Lampard will be keen to outthink Jürgen Klopp after last season’s touchline spat. Jacob Steinberg

Newcastle have fared fairly badly against Brighton since the pair were promoted together in 2017. They have lost two and drawn four of their past six meetings but the home side’s desire for atonement is far from the sole subplot in this match between two teams in transition. While Graham Potter oversaw a radical, and still ongoing, change in Brighton’s much more expansive style last season, Steve Bruce is proceeding more cautiously with Newcastle. Indeed his side managed only 36 % of possession during the midweek Carabao Cup win over Blackburn on Tyneside. Louise Taylor

Arsenal aim to channel the good feeling of Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang’s new contract and the continuation of their fine summer form. West Ham were their final opponents before the Covid-19 shutdown in March and, as Mikel Arteta admitted, Arsenal were fortunate to win that day. But they have progressed since then while it is hard to find too much positivity for David Moyes’ side, who need to tighten up their defence if they are not to endure a torrid evening. Arteta must decide whether David Luiz is ready to return and waits on Granit Xhaka but, based on the win at Fulham, the rest of his team picks itself. Nick Ames

When Scott Parker watched Leeds lose 4-3 in the most gallantly swashbuckling of fashions at Liverpool last weekend he was not remotely taken aback. “I wasn’t surprised at all,” said Fulham’s manager. “I won’t be surprised if they keep doing that all season.” Parker duly anticipates a challenge at Elland Road, even if it will not be quite the occasion these two recent arrivals from the Championship once envisaged owing to a silent stadium. Louise Taylor

Expect Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s sole signing, Donny van de Beek, to be a replacement as Manchester United hunt for the winning start needed if they are to have any real hope of challenging Liverpool and Manchester City this term. Crystal Palace won last season’s corresponding fixture 2-1, so this may be close. Jamie Jackson

More of the same for one manager and a fresh start for another. Carlo Ancelotti’s side and new-look midfield were highly impressive at Tottenham on the opening weekend and Everton are looking to start a season with successive league wins for the first time since 2012-13. For Slaven Bilic, by contrast, an immediate reset is required following a home defeat by Leicester that underlined the improvement demanded of West Brom. Everton are short on central defensive options with both Mason Holgate and Jarrad Branthwaite injured. Andy Hunter

Last season’s meetings between these two clubs were very tight and the outcome of this one may well depend on which side has recharged better from impressive and draining campaigns. Wolves have had a shorter rest and no pre-season matches, and their new signings have had little time to integrate so they may not start. Having lost both his first-choice full-backs from last season for this game – Jonny is injured and Matt Doherty has gone to Tottenham – Nuno Espírito Santo will be hoping that Adama Traoré, in particular, ensures that Sheffield United’s wide players have to spend most of their time going backwards. Attack certainly seems the best policy for the hosts, especially as United will be giving a debut to a new goalkeeper, Aaron Ramsdale. Paul Doyle

West Brom are back in the Premier League and face the significant challenge of a Leciester side eager to bounce back from last season’s poor finish. Brendan Rodgers still has a headache in defence, though, with Jonny Evans suspended and Ricardo Pereira injured. If Jamie Vardy can snag a through ball or two then those problems may fall by the wayside. Rodgers will be looking for Harvey Barnes to step up, with James Maddison still sidelined. Graham Searles

Frank Lampard’s new-look Chelsea begin away at Brighton, with Timo Werner and Kai Havertz set to start following big-money moves, though the game comes too soon for Hakim Ziyech, Ben Chilwell and Thiago Silva, who is yet to train with his new teammates. Werner scored when these sides played out a friendly draw two weeks ago – part of a government trial event for the return of supporters – and will be keen to make his mark in the league. The former Liverpool midfielder Adam Lallana and Ben White, who excelled on loan at Leeds last season, are in line for their debuts for Brighton. Ben Fisher

There is a prize at stake for the team that start as they hope to go on – the chance to lay down a marker for a top-six finish. José Mourinho sees Everton as challengers to this tier and Carlo Ancelotti has fired the imagination with his transfer business, particularly the signing of James Rodríguez. Mourinho has added proven Premier League pedigree – Matt Doherty and Pierre-Emile Højbjerg are in line to make debuts – making this a battle between steel and silk. David Hytner

Michy Batshuayi returns to Crystal Palace on loan to hopefully bring goals to an attack that scored a second-worst total of 31 in the league last season. Ralph Hasenhüttl will hope Danny Ings continues the red-hot form for Southampton that almost stole the golden boot away from Jamie Vardy. Ings may produce exactly that as he comes up against a severely depleted Palace defence. Graham Searles

West Ham are already under pressure after angering their players and their supporters with the controversial sale of Grady Diangana to West Brom. They have made no signings after spending last season battling against relegation and David Moyes needs his team to be resilient against Newcastle, who are feeling good after buying Ryan Fraser, Jamal Lewis and Callum Wilson. Jacob Steinberg

Two of the better Premier League midfielders from the past 15 years do battle from the dugout, with Scott Parker and Mikel Arteta both hoping new additions settle quickly. Parker signed France goalkeeper Alphonse Areola and the Netherlands right-back Kenny Tete this week and faces a decision on how soon to pitch them in for Fulham. Arteta, usually overstocked with centre-backs, finds himself down to three. William Saliba should make his debut, but Gabriel Magalhães has only recently begun to train with his Arsenal teammates. Further forward, Willian is available to add much-needed experience. Nick Ames

What a contest to start with, and what a pity there can be no crowd for the occasion. Leeds return to the top flight after an absence of 5,964 days at the champions, who are unbeaten at Anfield for three successive seasons and are four games shy of equalling the club record of 63 home league games without defeat. Liverpool have scored at least three goals in every opening game under Jürgen Klopp but Marcelo Bielsa, fresh from signing a new one-year contract, will pose a fresh conundrum. Andy Hunter

Aston Villa fought valiantly in the Carabao Cup final and will have hope of staying up if they can maintain such defensive improvement. The worry is still end product in front of goal though and the need for those around Jack Grealish to match his endeavour. Brendan Rodgers’ anxiety will have been relieved by safe passage into the FA Cup quarter-finals and Jamie Vardy’s return to the side. Champions League qualification looks assured but another defeat to a struggling side would raise eyebrows. Graham Searles

Manchester United can record an impressive third win over Manchester City this season in a 182nd derby staged as these rivals hit prime form. There may be injury concerns regarding United’s Harry Maguire and City’s Kevin De Bruyne but whoever plays will surely provide a spectacle due to the importance of the encounter. Jamie Jackson

Carlo Ancelotti returns to Stamford Bridge with a familiar face in Frank Lampard in charge of Chelsea. Lampard describes the Italian as a gentleman and a fantastic manager and his work with Everton has shown as such. Fans adore him and the side’s improvement is plain to see. European football is now a possibility and Ancelotti will be keen to demonstrate what his former club are missing. Chelsea soothed the pain of their Champions League nightmare by beating Liverpool in the Cup but with a gathering pack of clubs hungry for a taste next season Lampard needs to find the same performances in the league to make sure his side qualify. The large number of missing players, especially in midfield, is a headache he could do without. Graham Searles

Arsenal’s unlikely Champions League tilt will have real momentum if they rack up a third consecutive win. It could make for a tense affair given that their season is, since losing in the Europa League Olympiakos, on something of a knife-edge and West Ham themselves desperately need points. David Moyes visits his one-time midfield maestro at Everton, Mikel Arteta, and will think a good performance at Anfield and resounding win over Southampton have formed a solid basis to trouble opponents who remain fragile. Nick Ames

Liverpool will move a nerve-shredding 25 points clear with nine games to play should they set a new English top-flight record of 22 consecutive home league wins with victory over relegation-threatened Bournemouth. Mohamed Salah is in line to make his 100th Premier League appearance for the club. He has scored 69 league goals for Jürgen Klopp’s team so far, including seven in five outings against Bournemouth, and needs one more to become the first Liverpool player since Michael Owen to score 20 goals in three successive seasons in all competitions. The visitors have lost their last five away matches. Andy Hunter

Burnley are on a roll at the moment and could overtake Tottenham if they can keep up their impressive record against top sides. That might not be as improbable as it sounds, for José Mourinho’s side have lost four in a row since Son Heung-min joined Harry Kane on the injury list, and Tottenham have a Champion League trip to RB Leipzig on Tuesday to worry about. Paul Wilson

The relative safety of 12th place with 10 games to go after back-to-back wins has helped Roy Hodgson land a deal for another season at Crystal Palace, whom he joined in September 2017 when they had no points after seven games under the guidance of Frank de Boer. The rest is history as the former England manager helped extend their longest ever spell in the top flight to seven seasons. Last season’s best-ever points total of 49 is a realistic target too, if they can capitalise in front of goal. Palace have 11 goals from 14 home games, the worst in the division, while Watford, 11 away goals in 14, finally moved out of the bottom three with last week’s shock defeat of Liverpool but will have to get a result without the services of the livewire Gerard Deulofeu, who ruptured an ACL ligament in that game. Mark Tallentire

These two have gone in different directions since their promotion last spring but Norwich remain tantalisingly within reach of safety and have enjoyed a stellar week. Can they top the win against Leicester and FA Cup victory over Tottenham by seeing off Chris Wilder’s side? With Tim Krul in the Norwich goal, Sheffield United face a significant obstacle in their push for European qualification. Louise Taylor

Newcastle have won once in 10 Premier League games, and didn’t score a goal in their four February league matches. Despite those grim statistics, Steve Bruce is “quietly confident” of getting a result at St Mary’s, with morale boosted by their FA Cup run, and new contracts given to Jonjo Shelvey and Matt Ritchie. Newcastle fans may be more pessimistic – the long journey to Southampton has yielded three points once since 1972. For the hosts, Stuart Armstrong is ruled out with a concussion, so Moussa Djenepo could return in his place. Niall McVeigh

Wolves have hit form and are three points off fourth place after a brilliant win over Tottenham and as such the Champions League feels tantalisingly close. Why settle for fourth though? Leicester’s recent struggles suggest third is still up for grabs and victory over Brighton would be an ideal way to start hauling them in. Wolves will have to try and do so without Adama Traoré’s venomous pace and power which will undoubtedly be a relief for Graham Potter’s defence. Struggling Brighton sit a single point above relegation and are still winless this year. Relegation beckons on current form. Graham Searles

Ole Gunnar Solskjær issued a public apology and threatened a clear-out after the 4-0 humbling at Goodison Park last season. The exodus never materialised but Sunday’s return is opportunity to demonstrate that, with Bruno Fernandes making an immediate impact and United unbeaten in seven matches in all competitions, lessons have been learned and progress is being made. Defeat at Arsenal last Sunday delivered a reminder of Everton’s shortcomings and confirmed Carlo Ancelotti was right to ignore the hype about Champions League qualification. The Europa League is his target and he could do with a repeat of last season’s victory to ensure it remains a realistic one. Andy Hunter

Manchester City’s Champions League ban has raised the temperature of this fixture. For Tottenham and Wolves, the discussion has turned towards a top-five finish and victory would represent a tonic. Injury-hit Spurs have flattered to deceive under José Mourinho but they have found a way to dig out results. Wolves, unbeaten in London since their promotion in 2018 – a run of eight matches – are always a tough nut to crack. David Hytner

Frank Lampard will demand a positive reaction from Chelsea after being punished by Bayern Munich at Stamford Bridge on Tuesday. A trip to Bournemouth may be the perfect opportunity to do exactly that as Chelsea have more points on the road than at home this season. Olivier Giroud will continue to lead the line while Tammy Abraham’s rehab continues. Eddie Howe watched his side demolish Chelsea in this fixture last season but would surely settle for a point as their relegation rivals are either out of action or facing tough opposition. Graham Searles

West Ham produced an encouraging performance despite losing to Liverpool on Monday and David Moyes needs his struggling side to maintain that level when they host Southampton. However Saints are in good form and West Ham, who remain in the bottom three, have not won in the league since thumping Bournemouth on 1 January. It will not be easy for Moyes’s side, especially as they have lost Tomas Soucek to injury. Jacob Steinberg

Watford are in trouble and have the horrible task of facing all-conquering Liverpool so hell for leather is the only option for Nigel Pearson’s side. There feels little point in thinking what might have been when the divide is so large between the two sides. Ismaila Sarr may start for Watford and, if so, be given the task of captitalising on any complacency as a first Premier League title comes ever closer for Liverpool. Graham Searles

Brighton are still winless this year and under pressure as they gear up to face bitter rivals Crystal Palace. Roy Hodgson’s side were in the same boat until last weekend. The confidence three points can bring could give Palace a useful edge with Brighton looking over their shoulder into the relegation zone. One certainty is Graham Potter needs to plan for Wilfired Zaha. The forward tends to save his best for this “derby”. Avoiding defeat could be the order of the day again for both sides. Graham Searles

Newcastle are struggling and possesion has represented a huge stumbling block for Steve Bruce, who hopes a planned change of formation, almost certainly featuring a reversion to a back four, will facilitate an improvement. With relegation fears rising and supporter dissent resurfacing, Bruce could do with a win. Louise Taylor

A deal of pity can be felt for West Ham who follow up a defeat at Manchester City with a trip to Anfield. Only another win for Liverpool feels likely especially after losing narrowly in Spain on Tuesday. The defeat against Atlético Madrid will have stung a little and Jürgen Klopp will be keen for his side to salve the wound. David Moyes’s side are winless in seven in all competitions but their fixture run looks challenging. Next up are Southampton, Arsenal, Wolves, Tottenham annd Chelsea. Relegation fears could begin to escalate quickly. Graham Searles

Wolves will be in bright spirits after demolishing Espanyol and spurred on by the chance to end their winless league run against struggling Norwich. Goals finally came for Nuno Espírito Santo and they will likely flow once more against a side who concede close to two a game on average. To stop Wolves Daniel Farke will hope the winter break has refreshed tired legs and minds. Norwich are eight points from safety and are running out of time. Teemu Pukki being given better service to score from open play would be a huge help as two penalties are all he has to his name in 2020. Graham Searles

Odion Ighalo could make his full Manchester United debut against his former club and expect David De Gea, Bruno Fernandes and Fred to be restored to Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s starting lineup following Thursday’s 1-1 draw at Club Brugge. Nigel Pearson’s Watford will fancy a win at Old Trafford as they were victorous in December’s reverse fixture, an indication of United’s struggles against the lower-ranked sides. Jamie Jackson

Everton have managed four draws at the Emirates in 14 visits and last won at Arsenal in January 1996 but they will go into this match fancying their chances more than ever in a meeting of managers who were linked with each other’s jobs when they were vacant late last year. Everton are showing decent form under Carlo Ancelotti, 17 points from 24, while Mikel Arteta’s Arsenal have improved defensively, although they are drawing more games than they would prefer. Mesut Özil is available after missing the 1-0 Europa League win at Olympiakos, while André Gomes is “ready to play” for Everton only 16 weeks after a fracture and dislocation of an ankle. Mark Tallentire

Manchester City’s European ban is overshadowing their football but they returned to the pitch after Uefa’s action and dominated West Ham. Pep Guardiola will be looking for City to be even better as they gear up to face Real Madrid in the Champions League. Leicester’s lack of defensive midfielders could invite another mauling – three are either injured or suspended for Brendan Rodgers. A second appearance in Europe’s elite competition beckons for Leicester and a shock win would take them ever closer. Graham Searles

José Mourinho returns to Stamford Bridge hoping to nab Chelsea’s place in the top four. But while Tottenham are a point behind, their push for Champions League qualification has been disrupted by long-term injuries to Harry Kane and Son Heung-min. Chelsea also have problems. N’Golo Kanté is out and Tammy Abraham is a doubt with an ankle injury. Jacob Steinberg

Crystal Palace have tumbled from seventh to 14th since December after a run of one win in 13 matches. Panic is not yet required though as injuries have ravaged the squad and draws against Arsenal and Manchester City show Roy Hodgson’s side are mentally present. Relegation seems an unlikely prospect as it does for Newcastle, who are a point ahead in 13th. Goals are likely to be at a premium with Palace and Newcastle the lowest and second-lowest scoring sides in the league respectively. One goal could be enough as it was earlier in the season for Steve Bruce. Graham Searles

Burnley have won three of their past four games, with a draw against Arsenal in between, and the 10 points gained have taken them into the company of Wolves, Everton and Arsenal in mid-table. Victory over Bournemouth would take them to the fringe of the Europa League positions. Not that there is likely to be much enthusiasm for that prospect at Turf Moor after what happened last season. Bournemouth are only two points above the drop zone and like Brighton and Aston Villa need to put a few results together to pull away. Paul Wilson

Graham Potter seems in a stern mood following the “Brighton Balloon four’s Canary Island incident”. During last week’s winter break a video surfaced of a quartet of Potter’s players – Shane Duffy, Pascal Gross, Leandro Trossard and Alireza Jahanbakhsh – apparently inhaling from balloons in a bar in Tenerife where Brighton were having a winter break. The club denied the four inhaled nitrous oxide – aka laughing gas. “It was probably not the best decision in the world,” said an unamused Potter, whose team hover three points above the relegation zone. “Occasionally they do things that aren’t so clever.” Sheffield United trust their Dubai break will help secure European qualification. Louise Taylor

Aston Villa have taken just eight points from 39 on the road this season, but may fancy their chances against the team with the league’s worst home record. Southampton’s stellar away form has carried them close to safety, but Villa would be three points behind them with a win at St Mary’s. Southampton will be without Nathan Redmond, sidelined for at least a month, while Sofiane Boufal and loanee Kyle Walter-Peters also miss out. For the visitors, defender Tyrone Mings is available again after missing the defeat to Spurs with tonsillitis. Niall McVeigh

This meeting begins a 13-game run-in during which Chelsea and Manchester United each hope to claim a Champions League berth. For Frank Lampard’s side the carrot is knowing a win takes them nine points clear of their visitors who for the same reason will be desperate to avoid this and claim victory themselves to close to within three points to the hosts. Odion Ighalo will be in United’s squad and the on-loan striker may play at some point. Jamie Jackson

When Arsenal won 1-0 at St James’ Park on the opening day of the season the suggestion the two sides would have the same number of points after 25 games would have got you strange looks in Newcastle and north London alike. And yet through the departure of Unai Emery, the brief interim tenure of Freddie Ljungberg and now the arrival of Mikel Arteta, the Gunners have won just five more times in the league to languish in 10th, ahead of Steve Bruce’s surprisingly resilient side only on goal difference. Arteta has drawn five of his seven league games in charge and Arsenal have drawn 13 from 25 in total: after the extravagance of a winter break in Dubai you get the feeling the Emirates crowd will accept nothing less than all three points on Sunday. Paul Chronnell

Tottenham have a formidable record at Villa Park – they have not been beaten on their last nine visits and they have won their last five away trips at Villa with a combined scored of 14-1. How they would love for that trend to continue on Sunday. Back-to-back wins have reignited Tottenham’s hopes of a top-four finish but Villa are on the right side of the dotted line – just – and have developed a habit for unexpected wins at just the right time. John Ashdown

Norwich are bottom and seven points from safety with the joint leakiest defence in the top flight so this may not be the ideal time for them to face Liverpool – Jürgen Klopp’s side have scored 28 goals against Norwich in their past seven Premier League encounters, including a 4-1 victory at Anfield on the opening day of the season. Daniel Farke will need Teemu Pukki to rediscover some form if the home side are to inflict Liverpool’s first league defeat since January 2019 as the Finnish striker has scored only twice in his past seven appearances after starting the season with five goals in three games. Liverpool, already overwhelming favourites to take all three points, should be boosted by the return from injury of Sadio Mané and James Milner. Rich Flower

Burnley won the season-opening reverse fixture 3-0, a result that set Southampton up for a miserable autumn. Both sides are now sitting comfortably in mid-table, but neither manager seems likely to accept any drop in intensity after the winter break. James Ward-Prowse is in contention after suffering a cut to his knee in the FA Cup defeat to Tottenham, while Matt Lowton and Charlie Taylor face late fitness tests for Burnley. Ashley Barnes, who scored twice in the August game at Turf Moor, remains sidelined with a groin problem. Burnley are something of a bogey side for Southampton; the Saints are winless in their last six Premier League meetings, scoring only two goals. Niall McVeigh

Sheffield United are off for winter break in Dubai after this but Europe still remains their intended final destination this season. Bournemouth meanwhile will be simply happy to stay out of the Championship and two straight wins, against Aston Villa and Brighton, have bolstered Eddie Howe’s morale. Much may hinge on Chris Wilder’s signing, Sander Berge who is expected to make his home debut in midfield before body and mind can be replenished. Not that Wilder’s players really need a boost. No Premier League team is fitter, or less injury prone, than Sheffield United. Louise Taylor

Manchester City are staring at a 22-point deficit to Liverpool and have lost Raheem Sterling, whose hamstring injury may rule him out for several weeks. On the plus side: after West Ham’s visit there is a fortnight off to rest and regroup ahead of facing Real Madrid in the Champions League at the end of February. Jamie Jackson

Had it not been for the stoppage-time implosion against Newcastle Carlo Ancelotti would be seeking his fourth win in four home matches as Everton manager. Having overseen the club’s first comeback victory in the Premier League for over two years last weekend, however, and with 10 men at Watford, he had no complaints over the response. Palace lack that momentum, with no wins in 2020, only three victories in the last 17 league games and an underwhelming transfer window fuelling frustration around Selhurst Park, yet only three points separate these sides. Andy Hunter

Watford need to break their recent crippling habit of throwing away leads. Nigel Pearson’s side have nothing to show from their last two league games despite leading in both and sit in the relegation zone when they could have been five points clear. Brighton also need to snap a dangerous winless streak stretching five matches and back to December. The resurgence of Glenn Murray could give them the required boost as goals have not been flowing freely. Murray’s heroics in last weekend’s draw against West Ham after all looked lost could inspire another important result in Graham Potter’s bid to keep Brighton up. Graham Searles

Burnley are now level on points with Arsenal in the table and arguably in better league form with wins in their last two Premier League games. The visit of Mikel Arteta’s side to Turf Moor was originally viewed as the last challenge in a gruelling sequence of games against top sides that Burnley would be glad to put behind them, but after beating Leicester and Manchester United to climb to mid-table Sean Dyche and his players have every reason to be confident. Paul Wilson

José Mourinho has not always seen eye to eye with Pep Guardiola as they have clashed across divides in Spain and Manchester. There was also that Champions League semi-final between Mourinho’s Internazionale and Guardiola’s Barcelona. But on the eve of this showpiece, Mourinho wanted to remind everybody of the four years that they spent together, when he was a translator then assistant manager at Barcelona and Guardiola was a player. Forget the sideshow, he suggested. Sunday is all about the football. David Hytner

West Ham are under immense pressure before hosting Brighton. They are winless in five attempts against Graham Potter’s side and could be in the bottom three by the end of the weekend. But while Michail Antonio is out with a hamstring problem, the arrival of Tomas Soucek has raised spirits. The midfielder could make his debut against Brighton, who also have relegation concerns after a bad run. Jacob Steinberg

After the disappointment of their midweek Carabao Cup defeat by Aston Villa, Leicester aim to bounce back by gaining a victory that would strengthen their hold on a Champions League qualification spot. Jamie Vardy suffered no ill-effects from his appearance off the bench at Villa so could be unleashed from the start on Saturday, which means Chelsea’s fragile central defence will have little room for error. Chelsea’s forwards have not been clinical enough this season and cannot afford to fritter away any chances they create at the King Power. Paul Doyle

Richarlison is likely to return for Everton to face his former club Watford after missing two matches. Nigel Pearson has Will Hughes and Danny Welbeck back at his disposal and both could be useful options after a damaging late defeat against Aston Villa. The loss put Watford back in the relegation zone and a morale-boosting win would be fantastic when their rivals at the bottom Brighton are up next with Manchester United and Liverpool to follow. Graham Searles

The runaway league leaders hit the 70 point mark with victory over West Ham in midweek – more than Liverpool have accumulated in 17 of the 27 complete Premier League seasons – and are seeking a 20th consecutive home league win as they close in on the club’s first title in 30 years. It is over a year since Jürgen Klopp’s team last failed to win at Anfield in the league and over two years since they lost to a team outside of the so-called ‘big six’. Southampton have won their last four away league matches to propel themselves out of trouble but a fifth will require a monumental feat. Andy Hunter

Sheffield United have strengthened in the transfer window and club record signing Sander Berge may feature in midfield but most likely from the bench. Crystal Palace’s addition Cenk Tosun is missing with injury but Roy Hodgson welcomes back Andros Townsend and Christian Benteke from injury to cover the Turkish striker. Chris Wilder’s first win in the top flight was against Palace and the Blades can return to fifth place with another set of three points if results go their way. A tight game could be on the cards as Palace have neither scored or conceded more than twice in any of their 12 home games this season. Graham Searles

When Newcastle were sunk 3-1 at Carrow Road in August, with Teemu Pukki scoring a hat-trick, gloom enveloped Tyneside. How times have since changed. Now Norwich are the team struggling at the bottom as Newcastle seek the win which lift Steve Bruce’s players to a very respectable February tally of 33 points. Danny Rose is expected to make his debut at left wing-back on a day when the Toon remains enveloped by one thing: confusion. Is the proposed Saudi takeover at St James’ Park a real possibility or merely another mirage? Louise Taylor

Nemanja Matic’s suspension increases the prospect of Bruno Fernandes making a full Manchester United debut following his £46.5m move. Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s side have already drawn twice and won once against Wolves this season: their temperamental nature means that despite Wednesday’s win at Manchester City there are no guarantees in this final game before the winter break. Jamie Jackson

Bournemouth and Aston Villa need a win as crunch time is approaching in the relegation battle. Eddie Howe’s side could climb out of danger with three points while dropping their rivals into trouble and a dip in form may be on the cards for Villa after the thrill of making the League Cup final. Mbwana Samatta’s first start in the Premier League will hopefully provide the goal threat Dean Smith’s side have lacked. Bournemouth have to put FA Cup defeat behind them and reproduce the performance that beat Brighton and snapped their six-match winless run. Graham Searles

Football fans are naturally superstitious but funny things can happen when your team is on a long unbeaten run. Arsenal supporters will remember the “this is the day we are going to lose” mentality in the latter stages of the record 49-game streak in 2003-04. It could be a tricky looking away game, or perhaps an early kick-off, but usually it would just be against a bitter rival who you knew would enjoy ending your run more than anybody else. So it is entirely natural that Liverpool – unbeaten this season, unbeaten in 38 league matches and unbeaten in the league at Anfield since April 2017 – seem to be entertaining the fact they will lose to Manchester United on Sunday. True, United are the only team to take a point off Jürgen Klopp’s side this season courtesy of October’s 1-1 draw at Old Trafford but their inconsistent away form has seen them lose at Watford and Arsenal of late and there is little to suggest they can silence Anfield. Apart from the fact that this is football, of course. Paul Chronnell

Burnley are in a bit of a tight spot, only three points above the teams in the relegation zone, without a win or even a draw since Christmas, and with Manchester United and Arsenal up next after Brendan Rodgers’ high-flying Leicester. Surprisingly beaten by Southampton last week, Leicester still look a good bet for a top-four finish. Burnley will have their work cut out if they are to pick up any points before February, particularly with Ashley Barnes out injured. Paul Wilson

Appearances can be deceptive. Newcastle United might look safe in mid-table, with fans even having begun to chant Steve Bruce’s name but they are only five points above the relegation zone, on a poor run and their sole fit striker is the less than prolific £40m Brazilian Joelinton. With Chelsea anxious about qualifying for next season’s Champions League it could be a surprisingly tense evening on Tyneside where the drama seems set to be enriched appreciably by the expected return of Newcastle’s Allan Saint-Maximin following injury. Louise Taylor

Arsenal’s woeful performance when these teams last met, in a 1-0 home win for Sheffield United on 21 October, was one of the showings that set Unai Emery’s demise in train. They have perked up since Mikel Arteta’s arrival but, in order to exact revenge on Chris Wilder’s side, will have to find a means of achieving something they have found exceptionally difficult over the past two years: winning a game without Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang. The captain is suspended and Arsenal’s other striker, Alexandre Lacazette, is suffering on a barren run. United’s David McGoldrick knows that feeling but Arsenal’s defence should offer chances to finally find the goal his performances so richly deserve. Nick Ames

Watford are on an incredible run and huge credit must be given to Nigel Pearson and his squad for the potentially season-saving turnaround. José Mourinho needs to stop Troy Deeney from running rampant for Tottenham to stand a chance of not becoming their latest scalp. Mourinho’s forte is negative tactics but, without a goalscorer, a victory against any in-form side will be difficult. Hopes of Champions League football next season may begin to fade if Spurs’ fortunes continue to slide. They will be wary of potentially falling 12 points behind Chelsea. Graham Searles

Pep Guardiola is now talking of securing Champions League football as early as possible and, while Crystal Palace may be no walkover, victory would take Manchester City a minimum of 15 points clear of fifth place. This game is too early for Aymeric Laporte but the defensive lynchpin’s return is imminent to further brighten the mood at the Etihad. Jamie Jackson

Teemu Pukki is available for the first time since New Year’s Day and how Norwich need their top scorer to step up. A defeat against fellow strugglers Bournemouth would leave them a minimum of seven points behind 19th. But can Eddie Howe rouse a performance from his injury-stricken side? Recent results suggest not. Bournemouth have four points from their past 11 matches, while Norwich have seven in the same sequence. It looks a possible warm-up for meetings in the Championship next season. Graham Searles

It was hard to detect much enthusiasm from Evertonians when there was talk of bringing David Moyes back to Goodison Park. Everton ended up appointing Carlo Ancelotti and Moyes has since returned to West Ham, who are a point above the bottom three. West Ham, who are expected to start Darren Randolph in goal, have struggled at home of late. They need to perform against opponents who have won only twice on the road this season. Jacob Steinberg

Aston Villa need to move on quickly from the 6-1 home thrashing by Manchester City and focus on how to get the better of their relegation rivals Brighton. Dean Smith’s side have a respectable 14 points from eight games against teams in the bottom seven so panic must not set in despite residing in the danger zone. A huge boost is Pepe Reina’s arrival between the sticks. His 285 appearances in the Premier League for Liverpool will provide guidance for the second-worst defence in the league – one goal shy of conceding two goals per game. Brighton will hope Reina’s advancing years render him a spent force at 37. Brighton would be well-advised to try to test him severely. Graham Searles

After surging clear of the relegation battle, Southampton can afford to start looking up rather than down – and victory would put them level with Wolves and in the hunt for Europe. Ralph Hasenhüttl has no new injury concerns, while Diogo Jota is not quite ready to return for the visitors. Wolves could use extra firepower: they have scored twice in their five games since beating Manchester City, with Raúl Jiménez goalless since grabbing the equaliser in that memorable win. Niall McVeigh

A potential preview of the Carabao Cup final. Manchester City are rolling once more after dismantling Manchester United in 45 minutes in midweek. Aston Villa are struggling with injuries and will need to be just as disciplined as they were against Leicester to gain anything positive. Kevin De Bruyne’s revelation that it only took 15 minutes to plan for their Carabao Cup win is ominous. Imagine if they discuessed tactics for Villa a little longer. Graham Searles

If Watford’s resurgence continues with a victory against Bournemouth they can climb out of the relegation zone, while pushing their opponents further into the mire, if Aston Villa lose against Manchester City. Nigel Pearson’s side were brilliant over the festive period earning 10 points from 12. Eddie Howe’s side are trending in the opposite direction with their huge injury list taking its toll. Bournemouth gained one point in the same set of four matches. Pearson will surely be hoping his side have the confidence to compound any January blues at the Vitality Stadium and continue building toward a comfortable finish come the Spring. Graham Searles

Sky Sports would have you believe this is an identical scenario to the one in late April 2014 when José Mourinho took his Chelsea side to Anfield, Steven Gerrard slipped, Demba Ba scored and Liverpool were beaten 2-0 and thus blew their chances of ending their long wait for a Premier League title. This time the game is not at Anfield, Liverpool have the small matter of a 13-point lead and 18 games still to play but, well, there’s the narrative and Mourinho will not be shy of running with it. Despite his depleted Tottenham squad the Portuguese will indeed be desperate to inflict a first defeat of the season on Jürgen Klopp’s seemingly unstoppable side, as will his players who – lest we forget – lost a Champions League final to Liverpool fewer than eight months ago and were only beaten in the reverse fixture at Anfield in October by a controversial late penalty. Paul Chronnell

Arsenal have begun winning games again and will hope to continue that trend against a Crystal Palace side hampered by significant injury problems and Luka Milivojevic missing out through suspension. Roy Hodgson is unlikely to be afraid considering the fragility of Arsenal’s confidence and, more pertinently, their defence. Palace are a point ahead of Mikel Arteta’s side and will want to remain that way. Wilfried Zaha being linked to a move away could upset the applecart and provide an opportunity for Arsenal to sneak another scratchy win. Graham Searles

Chelsea could do without a visit from Burnley after their recent problems at home. Burnley have only lost one of their last four games at Stamford Bridge and have the capacity to cause problems for any team. Chelsea, who will be without Christian Pulisic for a fortnight because of an adductor injury, need to sharpen up against opponents lying four points above the bottom three. Jacob Steinberg

Everton’s revival has slowed after a narrow defeat to Manchester City on New Year’s Day and an infuriating FA Cup defeat to Liverpool’s kids but they have a chance to kick things back into gear against Brighton. Alireza Jahanbakhsh will be pushing to start for Graham Potter’s side after finally finding form but Aaron Mooy may miss out with a knock. Brighton will hope the negative atmosphere at Goodison Park – highlighted by a small group of angry fans attempting to address players at Finch Farm on Tuesday – gives them an advantage. Graham Searles

Manchester United’s season-long groundhog day of struggle has entered the period where a rebound from a loss – Tuesday’s near-surrender to Manchester City – with a win is again required. Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s side beat Norwich 3-1 in October’s reverse fixture yet should they lose – as they might – to the bottom team expect another inquiry into where United are heading. Jamie Jackson

Leicester destroyed Southampton 9-0 earlier in the season but Ralph Hasenhüttl’s side have improved considerably since then. They now sit 12th after residing in the relegation zone with Danny Ings, in particular, catching the eye. His nine goals in Southampton’s last 10 matches have been crucial to their revival. Leicester are unlikely to be fazed but Brendan Roders will need to make sure his side avoid any complacency. Anything other than victory will likely allow Manchester City to regain second place. Graham Searles

Wolves and Newcastle are both attempting to end losing runs – Nuno Espírito Santo’s side may have one successive defeat fewer but if they do stack a third it will be their poorest set of results in the Premier League since November 2018. Diogo Jota’s presence in attack was missed against Watford and Newcastle will hope his absence continues. Steve Bruce will need to plan for Adama Traoré as Wolves will look to the winger’s lightning pace and unstoppable force to create chances for Raúl Jimenéz. Miguel Almirón has begun to have more influence for Newcastle and has great potential to cause problems. Graham Searles

Mikel Arteta takes charge of Arsenal at home for the first time and will be keen to start rejuvenating the Emirates atmosphere. That may depend on which version of Chelsea turn up – the swashbuckling side who outclassed Tottenham, or the team who have lost at home to Southampton, Bournemouth and West Ham in recent weeks. Arsenal, who could start the game as low as 13th in the table, will hope it is the latter. Niall McVeigh

Liverpool’s thumping win at Leicester extinguished any fears that their mid-season trip to Qatar might disrupt their march towards the title, while Wolves’ comeback win over 10-man Manchester City leaves Jürgen Klopp’s side 14 points clear of the defending champions. The gap to the chasing pack might be growing, but Klopp will ensure his team keep their focus; after an FA Cup third-round derby next week, Liverpool face Spurs, United and Wolves again in the league. Niall McVeigh

Sheffield United have not lost an away game since last January, but that extraordinary run will be severely tested this week. Chris Wilder’s side head to Anfield on Thursday, after taking on a City side still licking their wounds after the dramatic 3-2 defeat to Wolves. Ederson is suspended after his red card, meaning substitute Claudio Bravo will continue in goal. These two teams have not met since 2008, when a rogue balloon helped the Blades to an FA Cup fourth-round win. Niall McVeigh

Manchester United have won two of nine away league games this season – and one of those came at Manchester City. The short trip to Burnley offers a chance for United to get over their travel sickness; they have lost only once at Turf Moor in 13 visits, a run that dates back to 1968. Paul Pogba looks set to start for the first time since September owing to Scott McTominay injuring his knee against Newcastle. Niall McVeigh

Watford are finally off the bottom with a win and draw in their last two games and Nigel Pearson will see this as a chance to begin roping in Villa, third-bottom and five points ahead. Dean Smith’s side are also showing a hint of long overdue form after their defeat of Norwich on Boxing Day, only their second win in 10 attempts. Pearson must decide whether to stick with Troy Deeney up front; the Watford captain’s fitness must be managed but he scored late winners against Villa twice in 2015-16 – the last season these teams were in the same division. Mark Tallentire

José Mourinho’s hand has been forced with regard to squad rotation, with Moussa Sissoko, Harry Winks and Son Heung-min suspended. Giovani Lo Celso is likely to make his first start under Mourinho, while Dele Alli is a doubt with cramp. Mourinho will be happy with the comeback against Brighton but will want his side to take control from the off against Norwich, who are bottom and winless in their past six games. Three points for Spurs will send them into fourth place, with Chelsea not playing until Sunday. Graham Searles

West Ham are a point above the bottom three after their last-minute defeat against Crystal Palace on Boxing Day and calls for Manuel Pellegrini to be sacked may intensify if Leicester triumph at the London Stadium. West Ham could be boosted by the return of Lukasz Fabianski in goal and it may be a good time to face Leicester, who are winless in three matches. Jacob Steinberg

Brighton and Bournemouth are 15th and 16th respectively and have identical records at the halfway stage of the season. But with only two wins between them from their last 16 matches combined, Graham Potter and Eddie Howe know nothing is guaranteed yet in terms of survival. Brighton were thumped 5-0 by the Cherries at home last season – their heaviest home league defeat since December 1973 – while Bournemouth are hoping to record successive away league victories for the first time since October 2018. Ed Aarons

Football royalty is in Toon in the shape of Everton’s Carlo Ancelotti as Newcastle aim to atone for the heavy Boxing Day defeat at Manchester United. The league fixture list imbues the need for a swift improvement with added urgency; after Everton Steve Bruce’s side face Leicester, Wolves, Chelsea and Everton again. Newcastle may have enjoyed a better first half of the campaign than widely expected but there could yet be a few anxious moments in store on Tyneside before May. Louise Taylor

Southampton’s survival prospects looked bleak after they were beaten at home by West Ham but two impressive away wins on the bounce have changed all that and victory over Crystal Palace could move Ralph Hasenhüttl’s side toward the middle of the pack. Top scorer Danny Ings is likely to be recalled, with teenager Michael Obafemi staking a claim to retain his place after a fantastic finish against Chelsea. That win means Southampton have twice as many away points (14) as they have earned at St Mary’s (seven). That statistic will need to change if Southampton are to stay clear of the relegation battle. Niall McVeigh

José Mourinho v Frank Lampard. Master v pupil. It is easy to locate the juiciest subplot of this derby, with Mourinho going up against Lampard, the former Chelsea manager locking horns with his one-time midfield talisman. The head to head has happened before, with Mourinho’s Manchester United losing to Lampard’s Derby on penalties in last season’s Carabao Cup. More importantly, Mourinho’s resurgent Tottenham know victory would take them into fourth place at the expense of Chelsea, who have lost four of their previous five games. David Hytner

It is hard to see Watford turning things around until Nigel Pearson has had a chance to refresh the side in January and, as such, hard to see them stopping Manchester United. Watford have conceded from open play after the 80th minute in each of their last four defeats, scored nine goals in 17 matches and are the only side not to win at home this season. Their last home win was April. Their misery is relentless and United will be eager to profit as they try to gain ground in the race for the top four. Graham Searles

Mikel Arteta will get a good look at what he is dealing with when he watches Arsenal play his former team. That said Arteta had an excellent view when Manchester City pushed them aside so effortlessly it would have made Roger Federer jealous last week. Duncan Ferguson is again in charge of Everton and the fight he has instilled will likely cause Arsenal problems. A defensive crisis is always looming at the Emirates and with no fit left-backs and Sokratis Papastathopoulos suspended another defeat is on the cards. Graham Searles

Bournemouth could be without 12 players against Burnley but they were similarly undermanned against Chelsea and snatched a memorable victory. Adversity may be bringing Eddie Howe’s side together but Sean Dyche, who succeeded Howe as manager at Turf Moor in October 2012, is certain to want to capitalise with a win that could bump Burnley up into the top half. Graham Searles

Brendan Rodgers may be a prospective candidate to manage Manchester City in the future so a win for his impressive Leicester over the champions would offer a personal fillip beyond the three points needed to maintain pressure on the leaders, Liverpool. As ever, Pep Guardiola’s side should have something significant to say about that. Jamie Jackson

How many people remember back in 2001 Steve Bruce was briefly Crystal Palace’s manager? He resigned swiftly in order to take over at Birmingham but his arrival in the midlands was delayed when the Palace board took out an injunction to temporarily stop the move. Two decades ago Bruce had a reputation for developing itchy feet but now he is determined to stay put at Newcastle and, with his latest side unbeaten at home since the season’s opening day, looks like doing so. Roy Hodgson’s team flew north without a handful of injured personnel but their hosts are sure to miss the influential, but hamstrung, Allan Saint-Maximin. Louise Taylor

Two exciting managers meet for the first time in the Premier League. Graham Potter and Chris Wilder, who previously plied their trade in the Championship, have been mightily impressive in the top flight. Wilder’s Sheffield United are unbeaten on the road and in high spirits after winning consecutive matches for the first time this season. If they avoid defeat they will match Burnley’s record of nine undefeated for a promoted side away from home. Potter’s Brighton are finding a new attacking identity – Neal Maupay being the key addition of flair and goals – and when it works they have the power to dampen United’s spectacular start. Graham Searles

Norwich need to find the performance that stopped Leicester’s winning run last time out in order to challenge Wolves and not slip further from safety. Nuno Espírito Santo’s side will be hurting after losing to Tottenham late. The pain of that fine unbeaten run ending is likely to inspire Jota, Adama Traoré and Raúl Jiménez to wreak havoc on a Norwich defence who average a touch over two goals conceded per game. Add that to Teemu Pukki playing with an injured toe and Norwich could be in a heap of trouble. Graham Searles

Southampton can swap places in the relegation zone with victory against Aston Villa as they sit level on points but with an inferior goal difference. Villa have lost their last three but making the Carabao Cup semi-finals in emphatic fashion may have restored confidence. Wesley scoring for the first time since 6 October was a particular highlight for Dean Smith. A little lift may be all that is required to beat Southampton, who have slumped to two straight defeats. Tyrone Mings missing out again will be a relief for Danny Ings – Southampton’s only goal threat. An early pointer to where these clubs will be next season. Graham Searles

Crystal Palace’s season was summed up nicely by their goalless draw with Watford in midweek. A third successive clean sheet but no end product of their own. Roy Hodgson’s side have the second-worst scoring record in the league and Brighton will look to take full advantage in the M23 derby. Palace are without four defenders and will need a fill-in at left back too. A win for Graham Potter’s side will draw them level with Palace in the table. Graham Searles

Manchester United are aiming to win three consecutive league matches for the first time since mid-January while Duncan Ferguson hopes to claim a second win in a row as Everton caretaker manager. This is United’s last league outing before Wednesday’s one-year anniversary of Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s temporary appointment so there is extra incentive to claim victory. Jamie Jackson

Freddie Ljungberg oversees his fifth game as Arsenal’s interim head coach and the scalp of Manchester City would present a compelling argument for him to be offered the role on a longer basis. He has a number of injury concerns though, with Granit Xhaka and Kieran Tierney among those missing out, and must hope Nicolas Pépé is fit to start after what may have been a breakthrough performance in Monday’s win at West Ham. City, bruised by their defeat in the Manchester derby, are vulnerable but Ljungberg may need Arsenal to hit a level they have barely reached this season. Nick Ames

Wolves and Tottenham omitted key players from their European assignments in midweek in order to preserve them for this clash, which is crucial to their chances of finishing in the European places again this season. With Diogo Jota having scored five goals in his last two matches and Raul Jiménez and Adama Traoré fresh after a week off, Wolves have the firepower to expose the defensive frailties that José Mourinho has yet to resolve. Paul Doyle

Sheffield United are the front-running promoted side this season and will be confident they can build another unbeaten run against an Aston Villa side teetering just above the relegation zone. They have Brighton and Watford up next. If Dean Smith’s side do lose again and Southampton draw or win then they will sink into the bottom three. Sticking with an almost unchanged side after promotion seems to have worked for Chris Wilder while Villa, who signed 10 players in the summer, have struggled. Lys Mousset – the critical addition in attack to Wilder’s side – will relish Tyrone Mings missing out. Graham Searles

Burnley are below Newcastle in the table after three consecutive defeats and although allowances perhaps ought to be made for having to play Manchester City and Tottenham in that sequence, the aggregate score of 11-1 must irk a side who used to pride themselves on a miserly defence, as must the haunting memory of Son Heung-min’s wonder goal last weekend. Sean Dyche will be aiming to put things right against Newcastle, while aware Steve Bruce’s impressive turnaround on Tyneside has produced only one defeat in the past seven games. Paul Wilson

“The plan is to make it the best time of our life,” said Jürgen Klopp when outlining his aims for Liverpool over the next five years of his new contract. The plan already appears well under way. The European champions booked their place in the knockout stage of the Champions League in midweek and host bottom club Watford seeking a 25th win from their last 26 Premier League games. Nigel Pearson, Watford’s 13th manager this decade, may have wished for an easier start in charge of the visitors. Andy Hunter

Manuel Pellegrini is clinging on to his job at West Ham but defeat here, and a potential tumble into the bottom three, would surely signal the end. The manager has to get his forward line firing again, and could recall Sébastien Haller and Andriy Yarmolenko. Pellegrini could also use a performance from Felipe Anderson like the one that earned all three points at St Mary’s last December. Southampton’s own mercurial playmaker, Sofiane Boufal, is likely to be restricted to a cameo off the bench again, as he manages an ongoing toe injury. Niall McVeigh

Bournemouth are a point above the bottom three before their trip to Stamford Bridge. Eddie Howe’s side have lost their last five games and will be without Nathan Aké and Callum Wilson against Chelsea, who reached the last 16 of the Champions League this week. If there is a positive for Bournemouth, though, it is that Chelsea have lost three of their last four league games. Jacob Steinberg

As Leicester chase Liverpool and records, they have shown a relentlessness that makes one fear for Norwich, owners of the second-leakiest defence in the Premier League. Brendan Rodgers’ side are aiming for a ninth straight win – that would equal the club’s best run across all divisions – and Jamie Vardy is hoping to score in a ninth consecutive game, which would edge him close to the milestone of 100 top-flight goals. He goes into this game on 96 and counting. Paul Doyle

Southampton arrive on Tyneside bolstered by the collection of seven points in their past three games but Newcastle are buoyed by their haul of four from two tricky looking fixtures against Manchester City and Sheffield United. By making the most of sometimes startlingly low possession, Steve Bruce is not only beginning to win a few initially flinty hearts and minds at St James’ Park but seems to be bringing the best out of Jonjo Shelvey as he attempts to make the 3-4-3 template he inherited from Rafael Benítez a little more attacking while retaining its defensive meanness. Louise Taylor

Norwich came up as champions by five points from Sheffield United last season and this fixture finished as a 2-2 draw with Billy Sharp twice equalising for the Blades, who have adjusted to life in the top flight rather better than their peers. “Sheffield United have been settled at the back and have been able to play with almost the same starting lineup each week,” said Daniel Farke, whose side’s revival came to an abrupt stop at Southampton in midweek to leave them rooted in the bottom three. “We now have a home game and if we carry on in the way we finished that game then we have every chance of a win. It is not like Southampton played us out of the park, we were just bullied [at set pieces].” United’s Lys Mousset, who was dropped to the bench for the surprising home defeat by Newcastle on Thursday, is likely to be recalled. “It’ll be tough,” said the manager, Chris Wilder. “They were the outstanding team in the Championship last season. I was delighted to get as close as we did to them.” Mark Tallentire

After the highs of Thursday’s excellent and merited win at the Emirates Brighton return home and face a Wolves side who took their unbeaten league run to 10 matches with Wednesday’s 2-0 defeat of West Ham and are starting to look like the team who so impressed everybody last season. Nuno Espírito Santo’s side have now played 28 games in all competitions though, which is 11 more than Brighton, and their manager gave them a rare day off on Thursday – he will be hoping the extra day’s rest pays dividends for his players on Sunday as they aim to consolidate fifth place in the table. Paul Chronnell

Leicester have had seven wins in a row and Brendan Rodgers is the recipient of an extended and improved contract until 2025 after never quite ruling himself out of the vacant Arsenal job until Friday. Demarai Gray comes back into contention for Sunday’s trip to Villa after missing the last two matches with flu and the manager hopes Ben Chilwell will make it after missing the midweek win over Watford with a hip injury. Villa are a point above the relegation zone after their midweek defeat at Chelsea but they have Anwar El Ghazi in contention after a knee injury. “They are on a fantastic run of form but there aren’t many teams who will come away from Villa Park and think they’ve had an easy game,” Dean Smith said. Mark Tallentire

Arsenal are the only team in the league not to have won a match in their last six and are winless since 6 October. Put simply this is relegation form. The club must find a permanent replacement for Unai Emery – crucially not Freddie Ljungberg – quickly to turn things around. West Ham reverted to type after beating Chelsea but the spiralling atomic nightmare that is Arsenal should provide a chance for Manuel Pellegrini to rebound once again. Michail Antonio’s fitness, or lack thereof, could be crucial to their chances. Graham Searles

It is still early doors but Liverpool look head and shoulders above the rest in the Premier League. They are unbeaten in 32 games – a club record – and can win with explosive attacking power or with defensive grit and determination. Bournemouth’s chances of even a point look grim considering their best player this season – Harry Wilson – is unavailable to face his parent club. Liverpool have won their last four meetings by an aggregate score of 14-0. Graham Searles

Tottenham were strangely passive in defeat at Manchester United on Wednesday – the first bump in the road for José Mourinho. It felt as though the players were preoccupied by what United might do, rather than how they might impose themselves. Had Mourinho’s pre-match instructions been too reactive? Spurs will need greater positivity against a Burnley team who have lost five out of seven but always make life difficult. David Hytner

There will be a rare bond of unity between the Everton crowd and technical area on Saturday when Duncan Ferguson takes temporary charge against Chelsea following the dismissal of Marco Silva. For all the goodwill that will come Ferguson’s way, his promotion is not a cause for celebration but a symbol of Everton’s malfunction under the erratic ownership of Farhad Moshiri. A club that has spent over £450m on players since Moshiri’s arrival finds itself in the bottom three and led by a sixth different coach in under four years. Chelsea will relish the opportunity. Andy Hunter

Manchester City need a victory to ensure Liverpool’s lead is kept to a minimum of 11 points. For Manchester United it is about winning a consecutive league game for the first time since March. Both, of course, want the three points because this is the 179th Manchester derby. Jamie Jackson

Crystal Palace have banked six points without conceding after a brutal run of defeats against Liverpool, Chelsea and Manchester City. Roy Hodgson will be confident his side can maintain their run against managerless Watford who are back in a rut. Seven points from safety could quickly snowball into being completely cut adrift if they do not hire the right man soon. Wilfried Zaha finding form escalates the danger of a fourth consecutive defeat. Graham Searles

Manchester United are stuttering again and while the Europa League defeat at Astana on Thursday was with a youthful side, Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s team have to regain momentum. They will hope to do so against a Villa side with the worst away record in the division and who have won at Old Trafford once in 35 years. Jamie Jackson

It would not be surprising if the only reason Marco Silva is still Everton’s manager is because no one else would want to walk into the hellish run of fixtures on which he is about to embark. Winning at Leicester would certainly silence Silva’s critics for a while but it is hard to see how such a result could be achieved, with Leicester’s fluency, solidity and sharpness offering an almost perfect contrast to Everton. A sixth consecutive victoryfor Brendan Rodgers’ team is the safest bet, particularly in light of a mounting injury list for the visitors. Paul Doyle

Nuno Espírito Santo and Chris Wilder are managers in demand and their teams are likely to continue showing why when they meet at Molineux with both sides just outside the top four. Wolves have been juggling European and domestic duties well, so may not suffer any after-effects from Thursday’s draw on a heavy pitch in Portugal. Sheffield United, unbeaten away this season, will give them a stringent test anyway, especially with John Egan and Dean Henderson back. Paul Doyle

Everything about this match was chucked up in the air by events at London Colney on Friday morning. What had been cast as a possible upset now looks like a chance for Arsenal to restore confidence, with interim coach Freddie Ljungberg expected to go back to basics. Norwich meanwhile look finally to be over their injury crisis and will have restored confidence after an away win at Goodison, though Alex Tettey misses out in midfield for family reasons. Paul MacInnes

José Mourinho’s two games in charge of Tottenham have been manic but fans will breathe a sigh of relief they are safely through to the knockout stages of the Champions League. Bournemouth will hope Mourinho’s defence continues to struggle as they attempt to end a disappointing losing streak since beating Manchester United. Eddie Howe has to do without Josh King, with Ryan Fraser also a doubt, and the scales feel tipped in Mourinho’s favour. Graham Searles

West Ham are three points above the teams in the bottom three before visiting Stamford Bridge and are unlikely to find Frank Lampard in a charitable mood. The Chelsea manager will want his team to show no mercy against his former side and another defeat could force West Ham to sack Manuel Pellegrini. Lampard, who played for Pellegrini at Manchester City, is without Tammy Abraham after the forward injured his hip against Valencia. Jacob Steinberg

Graham Potter could not have a more daunting assignment after signing a six-year contract with Brighton than a visit to the Premier League leaders. Liverpool are unbeaten in 46 league games at Anfield, winning 36, and will equal the club record of 31 league games without defeat set by Kenny Dalglish’s team in 1987-88 should they maintain their imperious form. Fabinho’s absence through injury is a blow for Jürgen Klopp but he is not short of alternatives in central midfield. Andy Hunter

Joelinton, Miguel Almirón and Allan Saint-Maximin cost a collective £77m but have scored only one goal between them. Nevertheless Steve Bruce will keep faith with the front three as Newcastle look to reprise last season’s win at St James’ Park. “I would love them to score a goal but the threat they’ve caused at the top end of the pitch and what they contribute towards the team is the thing I look at,” Bruce said. “At times they’ve been terrific and, when they do start scoring, we’ll be fine.” City face a testing run as they aim to keep in touch with Liverpool and cannot afford to drop points. Louise Taylor

Burnley are showing much more consistency after an uneven startand have climbed to seventh, sitting proudly above Arsenal, Manchester United and Spurs with not even a hint of dissatisfaction with the manager. Crystal Palace have lost their past three games since drawing with Arsenal at the Emirates but have a couple of away wins under their belt , one against Manchester United in August. Paul Wilson

The bottom sides meet in Saturday’s late kick-off, with the Premier League’s leakiest defence welcoming its least potent attack. Both sides began the season with top-half aspirations but face a battle to avoid being cut adrift over the festive period. Watford’s Quique Sánchez Flores faces a defensive injury crisis, with Craig Dawson and Christian Kabasele ruled out this week. Southampton will hope Danny Ings can take advantage and score for a third straight game. Niall McVeigh

Chris Wilder does not want Manchester United’s visit to turn into the “Harry Maguire Show” as the club’s one-time centre-back returns to his first club. From Bramall Lane’s academy Maguire progressed to Hull, Leicester and England, ultimately becoming the world’s most expensive defender when he arrived at Old Trafford in the summer. Sheffield United’s manager said: “I usually say it’s just the next game but perhaps this one does have a little more to it. It’s Manchester United and one of our former players will be playing for them. But I don’t want it to be ‘the Harry Maguire Show’. I want it to be the Sheffield United Show. I want us to show how good we are.” Dean Henderson, the home goalkeeper on loan from Manchester United cannot play so Simon Moore will get a rare outing. “It’s a great opportunity for Simon,” said Wilder. “I’m sure he won’t let us down.” Louise Taylor

Despite the summer of turbulence on Tyneside, Newcastle find themselves in a respectable 13th place in the table and could potentially win their third game in a row on Steve Bruce’s first return to Villa Park since his dismissal last October. Villa on the other hand, have lost their last three, albeit two of those were to Manchester City and Liverpool. Jack Grealish should be a welcome return to Dean Smith’s side after a calf injury. Will Dickson

Brighton will be without their captain, Lewis Dunk, for the match against Leicester. The centre-back serves a one-match ban after receiving five yellow cards. Adam Webster, who should be fit after an ankle injury, could replace Dunk in the side and will be tasked with containing Jamie Vardy. Brighton’s manager, Graham Potter, described the Leicester striker as ‘a top centre-forward, who does not need too many chances to score’ but his side have won their last three home games and so should be full of confidence. His counterpart at Leicester, Brendan Rodgers, believes the recent international break will not interupt the form of his side – they have won five out of six in all competitions. “I think it is important when players come back from international duty to press the reset button again,” he said. Rich Flower

Bournemouth, on the slide after only one win in their past six matches, host one of the division’s form sides in Wolves, who have beaten only once in their past 11 games. Bournemouth will be without Josh King, who sustained a hamstring injury on international duty with Norway, so Dominic Solanke is likely to partner Callum Wilson in attack. Wolves will give Adama Traoré a late fitness test after the forward dropped out of the Spain squad last week with a hamstring problem. Rich Flower

Marco Silva believes Everton have “reacted strongly” to recent adversity, notably André Gomes’s horrific injury against Tottenham and the VAR debacle at Brighton, and three wins in their last five games in all competitions does suggest an upturn. They must exploit the lack of confidence in the league’s bottom club and give the manager’s claim greater substance. Silva’s side face a testing run of fixtures against Leicester, Liverpool, Chelsea and Manchester United following the visit of Norwich, who are without a win in seven matches since defeating Manchester City in September. Andy Hunter

José Mourinho would love to begin his reign at Tottenham by heightening the pressure on Manuel Pellegrini. Mauricio Pochettino’s replacement has rarely seen eye-to-eye with his West Ham counterpart, whose side have slipped towards the bottom three during a run of seven games without a win in all competitions. Yet this is a hard one to call. West Ham raise their level in this fixture and Tottenham have not won away in the league since January, which is partly why they felt compelled to replace Pochettino with Mourinho this week. Jacob Steinberg

Unai Emery has his board’s public backing but that will surely wear exceedingly thin if Arsenal slip up against Southampton or, next weekend, Norwich.
