Gerard Deulofeu and Roberto Pereyra may miss out to rehabilitate respective ankle and hip problems. Graham Searles

Eddie Howe takes charge of his 500th game as Bournemouth manager against Fulham and his side will be hopeful they can mark the occasion by dispatching relegated Fulham. Scott Parker would be delighted with a repeat of the showing that beat Everton last time out to continue making progress before life in the Championship begins. Fulham’s record of only two points from 17 away games is rather ominous, though. Graham Searles

The game when the title slipped from Liverpool’s grasp in 2014 should hold no concerns at Anfield. There are two different managers in the dugouts and probably 20 different players in the starting lineups (Mohamed Salah is one of only two survivors and was in the Chelsea ranks that day). More relevant is Liverpool’s failure to beat Chelsea in the last eight encounters at Anfield and their opponents’ problems on the road, with Maurizio Sarri’s side losing four of their last six away league games. A Liverpool win, however, loads the pressure on Manchester City before a daunting sequence. Andy Hunter

On paper, this is no contest. Crystal Palace have already lost eight home games this season, and scored only 13 times in 16 matches, and are now without both first-choice centre-halves. Manchester City will spy it as an opportunity. Yet Roy Hodgson’s side were one of two clubs to stop City scoring in the league last season, missing a last minute penalty which might have won this fixture, and remain the only team to claim points from the Etihad Stadium this term. Pep Guardiola will be wary. Dominic Fifield

Arsenal were accused of lacking the “cojones” to defend a lead at Vicarage Road by Troy Deeney after Watford turned a 1-0 deficit into a 2-1 win. Arsenal’s away form is still awful but the addition of Lucas Torreira, who looked fresh as a daisy against Napoli, and Matteó Guendouzi to midfield should add the bite that Deeney found lacking. Javi Gracia will be unconcerned though as his side are much improved since last season. The FA Cup final will be on his mind but what better way to warm up than leading from the front this time and beating Arsenal again. Graham Searles

Two teams that have been slowly falling down the table meet at the Amex Stadium. Bournemouth have been awful recently and could struggle once more considering their horrendous luck with injuries. Chris Hughton will have to rebound from exiting the FA Cup with a whimper against Manchester City, especially since the prospect of relegation could become a lot more distinct if they fail two win and Cardiff earn three points. Brighton would be just two above the drop zone. Jack Murphy

Mauricio Pochettino has been enraged this season by damaging lapses in games that he felt his Spurs team should have won – chiefly, the defeats at Watford, Burnley and Southampton. His message to his players before the visit of Huddersfield is simple. Forget the Champions League return at Manchester City on Wednesday and make sure there is there is no complacency against a team that stands to go down as one of the worst in Premier League history. David Hytner

A fourth successive win for Everton would keep up their late push for seventh place and a possible Europa League spot while for already relegated Fulham any positive result would be welcome after nine consecutive defeats. Scott Parker, the caretaker in charge for the last five of them, is also looking to use the run-in as a testing ground for next season’s intended promotion push. “We’ve had a really good week, put in some good work, and I feel confident the players have prepared right for a very good side,” he said. Marco Silva, meanwhile, will have to decide which of his centre-backs to start alongside Kurt Zouma after Phil Jagielka, the late stand-in for the ill Michael Keane in last Sunday’s win over Arsenal, bagged the only goal to make it three wins in a row against London clubs. Mark Tallentire

Burnley have been looking at this game as a potential lifesaver for some weeks, though winning their past two games, against Wolves and Bournemouth, has given themselves some breathing space. It remains an important date in Neil Warnock’s diary, the first of four games in Cardiff’s run-in against opponents from the bottom half of the table. Paul Wilson

Ole Gunnar Solskjær continues to target 15 points from the last six games for a Champions League berth so his side really dare not lose this one. West Ham are 14 points above the drop zone so are all but mathematically safe but would still relish a win at Old Trafford. Jamie Jackson

Ralph Hasenhüttl has no new injury worries as his side enter the home straight, although Mario Lemina is still not fit. With six winnable games to go and a five-point cushion over Cardiff, the Austrian’s primary objective of avoiding relegation is within reach. Wolves may be more obliging opponents than expected – remarkably, they have earned more points per game against the top six than the bottom six. The Wembley collapse against Watford may have sharpened their focus though and Wolves have not lost to Southampton since a 6-0 thrashing in 2007. Niall McVeigh

Arsenal are gaining momentum in pursuit of Champions League qualification but Goodison Park presents a trickier assignment than it has done for most of the season, as Chelsea discovered last month. Everton’s overall form has improved significantly since an enforced 17-day break in February. Four clean sheets in their last five matches will encourage a defence that will be tested by the in-form Arsenal duo of Alexandre Lacazette and Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang. Unai Emery’s side are unbeaten in six league games, winning five, and victory on Merseyside would be a significant step towards a top four finish. Andy Hunter

Maurizio Sarri insisted Monday’s visit of West Ham to Stamford Bridge could prove a treacherous fixture given his opponents’ wildly unpredictable form. “They are a really very dangerous team,” said Sarri, “because, this season, they were not able to have consistency but are still a team with high quality.” That will ensure an almost cup-tie feel to this derby as the hosts juggle their selection and seek to make in-roads into the top four, while the visitors’ former Chelsea youth-team player, Declan Rice, showcases what they might have had. Dominic Fifield

Huddersfield are relegated and now are playing for their futures, according to Christopher Schindler. A decent impetus, all things considered. That alone is unlikely to be enough to give the home fans something to cheer against Leicester, sadly. Brendan Rodgers has improved Leicester dramatically and Youri Tielemans will have Huddersfield chasing shadows if previous performances are anything to go by. A win by two goals or more will lift Leicester to seventh. Graham Searles

Will Andros Townsend start for Crystal Palace against his old club? Might Rafael Benítez’s long standing desire to bring Townsend back to Tyneside form part of on-going discussions with Mike Ashley about extending a managerial contract which expires next month? If Newcastle win they would be effectively safe and the owner will want to know whether Benitez is staying or going. Ideally, he hopes to remain but requires quite a few assurances first. Should Miguel Almirón - still seeking his first Newcastle goal - and friends do their stuff on the pitch, an intense behind the scenes drama will start unfolding. Louise Taylor

Dwight McNeil blasted Wolves away in Burnley’s last match and the teenager will be raring to continue his impressive run of form against Bournemouth. Eddie Howe’s defence will need to keep tabs on him. If McNeil is allowed to inspire another victory then three points will give Burnley an excellent chance of avoiding relegation after an inconsistent campaign. Bournemouth have lost only four games at home this season though. Adam Smith is in contention after recovering from a hamstring injury in March. Graham Searles

All eyes will be on Callum Hudson-Odoi in the wake of the teenager make his England debut last week. Will Maurizio Sarri finally give the winger his first Premier League start? Whether that happens or not, Chelsea need to address their awful form on the road – they have lost four of five Premier League away matches in 2019. That statistic should encourage Cardiff, whose home record – they beat West Ham 2-0 last time out – means they are in with a fighting chance of survival with eight games left. Stuart James

Unai Emery felt the need to schedule a friendly on Tuesday against Al-Nasr at the end of Arsenal’s training break to Dubai in order to keep his players ticking over. They had not played, after all, since the Europa League win over Rennes on 14 March. He is determined to see his players hit the ground running against an in-form Newcastle. Arsenal’s margin for error in the top four battle is minimal. David Hytner

Every game is crucial in a tight title race but this fixture carries extra weight for the league leaders. On paper, Tottenham are the toughest opponent remaining for Jürgen Klopp’s team and a 15 point advantage over a side that finished last season two points ahead is further evidence of the hosts’ outstanding progress. Liverpool have lost only one of the last dozen games with Mauricio Pochettino’s team and one of the last 24 league meetings at Anfield. Extending that run would be hugely significant for a squad that welcomes back Joe Gomez after almost four months out with a fractured leg. Andy Hunter

Saturday at 3pm – what better time for Ole Gunnar Solskjær to take on his first game as Manchester United’s permanent manager and it is a sobering thought that had things been different at the end of the Alex Ferguson era, David Moyes would still have four months left on his six-year deal. Solskjær is the third appointment since Moyes was sacked and he will immediately have to correct a dip in form which has seen United lose their past two games. Watford would seem to be timely visitors, preparing as they are for an FA Cup semi-final with Wolves on Sunday week. “We have to know some players have been with their national teams and with three games in a row in a short time, we need to make decisions in selection,” said Javi Gracia, the Watford manager. Mark Tallentire

Regardless of what happens on the pitch, Leicester supporters will be well catered for off it here. The club are marking the birthday of Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha, their former owner who passed away in October, by laying on free beer, water and cupcakes for their fans. They should be fairly confident of picking up three points, too, given that Leicester have won three of their last four matches. Junior Stanislas, Adam Smith and Dan Gosling could all make a return for Bournemouth, whose away form has been desperately poor this season. Stuart James

Fulham have improved in recent weeks, and pushed Liverpool all the way in their last game, but it is hard to escape the feeling they will take a hammering in this one. Manchester City arrive in west London fully intent on returning to top spot and with a host of first-team players expected to return from injury, including Kevin De Bruyne and Fernandinho. Pep Guardiola’s side will dominate and, barring a miracle, win comfortably. Sachin Nakrani

Huddersfield’s emphatic 3-0 win at Selhurst Park on the opening day of last season has proved to be one of the highlights of their stint back in the top flight. But, even if Crystal Palace’s shoddy home form offers hope the agony can be prolonged for another week, their first return to south London could be the day the descent back into the Championship is confirmed. At least they will return to the second tier far stronger off the pitch, and with the likes of Karlan Grant offering promise for the future. Dominic Fifield

Brighton and Southampton still have work to do to secure their Premier League status and both sides will be looking at this one as a chance to take a major step towards safety. Saints won August’s League Cup tie at the Amex with a late goal from Charlie Austin but all three of the previous Premier League meetings have finished in draws. Albion are three points better off with a game in hand while Southampton’s James Ward-Prowse is full of confidence after his England recall. “This is a big game for us, as they are all,” said the Brighton manager, Chris Hughton. “It’s a game against a team that are in the same area of the league as we are and that does add another importance to the game.” Mark Tallentire

Burnley have lost four games in a row to leave them on the brink of moving into the relegation zone, and it might be hard to arrest that slide against a carefree Wolves side in the top half of the table and battling it out with fellow FA Cup semi-finalists Watford for seventh place. Sean Dyche needs points quickly, though perhaps the next home game against Cardiff will have the greatest bearing on who survives. Paul Wilson

This contest between two of the contenders hoping to finish seventh is likely to be tight. West Ham are two points above ninth-placed Everton and have not lost at home since 22 December. But while West Ham triumphed at Goodison Park in September, Everton will travel to east London full of confidence after an impressive win over Chelsea two weeks ago. There is little to choose between them. Jacob Steinberg

Liverpool are looking for a return to the top with a ninth successive Premier League win against a promoted side. Jürgen Klopp will be confident after the Champions League victory over Bayern Munich. He may have one eye on the quarter-final against Porto but Liverpool need to focus as they have not been perfect of late domestically. Fulham, under the caretaker manager, Scott Parker, may feel their race is run in the top flight, with their following game being against Manchester City. Jess Hayden

Confidence should outweigh fatigue for Chelsea on their return from a 5-0 victory at Dynamo Kyiv as they look to close the gap on the Champions League places with victory at Everton. Chelsea have reacted impressively to defeat in the Carabao Cup final, while the hosts remain as erratic as their goalkeeper Jordan Pickford, who is under pressure following a poor display in the defeat at Newcastle. Everton have lost six of their past nine matches and need to rediscover the fight they showed against Liverpool. Andy Hunter

Burnley are back in the relegation mix after losing their last three games, one of half a dozen teams worried about finishing 18th if it is assumed Huddersfield and Fulham have too much ground to recover. Cardiff’s visit to Turf Moor next month already looks likely to be highly significant, but Burnley would prefer to earn points before that with two home games against Leicester and Wolves. Leicester beat Fulham last week but have yet to win away under Brendan Rodgers. Paul Wilson

Marko Arnautovic is set to start his first game for West Ham since January and will be confident he can find the net against Huddersfield. Jan Siewert said his side’s performance against Bournemouth was unacceptable so will want more against West Ham. But how much more can they give? They are 16 points from safety with 24 remaining to earn. Another shocker like Manuel Pellegrini’s side produced against Cardiff would be a welcome bonus for Siewert. Graham Searles

Newcastle are enjoying life again after three wins from four but their next challenge against Bournemouth is to address their poor away form. Rafael Benítez’s side have won twice away this season. The task is made more difficult by Fabian Schär’s suspension and Jamaal Lascelles missing out through injury. Bournemouth are all-but safe, so can throw caution to the win as they chase a return to the top half of the table. Eddie Howe has injury problems of his own though, with six players absent. Graham Searles

Chelsea have been much improved but a visit from Wolves, a team with an uncanny knack of unsettling elite sides, would represent a banana skin even without the home side’s inconsistencies. “We have improved in the last five matches, winning four and conceding only once, so we are improving,” Maurizio Sarri said. “But we have to be careful. We had a long period of good results in the past and then, suddenly, two weeks of disaster.” Wolves had rallied to defeat and deflate them at Molineux. Chelsea, pursuing the top four, can ill afford a repeat. Dominic Fifield

Unai Emery needs to dig deep into his bag of tricks to find a way of thwarting Manchester United. Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s record since taking charge is phenomenal and especially away from home, proceedings in Paris on Wednesday night being a prime example. Arsenal’s trip to France was the total opposite. Emery’s side were humiliated because of the usual brand of brainless defending. Arsenal will slip four points behind United in fourth if they produce the same. Graham Searles

For the first time since 7 December Liverpool find themselves playing catch-up in the title race having played the same number of games as Manchester City. Manager and players alike have said their approach will not change and they cannot afford to falter against a Burnley team who, since beating Tottenham, have lost their last two games. Anfield strengthens confidence in that regard. Liverpool were outstanding in their previous home match against Watford and Mohamed Salah needs one goal to reach his Premier League half century for the club in record time. Andy Hunter

A second home win in a row would enable Jan Siewert to point to progress at Huddersfield. To avert that, Eddie Howe needs to find a solution to Bournemouth’s away form, as they have not won on their travels since October. Paul Doyle

The first home game of the Brendan Rodgers era at Leicester and, on the face of it, a great opportunity to pick up three points. Fulham have lost eight of their last nine league matches, including five in a row, and, realistically, it is a matter of when, not if, they will be relegated. Jamie Vardy is fit to start, despite requiring stitches in his tongue following the 2-1 defeat at Watford, and has another milestone in his sights – his next goal will be his 100th in Leicester colours. Stuart James

By Neil Warnock’s own admission, Cardiff have endured their worst week of the season. The 2-0 loss at Wolves made it three straight defeats and Sol Bamba ruptured his anterior cruciate ligament in that match. Cardiff need to clear their heads – and fast. Warnock insists this is not a must-win match, but some Cardiff fans my beg to differ with a run of tricky fixtures to come. West Ham still have a chance of finishing seventh, although they have lost four of their last five league games on the road. Stuart James

If Manchester City can defeat Watford they will stretch their lead to four points and apply pressure on Liverpool who play Burnley at noon on Sunday. Do so and another game is chalked off in City’s bid to retain the title for a first time in their history and become the first club since Manchester United in 2009 to claim consecutive crowns. Jamie Jackson

Which Tottenham team will show up at St Mary’s? While others were blowing first-leg leads, Tottenham competed a clinical Champions League victory over Dortmund – but they are winless in their last three league games. Mauricio Pochettino begins his touchline ban and will be without Kieran Trippier, although Dele Alli and Harry Winks could feature. Southampton have shown signs of recovery in beating Fulham and pushing Manchester United at Old Trafford but must contain Harry Kane, who has seven goals in eight Premier League games against them. The hosts will be without their own top scorer, Danny Ings, who is still out with a hamstring problem. Niall McVeigh

Crystal Palace and Brighton are tantalisingly close to securing Premier League survival, which might thrust greater significance on to a collision of bitter rivals. Glenn Murray has scored in one league game since the return fixture at the Amex, won comfortably by Albion’s 10 men, but will seek a 100th league goal for Brighton back on familiar territory. Wilfried Zaha, in contrast, is in his most productive spell of the campaign with five goals in as many matches. “In good form, he is a major headache for any team in the Premier League,” said Roy Hodgson. No one will be more anxious to make his mark. Dominic Fifield

Newcastle are looking to earn a fifth consecutive win at St James’ Park for the first time since 2004. They will have to do so without Sean Longstaff who is out for the season with a knee injury. Everton have steadied the ship and have a good record against teams in the bottom half of the league. Gylfi Sigurdsson’s excellent form could also be a deciding factor. Graham Searles

Scott Parker takes charge of Fulham following the sacking of Claudio Ranieri and, essentially, his task is to ensure the club’s return to the Championship is as bump-free as possible. Nevertheless, there are notable highs for Fulham to aim for before now and relegation, including a first win in 18 attempts against their local rivals. Chelsea have monopolised this particular west London feud and will feel confident of prevailing again, especially after their midweek victory over Tottenham. Willy Caballero started that game and it will be intriguing to see if he retains his place ahead of Kepa Arrizabalaga. Sachin Nakrani

The 96th minute of the last Merseyside derby, when Jordan Pickford gifted Liverpool’s winner to Divock Origi, can be pin-pointed as the moment Everton’s form and confidence plummeted. This, the 200th league meeting between the clubs and the 233rd in total, offers a chance of redemption for Marco Silva’s side, although they have not beaten any team in the top half of the table this season. Liverpool are unbeaten in 16 derbies – a record run that stretches to October 2010 – and will not fear a trip across Stanley Park as they pursue the Premier League title. Andy Hunter

Watford lost their last game 5-0 and won the one before that 5-1, while Leicester are under new management, making this match hard to predict. After Sunday’s game, Leicester will not meet another team now in the top half until late April, giving Brendan Rodgers a chance to improve results before a nasty run-in. Watford will be determined to prove Wednesday’s thrashing at Anfield – a game played while their under-18s were knocking Leicester out of the FA Youth Cup – was an aberration. Simon Burnton

Newcastle can feel that the job is almost done. Rafa Benítez’s side have risen six points above the bottom three after two consecutive victories and safety will be within reach if they win at the London Stadium. But while Newcastle have fond memories of this fixture last season, West Ham have improved under Manuel Pellegrini and were unfortunate to lose at Manchester City on Wednesday. It should be a tight match. Jacob Steinberg

Losing 2-0 at Newcastle was a shock for Burnley, who had been unbeaten in the league in 2019, but Sean Dyche’s assurance endures. “We’re back to that mentality of we’ll take on anyone,” he said. Crystal Palace’s own revival ended when losing 3-1 at home to Manchester United. Their last visit to Turf Moor, in September 2017, ended in a 1-0 defeat, a fifth scoreless defeat in a row that did for the previous manager Frank de Boer. John Brewin

Arsenal are back in the top-four conversation thanks to their imposing form at the Emirates but one question tracks them into the derby – can they do it on a mild Saturday lunchtime at Wembley? The disparity between their home and away records has been hard to explain but they will travel in the hope of exploiting a sudden wobble from their rivals. In less than a week, Spurs have gone from title contenders to glancing nervously over their shoulders. There’s a word for that, somewhere. David Hytner

Ole Gunnar Solskjær has been near-faultless as interim manager but Manchester United are still a point off fourth and sixth-placed Chelsea can leapfrog them by winning their game in hand. Southampton’s midweek win over Fulham was their only success in six league outings, so United really should take all three points – although the visitors have a good recent record at Old Trafford, losing just one in five visits. Marcus Rashford should be fit to start after the ankle injury that hampered the forward against Liverpool last Sunday. Jamie Jackson

Two promoted teams with vastly different aims meet at Molineux, with Wolves chasing Europe and Cardiff dropping into the bottom three in midweek and facing five of the top seven in their last 10 games. Neil Warnock can take heart from Wolves’ slip at Huddersfield as he squares up to his old adversary and “my wife’s favourite manager”, Nuno Espírito Santo. John Ruddy will start in goal for Wolves, while the return of Victor Camarasa is a boost for Cardiff. Niall McVeigh

Manchester City will regain top spot, even if only momentarily, if they win at Bournemouth. History is emphatically in Pep Guardiola’s favour, given that in seven top-flight meetings City lead 24-3 on aggregate. Callum Wilson and David Brooks, who spent 10 years on the books at City, could feature for the hosts, with Eddie Howe insisting his side are not safe from relegation with 10 games to play. For City, Gabriel Jesus and John Stones are in contention after recovering from injuries. Ben Fisher

At the end of 2018, with Brighton 13th and basking in the afterglow of a 1-0 win over Everton, Chris Hughton warned they still could not “afford to look upwards”. Perhaps he knew something, because Brighton have not won in the league since and hover perilously above the relegation spots. This fixture looks vital to get them going again. Huddersfield are surely going down, although on the back of a rousing late win over Wolves another win could spark a few “they couldn’t ... could they?” mutterings. Nick Ames

After beating Tottenham, Arsenal and Chelsea on the road Ole Gunnar Solskjær can further strengthen his case to be made permanent Manchester United manager by registering the result fans prioritise: a home win against Liverpool. That this would also be in a blow to Liverpool’s bid to claim a first championship in 29 years would further delight the support and be one more high-point of the former forward’s return as caretaker boss. Jamie Jackson

Unai Emery said he will continue to rotate Mesut Özil but it would seem foolish for the midfielder to miss out against Southampton considering how much improved Arsenal were against Bate with him in the side. If Özil does sit out another game then Arsenal’s home form – four wins from their last four – suggests they should still find a way but Southampton have the fear of relegation to motivate them. Ralph Hasenhüttl will take heart from the knowledge Saints are likely to score as Arsenal rarely keep clean sheets. It was Southampton who ended Arsenal’s 22-match unbeaten run earlier in the season, too. Graham Searles

Tottenham can cut the gap to Manchester City and Liverpool, at least until Jürgen Klopp’s side face Manchester United on Sunday, to two points if they beat Burnley. No easy task considering Sean Dyche’s side are back to their best and enjoying a seven-match unbeaten run – their best ever string of games in the Premier League. Harry Kane has returned to training and may feature but they may not need the striker’s prowess in front of goal as Son Heung-min has shone in his absence. The forward has four goals in his last four matches. Graham Searles

Given that Huddersfield are bottom and have collected only one point from their last 13 games, Rafael Benítez will be deeply disappointed should his Newcastle players – fresh from a warm-ish weather training break in southern Spain – stumble here. While Benítez ponders whether to offer his new £21m Paraguay playmaker, Miguel Almirón a full home debut, Jan Siewert craves his first win since succeeding David Wagner as Huddersfield manager. The German says he will “fight to the end” to stay up and really needs to overcome opponents still in real relegation peril themselves. Louise Taylor

Roy Hodgson will become the oldest manager in Premier League history when he takes charge of Crystal Palace against Leicester and he would no doubt love to celebrate with a win. To do so he will have to be wary of the threat posed by Leicester’s January loan signing Youri Tielemans. The Belgian was the best player on the pitch despite being on the losing side against Tottenham. Claude Puel will hope he reproduces the display and in his side’s bid to end their five-game winless run. He should probably start Jamie Vardy too. Graham Searles

Bournemouth will be glad to return to the comforts of the Vitality Stadium after successive defeats without scoring on the road. Stark contrast to the previous two games at home which they won with an aggregate score of 6-0. Callum Wilson and David Brooks are still missing, though. Wolves will arrive in good spirits after making the quarter-finals of the FA Cup but could miss Diogo Jota, who is struggling with a dead leg. Eddie Howe’s side can close the gap on Wolves to three points with a win. Graham Searles

Wolves are bounding after three successive wins and a fourth against Newcastle would be their best run of the season. It could also put them an impressive seven points above eighth place. Miguel Almirón is ready to debut now though and it will be exciting to see how the attacking playmaker fares. The Paraguay international has the potential to add goals to his side that are sorely needed. Only Huddersfield have scored fewer at present. Rafael Benítez will still fancy his chances of snatching a result though such is the calibre of this defence. Graham Searles

Manchester City may be playing catch up again if Liverpool win their game against Bournemouth on Saturday before Chelsea arrive at the Etihad Stadium on Sunday. Maurizio Sarri claims City are the best side in Europe yet the champions first league defeat came in the reverse at Stamford Bridge. Pep Guardiola believes if Chelsea can be beaten they will remain contenders until the end of the season so what might a defeat do for their mentality? Jamie Jackson

Nobody has been more voluble than Mauricio Pochettino about why Tottenham cannot be expected to win the title but they continue to cling onto the leaders’ coat-tails. Three times in three matches they have scored late winners and the impression has been of a team that is determined to find a way, however much the odds and external circumstances (namely, the new stadium build) are stacked against them. Leicester have hit another downturn yet they have shown a capacity to rouse themselves against the big boys this season. David Hytner

Brighton are on a dismal run after winning once in their last 10 matches and face a Burnley side unbeaten in 2019. Sean Dyche seems to have his old warriors back while Chris Hughton will hope his side’s battling FA Cup win can breathe some life back into his side. A close encounter is sure to ensue with neither side wanting to drop points in the fight to stay in the league. Graham Searles

This could be a tale of three strikers. Marko Arnautovic is set to return for West Ham after a foot injury, and still has bridges to rebuild after that dalliance with the Chinese Super League last month. Palace, meanwhile, have Christian Benteke fit and sharp, and his compatriot Michy Batshuayi chomping at the bit to play his part after an eye-catching cameo last weekend. The home side will be glad to have Wilfried Zaha available after appealing against the extra one-match ban imposed for his sarcastic clapping of an official. Dominic Fifield

The onus is on Jürgen Klopp’s team to respond to Manchester City usurping them at the top of the Premier League and to increase pressure on the champions before they face Chelsea on Sunday. There is also a requirement on Liverpool to improve their own form. Liverpool have averaged three goals per game in the last six meetings with Bournemouth, who have never won at Anfield. Mohamed Salah, who scored a hat-trick against Eddie Howe’s team in December, needs one more goal to become the first Liverpool player since Luis Suárez in 2013-14 to hit the 20-goal mark in successive seasons. Andy Hunter

Without an away victory in the league since November, Arsenal need to improve on the road if they are to make a push for the top four. Their task at Huddersfield will be complicated by a spate of defensive injuries, while the bottom club could give a first league start to Karlan Grant, the striker they signed in January. Jan Siewert’s hope of securing a first win since his appointment as manager are also boosted by the return of his team’s best midfielder. Jonathan Hogg is in line to return alongside Aaron Mooy and Philip Billing. Paul Doyle

This will be another difficult day for Cardiff and their supporters, after Thursday’s confirmation that Emiliano Sala was killed in a plane crash. Cardiff have, to their immense credit, maintained their on-field focus as the tragedy has unfolded around them. Victory over Southampton would see Cardiff climb above their hosts and out of the bottom three, even if the result may still feel secondary to Neil Warnock and his players. Like their visitors, Southampton must try to put emotions aside against a relegation rival on what could be a pivotal weekend in the battle for safety. Niall McVeigh

Troy Deeney made some typically injudicious remarks to a Watford fans’ forum in the week and that will up the ante for what is already a high-tariff game for the home team following the perceived slight of Everton rating their previous manager and then hiring Marco Silva four months after he was sacked at Vicarage Road. Among other things, the Watford captain said that the players would prefer it if their fans did not boo the Everton manager and “let us kick the shit out of them”, but Silva is under enough pressure as it is from pockets of his own support after a run of four losses in five and a season-long deluge of concessions from set plays. “I’m ready for everything and my job is to get my players ready for everything,” he said. To that end Yerry Mina may be available again and Watford are hoping to call on Abdoulaye Doucouré after four games injured. Mark Tallentire

Fulham have eight points from their past eight games and if they continue like that for the rest of the season, they would finish on 30 points, which is unlikely to be enough to stay up. So Claudio Ranieri’s need for victories is urgent but they face Manchester United, who have dropped only two points since José Mourinho was sacked. Ranieri’s team may well find themselves behind against Marcus Rashford and company, much as they did against Brighton last week. However, they recovered famously to win 4-2. Ranieri will need that sort of spirit again to get anything against the Premier League’s most in-form side. Conrad Leach

Liverpool’s lead over Manchester City could be down to two points by the time they face West Ham. But while Jürgen Klopp’s side showed the first sign of nerves during the 1-1 draw with Leicester, they will take heart from scoring nine goals on their last two visits to the London Stadium. The title remains Liverpool’s to lose and the return of James Milner from a one-game ban could help them return to winning ways against West Ham, who are sweating on Marko Arnautovic’s fitness. Jacob Steinberg

A make-or-break week for Manchester City’s title defence begins with Arsenal before they travel to Everton on Wednesday and then Chelsea. Following Tuesday’s defeat by Newcastle Pep Guardiola’s side require a run of victories while hoping that Liverpool slip up. Against Unai Emery’s side it will be tough, Arsenal having moved up to fourth. Jamie Jackson

This is the sort of game Leicester will probably relish. They have beaten Chelsea and Manchester City at home and drawn away at Liverpool in the last six weeks. United, who have fitness concerns in relation to Paul Pogba and Anthony Martial, hope to win five successive away games in all competitions for the first time since Sir Alex Ferguson was in charge. Youri Tielemans, who has joined on loan from Monaco, could make his Leicester debut. Marcus Rashford is set to make his 100th Premier League appearance. Stuart James

With this being the first game at the Cardiff City Stadium since the plane Emiliano Sala was on board disappeared, it is sure to be an emotional occasion. Leandro Bacuna, signed from Reading on deadline day, is expected to make his debut as Neil Warnock’s side go in search of a first win in six games. It is hard to know what to expect from Bournemouth. They thrashed Chelsea 4-0 on Wednesday but have lost seven successive away games. Dominic Solanke could make his Bournemouth debut. Stuart James

Newcastle have lost seven consecutive games at Wembley since they won the FA Cup in 1955 but they will arrive with renewed optimism after their surprise win against Manchester City in midweek. Their new No 10, Miguel Almirón, is unavailable as he awaits a work permit, although the loanee left-back Antonio Barrera is in the squad. Tottenham, still wrestling with the injuries to Harry Kane, Dele Alli and Ben Davies as well as the soaring bill for their new stadium, failed to strengthen for second transfer window running but have their own addition to the squad list, the all-but forgotten £17m Dutch striker Vincent Janssen. “The most important thing now is to treat him properly, because he’s a person and my responsibility is to manage people, not chairs or sofas or furniture,” Mauricio Pochettino said. Mark Tallentire

These teams emerged from the transfer window with their attacking ranks reinforced, though Michy Batshuayi and Lazar Markovic may have to wait for their chances to impress for Crystal Palace and Fulham respectively. Palace must prove again they can triumph in the absence of Wilfried Zaha – the winger’s dismissal in midweek was untimely given a critical run of games – while Fulham seek to build on that rip-roaring comeback against Brighton. They have secured only two points on their travels but Palace’s home form is hardly impressive. Dominic Fifield

Maurizio Sarri has presided over Chelsea being humiliated in their last two Premier League games and dropping out of the top four, heaping pressure on the manager before the visit of struggling Huddersfield. This might normally be an appealing fixture in which to kick-start a revival, and for Gonzalo Higuaín to adjust better to the frantic rhythm of the Premier League, but Huddersfield arrive with little to lose. They guaranteed their top-flight survival in this fixture last season. Stamford Bridge holds plenty of good memories. Dominic Fifield

It is 40 years since Wolves last won at Goodison Park but they will arrive confident of increasing the gap over Marco Silva’s side having scored seven goals in two consecutive league victories. Everton’s fragile form and confidence, plus the likely absence of a recognised left-back, offer clear targets for Nuno Espírito Santo. His opposite number found respite in the midweek win at bottom-club Huddersfield but knows the performance level must improve. Idrissa Gueye’s state of mind having been denied a dream move to PSG is another issue. Andy Hunter

Burnley would have made it to mid-table if they had held on for victory at Manchester United in midweek, though an away point was still welcome in their bid to climb away from relegation trouble. They are level on points with Southampton and Sean Dyche will be looking for their improved home form since the turn of the year to continue, though since Ralph Hasenhüttl’s arrival the Saints have been harder to beat away from home. Paul Wilson

Brighton and Watford both lost from winning positions in midweek but Chris Hughton will be the manager left scratching his head after his side converted a 2-0 lead into a 4-2 defeat at Craven Cottage. Brighton have lost three in succession and Javi Gracia will be eager to compound their misery as he celebrates his 39th game in charge. The milestone represents the longest tenure of any manager in the Premier League for Watford. The fact he has lasted so long in the face of ownership’s usual chop and change tactics is testament to the job he is doing. They can move up to seventh with a win if results turn out in their favour. Graham Searles

Tottenham’s first test to survive following Son Heung-min leaving for the Asian Cup and Harry Kane suffering an ankle injury is a trip to Fulham. Claudio Ranieri’s side are five points from safety and will feel hope that they can salvage something. Ryan Babel making his Premier League return after eight years could help their cause. Érik Lamela and Fernando Llorente are solid replacements for Kane and Son though and should test Fulham’s improving but still imperfect defence. Graham Searles

Most Huddersfield fans were sad to see David Wagner leave as manager despite the club’s position at the bottom of the Premier League. Beating Manchester City while under the caretaker charge of Mark Hudson would go some way to cheering up the locals and convincing them that relegation is not a certainty. But it is a mighty tall order, with Pep Guardiola’s side in fabulous form as they continue to chase Liverpool at the top of the table. Paul Doyle

There is little love lost between Rafa Benítez and Neil Warnock so expect technical area tensions during this relegation six-pointer. Newcastle have won only twice at home all season and Benítez hopes their fans will contain understandable anger at the owner, Mike Ashley’s regime. “Cardiff’s game-plan will be to stop us and make sure our fans are nervous and anxious,” said Newcastle’s manager. “My message is very clear: stay together behind our team, keep helping the players. If we want to stay up, we need every single fan behind the players.” Louise Taylor

Wolves have lost five of their last seven matches at home and will want to avoid a third defeat to Leicester this season. Claude Puel is under pressure despite Leicester sitting comfortably in eighth and the chance to earn a third successive away win at the Molineux. Disappointing defeats to Newport County and Cardiff are the source of unrest and Puel’s reliance on Jamie Vardy is a problem. Leicester have won three of the 11 matches Vardy has played in but failed to score. Stopping him is key. Graham Searles

Watford and Burnley are unbeaten since Boxing Day. Sean Dyche seems to have stumbled across a purple patch thanks largely due installing Tom Heaton back in goal. Heaton has conceded two goals in four successive Burnley wins since Joe Hart conceded five to Everton. Goals still come at a premium for Dyche though as illustrated by miraculously beating Fulham 2-1 without a single shot on target. Watford will miss Will Hughes through concussion but Troy Deeney has hit form with four goals in six matches. Graham Searles

If Manchester United can reel off the seventh straight win under Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s tenure they will gain ground on Arsenal or Chelsea whatever the result in the fixture between them. Do so and suddenly United’s bid to earn a Champions League berth is realistic, the Norwegian having taken over with the gap 11 points. Jamie Jackson

For Arsenal, the situation is laced with peril. Lose and their top-four hopes could be over. Unai Emery’s side have hit a downturn, losing three of their last six league games, but the defeats have come away from home. As Emery has been happy to point out, Arsenal have been impressive at the Emirates. Chelsea are not firing on all cylinders, with goals difficult to come by. January transfer activity (or the lack of it at Arsenal) provides the background noise. David Hytner

Liverpool have gone 31 league games unbeaten at Anfield since losing to Palace in April 2017, winning 22 and drawing nine in a formidable sequence that also includes 21 clean sheets. Another victory here would restore a seven-point lead over Manchester City, at least until Sunday, and set a new club record for points won after 23 matches. Roy Hodgson returns to his former club without his main goalkeeping options, the injured Wayne Hennessey and Vicente Guaita, meaning a first start since December 2017 for the Premier League’s oldest player, 39-year-old Julian Speroni. Andy Hunter

West Ham impressed against Arsenal and will be raring to face a Bournemouth side with the third worst defensive record in the league. Eddie Howe’s charges concede almost two goals a game on average so attack, as usual, will be the best form of defence for Bournemouth. Doubts remain over the fitness of top scorer Callum Wilson though. After a dreadful start Manuel Pellegrini has done a magnificent job turning West Ham’s season around. A win could send them seventh. Graham Searles

Southampton could further ease their relegation fears by following up victory at Leicester against another top-half team struggling to meet high expectations. Ralph Hasenhüttl was left concerned by the midweek FA Cup defeat on penalties to Derby, which has sapped his squad’s energy as well as their morale. The Austrian plans to freshen up his starting XI, with Danny Ings winning his fitness battle and both Charlie Austin and Pierre-Emile Højbjerg back from suspension. Everton’s away form this season and record at St Mary’s are equally poor – two wins from 10 in both cases. Marco Silva has suggested he may not invest in attacking reinforcements in this transfer window, and is banking on Richarlison rediscovering his goalscoring touch – the Brazilian last scored on Boxing Day. Niall McVeigh

Two out-of-form teams meet at Goodison Park, although only one manager finds himself under scrutiny. Marco Silva delivered a passionate yet reasoned defence of his early work at Everton on Friday following criticism of the team’s league position from the majority shareholder, Farhad Moshiri. It is criticism Silva accepts after a run of one win in eight league games. Bournemouth’s recent results are even worse, with Eddie Howe’s side losing 10 of their last 13 matches in all competitions. Liverpool loanee Nathaniel Clyne is in line for his league debut but fellow new boy Dominic Solanke is sidelined with a hamstring problem. Andy Hunter

Having beaten Liverpool and then scored 16 in their last two matches Manchester City will be delighted with a fourth consecutive home match when Wolves arrive on Monday. Nuno Espírito Santo’s side are ninth with 29 points but a negative goal difference does not augur well for their meeting with the Pep Guardiola’s side. Jamie Jackson

Tottenham looked jaded in their Carabao Cup semi-final against Chelsea, while Manchester United ought to be refreshed after their training break in Dubai. Yet Mauricio Pochettino could be encouraged at how his team still toughed out a 1-0 win. It was a sign, he said, of their greater maturity and competitiveness. United are resurgent under Ole Gunnar Solsjkær but after wins over bottom-half clubs, this is a first major test for him. David Hytner

A big game for both clubs – and for entirely different reasons. Southampton are back in the relegation zone and badly need points. Although Leicester have no such worries, Claude Puel, Southampton’s former manager, is once again under pressure after a humiliating FA Cup exit at the hands of Newport. Jamie Vardy, among others, will be restored to Leicester’s starting lineup. Southampton will have to make do without three strikers, with Danny Ings and Michael Obafemi injured and Charlie Austin suspended. Stuart James

It seems remarkable to think Cardiff are out of the bottom three despite leading for a total of 93 minutes this season. Neil Warnock would happily settle for another injury-time winner as Cardiff host Huddersfield in a proper relegation scrap. Huddersfield have lost eight league games in a row and are eight points adrift of safety, making this a must-win game. Cardiff have enjoyed plenty of home comforts this season but their last two games in front of their own supporters were both heavy defeats. Stuart James

The focus will be on Marko Arnautovic when West Ham host Arsenal. He has made it clear he wants West Ham to let him move to China and it will be fascinating to see if he is in the right frame of mind against Unai Emery’s side, who have welcomed Hector Bellerín, Shkodran Mustafi, Nacho Monreal and Mesut Özil back to training. Arsenal, who are pushing hard for a place in the top four, will hope the forward’s focus is elsewhere. Jacob Steinberg

Chelsea will want to move on from their defeat in the League Cup and are likely to do just that against Newcastle. To do so Maurizio Sarri needs to figure out what is ailing his side considering their relative poor form since beating Manchester City in December. Newcastle could give him chance to experiment because Rafael Bentítez has a depleted squad through injury, players away on international duty and Kenedy ineligible against his parent club. Graham Searles

Watford have been a rollercoaster ride producing the sublime and less sublime so far. They have been an open book scoring and conceding freely, the 3-3 draw with Bournemouth last time out a perfect example of their season. Crystal Palace are enjoying a welcome upturn with unlikely wins against Leicester, Manchester City and Wolves in their last five matches. Another win could put Palace nine points above the relegation zone. Javi Gracia should be worried, especially as the sole goalscoring burden has been lifted from Wilfired Zaha. Graham Searles

Brighton have the best home record outside of the top six this season but that might count for little against a Liverpool side itching to return to winning ways. Jürgen Klopp still holds a four-point lead and he will desperately want to avoid the gap being reduced further. Chris Hughton will be pleased to see Fabinho remain in defence so Glenn Murray can bully the Brazilian, and with Jürgen Locadia finally showing his attacking ability, a cliche Liverpool clean sheet is unlikely. Graham Searles

Burnley have shown signs of recovery and are looking for a third successive league win when they take on Fulham, who come to Turf Moor second bottom and without an away win this season. It seems a long time ago now but these sides were involved in a six-goal thriller in August, when Fulham won 4-2 at Craven Cottage to raise expectations for the season that has sadly failed to materialise. Paul Wilson

Crystal Palace will be another test of whether Maurizio Sarri can produce consistency from Chelsea. Their win on Boxing Day restored morale after the relatively slack display in defeat to Leicester but, while Palace’s home record is unimpressive, Chelsea have not always found life easy at Selhurst Park. Palace’s problems, briefly masked by that eye-catching win at Manchester City, were exposed at home by Cardiff and this team pine for a natural goalscorer who is fully fit and ready. Dominic Fifield

Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s has had the dream start at Manchester United, so the trick is to earn a third win and against a Bournemouth side who were beaten 2-1 in November’s reverse fixture. While Eddie Howe usually poses problems for any side, United, with Romelu Lukaku, Anthony Martial and Alexis Sánchez all potentially available again, surely have the tools to win. Jamie Jackson

Southampton will be downbeat after losing to an injury ravaged West Ham and Ralph Hasenhüttl’s gloss could be further stripped away by Manchester City. Pep Guardiola is surely furious after watching City lose three of their last four games and will demand a commanding performance. But can City produce one? Pressure from Liverpool’s dominance could tell if Jürgen Klopp’s side extend their lead over Guardiola’s to 10 points on Saturday. Graham Searles

Sean Dyche accepts the time for action is now at Burnley, who have lost nine of their last 11 and slipped three points from safety. “I don’t think we’re miles away,” Dyche said. “A couple of games got away from us when they shouldn’t have done, there’s a few we should have got something from. We’ve worked on the training ground, we’ve looked at analysis, we’ve looked at shape changes. You have to keep monitoring the situation.” At least Johann Berg Gudmundsson is fit for Burnley, while West Ham are hoping Pablo Zabaleta can recover from illness in time for Sunday’s trip. Resurgent after winning five of their last six, they could only fill six of their seven substitute berths for Thursday’s 2-1 win at Southampton. Mark Tallentire

Watford’s revival ended at the hands of Chelsea but a spirited display in defeat will give Javi Gracia hope they can rebound against struggling Newcastle. Rafael Benítez will want a repeat of the performance from earlier in the season when his side recorded their first win after 10 games against Gracia’s. Benítez still believes it will take a miracle for Newcastle to avoid relegation and he may be on to something if they fail to win here as Manchester United and Chelsea are up next. Graham Searles

Mauricio Pochettino can reflect on the first-half of the season with pride. Flying high in the Premier League, his Tottenham side are also into the Champions League last 16 and the Carabao Cup semi-finals. He could scarcely have wished for more yet it is what lies ahead that tantalises. Can Spurs win the league? Play like they have done since Pochettino was strongly linked to Manchester United and they could. Wolves have stabilised after a wobble and they will threaten on the counter. David Hytner

Liverpool look strong favourites to beat an Arsenal side still reeling from injuries in defence. Jürgen Klopp’s aggressive style could produce a similar scoreline to the 4-0 win last season at Anfield. Unai Emery has the chance to show his tactical nous, considering how limited his options are, but he could be forgiven for wishing this match came in January when Arsenal have brought in reinforcements. Liverpool’s last league defeat at home was in April 2017. Graham Searles

Unlikely victories over Chelsea and Manchester City have elevated Leicester to seventh and eased the pressure on Claude Puel. With Cardiff up next, Leicester will hope to make it three straight wins, given Neil Warnock’s side have collected only two points on the road all season. The Cardiff manager is expected to bring Harry Arter and Aron Gunnarsson back into the starting lineup but Callum Paterson, who has been converted into a striker, faces a fitness test. Leicester have no new injury concerns. Stuart James

Everton become the first club to complete 4,500 top-flight matches against Brighton, and they travel in mixed form. A pre-Christmas 6-2 thumping by Spurs was followed by a 5-1 win at Burnley on Boxing Day and with Richarlison expected to start after appearing as a scoring substitute at Turf Moor, they will be expecting to add more goals. Brighton have Lewis Dunk restored to the defence after suspension but will be without their goalkeeper Mat Ryan, who has played every minute of every league match since Albion returned to the top flight in 2017, as he has joined up with Australia for the Asian Cup in the UAE. David Button is expected to deputise. Mark Tallentire

Second-bottom Fulham host last-placed Huddersfield. A relegation six-pointer, despite the season having only reached the halfway stage. Neither side can climb out of the mire with a win but avoiding being further cut adrift will be imperative to both managers. David Wagner’s first win of the season came against Fulham in November but, with Claudio Ranieri in charge, Fulham have tightened up. If they continue that trend Ranieri will be confident his side have the better chance. Huddersfield have lost six in a row, while scoring only four goals. Graham Searles

The last time Everton beat Tottenham Gylfi Sigurdsson came off the bench to try to grab an equaliser for André Villas-Boas in December 2012. Six years later and the Iceland midfielder is key to Everton’s chances. If given the freedom to create for Richarlison then Marco Silva’s side have a great chance to arrest their run of four games without a win. A rather large if considering Everton failed to score in either fixture last season. Tottenham have a lengthy list of injured players but do not look too troubled. They have been brilliant since their humbling at the Emirates. Graham Searles

Unai Emery is under pressure after defeats to Southampton and Tottenham. He is severely hampered in defence and the player who makes treacle look like it runs fast, Stephan Lichtsteiner, will have to continue his static presence in the backline. Sean Dyche will be delighted but it is unlikely he is dreaming of an upset victory because Burnley’s last league win against Arsenal was in 1974. A 0-0 grinder should suit him just fine. Graham Searles

If Liverpool beat Wolves then Manchester City cannot be top at Christmas even if they beat Crystal Palace. Jürgen Klopp’s side show no sign of fading so the champions understand the need to be near-faultless. With Kevin De Bruyne and Sergio Agüero fit again Manchester City are in good shape to ensure they are, starting with this opening festive-season fixture. Jamie Jackson

In a strange twist of fate, Ole Gunnar Solskjær’s first match in charge of Manchester United is back at the club where he was sacked after only nine months in charge. That was in 2014 and few Cardiff fans could have imagined the Norwegian would return one day as the manager of United. Although this is an awkward game for Solskjær – Cardiff have won four of their past five at home – there is a sense that United’s players will feel liberated now that José Mourinho has gone. Stuart James

Claudio Ranieri has joked that, as a manager, “Rafael Benítez is more Italian than me”. The Fulham and Newcastle rivals are old friends who find themselves preparing for a relegation dogfight in which the Fulham centre-forward Aleksandar Mitrovic will be desperate to jog his former public’s memory with a goal – or two. He was popular with Newcastle fans but Benítez, who must hope his side build on their potentially vital win at Huddersfield, never seemed to rate the striker who departed for Fulham for £22m last summer. Louise Taylor

Watford ended a six-game run without a win with a 3-2 victory over Cardiff at Vicarage Road, although earning successive wins could prove to be a challenge for Javi Gracia. His side have won two of their last away 20 away games and improving that record will be difficult considering how good West Ham have been of late. They have won four on the bounce and appear to be making the London Stadium a happy hunting ground. Hritika Sharma

Bournemouth’s form has dipped after a bright start. A combination of a tough run and a lengthy injury list has resulted in seven defeats in their last eight games in all competitions. With trips to Tottenham and Manchester United coming up, this match is crucial. It also presents an opportunity for Brighton to get their third away win of the season, although Chris Hughton dismissed the suggestion it was a good time to face Eddie Howe’s side and said he was expecting a difficult game. Hritika Sharma

The pressure is slowly mounting again on Claude Puel after one win in six league games and after Chelsea there is the tricky test of a visit by Manchester City on Boxing Day. Leicester will need to be more incisive than they were in defeat at Crystal Palace last weekend but they are facing a Chelsea side who have rediscovered their rhythm. Eden Hazard, his ankles recovered for another week, is back at his early season best and is likely to start in the No 9 role again. This could be an awkward occasion for the visitors. Dominic Fifield

Southampton hope to confirm their revival under Ralph Hasenhüttl by claiming a win that would create more distance to the bottom three, where Huddersfield reside. In last week’s win over Arsenal Saints rediscovered dynamism and the sharpness up front they had been lacking. Huddersfield have never been short of dynamism but have often been blunt. If Huddersfield are to gain a win that would lift them above Saints, they will need Steve Mounié to thrive on his return from suspension. Paul Doyle

The table, form, individual quality, defensive cohesion and a clear style of play all point to victory for the Premier League leaders at Anfield but Liverpool know better than to treat their north-west rivals lightly, or any team managed by José Mourinho for that matter. Manchester United are unbeaten in the last eight league meetings between the clubs and are the only Premier League team that Jürgen Klopp has faced and not defeated. Injuries to several right-sided defenders will concern the Liverpool manager, although his side have not lost at home in the league for 20 months. Andy Hunter

Brighton have not lost at home since Tottenham’s visit in September but greet a Chelsea team revitalised by their eye-catching defeat of Manchester City. Inevitably there will be eyes cast off the pitch after the unsavoury incidents in the stands during that game and the Europa League tie with Vidi; further disgrace is surely unthinkable and Chris Hughton’s home side, who will have a clean bill of health if José Izquierdo and Alireza Jahanbakhsh are passed fit, will hope the headlines can be dominated by their latest major scalp. Nick Ames

Ralph Hasenhüttl has urged Southampton to “be brave from the first minute” as they begin a tough run of festive fixtures. Arsenal will be without suspended centre-backs Shkodran Mustafi and Sokratis Papastathopoulos, although Laurent Koscielny and Nacho Montreal came through the Qarabag game unscathed. For Southampton, Danny Ings, Shane Long and Cédric Soares are in contention but Ryan Bertrand is still out with a back problem. The hosts led last season’s corresponding fixture for 85 minutes before conceding a late equaliser. In the 12 months since, Southampton have thrown away a lead at home on eight occasions, winning just once. Niall McVeigh

Cardiff are going to lose or rather they will if the form book is to be believed. Neil Warnock’s side have followed up all of their wins this season with defeats. So how can they avoid such a fate? They might not need that much help. Watford are missing Will Hughes and the steadying presence of Étienne Capoue in midfield through injury and the final game of a three-game suspension respectively. Javi Gracia’s side are winless since October and have scored just four goals in the six matches since beating Huddersfield. Graham Searles

Huddersfield have been playing well in recent weeks but face a challenge continuing that form following an unfortunate slew of injuries. David Wagner will have to tweak his midfield, in particular, following the loss of Aaron Mooy and Danny Williams, though the return of Philip Billing from suspension is well-timed. It remains to be seen whether Newcastle, who have lost two of their last three matches, are good enough to take advantage of the hosts’ misfortune. Paul Doyle

Tottenham’s physios will be busy before this match, with four defenders – Serge Aurier, Davinson Sánchez, Juan Foyth and Kieran Trippier – all facing late fitness tests. Mauricio Pochettino must refocus his team after their dramatic Champions League qualification, and keep pressure on Liverpool and Manchester City, against a Burnley side who have proved tricky opponents in recent visits to Wembley and White Hart Lane. Sean Dyche’s side have two tough away trips in succession – they go to Arsenal next week, and have not won in the league at either north London side since 1974. Dyche has urged his team to play with more attacking freedom, but that may be easier said than done. Niall McVeigh

Crystal Palace won this fixture at a canter back in the spring, rattling up their biggest ever Premier League victory en route to top-flight survival as Leicester wilted and left Claude Puel under pressure. Now it is Roy Hodgson in the spotlight. Palace had been playing well but missing out up to last week, but their capitulations at Brighton and West Ham have cast a grimmer shadow on an underwhelming campaign so far. They have not won without Wilfried Zaha since September 2016, and face Manchester City next. These are worrying times. Dominic Fifield

Fulham were desperately poor against Manchester United last time out but now face arguably a tougher task in hosting West Ham. A fourth win in a row is on the cards and with Felipe Anderson playing so magnificently Fulham’s notional defence could be in for a very difficult and draining evening. Claudio Ranieri may look forward to fixtures against Newcastle and Huddersfield to pick up much-needed points over Christmas instead. Graham Searles

Manchester City welcome Everton in the unfamiliar position of not leading the league, having done so for 10 of the 16 Premier League games this season before last week’s loss at Chelsea. Yet as Liverpool do not play Manchester United until Sunday Pep Guardiola’s side can leapfrog Jürgen Klopp’s by defeating Everton. Marco Silva’s team, though, are the only one Guardiola’s have played at home twice in the league and not beaten so it may be a tricky afternoon. Jamie Jackson

Wolves are chasing a third successive win, thanks largely to Diogo Jota’s return to form, against Bournemouth. After failing to score in 14 appearances in all competitions he found the net in wins against Chelsea and Newcastle. Nuno Espírito Santo’s side can leapfrog Eddie Howe’s with victory. Bournemouth have slipped from their impressive start and could be in trouble. One, somewhat fortunate, win against Huddersfield and five defeats in their past six is troubling. A key aspect could be Ryan Fraser’s partnership with Callum Wilson and whether Wolves are able to shut them down, if Wilson is passed fit. Graham Searles

Marco Silva faces Watford for the first time since being sacked at Vicarage Road. The background to his dismissal remains subject of a legal complaint from the visitors but a more immediate concern to the Everton manager is breaking down disciplined and resilient opposition at Goodison Park in the absence of an established striker. Newcastle were the latest side to frustrate Everton at home and, with Cenk Tosun failing against Rafael Benítez’s packed defence, Richarlison may resume striking duties. Andy Hunter

With Paul Dummett once again absent, injured, at left back for Newcastle and specialist cover thin on the ground Rafael Benítez may be tempted to play five at the back against a Wolves side seemingly recovered from their recent wobble. Whatever formation he fields is likely to be cheered on by a full house after home fans abandoned plans to boycott the game in protest at Mike Ashley’s 11-year ownership of the club. Ashley now claims he is close to selling up and has even talked of a January takeover. Like the rest of us, Benítez will believe it when it happens. Louise Taylor

A tricky match for Tottenham to negotiate, not least because they have a critical Champions League tie away against Barcelona on Tuesday. Three points would give Spurs their best top-flight record after 16 matches since the 1960-61 season. Jan Vertonghen is back from suspension but Kieran Trippier and Juan Foyth are out. Leicester welcome back Harry Maguire after a five-week absence but they are still missing Jamie Vardy, who has a groin problem, leaving the onus on Kelechi Iheanacho to rediscover his touch in front of goal. Stuart James

The Ralph Hasenhüttl era gets underway for Southampton in the Welsh capital in a relegation six-pointer. The omens are not good for the Austrian – Paul Sturrock was the last permanent Southampton manager to win his first game in charge back in 2004 and plenty have been and gone since then. Yet if Hasenhüttl’s colourful first press conference is anything to go by, the players should at least arrive in Cardiff with a spring in their step. Cardiff, two places above Saints, have won three of their last four at home. Stuart James

José Mourinho’s distinctly odd campaign had its latest instalment in Jorge Mendes’s statement on Friday that said his client will not be vacating his post at Manchester United. He may, though, have zero say if United fail to beat Fulham, the bottom side, as sooner rather than later Mourinho has to start winning matches consistently. There has been no Premier League victory for over a month and United are a yawning 18 points behind Manchester City. Something, surely, has to change. Jamie Jackson

The story about the night on the eve of the season when some of the Arsenal players allegedly inhaled nitrous oxide brought some shock value – partly because the club have come to sail under the news agenda. Since Unai Emery took charge they have done their talking on the pitch, quietly piecing together a 20-game unbeaten run. Despite the controversy Huddersfield are unlikely to end it. David Hytner

Chelsea take on Manchester City having lost two of their last three in the league, most recently at newly promoted Wolves, acutely aware that defeat to City would leave them 13 points behind the league leaders. This is arguably the champions’ trickiest remaining fixture this season, but they are unbeaten, averaging three goals a game, and seeking successive league wins at Stamford Bridge for the first time since 1955. Pep Guardiola boasts a perfect record against his opposite number, winning all three of their previous meetings. A difficult evening awaits for the hosts. Ethan Van Ristell

Neutrals might hope for a repeat of 2016’s frantic game when Bournemouth came from 3-0 down to snatch a late 4-3 victory but alas Liverpool’s watertight defence will probably prevent that. Jürgen Klopp will have to do without Joe Gomez, who broke his leg against Burnley on Wednesday, while Dejan Lovren also misses out. Joël Matip will partner Virgil van Dijk. Sadio Mané is doubtful too, so this could be the first test of Liverpool’s strength in depth. Can Bournemouth, back to winning ways after a four-game losing streak, take advantage? Nick Miller

Burnley have to regard this as a must-win match, even if Brighton are 12 points better off and in the top half of the table. Tottenham, Arsenal and Everton are next for Sean Dyche’s side so they could easily be spending Christmas in the bottom three, uncomfortably aware some of the clubs around them are either showing signs of improvement or hopeful of climbing out of trouble after appointing a new manager. Brighton are unbeaten in their past three matches. Paul Wilson

These sides head into this London derby in contrasting moods. While West Ham are looking to win three consecutive games in the Premier League for the first time since December 2016, Crystal Palace are reeling from their humbling by Brighton on Tuesday. Roy Hodgson will demand a response from his players. However West Ham, who will be without the injured Marko Arnautovic, are unbeaten in six matches against Palace. Jacob Steinberg

Jürgen Klopp believes this Merseyside derby will be his toughest as the Liverpool manager. Everton’s recent form under Marco Silva would suggest so, with summer signings André Gomes, Richarlison and Yerry Mina raising the standard. It still demands a significant step forward by Everton to win at Anfield for the first time since 1999. Liverpool are unbeaten in 17 derbies in all competitions, a record, and have not lost a league game at home since April 2017. Andy Hunter

What a game this promises to be. Unai Emery has made his mark at Arsenal so far by attacking from all angles and – when required – making bold, offensive changes while Tottenham have found greater rhythm in recent matches, not least in the overwhelming of Chelsea last Saturday. Fatigue could be a factor, mainly for Spurs, who went through the wringer against Internazionale on Wednesday. Emery will pick a different team to the one he fielded in Thursday’s Europa League tie away against Vorskla. David Hytner

Claudio Ranieri’s second game in charge takes him back to Stamford Bridge, his old stomping ground for four years at the turn of the millennium which, probably unfairly, is remembered more now for the lengthy period he was a dead man walking while Roman Abramovich waited to appoint José Mourinho. Fulham’s only success at their neighbours in the last 54 years came in the Second Division back in 1979, but their pace and invention on the counter, and Aleksandar Mitrovic’s brawn, could unsettle the hosts. Whether the visitors’ defence can withstand Eden Hazard is another matter entirely. Dominic Fifield

Three straight defeats in the league represents the worst run of the season so far for Bournemouth. Matters will not be getting any easier for them on Saturday. Eddie Howe’s side face Manchester City, the champions have scored 13 goals against Bournemouth in just three games at the Etihad Stadium, conceding just one in the process. After his side’s demolition of West Ham last weekend, Pep Guardiola might just be anticipating another awe-inspiring display from his breathtaking unit. Ethan Van Ristell

José Mourinho said earlier this week he would always prefer to play at Old Trafford, but he might think twice if offered a change of venue on Saturday. Southampton have not won at home since April and slipped into the relegation zone after defeat at Fulham, while their only win over Manchester United at St Mary’s came back in 2003. Alexis Sánchez is likely to be out until the new year with a hamstring injury, so Romelu Lukaku may get a chance to end his goal drought. Lukaku has gone 12 games without a goal, but has six in nine appearances against Southampton. For the hosts, top scorer Danny Ings is set to miss out, while Ryan Bertrand is also a doubt with a back injury. Niall McVeigh

Many people would say Jonjo Shelvey and Jamaal Lascelles are Newcastle’s best players but after injuries cost them their places the fit again pair are struggling to get back into a team which has won its past three games. Rafael Benítez – a manager much admired by West Ham’s hierarchy – hopes this momentum will not be disrupted by a planned fans’ protest against Mike Ashley’s 11-year ownership of Newcastle whereby supporters will delay entry into St James’ Park until the 11th minute. Louise Taylor

This is not the assignment Chris Hughton would have chosen as he seeks to end Huddersfield’s three-match winless run. Huddersfield have beaten Brighton on their last two meetings at the John Smith’s Stadium and David Wagner’s side go into this match in their best form of the season and aiming for a win that would lift them further away from the relegation zone. Paul Doyle

After a rather fortunate victory over Southampton in the Carabao Cup via penalties, Leicester go in search of their first home league win for more than two months. Watford, two points above, have lost momentum after a superb start and have scored once in their last three matches. Tom Cleverley could return for Watford after a lengthy absence and José Holebas, Sebastian Prödl and Daryl Janmaat are available again. Harry Maguire remains out for Leicester but is set to return to training next week. Stuart James

Crystal Palace emerged from a daunting run relatively chuffed by the points gained against Arsenal and Manchester United, though it has been their inability to beat the teams around them that has left them mired a point off the bottom and without a league victory since mid-September. This will be a seventh attempt to secure a first home win, a dreadful record that has Palace only marginally better off than this time last year. Burnley, winless in six themselves, are only below Palace on goal difference. It is tempting to suggest something will have to give at Selhurst Park. Dominic Fifield

Wolves arrested a poor run by stifling Arsenal last time out and will be confident they can move back into the top half with a victory against Huddersfield. David Wagner’s side had their own slice of good fortune before the break by moving off the foot of the table but with only six goals from 12 matches that may not last much longer. The omens continue to slide toward despair for Wagner as defenders Mathias Jørgensen and Chris Löwe are missing through suspension and injury respectively. Graham Searles

Two wins in their past two matches enabled Newcastle to climb above Burnley, an indication of the stuttering start to the season Sean Dyche and his players have made. Admittedly the clubs are separated only by goal difference, though that in itself tells a story. Typically for a Rafael Benítez side Newcastle are among the best defenders in the bottom half, whereas Burnley, once so solid, have conceded 25 goals in 12 matches. Only the bottom club, Fulham, have conceded more this season. Paul Wilson

Arsenal, while enjoying a 16-game unbeaten run, bizarrely will be feeling pressure to keep up with their rivals after three successive draws. A trip to Bournemouth hardly represents the best opportunity for this but they should still have enough on paper. Eddie Howe’s side were unlucky to lose to Manchester United in their last home match and always create chances for Callum Wilson. How hungry the England international is to expose Arsenal’s suspect backline and keep his excellent season running could determine the outcome. Graham Searles

Cardiff have not won at Goodison Park since 1926, a year before their FA Cup win. With a paltry two away goals for the season – a Football League low – they would presumably be more than happy with a point as Neil Warnock counts down to January when he intends to get a forward or two to enhance Cardiff’s survival prospects. Two wins in the past four games represent their best run of the season. Everton will have to be wary as they seek to finish of a month of improved results with three points and contemplate December, which includes trips to Liverpool and Manchester City as well as a visit from Spurs. Gylfi Sigurdsson, André Gomes and Ademola Lookman are all fit, while Kurt Zouma is available after missing the 0-0 draw at his parent club Chelsea. Mark Tallentire

Jonny Evans has said Leicester’s players felt “emotionally drained” after the death of the club’s owner, Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha, and are now trying to regain their focus. Leicester were the only team outside the top three to win in the league at the Amex last season but could be without Jamie Vardy, who picked up a groin strain against Burnley. James Maddison is back in training but Harry Maguire has not recovered from a knee injury in time. For the hosts, Chris Hughton could recall the playmaker Pascal Gross, who is fit after almost three months out. Niall McVeigh

Fulham have lost six league games in a row while Southampton are winless in eight, so something has to give, with Claudio Ranieri’s appointment intended to provide a lift to the bottom club. The irony that Mark Hughes spent a season as the manager at Craven Cottage but left in the summer of 2011 “to further my experiences” will be lost on none of the home fans. A 4-0 home win is the requirement to move above the Saints and leave Hughes needing a result against Manchester United or Spurs the following week. “After 20 years doing this job it’s nothing I haven’t seen and dealt with before,” he said. “It’s part of the job and doesn’t faze me. Clearly Fulham are close to us and it’s an opportunity for us to take maximum points.” Mark Tallentire

José Mourinho remains adamant Manchester United will break into the top four come the festive season so Crystal Palace, at home, really has to end in victory. Last year’s corresponding fixture was a 4-0 hammering of Roy Hodgson’s side and, with Paul Pogba fit again, there can be no excuses if calamity occurs. Jamie Jackson
