Michael Laudrup will hope that Michu can excel against the bottom-placed team although the Dane will also be wary of the return to Sunderland's ranks of Steven Fletcher, who should lead the visitors' attack after recovering from a shoulder injury. John Stephens

Stoke have lost their last three games and are no doubt hoping to recapture the home form they have been noted for. Four goals in seven games have left Mark Hughes's men with the worst goals-scored record in the division, and they face a West Bromwich side who are on an encouraging unbeaten run. In Saido Berahino, Albion also possess an exciting, young goal-threat. John Stephens

Spurs have beaten Villa 4-0 on their own patch twice in the past 10 months but this latest contest promises to be closer. Christian Benteke, a transfer target for Spurs in the summer, has a chance of returning to a Villa side that defeated Manchester City in their last home league game. The spotlight will again shine brightly on Andros Townsend, the winger who made such an impressive contribution for England against Montenegro and Poland. Stuart James

Cardiff City might consider the wounds suffered over recent weeks to have been self-inflicted, the departure of Iain Moody as chief scout unsettling Malky Mackay when he should have been savouring a promising start to his side's top-flight return. Chelsea have not lost at home to the Welsh club since 1981, yet José Mourinho still expects an awkward challenge. "They are motivated, they beat Manchester City, have already won away from home, and the boys who have come back from Chile and Iceland will be full of good feelings," he said. "Losing the scout is a problem for the owner, for Mackay, not the players". Dominic Fifield

Ian Holloway has described the visit of Fulham as a "must not lose game" for Crystal Palace yet privately the manager must accept this derby provides his team with a great chance to capture just their second win of the season. Selhurst Park should be rocking under the lights and Fulham, who may include Maarten Stekelenburg in their side, could well be there for the taking. Sachin Nakrani

Norwich travel to the league leaders with just one win in their past four games and finding themselves in the relegation zone. A trip, then, to the Emirates to face a side brimming with confidence is not what Chris Hughton would want right now. Aaron Ramsey kept up his impressive recent form with a goal for Wales in midweek and will pose a threat again. John Stephens

The last thing Alan Pardew would have wanted before Newcastle face Daniel Sturridge and Luis Suárez is a centre-back injury crisis but that is what he has got. Fabricio Coloccini and Steven Taylor are absent for the visit of what Brendan Rodgers has described as the best strike partnership in England. Victory for Liverpool would take them top for a couple of hours at least. Sachin Nakrani

Few would have predicted Southampton would find themselves above the champions after seven games of the season. Mauricio Pochettino's side have prospered thanks to a solid defence and from securing key victories, such as their 1-0 triumph against Liverpool. United won at Sunderland in their last outing with a double from Adnan Januzaj and he is likely to feature again. John Stephens

Only one point seperates promoted Hull from opponents with a long-established top-flight status, yet few expect Steve Bruce's side to get much out of their visit to Goodison Park. Everton have lost just once this season, have generally looked impressive, and in Leighton Baines and Romelu Lukaku have two players who are shining at international and club level right now. John Stephens

Talk of crisis was washed away by the wave of goodwill that arrived with Mesut Özil and Arsenal are looking for their 11th win in a row in all competitions. Bacary Sagna has a hamstring injury while Santi Cazorla is not yet fit, meaning another team light on width. Albion are basking in their win at Old Trafford but Scott Sinclair's hamstring strain picked up there will keep him out, though Nicolas Anelka and Chris Brunt could return. Nick Miller

It is to be hoped that the headlines are driven by what happens on the field, rather than off it where it is to be expected that Tottenham's fans will sing what they want, which will not sit well with the police. The potential for conflict bubbles between these rivals yet Tottenham simply intend to extend their solid start. Only Olivier Giroud and John Terry have scored against them in 11 games so far. West Ham need a tonic after a poor spell. David Hytner

A win against the champions would be a big tick on Kevin Ball's CV as the Sunderland board take the international break to appoint a replacement for Paolo Di Canio. The home side are still missing Steven Fletcher and need Jozy Altidore to start repaying the £8m spent on the American striker. Meanwhile, David Moyes needs all three points to stem the United in crisis narrative. Toby Moses

Manuel Pellegrini has problems due to Joe Hart's awful form and the need to rebuild belief following the 3-1 hiding Bayern Munich handed his side in the midweek Champions League game. Everton, the league's only unbeaten side, arrive with two more points, and are a tricky proposition due to the form of Romelu Lukaku and Ross Barkley. Given Alvaro Negredo's consistent impact whenever he is given a chance, the Spanish striker could start in place of Edin Dzeko for City. Jamie Jackson

Mark Hughes returns to the club that he left under something of a cloud in the summer of 2011 having admitted he made a mistake in going from Fulham to "further his career"– a decision that saw him presiding over a chaotic 10-month period at QPR. Hughes seems to have found some stability now at Stoke while Fulham have problems of their own with Martin Jol's managership starting to sink as the home fans turn against him. Rich Flower

This is a meeting between two of the Premier League's dark horses, with both sides justifiably upbeat about their prospects this season. Southampton were briefly as high as fourth last weekend but the visit of Michael Laudrup's side promises to be a stern test. The games are coming thick and fast for Swansea, and Southampton will hope that their Europa League exertions on Thursday will have a negative effect on the Welsh side. Jacob Steinberg

Chris Hughton will want his Norwich side to recoup at least a point on Sunday or the momentum of last week's 1-0 victory at Stoke could go to waste, particularly with the daunting prospect of a trip to Arsenal looming after the international break. Chelsea have not lost at Carrow Road since December 1994, but in the absence of Fernando Torres, scoring enough goals to secure a win could be problematic. Rich Flower

After a pair of 3-2 defeats, Newcastle will be grateful for any sort of good news, and that might come with Yohan Cabaye returning to the starting lineup. The French midfielder came on in the loss at Everton, and Alan Pardew thinks he could feature from the start on Saturday. The Cardiff manager, Malky Mackay, has no further injury concerns, with summer signing Andreas Cornelius still working his way back to fitness. Nick Miller

This would appear to be one of the day's more obvious home bankers. Luis Suárez's winning and scoring return at Sunderland, and his link-up play with Daniel Sturridge, promise to give Liverpool's attack extra potency. Palace have not been overwhelmed by anyone so far but are struggling to score, beset by injuries and their search for a first away point is likely to continue. Tom Davies

Both sides will have a spring in their step as each seek a third consecutive win. Hull have been confident and purposeful at home so far, although the absence of their incisive midfielder Robbie Brady is a blow. Villa are also missing a key man in Christian Benteke, but last week's win over Manchester City demonstrated their resilience and tenacity, which they will need to show again here. Tom Davies

While Manchester United still smart from the 4-1 derby humiliation at Manchester City, the midweek Capital One Cup defeat of Liverpool offered considerable succour before West Bromwich Albion's arrival at Old Trafford. If David Moyes is serious about retaining the title for the club then this is precisely the ilk of opposition who must be beaten. Last time out the fixture was a helter-skelter 5-5 draw in Sir Alex Ferguson's last game as manager. Moyes would settle for as 1-0 win, Steve Clarke for any kind of draw. Jamie Jackson

It will be a tale of two missing strikers in the clash at Villa Park on Saturday afternoon, with Christian Benteke and Sergio Agüero ruled out through injury. Whereas City have Edin Dzeko, Álvaro Negredo and Stevan Jovetic to call upon, Villa will be hoping that their new signing Libor Kozak can repeat his debut heroics from last week at Norwich, where he scored the only goal in a 1-0 victory. Simeon Gholam

A game for the purist. Michael Laudrup's easy-on-the-eye Swansea City side take on an Arsenal team full of confidence on the back of a run of eight straight wins in all competitions, including Wednesday's penalty shootout victory over West Bromwich Albion in the Capital One Cup. With a long list of injuries, Arsène Wenger will be desperately hoping that Aaron Ramsey and Mathieu Flamini pass fitness tests. Swansea, who have failed to win at home in their past seven Premier League matches, are likely to be without their captain, Ashley Williams, who is struggling with an ankle problem. Stuart James

These sides enjoyed midweek Capital One Cup wins against lower-league opposition and although Stephen Ireland went off injured having scored for Stoke against Tranmere – his first goal in almost two years – he is expected to return in time for Sunday's match. Gary Hooper found the net twice for Norwich against Watford and may now make his first Premier League start for the visitors. Jonny Weeks

Not too many would have predicted Hull sitting comfortably in mid-table at any point this season but that is exactly where they are after accruing seven points from their first five games. West Ham have struggled somewhat for goals so far, but have coped well defensively, particularly away from home where both of their games so far have ended goalless. An edgy game with few goalscoring opportunities at either end would not be too much of a surprise. Simeon Gholam

Having secured victory over West Ham last week with two stunning Leighton Baines free-kicks, Everton remain the only team in the Premier League yet to be beaten. From the poignant Hillsborough tribute before kick-off to Demba Ba's dramatic last-gasp equaliser, this fixture was one of last season's unforgettable games. Now, with Roberto Martínez attempting to adapt Everton's style of play attractively and with Newcastle having the joint second leakiest defence in this season's Premier League, an entertaining affair should be on the cards. Simeon Gholam

Tuesday's victory over Everton in the Capital One Cup relieved some of the pressure on Martin Jol, whose job is said to be in jeopardy following an unconvincing run of form. By coming from behind to win, Fulham showed the bite and balance that critics have accused them of lacking, and the likes of Adel Taarabt, Darren Bent and Dimitar Berbatov moved closer to full fitness. But that was against a weakened Everton side and Fulham will have to raise their performance even higher to prevail against a Cardiff team that have already demonstrated their determination to stay in the top flight. Shahid Khan will be watching closely. Paul Doyle

This game would be intriguing enough without José Mourinho and André Villas-Boas coming up against each other for the first time since a once close relationship fractured. The north London derby aside, this campaign to date has been a real show of strength from Tottenham, a miserly defence and powerful midfield bullying opponents into submission. Chelsea will be braced for another stern test and, with Juan Mata back in contention, will still hope Ramires passes a late fitness test. Dominic Fifield

Luis Suárez's first Premier League game since his biting ban; Simon Mignolet's return to Wearside; Sunderland caretaker manager Kevin Ball's big audition for the vacancy as Paolo Di Canio's successor. There are sub-plots galore but do not be surprised if Lee Cattermole attempts to provoke Suárez as the home side – without their key striker, Steven Fletcher – seek to improve on a woeful tally of one point in five games. They could probably do without Mignolet reminding them of his goalkeeping brilliance. Louise Taylor

Southampton's win at Liverpool last Saturday was an unexpected but welcome bonus; now for the seemingly routine task of the visit of Crystal Palace. Yet the home side should not take victory over Ian Holloway's team, depleted by injuries, for granted given that their first two matches at St Mary's have seen them draw with Sunderland and West Ham. Mauricio Pochettino could do with £14.6m striker Daniel Osvaldo breaking his duck. Jacob Steinberg

Tottenham have a number of concerns after their exertions in the Europa League on Thursday night and in addition to definite absentees Étienne Capoue and Aaron Lennon, they could be without Nacer Chadli, Mousa Dembélé, Younes Kaboul and Danny Rose as well. Cardiff will look to take advantage of any weakness shown by the visitors, as they did less than a month ago against Manchester City. Rich Flower

A change of setup may be in order for West Bromwich Albion on Saturday – they are the only side in the division to have started every match in a 4-4-2 formation and it has brought them just two points and one goal so far. Stéphane Sessègnon should bring more creativity and could make a first Albion start against his former club who are propping up the table after a disastrous beginning to the season. Rich Flower

Paul Lambert returns to the club that he left under a cloud a year ago and while he believes that "the fans have always been good with me", the Aston Villa manager still harbours bitterness towards the Norwich hierachy over his departure. Lambert will be eager to prove his point by getting a good result at Carrow Road but he will have to do so without Jores Okore – Ciaran Clark is expected to step in. Rich Flower

José Mourinho's second coming has been a splutter to date, the period of adaptation rather too error-strewn for comfort. The visit of local rivals in Fulham, without a win at Stamford Bridge in 34 years and labouring this term, would normally constitute an opportunity for light relief, but it is hard to predict what Chelsea will muster these days. Four winless matches have raised the stakes already. Martin Jol's side will take encouragement from Basel's midweek success here as they seek to kick-start their own campaign, with their former Chelsea midfielder, Steve Sidwell, having opened talks over a new deal at the club. Dominic Fifield

Striker Romelu Lukaku could make his Everton debut. Lukaku was one of the players Sam Allardyce sought to sign for the Hammers during the summer, before a final-day swoop from Roberto Martínez took the Belgian to Merseyside. Both Darron Gibson and Arouna Koné could also feature following knee injuries. Joe Cole, Stewart Downing and Andy Carroll are all out for the Hammers. Jonny Weeks

Having notched their 10th consecutive away win in Marseille, Arsenal return home. Making his Emirates debut, Mesut Özil will again be the star turn, although the potential return of Mikel Arteta from injury is also of note. Stoke, for so long Arsène Wenger's bete noire, arrive in north London in good form and with a growing sense that they are evolving under Mark Hughes. Sachin Nakrani

Crisis what crisis? Alan Pardew is currently doing rather well for someone who was supposed to be a dead man walking. Newcastle have seven points from four games, are playing some pleasing attacking football and could gain further momentum here. As a former Sunderland manager, Hull's Steve Bruce – a boyhood Newcastle fan – can expect a particularly hot reception. Newcastle's Vurnon Anita, currently keeping Cheick Tioté benched, aims to impress once again. Louise Taylor

For the 166th Manchester derby United arrive at the Etihad Stadium with the same tally of points as City. While this indicates stuttering domestic form, Tuesday evening's Champions League group games provided confidence boosts for both teams, with Manuel Pellegrini's side winning 3-0 and David Moyes's 4-2. The Scot can be content with the way Wayne Rooney has started the campaign – three goals and a fresh focus – while his Chilean counterpart will be pleased at how his first-choice strikers, Sergio Agüero and Edin Dzeko, each scored on Tuesday. The cliche states that form is out the window for this occasion so picking a winner is foolish but there is sure to be incident. Jamie Jackson

Liverpool have never topped the Premier League after five matches but victory will deliver their highest points tally at this stage since the competition began in 1992. Creativity could be an issue with Philippe Coutinho injured and Luis Suárez serving the final game of his 10-match ban but in Daniel Sturridge they have a striker out to match John Aldridge's 1987 record of scoring in the first five league matches of a season. Southampton have not won since the opening day but were the last team to beat Liverpool, back in March. Andy Hunter

From the Mestalla to Selhurst Park. Thursday night's demolition of Valencia will have Swansea oozing confidence and Palace, having beaten Sunderland in their last home game, need to be ready to exploit any fatigue in what will be City's third match in seven days. The last time the Swans visited, in 2010, defeat left Palace bottom of the Championship. Both have come a long way since. John Ashdown

What a difference a year makes. After three games last season West Bromwich Albion were in third place but now they lie bottom with a solitary point and are the only team in the division yet to score. With no Romelu Lukaku or Peter Odemwingie to turn to, Steve Clarke will be hoping that his expensive new recruit Victor Anichebe can produce something against a Fulham side who have also endured a difficult start to the new campaign. Rich Flower

Hull and Cardiff have goalkeeping doubts ahead of their encounter at the KC Stadium. David Marshall sustained a hip injury while with Scotland and Allan McGregor missed the same World Cup qualifiers with a groin problem. The past four matches between these sides have produced 13 goals so Steve Bruce and Malky Mackay will both be hoping to have their first choice No1 available. Rich Flower

Both clubs were busy in the transfer window but while Chris Hughton did most of his business before the season began, Tottenham were forced by circumstance to leave things later. Erik Lamela and Christian Eriksen are expected to start for the hosts following their last-minute arrivals and they could come up against Gary Hooper, who joined Norwich on 26 July but has yet to feature after an injury in pre-season. Rich Flower

West Ham's plans have been thrown into disarray by Andy Carroll's latest setback after the luckless £15m forward suffered a potentially serious foot injury after returning to training this week and it is unknown when he will feature again, forcing Sam Allardyce to sign Mladen Petric on a free transfer. While they wonder where the goals are coming from, Southampton have a wealth of options in attack, although Mauricio Pochettino must find a way of getting the best out of Rickie Lambert and Dani Osvaldo. Jacob Steinberg

With Valencia on Thursday, will Swansea's Europa League adventure prove to be a Premier League distraction? The fans may prefer a long cup run, but the club need only look to Newcastle to see how European ambition can endanger top-flight status. Liverpool have no such distractions, and after sitting out England duty, Daniel Sturridge should be fit as they seek to preserve their 100% record. Toby Moses

Four points from Manchester United's opening three outings is a modest return as David Moyes embarks on a debut season as their manager. A home game against Crystal Palace in the weekend's opening fixture appears a banker to secure victory for only the second time, with United having lost 1-0 at Liverpool in their previous game. But Ian Holloway's side arrive with confidence high having beaten Sunderland 3-1 last time out and Moyes will be without Wayne Rooney as his head injury continues to heal. Jamie Jackson

A battling victory over Arsenal on the opening day is all that Paul Lambert's team have to show for their fine start to the season. Narrow defeats by Liverpool and Chelsea are nothing to be ashamed of but Villa need points from games like this if they are to avoid a relegation fight. Of course, the same could be said for Newcastle, who welcome back Yohan Cabaye to the starting lineup. Toby Moses

Manuel Pellegrini is in his early days as Manchester City manager but already there is some pressure on the Chilean following a start to a campaign in which his side lost at Cardiff and scraped to victory over Hull. He will be particularly keen on winning this game, then, as will Mark Hughes given his bitter history with City. Stevan Jovetic could make his first appearance for the visitors. Sachin Nakrani

Mesut Özil may make his Arsenal bow following his £42.5m move from Real Madrid but Sunderland have a midfield debutant of their own. Ki Sung-yueng, a South Korean loaned by Swansea, is earmarked for a key central role as Paolo Di Canio resists the temptation to switch to 4-5-1 against Arsène Wenger's side and instead retains faith with a more adventurous 4-4-2 configuration featuring two wingers in a frequently four-pronged attack. Louise Taylor

One month of the season has gone yet with Everton immersed in late transfer sagas and Chelsea involved in the Uefa Super Cup, their campaigns are only just beginning. Samuel Eto'o, Willian, James McCarthy and Gareth Barry could make their debuts for their new teams, though Everton loan signing Romelu Lukaku is ineligible to face his parent club as Roberto Martínez seeks his first league win at Everton. Chelsea were the only team to win at Everton in the league last season and their quality on the counterattack could punish Martínez's side. Andy Hunter

It has not exactly been the ideal start to the season for West Bromwich Albion or Swansea. Albion have yet to score, or spend a penny in the transfer market, while Swansea are still searching for their first point after tough opening fixtures against Manchester United and Tottenham. Although Nicolas Anelka is back in the Albion squad after returning from compassionate leave, Ben Foster and Matej Vydra are injured. Wilfried Bony, Ashley Williams and Jonjo Shelvey are all available for Swansea after missing Thursday's Europa League game in Romania. Stuart James

Mark Hughes has never won at Upton Park as a manager, losing four and drawing one of his five visits, but he knows he needs to improve Stoke's away form. Last week's victory over Crystal Palace showed they remain a formidable proposition at home but they only won twice on their travels last season. It will not be easy against Sam Allardyce's unbeaten West Ham side, however, although the hosts are still without the injured Andy Carroll. Jacob Steinberg

After their stunning win against Manchester City last week, Cardiff will be looking to maintain momentum against an Everton side that have drawn their opening two games of the season. The visitors have lacked a cutting edge and almost lost to Stevenage in the Capital One Cup in midweek. Uncertainty also surrounds the future of Leighton Baines and Marouane Fellaini. Charlotte Trundley

Arsenal dare not lose this one. After the outcry that followed the home defeat to Aston Villa, the wrong result here would lead to meltdowns. Arsène Wenger's team has stabilised with wins over Fenerbahce and Fulham but Tottenham represent a tough proposition. There is form and momentum behind them, fired in no small measure by their lavish summer transfer spend. The loss of Gareth Bale has not brought doom and gloom. It is Arsenal who are desperate for a tonic. David Hytner

Having suffered a shock defeat to Cardiff, Manchester City will want to get back to winning ways in this match. The hosts' defending will have to be better than it was in the Welsh capital last week, although perhaps not necessarily at its best given they face a Hull side that has scored just once in their opening two games and that a penalty in last week's win against Norwich. Charlotte Trundley

With a combined summer expenditure of over £65m, these teams are hoping to catch the eye this season. Southampton have begun well and are likely again to turn to their record signing Pablo Osvaldo after he came on as a subsitute against Sunderland last week. Having succumbed to 10-man Hull last week, Norwich will be keen to finish the afternoon with a victory. Charlotte Trundley

On a day the Kop displays a mosaic to mark 100 years since the birth of Bill Shankly, another Scottish manager will look to make an impact at Anfield. David Moyes never won there as Everton manager but, now able to call on Robin van Persie, will fancy his chances more than ever. The hosts are on a good run, however, and in Daniel Sturridge have their own in-form, clinical striker. Sachin Nakrani

Both teams are still looking for their first win of the season, with Paolo Di Canio keen for Sunderland to kickstart their campaign in order to avoid last year's relegation worries. Ian Holloway, meanwhile, has bemoaned the lack of Crystal Palace's signings this summer but can hope one new arrival, Marouane Chamakh, is in confident mood after scoring at Stoke last week. Charlotte Trundley

It is safe to assume Damien Duff is no longer the Fulham player Newcastle fans most love to hate. Duff's disappointing displays during his Tyneside days pale into insignificance next to Darren Bent's double crime of once playing for Sunderland and rejecting the chance to join the hosts this summer. If Bent can expect a hot reception, Newcastle's unsettled Yohan Cabaye may receive a mixed one should he end his one-man strike by returning to action. Louise Taylor

According to André Villas-Boas, "the body is tired but the mind is happy, absolutely", following Tottenham's 5-0 Europa League thumping of Dinamo Tbilisi, and Swansea are in similar mood. They, too, scored five in the competition, against Petrolul Ploiesti, albeit at home, helping them a little in terms of time not spent travelling. The mission for both clubs is to prove that Europe will not sap them. This fixture was tight last season and Villas-Boas is anticipating more of the same. David Hytner

José Mourinho has suggested Chelsea will make a third bid for Wayne Rooney following this match, in turn surely affecting David Moyes's thinking in regards to whether or not to select the unhappy striker. Should Rooney be picked from the start it will be interesting to see the reception he receives from a home crowd whose patience has been stretched by the will-he-won't-he-leave saga. Jamie Jackson

Both teams suffered less-than-surprising defeats in their respective opening day games so will be hoping to use this match to put their first points on the board. In their last meeting Stoke won 4-1, but judging from their showing against Spurs Ian Holloway's men should put up a fight, and could include Jason Puncheon, who has arrived on loan from Southampton. Sophy Coombes-Roberts

The fresh sense of crisis surrounding Arsenal has been eased by their midweek win over Fenerbahce but there remains pressure on Arsène Wenger's side to win following their unexpected loss to Aston Villa. Fulham, who could hand a debut to Scott Parker, are not expected to triumph given they have won three of their previous 24 Premier League games against the visitors. Sophy Coombes-Roberts

Defeat at West Ham was not the best way for Cardiff City to prepare for the visit of Manuel Pellegrini's Manchester City, who beat Newcastle in the opening weekend's most impressive display. Yet a concern for the Chilean is his defence, where Vincent Kompany's groin injury leaves Joleon Lescott is the only match-fit centre-back. Saying that, most of the action should be at the other end of the pitch anyway, where Jesus Navas's blistering pace should help City to a successive win. Jamie Jackson

These are exciting times on the south coast. The arrival of Pablo Osvaldo, signed for a record-breaking £14.6m from Roma, indicates the size of Southampton's ambition, although the Italy forward will do well to dislodge Rickie Lambert, who scored the winner at West Bromwich Albion last week. Sunderland, hoping for a repeat of last season's 1-0 win at St Mary's, are already under pressure after the 1-0 defeat by Fulham, and Paolo Di Canio needs a swift response from his players. Jacob Steinberg

West Bromwich Albion's commanding start to last season must appear a world away to Steve Clarke. A 90th-minute home defeat on the opening day has been compounded by Nicolas Anelka going on indefinite compassionate leave following the sudden death of his agent, Eric Manasse. Shane Long assumes greater responsibility in an attack adjusting to life without Romelu Lukaku, while the on-loan Scott Sinclair could make his debut. Roberto Martínez takes his league bow as Everton manager at Goodison Park looking to build on last week's encouraging draw at Norwich, minus the costly defensive errors. Andy Hunter

Both teams go into the game looking for their first win of the season. New arrival Tom Huddlestone is likely to start for Hull as Steve Bruce looks for a side full of new recruits to get off to a good start in front of their own supporters. Norwich, meanwhile, will be hoping record signing Ricky van Wolfswinkel can replicate his goal-scoring impact against Everton last week. Sophy Coombes-Roberts

The good news for Alan Pardew is that former Newcastle striker Andy Carroll will not feature in a visiting side managed by Sam Allardyce. If Allardyce was one of the least popular previous occupants of Pardew's office at St James' Park, few on Tyneside underestimate the threat posed by West Ham. Particularly on an afternoon when Newcastle – with or without the unsettled Yohan Cabaye – need to exorcise Monday's 4-0 thrashing at Manchester City. Louise Taylor

As Liverpool's star striker remains suspended Aston Villa's continues to shine. Christian Benteke has scored three times in his side's opening two games, only adding to the sense that Paul Lambert pulled off a masterstroke by convincing the Belgian to stay put. Without Luis Suárez, Liverpool impressed in their victory over Stoke last week but they will want to be more clinical this time around. Sachin Nakrani

The home side's manager, Steve Clarke, believes his side are "better and stronger" than the one that ended last season in eighth place but they may struggle unless new arrivals Nicolas Anelka and Matej Vydra can compensate for the loss of Romelu Lukaku. Southampton may field new signings Victor Wanyama and Dejan Lovren from the outset as Gastón Ramírez and Maya Yoshida both made long international trips in midweek. Rich Flower

Can David Moyes do it? Can he continue the work of Sir Alex Ferguson, who turned Manchester United into a trophy-greedy juggernaut? The answer is this Premier League season's must-see show. Whether the unhappy Wayne Rooney travels to the Liberty Stadium and is part of his matchday squad is a side issue. Moyes's prime focus is to leave south Wales unbeaten – victory would be a bonus. Jamie Jackson

Much has changed for both of these sides since Cardiff won 1-0 at Upton Park on the opening day of the Championship season two years ago. While Sam Allardyce led West Ham to 10th place last term, Cardiff have been promoted as champions and have spent heavily before their first ever Premier League campaign. West Ham, who lost four times at home last season, will be without the injured Andy Carroll but Stewart Downing will feature after his £6m signing from Liverpool. Jacob Steinberg

Glory, glory be. Tottenham Hotspur have a match and so, for 90 minutes at least, the relentless Gareth Bale transfer saga can be pushed to one side. Unless, that is, the team lack pace, penetration and goals out of nothing. Then he will loom larger still, even as he stays away from Selhurst Park because of injury. Tottenham look to have too much for newly-promoted Palace but Ian Holloway's team will carry the fight. It should be fun. David Hytner

The mood around the Emirates on Saturday afternoon should be optimistic yet many of the grumbles of recent seasons could be evident given Arsenal's alarming lack of transfer activity over the past few months. This was meant to be the summer when the club spent big yet, as things stand, Arsène Wenger's only fresh recruit is the young French attacker Yaya Sanogo. In contrast, Aston Villa have been busy and, with Christian Benteke remaining in situ, Paul Lambert will be expecting his young side to have the maturity to avoid a repeat of last season's relegation fight. Sachin Nakrani

Manuel Pellegrini begins his tenure at Manchester City having declared himself "absolutely" ready for the Premier League following a calm pre-season. The serene Chilean, hired in part as a kind of anti-Roberto Mancini, acquired Fernandinho, Jesús Navas, Stevan Jovetic and Alvaro Negredo early in the window so has had all summer to integrate them, and himself, into the club. Against Newcastle, whose manager Alan Pardew has to contend with answering to the new director of football, Joe Kinnear, anything but victory would be a surprise. Jamie Jackson

Darren Bent, newly arrived at Fulham on loan from Aston Villa, is available to feature but the striker may not recognise his one former club. Paolo Di Canio, Sunderland's manager, says he has presided over a "complete revolution" this summer. Embracing much enhanced discipline and fitness it is intended to have given the team a "new identity" courtesy of more attractive football, played from the back and 10 new summer signings. Louise Taylor

For all the distractions caused by you-know-who, Liverpool at least enter the campaign with goals in their team and an established style of play after one season with Brendan Rodgers. Daniel Sturridge is back from an ankle injury ahead of schedule and may start in place of Iago Aspas, who struggled against Celtic's physical defence in Dublin last weekend. Stoke, by contrast, begin life under Mark Hughes with the same attacking options that produced only 34 goals last season – a tally bettered by every team apart from relegated QPR – and searching for a new identity after the exit of Tony Pulis. Andy Hunter

This is a game of returns: for José Mourinho to Stamford Bridge, and Steve Bruce and Hull to the Premier League. The visitors have never won in this corner of south-west London and, even bolstered by summer reinforcements, will arrive braced for an instant reminder of the gulf between the top two divisions. Chelsea have quietly added to their options, but Mourinho is the main attraction. He did not lose a home league game first time round. That sequence is likely to be prolonged. Dominic Fifield

Arguably one of the most intriguing ties of the weekend because of the wholesale changes that have taken place at both clubs this summer. Everton begin life under their new manager, Roberto Martínez, who is expected to adopt a different tactical approach to his predecessor, David Moyes. Norwich, meanwhile, have moved boldly in the transfer market and Chris Hughton could hand debuts to a number of new recruits including Gary Hooper and the Canaries' record signing, Ricky van Wolfswinkel. James Riach

A year to the day since they beat Blackpool in the Championship play-off final, West Ham have the chance to seal a top-half finish in the top tier. That is an admirable achievement and in stark contrast to Reading's campaign. They came up as champions but have endured a difficult time back among the elite, with a change of manager not stopping their slide towards relegation. There will be one happy face within the visitors' ranks, however – goalkeeper Alex McCarthy, who has just been called up to England's senior squad. Sachin Nakrani

There could be six goals apiece, three red cards and a streaker on a donkey during this match and it is still unlikely that the final focus will stray beyond Sir Alex Ferguson and the long goodbye he has been experiencing ever since announcing his retirement 10 days ago. This is the Scot's 1500th and final match in charge of Manchester United and he goes out on a suitable high – with his side as champions and chasing a club record 29 victories in a Premier League season. The hosts have already secured their best-ever Premier League points total (48). Sachin Nakrani

Sunderland are safe and they travel to London without a clutch of key players. But any notion that they might already have their minds on the beach has been scorched by Paolo Di Canio. The visitors will be up for this one and they will seek to derail Tottenham's Champions League dream which, admittedly, also needs help from Newcastle United. André Villas-Boas will rely on the noises from the crowd to keep him informed of Arsenal's fortunes at St James' Park and he will focus merely on the victory he needs. It will be tense. David Hytner

As rumours swirl around Martin Jol's future, his side travel to Swansea hoping to avoid the (relative) ignominy of finishing a solitary place above the relegation zone. Mid-table had beckoned, but a wretched run-in (eight points from a possible 30) may have the powers that be considering a Gus Poyet-shaped replacement for their Dutch manager. In contrast, Swansea end their centenary season celebrating a trophy, assured of at least a 10th-place finish and delighted with Michael Laudrup's first season in the job. Toby Moses

With Premier League safety comfortably achieved by both clubs, matters on the pitch take a back seat on Sunday as Southampton and Stoke find themselves embroiled in behind-the-scenes controversy. Rumours surrounding the future of Southampton's executive chairman, Nicola Cortese, and the manager, Mauricio Pochettino, threaten to spoil the occasion at St Mary's Stadium. While the visitors' internal ructions are focused on the players rather than the staff they could also have a damaging effect as plans for next season begin to take shape. Rich Flower

A match that for much of the season looked like a potential relegation decider has turned out to be something of a damp squib. Wigan's defeat at Arsenal on Tuesday night made survival a mathematical impossibility and ensured that their run of improbable escapes came to an end. At least the hosts can console themselves with the not inconsiderable achievement of winning the FA Cup and qualifying for the Europa League while Aston Villa will be looking to build on the steady improvement shown by Paul Lambert's youthful charges. Rich Flower

Injury to Tim Krul and Rob Elliot's suspension dictate that the 38-year-old Steve Harper makes a final, richly deserved appearance in goal for Newcastle United after 20 years at the club. Harper will be hoping to avoid a repeat of last season's fixture in North London when Arsenal prevailed 7-3. Indeed after conceding nine goals in their last two home games against Sunderland and Liverpool, Alan Pardew's team could do with keeping a clean sheet. Desperate to qualify for the Champions League rather than the Europa Arsène Wenger will have very different ideas. Newcastle fans, meanwhile, will be hoping against hope that this is not Fabricio Coloccini's final game in black and white. Louise Taylor

Try telling Jamie Carragher that nothing is riding on this fixture. After 16 years and 737 appearances for Liverpool, a total bettered only by Ian Callaghan, the Bootle-born defender will bring his outstanding career to a close against Harry Redknapp's relegated side. Anfield will pay homage and then worry about a defence without its dominant leader next season. Carragher will probably still be throwing his body on the line in stoppage time. The absence of Steven Gerrard, Luis Suárez and Daniel Agger did not disrupt Liverpool or Daniel Sturridge's fine form at Fulham last week and, for QPR, Loïc Rémy is available. Andy Hunter

This will be the last hurrah for both Rafael Benítez and David Moyes at their respective clubs, with each seeking to bow out on a high. Everton have never won at Old Trafford, Stamford Bridge, the Emirates or Anfield under Moyes, so, with Manchester United to come, this at least provides one last opportunity to break that duck. Chelsea will be weary after their midweek success in the Europa League, but they need another victory to avoid the possibility of a play-off for third place. Whether the interim manager braves a lap of honour in the aftermath is open to question. Dominic Fifield

Now that Roberto Mancini has been sacked by Manchester City thoughts turn to his replacement, with the current Málaga manager, Manuel Pellegrini, the strong favourite. First, though, comes the visit of Norwich City. Brian Kidd, who started the first half of his duties as City's caretaker manager with Tuesday's win at Reading, will want to complete these by beating Chris Hughton's side. If so the Blues will end on a respectable 81 points and what promises to be an intriguing summer for the club will begin in earnest. Jamie Jackson

Playing away at Manchester United in the Premier League is never easy, particularly when the host side are eager to send their retiring manager, Sir Alex Ferguson, out on a high in his last home match. Swansea will therefore be boosted by the news that their leading scorer, Michu, is likely to return, as are Chico Flores and Ki Sung-yueng. Less encouraging is the news that Michel Vorm has failed to recover from the concussion he suffered against Wigan on Tuesday, while Angel Rangel's troublesome calf continues to keep him out. Rich Flower

Tottenham travel to the Britannia Stadium to face Stoke knowing that their dream of qualifying for the Champions League is out of their hands. Chelsea and Arsenal occupy the third and fourth spots respectively and will have to slip up in either of their remaining two matches for André Villas Boas' side to have a chance of finishing the season in third or with a play-off place in fourth. Stoke have been tough opposition in recent seasons and they are unbeaten in their last four games against Tottenham, though three of those were draws. Alex Sutch

Four defeats in a row, the most recent of which occurred against bottom-placed Reading, means Fulham are not yet clear of relegation trouble, which seems remarkable for a club who, it felt, reached safety weeks ago. In reality, the hosts are unlikely to go down but they still want to stop the rot and will hope Liverpool are there for the taking. The visitors retain a slim chance of finishing above Everton, and given events surrounding David Moyes this past week may feel their neighbours are vulnerable to a late swapping of places. Sachin Nakrani

Norwich are not in turmoil, according to their manager, Chris Hughton, but they seem to be doing their best to throw away their Premier League status after looking fairly safe. A woeful run of just two wins in 2013 has left the hosts requiring a victory on Sunday to avoid the unappealing prospect of needing to take something at Manchester City on the final day. Albion have also endured a slump of late but with 48 points already accrued thanks to a storming start to the season, they can allow thoughts to stray towards their summer break. Rich Flower

David Moyes should receive a rousing and emotional send-off as he manages Everton for the final time at Goodison Park after 11 years of tireless rebuilding work. No trophies arrived on his watch but he restored pride and fierce competitiveness to a club that had lost both when he arrived in 2002. The fact Everton are now an appealing proposition to other managers is down to Moyes alone, and he will desperately want to say farewell with the victory that secures sixth place for Everton and another finish above Liverpool. Andy Carroll and Kevin Nolan will want to do something about that. Andy Hunter

Newcastle United felt a little sore that their January transfer raid on Ligue 1 did not yield the signature of Loïc Rémy. They felt that they were close to a deal only for the striker to be tempted from Marseille by the more lucrative personal terms on offer at Harry Redknapp's QPR. Newcastle could feel a brutal sting if Rémy were to derail them at Loftus Road, as a defeat may leave them needing to get something from Arsenal at home on the final day. This is their chance to secure their top-flight status and avoid any such trauma. David Hytner

With Chelsea chasing a top-four finish and Aston Villa keen to put any lingering relegation fears to bed as well as banish the memory of their 8-0 mauling at Stamford Bridge in December, there is plenty at stake here. Rafael Benítez will have one eye on Wednesday's Europa League final, with Demba Ba, John Terry and Frank Lampard all set to start against Villa. It also promises to be an emotional occasion for Stilian Petrov, who announced his retirement from football this week, 15 months after he was diagnosed with acute leukaemia. Stuart James

Who, back in August, would have guessed that Sunderland and Southampton would end this season under the management of Paolo Di Canio and Mauricio Pochettino respectively? Both were greeted with initial scepticism but have swiftly won over their new club's supporters in mutually impressive style. With neither side yet mathematically safe, a game Di Canio has dubbed "our Champions League final" possesses added edge. It will also be the excellent Danny Rose's last match for Sunderland before the on loan left–back – ineligible for next weekend's game at White Hart Lane – returns to Tottenham. Rose, whose future looks extremely bright, deserves a warm ovation. Louise Taylor

It has been a good week for Gareth Bale, what with him cleaning up on the season's individual awards as only Cristiano Ronaldo had done previously. But the Welshman intends to perform one more party trick in leading Tottenham to the victory that would appear essential for their Champions League hopes. Bale's stars seem to be aligned – this will be his 200th appearance in Spurs colours against the club where he began his career. Southampton are all but safe from relegation but are determined to finish with a flourish. David Hytner

Back in August, Paolo Di Canio, then managing League One Swindon, won a Capital One Cup tie 4-3 at Stoke City. The Italian, now in charge of Sunderland, hopes for a second win of the season against Tony Pulis's side that would virtually extinguish Wearside relegation fears. After successive victories against Newcastle and Everton, Sunderland were thrashed 6-1 at Aston Villa last Monday but Di Canio, who diagnosed his players as suffering from "the poison of complacency", has "guaranteed" there will be no repeat on a night when he must cope without the suspended Stephane Sessègnon. Louise Taylor

The focus ahead of this game is on Aston Villa's attempt to stave off relegation but it should not be forgotten that Norwich have won just one of their last eight matches and are not safe themselves. A Villa win would lift them above Norwich and the visitors should be in confident mood given their sensational 6-1 destruction of Sunderland. The hosts have not kept a clean sheet in six matches so Chris Hughton's biggest task will be finding a way to contain the physical presence and technical quality of Christian Benteke. Lawrence Ostlere

Wigan's attempt to repeat their perennial escape act continues at The Hawthorns and a victory is near imperative given the five-point gap that exists between the visitors and 17th-placed Newcastle. After this game, Roberto Martínez's side host Swansea before heading to Arsenal, and they will want to have gained at least a couple of wins before the final day meeting with fellow relegation candidates Aston Villa. West Bromwich Albion do not have much to play for given the six-point swing both above and below them, but will want to build on their 3-0 win at Southampton last week. Lawrence Ostlere

Not many would have predicted at the start of the season that West Ham would go into this fixture as the club chasing a top-half finish with Newcastle teetering on the brink of relegation. Alan Pardew's men are in woeful form having conceded 14 goals in their past five matches and scored just twice. They desperately need to win this match but come up against a West Ham side that have proved competitive against Liverpool, Manchester United and Manchester City in recent weeks despite little reward. Lawrence Ostlere

This has the distinct feeling of a Premier League dead rubber but Fulham still have much to gain or lose from their three remaining fixtures of the season. Martin Jol's side are 11th, just three points above Newcastle in 17th and two behind Swansea in ninth, and the prize money on offer for finishing as high up in the league as possible will not be lost on the home side. Nigel Adkins is still searching for his first win as Reading manager and will be keen to achieve that before embarking on a Championship promotion campaign. Lawrence Ostlere

The game is up for Queens Park Rangers in the Premier League but Arsenal will hope confirmation of relegation does not free the hosts of their shackles. Arsène Wenger's side must prevail to maintain their pursuit of a top-four finish. They will move third with victory, and will envisage Manchester United inflicting some damage on Chelsea's challenge at Old Trafford on Sunday, with the manager preaching confidence. "We have gone through a period that was very sensitive, but we are coming out of it now," he said. "Everything is here to have a great future." QPR's hierarchy might say likewise about the future at Loftus Road, but their fan-base will take some convincing after this year's traumas. Dominic Fifield

The Capital One Cup hangover appears to have well and truly kicked in for Swansea – Michael Laudrup's side beat Newcastle immediately after winning the trophy in February but have not won any of their six fixtures since. The motivation of finishing in the top 10 and improving on last season's 11th-placed finish is there for the hosts, and they face a side that may be distracted by their appearance in next week's FA Cup final. Roberto Mancini, however, is likely to want Manchester City to finish the season strongly. Lawrence Ostlere

A fixture which in recent years has been pivotal in the destination of the championship is this season of material importance only for Chelsea given Manchester United have already wrapped up the title. Still, this remains a Sir Alex Ferguson side and so the visitors should expect a stern test in their first match since reaching the Europa League final and as they continue their pursuit of a Champions League berth. Relations between Ferguson and Rafael Benítez remain frosty so it will be worth keeping an eye on the respective managers. Jamie Jackson

Liverpool have not finished behind Everton for two successive seasons in the same division since 1936-37 and will give themselves hope of keeping it that way with victory in this game. Their confidence is based on Everton's dreadful record at Anfield – David Moyes has never won there and their last away derby win came in 1999 – and the emphatic response to losing Luis Suárez. Philippe Coutinho shone in the 6-0 rout of Newcastle last weekend and the availability or otherwise of Darron Gibson could be key to nullifying the threat from the mercurial Brazilian. Andy Hunter

Arsène Wenger says he wants Robin van Persie to be "respected" but, in reality, it is not going to happen. Some Arsenal supporters are even threatening to turn their backs on the guard of honour that ushers in Manchester United and the returning Van Persie as champions. Yet it is also fair to assume they will be looking enviously towards their former hero. Olivier Giroud, signed to replace him, has not even managed half of Van Persie's total of 24 league goals this season and will be suspended after his red card against Fulham last weekend. Arsenal, trying to nail down a Champions League place, go into this match 21 points behind their opponents and have beaten United only once in the last 11 attempts. Daniel Taylor

Paul Lambert views this fixture as a chance for Aston Villa to "pull Sunderland right back in" the relegation battle. Paolo Di Canio's appointment has rejuvenated the visitors, who arrive on the back of successive wins against Newcastle and Everton, but a Villa victory here would put them level on points with the north-east club with three matches remaining. Craig Gardner, a former Villa player, is available again for Sunderland after serving a two-match suspension. Lambert, meanwhile, has no fresh injury concerns following Monday's 3-0 defeat at Manchester United. Stuart James

This game may not be one for the neutral but there will be plenty at stake in the Potteries. Both these teams are not out of relegation trouble, even after picking up vital victories against QPR and Reading respectively last Saturday, and Tony Pulis's men will be especially keen to win this fixture given they face a potential six-pointer against Sunderland at the Stadium of Light next week. If Norwich were to secure only their second away win of the season it would see their Premier League future for next year all but confirmed. Jamie Burton

This is a fixture that will be found on the Championship calendar next season. Defeat here will condemn the losers to relegation but even the winners will be down if Aston Villa beat Sunderland on Monday night. Both clubs are already making plans for life in the Championship, so this could be a day to give a few fringe players a chance to prove their worth. Queens Park Rangers will be without Andros Townsend, who has a hamstring injury, Adel Taarabt will have a fitness test on his shoulder and Bobby Zamora is still suspended. Stuart James

It is hard to tell which of these teams are sitting in the top half of the table and which, up until recently, were caught up in the battle for Premier League survival. Southampton are fourth in the form table, behind only Arsenal, Chelsea and Manchester United, with Jay Rodriguez and Ricky Lambert currently playing with an almost telepathic understanding in attack. West Brom, meanwhile, have won only one of their last six matches with their cause not helped by the ongoing absence of Chris Brunt and the suspended Youssuf Mulumbu. Jamie Burton

The dog days of Manchester City's failed championship defence are now about them closing the 16-point gap to Manchester United. James Milner, Sergio Agüero and David Silva are all in contention for this game having recovered from their respective injuries and, ahead of the FA Cup final against Wigan on 11 May, this encounter could be viewed as the first of three trial games for those hoping to be selected by Roberto Mancini for the showpiece. Sam Allardyce's men, meanwhile, should be in relaxed mode given they arrive in Manchester having all but guaranteed Premier League safety. Jamie Jackson

Both sides go into the match with their destinies for this Premier League season all but sewn up. Sixth-placed Everton are five points ahead of local rivals Liverpool and have pretty much given up hope of climbing higher and qualifying for the Champions League, after defeat to a rejuvenated Sunderland side last weekend. Fulham, meanwhile, occupy a comfortable position in midtable having not won any of their last four games and travel to a ground where they have never been victorious in the league. A change of fortune seems unlikely. Jamie Burton

Mark Clattenburg returns to officiate at Stamford Bridge for the first time since last autumn's infamous racism row with Chelsea eager to transpose the momentum generated by their midweek win in Basel into the Premier League campaign. Swansea would appear to be convenient opponents given they have managed a solitary league win from six matches since claiming the Capital One Cup. "If we can play with the same intensity as we played in Basel it will be difficult for anyone to beat us," said Rafael Benítez, who will ring the changes yet again with Gary Cahill and Demba Ba expected to start. Dominic Fifield

It may be late April but there will be no end-of-season feel to this contest. Wigan, in their 300th Premier League fixture, will be seeking the win they desperately require to ease their relegation fears while Tottenham remain involved in an intriguingly tight battle for a Champions League qualifying place. Wigan won at White Hart Lane in November but they will be fearing the worst given how Tottenham tore through Manchester City last week en route to a 3-1 victory. Gareth Bale could once again prove the difference. Sachin Nakrani

As Brendan Rodgers tries to fathom out how to cope without the suspended Luis Suárez, Alan Pardew endeavours to avert a crisis at Newcastle United. While a win would leave his side all but safe from relegation, anything less could see the Tyneside crowd turn on a manager who has not been forgiven for losing 3-0 at home to Sunderland a fortnight ago. "We're all a bit nervous," Pardew said. "This club needs a win, and after what happened against Sunderland we're going to have to produce a performance worthy of the black-and-white shirt". Louise Taylor

The title race is all over bar the shouting but if Manchester City lose here, there will not even be that, as their neighbours United will surely wrap up the championship with a home win over Aston Villa on Monday. City have found their form too late but it is Tottenham who need the points more urgently, in what is the tightest race for third and fourth places. André Villas-Boas gave his players a four-day break after the Europa League exit against Basel and he admits that Sunday's scoreline will vindicate the decision or otherwise. David Hytner

Reaching a first FA Cup final has made this a season to remember for Wigan but if they fail to escape from the bottom three then it will also become one to forget for the club. Roberto Martínez's side hit encouraging form recently but they have drawn and lost their last two matches and are running out of fixtures in their pursuit of safety. The visitors can take heart from how they performed in the midweek defeat at Manchester City but will be aware that on the same night, West Ham came close to beating Manchester United. Sachin Nakrani

Southampton have found form at just the right time this season, with a five-match unbeaten run that could prove crucial in their quest to survive in the top flight, while Swansea appear to have suffered a Carling Cup hangover since winning the trophy in February. With Europa League qualification already secured, Michael Laudrup's main concern could be motivating his players for the last few games, although the end-of-season lull does provide him with a chance to ease Neil Taylor back into the side after a long absence with a broken ankle. Rich Flower

Norwich will see this as an opportunity surely to put their Premier League survival beyond doubt and also banish any further questions about the Ricky van Wolfswinkel transfer into the bargain. Reading had an inspired display by Alex McCarthy to thank for a point against Liverpool in their last outing but before that they lost seven in a row have the look of a side who know they are doomed to relegation. John Ruddy could feature in the hosts' squad for the first time since suffering a thigh injury against former club Everton in November. Rich Flower

Rafael Benítez will finally get a warm reception as Chelsea manager, albeit from the Kop, when he returns to Liverpool for the first time as an opponent but there is more to Sunday's game than a popularity contest on the sidelines. The visitors need to consolidate a top-four berth before the exertions of a demanding fixture list take their toll, while former Chelsea reserve manager Brendan Rodgers has to prevent Liverpool's season petering out with a whimper with Everton six points ahead. The improving form of another ex-Anfield favourite, Fernando Torres, adds to the intrigue surrounding this strange reunion. Andy Hunter

This could be a pivotal weekend for those chasing Champions League qualifying places, with Tottenham hosting Manchester City on Sunday while, on Saturday, Arsenal face a Fulham side who have failed to win in three matches. Triumph at Craven Cottage and Arsène Wenger's side could move five points clear of Spurs, albeit having played two games more before Tottenham's City date. The visitors should at least fancy their chances of scoring against a team who conceded three goals against Chelsea in a midweek encounter. Sachin Nakrani

Stoke's victory over Liverpool on Boxing Day left the Potters in eighth place, three points ahead of Brendan Rodgers' team and two behind Arsenal. But since that win at the Britannia Tony Pulis's side have picked up only six points from 14 matches, the fewest in the Premier League by a clear margin. That has seen them plummet into the relegation scrap and while today's fixture cannot be labelled a six-pointer – QPR are surely too far gone for that to be relevant – it is for Stoke a vital opportunity to stop the rot before it is too late. John Ashdown

Newcastle have plenty to play for here. Alan Pardew will expect a positive reaction after the humiliating home defeat against Sunderland last Sunday and his players also need a few points to banish any lingering relegation fears. Newcastle, who will be without Tim Krul, Cheik Tioté, Fabricio Coloccini and Sylvain Marveaux, have won only once away all season, although this may be a good time to face an Albion side who have faded after a superb start. The hosts' Youssouf Mulumbu serves the second game of his three-match suspension. Stuart James

If Manchester City lose at Tottenham on Sunday afternoon, Manchester United's 20th championship will be confirmed with three points against 17th-placed Aston Villa. Whatever occurs at White Hart Lane, Sir Alex Ferguson has informed his players the aim is to win all of their final five matches so Paul Lambert's side can expect a difficult evening at Old Trafford. When United's teamsheet is issued all eyes will search for Wayne Rooney after he was replaced at West Ham during the week after a disappointing display in the 2-2 draw. Jamie Jackson

Paolo Di Canio finally gets to strut his stuff before the Sunderland crowd in his first home match in charge after opening his tenure at Chelsea and Newcastle. The controversial Italian has already secured a fair portion of adoration from those fans not interested in his politics after last Sunday's emphatic 3-0 win at St James's Park in the Tyne-Wear derby. While his mission is to keep Sunderland up, David Moyes's Everton still cling to faint hopes of qualifying for Champions League football so a draw is unsatisfactory for either team. Jamie Jackson

Newcastle's victory over Fulham last week means all the pressure is on Sunderland ahead of a potentially fiery Tyne-Wear derby. Add Paolo Di Canio into the mix and this becomes the most highly anticipated match between these two rivals for some time. Police have warned Newcastle supporters not to aim racist or offensive gestures at Di Canio, such as fascist salutes, and with Sunderland precariously placed above the relegation zone on goal difference alone, how the Italian would love a victory after a difficult opening two weeks as manager. James Riach

Harry Redknapp, fresh from "the cruellest last kick" he has suffered in football – Shaun Maloney's stoppage-time equaliser for Wigan last weekend – desperately requires a remedy at Goodison Park. QPR are seven points adrift of safety with six games remaining and face an Everton team needing a win for their own aim of European qualification. QPR's task is not helped by the return from suspension of Marouane Fellaini and Steven Pienaar, although they did win the corresponding fixture 1-0 last season. That seems an awfully long time ago. Andy Hunter

Short of a catastrophic collapse Southampton and West Ham are practically guaranteed a place in the Premier League next year but equally neither will want to rest on their laurels for the remainder of this campaign. The hosts come into this one having won their last three matches, against Liverpool, Chelsea and Reading, while West Ham are able to recall Andy Carroll, who scored twice in his last appearance for Sam Allardyce's side, the 3-1 victory over West Bromwich Albion at Upton Park a fortnight ago. James Taylor

With Wigan not playing until midweek, Aston Villa supporters will see this game as a chance to put distance between themselves and the team in 18th. Christian Benteke has scored 10 times in his last 11 games, while Gabriel Agbonlahor and Andreas Weimann have also been playing well of late. Fulham, meanwhile, were unlucky not to head south with at least a point from Newcastle last week and Martin Jol will not want to relinquish his side's position in the top 10. Dimitar Berbatov could again be a key man for the visitors. James Taylor

Norwich are drawing their way, painstakingly, towards safety and with what would appear to be a favourable run-in, they might consider anything gained at the Emirates as a bonus. Their following three matches are against Reading, Stoke and Aston Villa. For Arsenal, though, the equation is simple. Win and leap into the Champions League places. Jack Wilshere and Theo Walcott are fit again and it feels set up for Arsenal to turn the screw on wavering Tottenham. Arsène Wenger's team have found momentum at the right time. David Hytner

Stoke are dropping like a stone. They have won one of their past 13 league games and looked like relegation material against Aston Villa last Saturday. Sir Alex Ferguson, though, is taking nothing for granted. "It's still a difficult place to go to," the United manager said ahead of the trip to the Britannia, where the league leaders have won on three of their past four visits. Ashley Young is injured but Jonny Evans is available and could return to a United side determined to bounce back from Monday's defeat against Manchester City. Stuart James

Having lost their past seven Premier League matches, equalling a club record, Reading are likely to be low on confidence. Nigel Adkins will have to be at his inspirational best but they still have a slim change of avoiding relegation and can take hope from Liverpool's inconsistent form. Brendan Rodgers's team have lost at Southampton and drawn with West Ham in their past three games. However, they should not be lacking for motivation given this is their final fixture before the 24th anniversary of the Hillsborough disaster. Sachin Nakrani

Should Aston Villa win this game, then Stoke could consider themselves involved in a relegation dogfight as they would sit only a point ahead of Paul Lambert's side. Lindsay Parsons, Stoke's chief scout, has apparently admitted his dislike of the direct style of Tony Pulis's team, which led to an impressive reaction from the manager, who said he likes "strong characters" around him. Pulis must hope his players are strong against a Villa side who have scored more goals on their travels than they have managed at home, 17 compared with 15. Jamie Jackson

Bragging rights have been replaced by title ambitions between the red and blue halves of Manchester but sadly for neutrals this season's fight will not go down to the wire. Manchester United, having opened up a 15-point gap over their neighbours, are cruising to a 20th championship and all City can hope for at Old Trafford is a burst of local pride. Even so, United would be wise to not get too confident and to remind themselves of last season's 6-1 derby thrashing on home turf – if they have forgotten it all. City will undoubtedly be going all out for victory once again. Dean Rudge

Much has changed since Norwich's 4-3 victory over Swansea in December's reverse fixture. Defeat at Wigan last week means the hosts are well and truly in relegation trouble having tasted victory just once in their past six matches and found goals increasingly hard to come by. Swansea, meanwhile, travel to Carrow Road hoping to end their own poor run of three defeats on the bounce. February's Capital One Cup victory appears to have led to an inevitable hangover for Michael Laudrup's generally impressive side. Dean Rudge

Nigel Adkins is not fooling anyone with claims that he "has nothing to prove" against his former club. After a debut to forget versus Arsenal last week, Adkins will do everything in his power to make Southampton rue their decision to sack him and stem the rot that has seen Reading lose their past six games. Also eager to cement his credentials is Rickie Lambert, who has 14 goals in his past 31 appearances. For his manager, Mauricio Pochettino, the aim is to build on consecutive victories against Liverpool and Chelsea. Joshua Kaye

Everton remain in control of their Champions League destiny, which might surprise people in London given they have scarcely paid heed to the role of David Moyes's team in the shake-up. The feeling has been that Everton will tail off, yet their tenacity, allied to their undoubted quality, has been impressive. They have won their past three league games and what they need to do now is win the final eight, including trips to Tottenham, Arsenal and Chelsea. They will fancy their chances against a Spurs side missing key personnel and fighting end-of-season-slump gremlins. David Hytner

Only Reading have lost more Premier League away games this season than West Ham, and Sam Allardyce's side – minus the ineligible Andy Carroll against his parent club – will require a major transformation to upset a Liverpool team enjoying their best run of the campaign with four wins in five matches. Brendan Rodgers's men have scored 20 goals in their past six home league games, have averaged three per game in their past six in total and have scored more at this stage of a campaign (59) than in any of the past 17 seasons. Andy Hunter

European concerns sit firmly at the forefront of Steve Clarke's and Arsène Wenger's minds ahead of this match. West Bromwich Albion are not far behind the Merseyside duo wrangling for a Europa League spot and will at least want to secure their highest Premier League finish. Arsenal, meanwhile, want the win that would put them in the top four for 24 hours at least. With the visitors still missing Theo Walcott and Jack Wilshere due to injury and West Brom having won their last two home games, the outcome of this game is far from obvious. Joshua Kaye

While all the attention has focused on their noisy new Italian neighbour just down the road at Sunderland, the fact Newcastle are only two points better off than Paolo Di Canio's team has not escaped Alan Pardew. With Sunderland visiting St James' Park next Sunday, the Newcastle manager has dubbed this fixture a "must win" game. In an attempt to minimise post-Europa League fatigue, Newcastle stayed in Lisbon on Thursday night following their 3-1 defeat at Benfica rather than flying back to Tyneside in the early hours of Friday morning. Louise Taylor

Last Monday's error-strewn defeat at Fulham prompted Harry Redknapp to state that Queens Park Rangers needed 14 points from their last seven games to avoid relegation. That target offers QPR a little wriggle room but should they lose this game then the lights can pretty much be turned out on their survival hopes. This is a "six-pointer" the hosts simply must win and it will not do their brittle confidence much good to know Wigan have won three of their past four games. QPR must hope Wigan minds are more focused on next week's FA Cup semi-final with Millwall. Sachin Nakrani

The focus up to now has been on whether Paolo Di Canio represents an acceptable appointment as Sunderland's manager on the basis of his political views, though this will offer a first indication as to whether he merits the position on footballing grounds. His is a daunting debut, even if Chelsea will presumably be much changed again from the lineups that beat Manchester United and Rubin Kazan this week. The Wearsiders, a solitary point clear of the cut-off, will crave some reward given that a derby with Newcastle and a visit from Everton await. Di Canio might already feel scorched by the reaction to his arrival. This will be another baptism of fire. Dominic Fifield

Bobby Zamora is fit and Harry Redknapp could do with a goal from the former Fulham striker against Martin Jol's side. Bottom of the league and seven points adrift of 17th-placed Aston Villa, QPR need to win but neighbours boasting Dimitar Berbatov up front and the confidence stemming from beating Tottenham in their last game look far from ideal opponents. Redknapp, though, is confident that this meeting can kick-start a QPR revival. "I'd be worried if performances were bad," he said. "But we're playing well." Louise Taylor

After their recent 2-0 win against Manchester City, Everton find themselves within two points of fifth-placed Arsenal – but they need to win more of these types of games. Last time they met Stoke it ended in a 1-1 draw, one of 12 Toffees draws this season. Everton's attack is weakened without suspended duo Steven Pienaar and Marouane Fellaini. Stoke are comfortable in 11th position, but there have been grumblings, with Tony Pulis's side having lost four of their last six away matches, and have only won one in 11. Mikkel Mousten

After two successive losses against West Brom and Arsenal, Swansea look set for a midtable finish after their glorious Capital One Cup run. Meanwhile, André Villas-Boas is hoping to maintain the distance between Spurs and rivals Arsenal. Like Swansea, Spurs have lost the last two matches, to Liverpool and Fulham, and are desperate for a win to dispel any notions of another end of season wobble. Jan Vertonghen scored the decisive goal in the 1-0 win at White Hart Lane, and another narrow victory would do today. Mikkel Mousten

Not for the first time Wigan finds themselves fighting to stay in the Premier League, needing a series of wins to escape the bottom three. Victory here will bring them closer to fourth-from-bottom Aston Villa. However, the last time the two sides met Norwich beat the Latics 2-1 at Carrow Road. With five draws in their last seven matches Norwich are also in need of a win to keep them clear of the relegation dogfight. Norwich still have to play against four more of the bottom six teams, so could yet be dragged into it. Mikkel Mousten

The last time these sides met Arsenal came out with a comfortable 5-2 win, although they had to battle back from four goals down when they made the same trip in the League Cup. Arsenal have now had just one defeat in seven and are going into the match four points behind Tottenham, with a game in hand in the race for the top four. Nigel Adkins takes charge of his first Reading game desperate to keep them in the Premier League, but Reading have lost their last six games and are seven points adrift of Aston Villa. Mikkel Mousten

The first of four games in three competitions this week for Chelsea will inevitably see some degree of rotation in Rafa Benítez's side. However, with Tottenham and Arsenal still within touching distance, Chelsea cannot afford to take it easy if they are to secure a top-four finish. John Terry is likely to take part, with Gary Cahill not expected to be fit until Monday's FA Cup quarter-final. Southampton too are far from safe, four points clear of relegation and Wigan, famed for their late-season heroics, still have a game in hand. Toby Moses

When Villa won at Liverpool in December it was felt a corner had been turned under Paul Lambert. It proved a false dawn but victory against QPR two weeks ago kept the Midlands side just above the relegation zone amid further talk of a belated renaissance. It is a year since Villa fans learnt that their captain, Stilian Petrov, was suffering from acute leukaemia and Lambert has marked the anniversary by revealing the Bulgarian midfielder, whose contract runs out this summer, will be offered a youth coaching job next season. Louise Taylor

With tricky fixtures to come in April against Liverpool, Manchester City and Manchester United, as well as an awkward trip to Southampton, Sam Allardyce will be looking for maximum points at Upton Park to halt any lingering relegation fears. He welcomes back Kevin Nolan from a broken toe and needs his captain to hit form immediately if they are to breach a stubborn West Brom defence. Steve Clarke's side have the incentive that a win will lift them above his former team Liverpool, who don't play until Sunday. Toby Moses

Vincent Kompany and Roberto Mancini will both pray the Manchester City captain emerges from this game unscathed. For Kompany any set-back following his return from a lingering calf problem would be a personal disaster given his manager's plea not to play for Belgium. For Mancini, City's chances of finishing second and winning the FA Cup recede if Kompany goes down. If he should, expect Mancini to explode, and it may just be in public. So keep an eye out for post-game interviews following the Newcastle's visit. Jamie Jackson

Sunderland trust Sir Alex Ferguson will field a weakened side for a fixture scheduled only 48 hours before United's FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea at Stamford Bridge. Martin O'Neill's problem is that they are adept at coping well with heavy rotation. Even so, Ferguson's preoccupation with besting Rafael Benítez on Easter Monday means this is a less bad than usual time to meet the league leaders. After no wins in seven games relegation fears are mounting on Wearside but a point today could alter the mood dramatically. Louise Taylor

Tony Pulis, after this week's sacking of his Reading counterpart Brian McDermott, is feeling sensitive to the plight of the Premier League manager. "It's a very fickle world where there's not a lot of common sense used. But it's a world that we live in and a world we have to work in," he said. Pulis's side have lost their last three games. Nine points separate Stoke from the relegation zone so a win against the normally obliging West Bromwich Albion would help appease fans who feel Pulis should be the next head to roll. James Callow

Southampton's forward line is a point of strength but Mauricio Pochettino was still disappointed to have missed out on signing Philippe Coutinho from Internazionale in January. The Brazilian, who had a loan spell under Pochettino at Espanyol, signed for Liverpool and is likely to be in opposition at St Mary's on Saturday. "Coutinho has that same quality that Ronaldinho and Messi have, but he has much to prove yet," said Pochettino. Despite recent progress, so too do Liverpool, whose record on the south coast is wretched. James Callow

Roberto Martínez will look to kick-start a league fightback by building on Wigan's recent FA Cup success against Everton. Martínez's side lie 18th, three points shy of Aston Villa in 17th position. "I do see it as the strongest fight out of the last four I've been involved in," said the Wigan manager. Still needing a couple of wins to steer clear of a relegation battle themselves, Newcastle will hope their in-form striker and Thursday night's Europa League saviour, Papiss Cissé, can add to his three goals in his last six Premier League games. Tom Clarke
