Tottenham have become synonymous with the jitters at around this time of the season and, after defeats by Liverpool and Internazionale, it would be easy to predict the reaction to another reverse. Yet Tottenham are a different proposition under André Villas‑Boas and the wobble will not turn into a meltdown. Besides, they played well at Liverpool and progressed over the two legs in the Europa League against Inter. Fulham feel that they need three wins to safeguard their Premier League status. Getting one here would be particularly sweet for Martin Jol. David Hytner

Having just ended a 101-year wait for major silverware, Swansea supporters could probably put Arsenal's current eight-year hiatus in perspective but this is no time for frivolity at the Emirates, despite Wednesday's impressive but ultimately futile win in Munich. Arsène Wenger's side have 10 games to haul themselves into the top four, and cannot afford a repeat of December's meeting in north London when Michu's late double earned Swansea a 2-0 win. Leon Britton and Luke Moore should be fit for the home side. Paul Chronnell

Roberto Mancini, determined to cut the points deficit ahead of next month's derby against Manchester United, will seek to change a dismal record against Everton. Mancini, who will again be without his injured captain Vincent Kompany, said: "We hope we can play [next month's Manchester] derby with nine, seven points, maybe 10. Less than 12 would be better." David Moyes will challenge his team to bounce back from the painful FA Cup defeat by Wigan. Tim Howard is still recovering from a back injury so Jan Mucha continues in goal. Tom Clarke

Another huge relegation battle for Aston Villa, who climbed out of the bottom three with a 2-1 win at Reading last Saturday. While that result has given Villa a timely confidence boost and opened up the possibility of winning back-to-back league games for the first time since May 2011, QPR are in good form themselves and will arrive in buoyant mood after defeating Sunderland and Southampton. With Fabian Delph still suspended, Paul Lambert is expected to name the same Villa side. Júlio Cesar and Adel Taarabt return to the QPR squad. Stuart James

Rafa Benítez has a rematch against the club that inflicted his first defeat as Chelsea manager on Sunday as his team face a West Ham side who are still without their captain, Kevin Nolan. Chelsea will have played three matches in a week once again and Benítez will be looking to make use of his sizeable squad. "There's no time to celebrate – the games are coming one after the other," Ramires, the Chelsea midfielder, said. West Ham are playing only their second game this month but are without a host of first-team players including, Mark Noble and Joe Cole. Matthew Taylor could feature after recovering from a recent bout of concussion. Tom Clarke

A group jolly to Cheltenham for Martin O'Neill's Sunderland squad was cancelled this week. With the club without a win in six games, having collected two points from a possible 18 and perched six points above the relegation zone, this seemed sensible. But Wearsiders will be heartened by Norwich's poor form, Chris Hughton's side having recorded one win in 10 matches. Sunderland will be eager to put one over the former Newcastle manager, with Manchester United, Chelsea and Newcastle next on the fixture list. Louise Taylor

After being knocked out of the Champions League by Real Madrid and surrendering a two-goal lead to Chelsea and scraping a draw to keep FA Cup hopes intact, a visit from a rudderless Reading team would probably be the first choice of Manchester United. This should be a regulation win against the second-bottom side who have just sacked Brian McDermott and are a yawning 48 points worse off. So the only hope for Manchester City, who trail United by 12 points, is to win in the early kick-off at Everton, then pray Reading pull off a footballing miracle. Jamie Jackson

The chance to climb from bottom place is on offer to Queens Park Rangers on Saturday afternoon and this really is the type of fixture the hosts must win if they are to avoid relegation to the Championship, a task that has taken on greater significance following the release of the club's most recent accounts, which show wages accounted for 91% of QPR's income during the 2011-12 season. Sunderland have not won any of their past five fixtures and have the feel of a team that is starting to dream about their summer holidays. Sachin Nakrani

Both these teams have 40 points and, with that minimum requirement easily achieved, their managers Steve Clarke and Michael Laudrup will not want their seasons to peter out early. Laudrup should be aware that problem has afflicted previous League Cup winners, but last weekend's victory over Newcastle suggests the Dane will not let standards slip despite European qualification already being assured. Clarke harboured similar hopes back in the autumn, but a winless January downsized his ambitions at The Hawthorns. Paul Chronnell

It's squeaky bum time at the bottom of the Premier League table. Reading take on Aston Villa, one point and one place below them, in a game that could have huge ramifications for both clubs. Brian McDermott's side have lost their last three but Villa, with one league win in their previous 11 matches, are not in much better shape. Stuart Taylor, a former Villa player, continues in goal for Reading in the absence of Adam Federici while Fabian Delph's suspension opens the door for Yacouba Sylla to make his full Villa debut. Stuart James

Luis Suárez and Gareth Bale can strengthen their player of the year claims at Anfield and their club's European ambitions in the process. Tottenham went third after winning the north London derby and secured a sixth victory in seven matches against Internazionale on Thursday. Bale has scored seven in the last five league games while Suárez has six in his last three outings. Liverpool have lost only one of the last 18 league meetings between the teams at Anfield and steady improvement has closed the gap on the Europa League places. Jamie Carragher is in line to make his 500th Premier League appearance for the club. Andy Hunter

An impressively organised display of intelligent defending earned Newcastle a 0-0 Europa League draw in Russia against Guus Hiddink's Anzhi laston Thursday, reinforcing the feeling that Alan Pardew's team are far too good to go down. Yet Newcastle remain in relegation danger and Stoke will hope the long flight back from Moscow in the early hours of Friday catches up with them. Tomorrow's outcome will determine plans for the home leg against Anzhi. "I need a win against Stoke to have the freedom to play a strong side on Thursday," said Pardew, whose team visit Wigan next Sunday. Louise Taylor

Last week's defeat to Queens Park Rangers was an unexpected setback for Southampton, who having looked like a team smoothly moving away from relegation trouble are now just three points above the drop zone. The Saints have played well under Mauricio Pochettino but two losses in a row mean the recently installed manager is under pressure. Norwich are also skirting with danger but remain something of a force at home. Victory in this game could see Chris Hughton's side enter the top half of the table. Sachin Nakrani

Sunderland will once again be without their captain, Lee Cattermole, as the combative midfielder continues to struggle with a knee injury and Martin O'Neill has admitted the 24-year-old may need to have surgery if an injection does not clear up the problem. Fulham, by contrast, could have Simon Davies available for the first time in almost a year after the winger overcame his own long-standing knee complaint. Fans should not expect too many goals on Saturday – the Stadium of Light has seen fewer than any other ground in the top flight this season. Rich Flower

West Ham travel to the Britannia Stadium without their captain, Kevin Nolan, out with a toe injury sustained in Monday's meeting with Tottenham. Both mid-table clubs will be hungry for a win, having lost their most recent engagements while the Stoke manager, Tony Pullis, has been talking down grumblings from supporters, claiming the club are busy putting in place an "infrastructure" while remaining in the Premier League. The hosts' defence will have to manage without Robert Huth, who was given a retrospective three-match ban after elbowing Fulham's Philippe Senderos. Henry Bodkin

The Liberty Stadium welcomes back the heroes of Wembley and no doubt the home supporters will be in jubilant mood ahead of kick-off. The priority for Michael Laudrup, however, is that his players remain focused and do not let their Capital One Cup success be a precursor to an end-of-season slump. Arriving in south Wales is a Newcastle side that has won three of its last four games and no longer appears consumed with relegations worries. It is a concern for the visitors, though, that their captain, Fabricio Coloccini, is out injured. Sachin Nakrani

Out of the Europa League and unlikely to make the Champions League, the danger for Liverpool is that they lack focus and motivation for the remainder of this season. Brendan Rodgers has urged his players to finish strongly, starting with this fixture, one which has surprisingly proved difficult for the Merseyside club in recent years. The hosts, yet again, find themselves in a relegation battle but will be boosted by their 3-0 win at Reading last week, not to mention the news that Daniel Sturridge is an injury doubt for the visitors. Sachin Nakrani

The QPR manager, Harry Redknapp, is expected to receive a hostile reception from the home crowd when his side visit St Mary's. Being in charge at Southampton when they were relegated from the top flight in 2005 could be forgiven, but leaving the club a few months later to return to Portsmouth was too much for many Saints supporters to accept. Redknapp has said he "will just get on with it" in the face of any abuse and he has more pressing problems to deal with – QPR are bottom of the table and without a win in six matches. A defeat on Saturday could make relegation unavoidable. Rich Flower

Tottenham have not finished above Arsenal since the 1994-95 season and this game should go a long way to determining whether they can break that pattern. André Villas-Boas's side currently have a four-point advantage over their rivals, they are also unbeaten in 11 games, and have Gareth Bale in the kind of form that made February's player-of-the-month award a formality. Arsenal, however, have won the last two north London derbies 5-2 and have a habit of catching, then overhauling, Tottenham at this stage of the season. Daniel Taylor

By the time this fixture begins Manchester City are likely once again to find themselves 15 points behind Manchester United. The chase is a taxing one but if last week's 2-0 victory against Chelsea is anything to go by, Roberto Mancini's side appear to have refound the battling qualities that made them champions. Their defence is sure to be tested by Christian Benteke, the spearhead of an Aston Villa side that remains in relegation trouble but can take heart from how they performed in the recent 2-1 defeat at Arsenal. Sachin Nakrani

West Bromwich Albion have become regular executioners for recent Chelsea managers, defeats inflicted at the Hawthorns having effectively done for André Villas-Boas and Roberto Di Matteo. Now the hat-trick actually appears on if Steve Clarke's return to Stamford Bridge yields a third successive league success. The atmosphere will be poisonous, the venom spat at Rafael Benítez after his midweek criticisms of fans for having "damaging agendas". Those agendas will feel all the more exposed now, particularly if Chelsea fail to secure a win to move them back into third, if potentially only for 24 hours. Dominic Fifield

Last week's late defeat at Norwich appears to have caused serious damage to Everton's hopes of qualifying for the Champions League and so David Moyes's team have no other option but to beat Reading if they are to maintain any realistic hopes of achieving a top-four place. It helps that Marouane Fellaini should be back from a knee injury and that the visitors, who are seeking to climb out of the relegation zone, are without the suspended Pavel Pogrebnyak. That could, however, lead to a start for top scorer Adam le Fondre. Sachin Nakrani

As Sir Alex Ferguson ponders the number of players he needs to rest ahead of Tuesday night's all-important meeting with Real Madrid, the Manchester United manager will be mindful of the pain surrounding his side's 1-0 defeat at Carrow Road last November. Optimism bolstered by that win, the Norwich manager, Chris Hughton, said: "There's a chance we can get something at Old Trafford. Our team will have no fear; we want to go there and play. Winning would involve us playing extremely well and United having one of their rare off days but we have hope." Louise Taylor

The Fulham manager, Martin Jol, has praised his counterpart at Stoke, Tony Pulis, despite the Dutchman describing Saturday's opponents as "like a rugby team" after the two teams met at the Britannia Stadium in November. "They play a style which is probably difficult for any team to play against," said Jol. "I like the people who make their choice and stick to their choice." The visitors are unlikely to alter their approach for the trip to Craven Cottage and the possible return of Marc Wilson after a long absence could provide a welcome fillip. Rich Flower

After home defeats by Blackburn Rovers and Bayern Munich, Arsenal's sole hope for a "trophy" lies in fourth place and a Champions League spot – win on Saturday and they will be one point behind Tottenham, whom they face next Sunday. The hosts have won their past two league matches in a most un-Wenger like manner, 1-0, but with confidence fragile Arsenal must prove they have the mettle to fight on after disappointments. Aston Villa have battled their way out of the relegation zone and are unbeaten in February, including an impressive 3-3 draw at Everton. Toby Moses

Emotions will be ripe ahead of kick-off as West Ham pay tribute to their former captain Bobby Moore through a minute's applause and the displaying of a mosaic depicting his old No6 shirt, yet it is vital the hosts remain firmly focused on the match itself. Sam Allardyce's side are in a poor run of form and, having looked like contenders for Europe before Christmas, now find themselves peering downwards. In contrast, Tottenham are in encouraging form and will be hoping Gareth Bale can once again inspire them to victory. Sachin Nakrani

Newcastle United have designated Sunday as "France Day" at St James' Park where the stands will be festooned with Tricolores. Fans are encouraged to wear fancy dress and strategically placed face-painting stations promise to reinforce the theme as the extremely Francophone club pays homage to Alan Pardew's imports. Controversially sacked as Southampton's manager in 2010, Pardew would revel in beating his old club. Mauricio Pochettino, though, will trust that Newcastle's players will still be tired after their long flight back from eastern Ukraine in the early hours of Friday morning after winning a Europa League tie at Metalist Kharkiv. Louise Taylor

A run of four wins and two draws has turned the Madejski Stadium into a formidable ground recently, yet Reading remain submerged in the relegation zone, one point shy of safety and only two points above the Roberto Martínez's side. Defensive midfielder Mikele Leigertwood had to be substituted after an hour of Reading's 2-1 FA Cup defeat at Old Trafford on Monday and is now a doubt for the visit of Wigan. Jimmy Kébé could return from a knock to take a place on the flank, though former Wigan striker Jason Roberts is still unavailable with a hip injury. Paraguay defender Antolín Alcaraz hopes to make his first appearance for Wigan since August, while Emmerson Boyce could also be passed fit. Jonny Weeks

West Bromwich Albion have an outside chance of a Europa League place, while Sunderland are still looking anxiously over their shoulder. Six points clear of the relegation zone, if they fall to a third straight February loss Martin O'Neill will once again have to answer questions about avoiding the drop. Steve Clarke's main dilemma will be over the inclusion of troubled striker Peter Odemwingie – he is yet to play since his ill-fated drive to Loftus Road, although the team did not seem to miss his presence in their win against Liverpool. Toby Moses

Everton need a win to keep the pressure on Arsenal above them and restore their six-point lead on rivals Liverpool, but a trip to Carrow Road is no easy task. Norwich have been beaten on their own turf by just three teams in the Premier League this season, boasting victories over Arsenal and Manchester United in that run, and the forecasted snow will only make the visit more arduous. Norwich have captain Grant Holt back from injury, while David Moyes needs Nikica Jelavic to rediscover last season's form, with Victor Anichebe a doubt. Toby Moses

This is the weekend of the big "if" in the Premier League title race. If Manchester City wake on Sunday to a 15-point deficit due to a Manchester United win at Queens Park Rangers the previous day then they know that if Chelsea beat them to confirm the margin it is surely all over for the champions in their quest to retain the title. However, if United (somehow) go down at Loftus Road then Roberto Mancini's side receive a timely boost and if they can beat Chelsea then the gap is closed to nine points, making the race interesting once more. Jamie Jackson

If results go their way, Manchester United could end the weekend 15 points ahead of Manchester City and the visit to Queens Park Rangers, who remain bottom of the table, should not present too many problems for the league leaders, although Sir Alex Ferguson will be without Phil Jones and Wayne Rooney. QPR are seven points off 17th and have not scored at home in the Premier League since Boxing Day, but at least Harry Redknapp has been cheered by the return to fitness of Loïc Rémy after his recovery from a groin injury. Jacob Steinberg

It was uncomfortable for Brendan Rodgers when Swansea visited Anfield in October and dismantled Liverpool's defence of the League Cup while supporters chanted "We don't need you anymore" at their former manager. It will be a lot worse should Michael Laudrup's team repeat the feat in the Premier League. Two losses in four days to West Bromwich Albion and Zenit St Petersburg have undermined talk of progress at Liverpool – though Daniel Sturridge, missing for both, will be back on Sunday – and Swansea arrive on Merseyside above Rodgers' team and preparing for next week's trip to Wembley. Andy Hunter

Every so often Aston Villa threaten to develop into a competent side. Last week Christian Benteke's brilliance had them 3-1 up at Everton but in the end their defensive failings meant they had to settle for a point. If they can sort out their problems at the back for the visit of West Ham, who have lost their previous four away matches, then they could have sufficient firepower to win in the league for the first time in two months. Much will depend on how Villa handle Andy Carroll, who is in good form after his return from a knee injury. Jacob Steinberg

Few Liverpool players have maintained as high standards as Jamie Carragher over a lean couple of decades at the club, but while his retirement at the end of the season will be much lamented, the club's manager, Brendan Rodgers, feels that Martin Kelly, another homegrown defender, can go some way to filling the void. Kelly, 22, has signed a new, long-term contract. Rodgers said: "Martin has shown a commitment to our vision here. He was exceptionally good in the games he played earlier in the season." West Brom travel eager to arrest a poor run of form and desperate to create headlines that do not revolve around Peter Odemwingie. James Callow

Adam Le Fondre broke new ground for a Barclays Player of the Month award winner when he scooped the accolade for January without starting a Premier League game, emerging from the bench for a total of 85 minutes during which time he scored five goals. Reading's 'impact sub' could be called upon again on Saturday as goals are bound to be at a premium against a Stoke side who have not won in the league since Boxing Day and who have failed to find the net 10 times this season, scoring a meagre 24 in total. Paul Chronnell

Manchester City will be hoping to have made a significant dent in their cross-city rivals' lead at the top of the Premier League by the end of this weekend. United have the distraction of the midweek meeting with Real Madrid and are likely to rest players, whereas City should be far stronger than in recent weeks, with Vincent Kompany and Yaya Touré decent bets to start against Southampton. Mauricio Pochettino has injury concerns over his full-backs but could hand Adam Lallana a first start since December. James Callow

With a nine-point cushion at the top of the Premier League, and Real Madrid to follow three days later, Sir Alex Ferguson will make several changes for Everton's visit to Old Trafford but United will not be short of motivation following last season's 4-4 draw with David Moyes' team. "It definitely cost us the league," rued Ferguson. Everton also inflicted a defeat on United at the start of the campaign and having struggled to recapture their early season form of late will need Marouane Fellaini recovered from a hip problem. Andy Hunter

Tottenham might have wanted this fixture before January. Back then, Newcastle were Newcastle and they were worried. Now, they are Neufchâteau, their mid-season shop having brought gifts from Ligue 1 and they travel to London with the fortification of back-to-back wins. Tottenham have problems up front. Then again, they have Gareth Bale and he may carry his threat in more central areas. Lewis Holtby is in line for a home debut as Spurs look to pull away from Arsenal and Everton, who have tough away fixtures. David Hytner

Martin O'Neill has warned his players to be wary of Jack Wilshere's influence in Arsenal's midfield. "Wilshere's come on in leaps and bounds and he can cause us problems," said Sunderland's manager. "He's come back from injury and added another dimension to his game. He's got that little burst of pace which kind of reminds me of Liam Brady." While a knee injury means Lee Cattermole is unlikely to be around to tackle Wilshere, O'Neill's team must also attempt to damage Arsenal's hopes of finishing in the top four without Connor Wickham. The England Under-21 striker has been loaned to Sheffield Wednesday. Louise Taylor

Locked together on 28 points from 25 games, both Chris Hughton and Martin Jol know that a couple of wins would help banish any lingering relegation fears. That is easier said than done when Norwich have not managed a league victory since before Christmas, while Fulham's season has yet to return to the heights of their 5-0 thrashing of the Canaries on the opening day last August. Grant Holt's lack of goals (one in his last 17 games) has not helped their cause, and the captain finding his form would be timely. Paul Chronnell

Glance at the league table and only one of the Spanish managers in the dug-outs at Stamford Bridge should feel under pressure though, this being Chelsea, such logic goes out of the window. Rafael Benítez, with his team third, can ill afford not to emerge victorious from this occasion after three wins in 10 matches in all competitions. More troubling has been the home form with one success in four games since Aston Villa were beaten 8-0 before Christmas. Wigan's only win at Chelsea came in the FA Cup in 1980. A repeat of that would have serious implications for Benítez's interim stewardship. Dominic Fifield

When these two teams met on the opening day of the season it was the appointment of Swansea's new manager, Michael Laudrup, that was under the microscope. But the Dane settled easily after the then unknown Michu scored twice in the 5-0 win at Loftus Road, and has guided the Swans to eighth place and a Wembley cup final. Life has not been quite so simple for QPR, who sacked Mark Hughes and made wholesale signings in August and January but remain bottom, as they will do even if they win on Saturday. Paul Chronnell

After the soap opera surrounding Peter Odemwingie's future, Albion will be glad to get back to playing football. They could also do with a decent result after a poor run. Steve Clarke's side have won two out of their past 13 fixtures in all competitions and picked up one point from a possible 15. Tottenham, in contrast, are unbeaten in their last eight Premier League matches, although The Hawthorns has unhappy memories for André Villas-Boas, who lost his job as Chelsea manager after a 1-0 defeat here last year. Stuart James

Burger salesmen may be quaking in their boots in north London as Nacho Monreal arrives at the Emirates, potentially sparking a new craze in half-time snacks. The Spaniard may go straight into the team in place of the much-maligned André Santos, while Mikel Arteta could also return. Although the perils of the Britannia Stadium may have caught the Gunners out in the past they have won their past 10 meetings with Stoke at home dating back to 1981. The Potters are without a win in five and have just one victory away from home all season. Phil Haigh

A hamstring injury has robbed Fulham fans of seeing their new hero Dimitar Berbatov face his former employers, leaving Hugo Rodallega with the bulk of the goalscoring responsibility. Goals look a likely prospect as United have managed only five clean sheets this season while Fulham have only four. Wayne Rooney is finding the back of the net again, meaning he and Robin van Persie will be looking to savage Fulham's soft underbelly. Home fans look forward to seeing the Holland international Urby Emanuelson, who is set to make his debut on the left wing. Phil Haigh

Martin O'Neill offered his unequivocal backing to Danny Graham on Friday, as he prepared to thrust the £5m signing straight into the squad. Graham, a childhood Newcastle fan, has made some less than complimentary statements about Sunderland in the past but O'Neill said: "I have really no doubts that he will score goals and he will prove a great buy." Reading invested in a new forward of their own recently and now Brian McDermott must decide whether to opt for Nick Blackman or give recent super-sub Adam Le Fondre a start. Rich Flower

The returning Paul Scharner is likely to go straight into the Wigan starting lineup as Roberto Martínez's injury problems in defence show little sign of abating. With Arouna Koné at the Africa Cup of Nations and Mauro Boselli out on another loan spell, the home side look short of cover in attack as well. Southampton, with two defeats in their past seven Premier League away matches – at Anfield and Old Trafford, both times by a single goal – can be expected to push Wigan's already stretched resources to the limit. Rich Flower

Harry Redknapp projects the air of someone who enjoys life's conundrums but selecting a team for this Saturday lunchtime fixture could vex even a man of his nous. This week Ryan Nelsen and Alejandro Faurlín have moved on, four new players have arrived of which at least two – Chris Samba and Yun Suk-young – are lacking match fitness. Redknapp must also reassure Jamie Mackie and Junior Hoilett, whom he tried to sell amid Thursday's self-inflicted day of chaos. Norwich seem serene by comparison, adding Kei Kamara and Luciano Becchio to their forward line. James Callow

A home defeat by Newcastle in midweek, combined with draws for Reading and Wigan, conspired to send Aston Villa to 19th place but manager Paul Lambert stuck to his philosophy of recruiting youngsters as the January transfer window closed. Whether the likes of Simon Dawkins and Yacouba Sylla can revive the visitors' season remains to be seen. While Everton also opted for an unproven player in the form of John Stones, David Moyes has the advantage of being able to count on experienced players at the club to help the 18-year-old develop, something that Lambert appears to be sorely lacking. Rich Flower

Soupe l'oignon, canard Coquille St-Jacques, sélection de fromages. C'est trop bon! So read the lunchtime menu at Newcastle United's training ground canteen on Thursday. With five new French signings and 14 French-speaking players at the club it is no surprise that Alan Pardew – sorry Alain Pardieu – staged a Gallic themed day ahead of a visit from Chelsea featuring Demba Ba's return to Tyneside. After scoring 29 goals in 54 league appearances for Newcastle, Ba deserves a decent reception but he might not be too well received after defecting south. Expect to see plenty of berets and tricolours among home supporters. Louise Taylor

Now is the time for Manchester City to go on a long run of wins. As the tilt at retaining their championship gets serious, the 2-2 draw in the reverse fixture indicates that Liverpool might not be the easiest side against which to start this quest. Until the draw at QPR on Tuesday evening, City had strung together four league wins on the trot, their best sequence of the campaign. Liverpool have not managed more than two consecutive wins this season yet they stand seven points behind fourth-placed Tottenham and still harbour hopes of Champions League qualification. Another draw would boost those prospects. Jamie Jackson

With only two wins in their previous 10 Premier League games, this is a crucial fixture for West Ham, who are seven points above the bottom three. They are boosted both by hanging on to Mohamed Diamé and also the return to fitness of Andy Carroll, who could start after coming off the bench during Wednesday's defeat at Fulham. Swansea, however, are unbeaten in seven and will be no pushovers – Michu will fancy ending a run of five games without a goal against a defence that has conceded 12 times in its past four matches. Jacob Steinberg

It has been a difficult start to the new year for both of these teams. Having surpassed expectation earlier in the season, West Bromwich Albion have slumped to three straight defeats, including last week's late, surprise collapse at Reading. Their problems seem relatively small compared to those at Aston Villa, however, with Paul Lambert's side having not won since mid-December. The visitors could at least be boosted by the return of defender Ron Vlaar. Maximum points would certainly be much welcomed from both camps. Ryan Grant

André Villas-Boas has not had a better moment in English football than Tottenham's 3-2 win at Old Trafford in September. It was their first victory over Sir Alex Ferguson's side in 27 attempts and gives them the opportunity to record their first double over United since the 1989-90 season. Spurs, however, have to make do without Emmanuel Adebayor, whose involvement in the Africa Cup of Nations leaves them with only one senior striker in Jermain Defoe. United, in contrast, have their full quartet of forwards available now Wayne Rooney is back from his knee injury. Whether Rooney is allowed to remain on penalty-taking duty is another matter after five misses so far this season. Daniel Taylor

Southampton's supporters who can beat the snow to attend Monday's tricky visit of Everton will still be baffled that they are not witnessing a team selected by Nigel Adkins. They are likely to be in open revolt, too, at the change in the dugout, with Mauricio Pochettino an unknown quantity charged with maintaining the team's encouraging recent form. Two defeats in 12 league games hardly suggests crisis, while a midweek draw at Chelsea would not normally be considered a sackable offence. Everton, competing for Champions League qualification, will provide a stern test of the new man's credentials. Dominic Fifield

Alan Pardew and Brian McDermott once worked together at Reading where Pardew, then the Berkshire club's manager, made McDermott his chief scout. "Alan paid me about £2.50 an hour, so he got his money's worth," joked McDermott who, having graduated to his mentor's old job, now brings Reading to Tyneside for what Pardew has dubbed "a relegation six-pointer". Danny Guthrie, formerly of Newcastle, will be anxious to prove a point in visiting colours. Pardew, meanwhile, says he "loves Brian to bits" but such affection could be tested should Reading depart with a point or three. Louise Taylor

Tony Pulis will be keen to guide Stoke back to winning ways with the team having picked up just one victory from their past seven games. That task will not be easy, however, given Stoke face a Swansea side who have tasted defeat at home just twice all season and are sure to be fresh given many of the players who were rested for Wednesday's 1-0 FA Cup defeat at Arsenal are likely to return for this one. Only one point and one place separates these teams and, for the winner, a Europa League spot should be firmly in sight. Ryan Grant

Home games are feeling like ordeals for Chelsea's players and their interim first-team manager. Aside from the poisonous atmosphere that has persisted throughout Rafael Benítez's spell at the club, the hosts have won only one of his six domestic games to date, with the team appearing on edge far too often at Stamford Bridge. Arsenal will at least not arrive intent merely on blanket defence, which should present space in which to play, but the visitors won 5-3 in this arena last term. Quite how the locals would respond to a similar drubbing this time around does not bear thinking. Dominic Fifield

Queens Park Rangers looked dead and buried after their 3-0 home defeat by Liverpool three weeks ago, but since then they have beaten Chelsea, drawn with Tottenham, reached the fourth round of the FA Cup and pipped Newcastle United to the £8m signing of Loïc Rémy from Marseille. The 26-year-old France striker is likely to go straight into the starting line-up at Upton Park, where West Ham have been strong this season. Home fans be warned, however – Harry Redknapp has an excellent record against his old club. Jacob Steinberg

Here is the champions' first chance to put pressure on Manchester United, with a win against Fulham cutting the leaders' advantage to four points until Sir Alex Ferguson's men kick-off at Tottenham Hotspur late on Sunday afternoon. Last week's heartening 2-0 win at Arsenal, Manchester City's first league outing in the absence of Yaya Touré, who is on Africa Cup of Nations duty, showed their resolve. Fulham are 23 points behind the hosts and have won only twice away all season, so this match should end with only one result. Jamie Jackson

Wigan are looking for the three points that could put daylight between themselves and the relegation zone. Roberto Martínez's side sit just one place above Aston Villa in 18th and while buoyed by last week's 1-1 draw at Fulham, the long-term injury suffered by defenderIvan Ramis during the same match has made their task of surviving the drop more difficult. Sunderland travel to the DW Stadium encouraged by last week's 3-0 home victory over West Ham but will be eager to forget their FA Cup third-round exit to Bolton on Tuesday. Rory O'Reilly

Liverpool need to start as they finished at Old Trafford and that should mean an Anfield debut for new £12m signing Daniel Sturridge, who will become the first player since Ray Kennedy in 1974 to score in his first three appearances for the club should he convert against Norwich. Brendan Rodgers also has a decision to make on Joe Allen in midfield and whether the time is right to rest Raheem Sterling. After a 10-game unbeaten run, Norwich have lost four and drawn one of their last five league games and have won away from home only once this season. Andy Hunter

Liverpool have not won a single game this season when they have faced teams from the top half of the table, losing five and drawing five. They are, however, in decent form as they prepare to renew hostilities with the Premier League leaders and a match that pits together the two most formidable strikers in the top division, Robin van Persie versus Luis Suárez. Wayne Rooney is still injured, according to Sir Alex Ferguson, while Daniel Sturridge is on standby for his first league appearance for Liverpool since signing from Chelsea. Sturridge, one imagines, has already endeared himself to his new club by describing them as the biggest in English football. Yet the two sides begin with a 21-point difference in United's favour. Daniel Taylor

Newcastle head into their first league match since the departure of top-scorer Demba Ba thankful that Papiss Cissé is fit to start after a thigh complaint. The Senegal striker needs to recapture the prolific form he showed after arriving in January last year, when he hit 13 goals in his first 14 appearances, if Alan Pardew's side are to arrest an alarming slide down the table. Norwich will hope that their own talisman, Grant Holt, is able to feature after hamstring trouble, although he too has been less prolific this season than he was in 2011-12. Rich Flower

Harry Redknapp insisted that revenge will not be on his agenda when his former team meet his current side at Loftus Road on Saturday. "I won't be thinking: 'It's Tottenham, we have to beat them,'" said the Rangers manager. "QPR are my club now, I'm not interested in Tottenham." Spurs have won seven of their last nine in the Premier League and will be confident of making that record read eight in 10, but QPR stunned Chelsea last time out in the league and could prise themselves from the foot of the table with a point. John Ashdown

This is a contest involving two buoyant sides, with Everton continuing to look like genuine Champions League contenders having won three of their last four games, and further boosted by Monday's 5-1 FA Cup win against Cheltenham, while Swansea arrive on Merseyside having beaten Chelsea at Stamford Bridge in the Capital One Cup. Another aspect linking these sides is the reported interest in their star players, with Marouane Fellaini and Michu catching the eye of a few leading clubs during the current transfer window. Sachin Nakrani

Fulham have won five of their past six games against Wigan (drawing the other), before which they had drawn five of their previous six matches against Wigan (winning the other). Wigan's current league form mirrors their recent run against Fulham – one point from six games. "I do feel the last three games we've played against Fulham we've been very unfortunate," insisted Roberto Martínez on Friday, when asked about the apparent jinx against Saturday's opponents. The visitors will miss Arouna Koné, who is at the Africa Cup of Nations. Simon Burnton

John Terry could return after a two-month absence – in which time Chelsea have managed just four clean sheets in 16 games – to take a place on the bench, as Rafael Benítez seeks to end England's last surviving unbeaten home record. He will be aided by the presence of Demba Ba, whose first visit to the Britannia Stadium, two years ago this week, saw him famously fail a medical, leading to Stoke pulling out of a deal to sign him from Hoffenheim. On his second visit, playing for Newcastle last season, he scored a hat-trick. Simon Burnton

West Bromwich Albion have lost their last two games yet remain one win away from a European qualification place, so it is unlikely they will come into this match feeling too low. Steve Clarke's men should certainly believe they can prevail over hosts who remain five points adrift of safety and appear incapable of stringing two wins together. Reading's supporters will be hoping new signings Daniel Carriço and Hope Akpan can improve their fortunes, and that the club's former striker, Shane Long, does not score for the visitors. Sachin Nakrani

Premier League visits to Arsenal have become a bind for Manchester City. The champions have not as much as scored at the Emirates in the league since DaMarcus Beasley's consolation six years ago, while their last top-flight win at the club was back in 1975 when Asa Hartford, Joe Royle and Rodney Marsh scored. Repeat that success and £62 a ticket might actually feel like a bargain as they attempt to stay in touch with Manchester United at the top. The hosts' ambitions are more sobering but they will need to respond if they start the day seven points off the Champions League places. Dominic Fifield

The Sunderland goalkeeper Simon Mignolet has made 120 saves this season, the most in the Premier League. West Ham have committed 253 fouls this term, the highest number of any team in England's top division. Statistics can be misleading but those two tell the story of two respective campaigns; while Sunderland's has been spent largely with backs to the wall, Sam Allardyce's players have, typically, fought for every ball. While neutrals will look forward to Joe Cole's appearance in a West Ham shirt once more, home fans are bound to boo Allardyce and Kevin Nolan, a former Newcastle manager and captain respectively. Louise Taylor

A bleak Christmas is turning into a bleaker new year for Aston Villa, who now not only find themselves struggling in the league but also on the verge of a shock Capital One Cup semi-final exit following Tuesday's 3-1 defeat to Bradford City. Confidence is low within Paul Lambert's squad but they must rouse themselves for this game given Southampton sit just one point and one place below them in 17th. The hosts could be boosted by the return from injury of Ron Vlaar while Southampton are definitely without defender José Fonte. Sachin Nakrani

Momentum is building at Tottenham. Their form is good, with four wins in five; they are beginning to play the way André Villas-Boas wants, and injured players are returning. The visit of Stoke marks the beginning of a festive programme that, on paper at least, promises points, although the visitors should not be underestimated given they are unbeaten in seven games. Gareth Bale returns from hamstring trouble but he will not face his old adversary Charlie Adam, who has been granted compassionate leave following the death of his father. David Hytner

Theo Walcott, whose contract saga continues to rumble on, could again start in a central attacking role for Arsenal at the DW Stadium after scoring in the club's recent 5-2 victory at Reading. Arsène Wenger has no new injury concerns and a win in Saturday's early kick-off would move Arsenal temporarily into third. Roberto Martínez, who Wenger believes has the potential to be a top-four Premier League manager in the future, has a selection dilemma after the defender Adrián López joined Wigan's already lengthy injury list. James Riach

Brendan Rodgers and his players "did not see that coming" against Aston Villa last weekend but at least they now know the cost of over-confidence at Anfield ahead of the visit of struggling Fulham. Martin Jol's team have won only once in nine league games and their midfield has been hit by injuries to Bryan Ruiz and Mahamadou Diarra plus a one-match suspension for Steve Sidwell. Liverpool were lethargic in the loss to Villa and the manager is contemplating a rest for Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen, among others. Andy Hunter

Whereas early season high-flyers West Bromwich Albion are in the midst of a slump, Norwich have turned their flagging season around with a 10-match unbeaten league run. Chris Hughton's side are now just two points behind the hosts, who registered their first point in four games against West Ham last weekend but continue to struggle for goals. They will be glad, at least, to hear Norwich could be without their top-scorer Grant Holt due to injury. These sides shared away wins last season and, judging by form, that trend is set to continue on Saturday. Sam Morgan

Victory at Anfield last weekend stretched Aston Villa's unbeaten run to five league games while the striker Christian Benteke has claimed four goals and three assists in his last five appearances to become an important component in Paul Lambert's side. Both he and Andreas Weimann could certainly trouble Chelsea's defence on Sunday. Rafa Benítez's men quelled suggestions of jet-lag with a 5-1 Capital One Cup win over Leeds United in midweek, but the Blues have not picked up three points at Stamford Bridge since the beginning of October. Liz Owen

It feels apt that three days after being drawn against Real Madrid in the Champions League, Manchester United should face a team that plays in all white and is managed by Bernabéu great Michael Laudrup. The focus, however, is very much domestic for the visitors as they look to maintain their healthy lead at the top of the table, a task aided by the return of captain Nemanja Vidic to the starting lineup for the first time since September. Swansea could themselves welcome back Michel Vorm, who has been out injured since October. Sachin Nakrani

Not for the first time David Moyes will have his work cut out having lost his top scorer, Marouane Fellaini, to suspension and after revealing there is "quite a lot" of injury news within his first-team squad, without going into specifics. Nine draws have hampered their push for a top-four spot and West Ham, who welcome Jack Collison into the squad for the first time since May's play-off final against Blackpool, have Boxing Day off thanks to the tube strike and will want to sign off for the year at Upton Park with a bang. Mark Tallentire

Both of these sides are out of the bottom three for now, but they can hardly afford to relax. Only goal difference is keeping Southampton above Wigan while Sunderland, a point and a place above them, are in a rut despite their recent victory over Reading. Nigel Adkins will know this is the sort of fixture Southampton must win if they are to beat the drop and they will be confident of doing so having gone four games undefeated at home. Yet they will be without their captain, Adam Lallana, after his knee injury and the visitors are showing signs of life in patches. It is bound to be a tense afternoon. Jacob Steinberg

Two teams that cancelled their Christmas parties due to poor form and two former West Ham managers meet on Tyneside in edgy rather than festive mood. While Alan Pardew's Newcastle have lost five of their last six fixtures and won only one of the past 11, Harry Redknapp's Queens Park Rangers boast one Premier League win all season. Much may depend on Demba Ba, a player QPR are extremely keen on signing in January. Meanwhile, Redknapp may wonder what might have been had he accepted Mike Ashley's offer to succeed Sam Allardyce as manager at St James' Park in January 2008. Louise Taylor

Two days after watching the Champions League enter its glamour phase with a last-16 draw that did not include his Manchester City side, Roberto Mancini faces the more prosaic test of trying to overcome Reading as he attempts to close the gap on leaders Manchester United. City are likely to be without their captain, Vincent Kompany, who has a groin problem, but even without him and the definite absentee Samir Nasri, defeating the Premier League's bottom-placed club should be straightforward enough for the champions. Jamie Jackson

As powerful sub-plots go Cheik Tioté versus Yaya Touré looks pretty decent. The two Ivorian central midfielders promise to play key roles on a day when City will be anxious to reassert their title credentials and Newcastle desperate to start climbing towards mid-table security. Newcastle fans trust their Senegalese strikers Demba Ba and Papiss Cissé will finally decide to start proving they can form an attacking partnership after all, but the home team is bound to miss the hamstrung Hatem Ben Arfa's catalytic creativity. Louise Taylor

Manchester United are flying, with a six-point lead and bolstered by the return of Sir Alex Ferguson's "warrior" leader and central defender, Nemanja Vidic, for the visit of Martin O'Neill's team. Sunderland now stand 15th following a much needed win over Reading in mid-week, as they face a United team still smarting at how the Sunderland fans delighted in Manchester City's late title win on the final day of last season, after United had triumphed at the Stadium of Light. If United get an early goal, they may fancy a rout. Jamie Jackson

Life is beautiful for Swansea City, and not only because of their advance into the League Cup semi-final; their best showing in a major knockout tournament in 48 years. Upwardly mobile in the Premier League, they are winning plaudits for their possession football, they can compete with anybody and it is a far cry from the dark days at the beginning of the last decade, when their very existence was threatened. Spurs provide the latest challenge but, after wins at Newcastle and Arsenal, the Swans travel without fear. David Hytner

Arsenal's last visit to Reading, in the Capital One Cup, saw them flirt with humiliation before an outlandish 7-5 win. You never know what you will get from Arsène Wenger's team but extremes of emotion come as standard. They know they need a morale-boost after Tuesday's humbling at Bradford but Reading, too, are desperate to ignite their season, as they struggle near the foot of the table. "Reading make it difficult for every team in every game," Wenger said. His side has come to specialise in doing likewise to themselves. David Hytner

Three successive defeats have put the brakes on West Brom's storming season. "With all the games in December you can quickly get into a good run or quickly into a bad run," said the Baggies manager Steve Clarke. "We've got into a bad run and the first objective is to stop that." West Ham have lost three of their last four but these have been hard games, not helped by a growing injury list, to which George McCartney's name was added this week. "It unfortunately leaves us very light on numbers," said Sam Allardyce. John Ashdown

Despite enjoying a superb run of form that has propelled the side to within four points of the Champions League places, Chris Hughton's Norwich have serious injury concerns going into this game at Carrow Road. Wigan's attacking trio of Jordi Gómez, Arouna Koné, and Franco Di Santo will fancy their chances of capitalising on the weakened home defence. But Roberto Martínez's side have defensive frailties of their own to cope with, and Wigan look set for their annual end of season relegation battle in the New Year. Robert Iddiols

Despite Everton's strong start to the season, if Tony Pulis can lead his team to a three-goal victory then Stoke could finish the weekend in fourth position, leapfrogging David Moyes's side in the process. It's a remarkable turn of fortunes for a side who seemed to be struggling in the early stages of the season. Pulis is refusing to rush back Michael Owen, despite the striker turning out in a behind-closed-doors friendly this week. Everton are again without the impressive Kevin Mirallas after a recurrence of his hamstring injury. Toby Moses

With Luis Suárez available after suspension, and Liverpool seeking a third successive home league win for the first time since May 2011, this fixture represents an inviting opportunity for Brendan Rodgers' team to continue their gradual ascent. Aston Villa have won once in 16 Premier League away games and their total of 12 goals is the lowest of any team in the top four divisions. However, since the 5-0 rout at Manchester City, Paul Lambert's team have found some resilience to concede only once in four league games. Andy Hunter

QPR set a Premier League record at the weekend by failing to overcome Wigan and become the only team not to secure a win after 16 games. They remain two points adrift at the foot of the table ahead of this West London derby, while Martin Jol's visitors look for back-to-back league victories for the first time since September. Four members of QPR's dressing-room have Champions League winners' medals, but few seem assured of their places as Harry Redknapp will most likely be looking for reinforcements in January. Robert Iddiols

It will be the battle of the Belgians at Goodison Park on Sunday. Marouane Fellaini has been a key player for Everton, scoring eight goals this season, while Kevin Mirallas, back from injury, could also provide the hosts with some added fire-power. Tottenham, meanwhile, are likely to have Jan Vertonghen in defence and Mousa Dembélé, also recently returned from injury, in their startling line-up. This is a meeting of two impressive sides aiming for Champions League football and should prove to be an early Christmas cracker. Declan Olley

The last time these sides met they were battling at the top of the Championship. Eight months on, they are battling near the bottom of the Premier League. Southampton come into this game in better form than Reading, who pipped the Saints to the Championship title by one point, but defensively both teams have been porous this season, with only two clean sheets kept between them. The hosts are better in attack, however, and are able to call upon Gaston Ramirez, who has just returned from a week's compassionate leave in his native Uruguay. Declan Olley

Last week West Ham faced a team containing a striker badly out of form, this week they face a team with no striker at all as Liverpool arrive in east London shorn of the suspended Luis Suárez. It will be up to Jonjo Shelvey, a boyhood Hammer, to lead the visitors' attack, a role he impressively carried out during Liverpool's recent Europa League draw with Young Boys. West Ham away is a sterner test, though, although they too are missing a key forward in Andy Carroll, who is injured but would regardless have been ineligible to face his parent club. Sachin Nakrani

Having only lost to the two Manchester clubs in their previous seven games, Paul Lambert's youthful Aston Villa side are beginning to grow in confidence. Christian Benteke is proving a handful for defenders while midfielder Ashley Westwood has made the step up from Football League to Premier League with little fuss. But Villa now face an in-form Stoke side, who are looking to win back-to-back away games. Peter Crouch could make a return for the visitors and may not have to take on Ron Vlaar, the Villa captain, who is likely to miss out again due to a calf injury. Declan Olley

Arsène Wenger has been in irritable mood all week, which is not too surprising given this is a man who once admitted that losing makes him feel "physically sick", and he has seen his side beaten twice and suffer another torrent of criticism from pundits and supporters alike. West Bromwich Albion have also lost their last two games, but the mood is very different within Steve Clarke's side who have surprised everybody by maintaining top-six pace into December. A victory on Saturday might just instil the belief they can stay there. Paul Chronnell

The 163rd Manchester derby provides a selection poser for Sir Alex Ferguson as he decides who to deploy in midfield and how to shape the side. With Anderson, Antonio Valencia, Nani, Shinji Kagawa and Tom Cleverley all injured, the choice comes down to a 4-2-3-1 with Michael Carrick and Darren Fletcher/Paul Scholes as the holding midfielders, or a diamond formation with Wayne Rooney at the tip. For Manchester City, who could be without Gaël Clichy and David Silva, defeat would be a sizeable blow given they are three points behind United. Jamie Jackson

Two anxious managers should contribute to an edgy atmosphere at the Stadium of Light, where Sunderland have won only one Premier League game since March. Accordingly, Martin O'Neill has called for "courage" from his struggling players. "It takes a strong person to play for Sunderland," he said. "It's tough and demanding playing at home; you have to have plenty of courage and ability to play here." Rafael Benítez, assisted by the former Sunderland midfielder Bolo Zenden, will be anxious to pacify Chelsea supporters with a win before flying to Japan for the World Club Championship from Newcastle airport on Saturday evening. Louise Taylor

Still without a win this season and currently eight points adrift from safety, Queens Park Rangers can ill afford to come away from the DW Stadium without a win. Their displays since the arrival of Harry Redknapp as manager are likely to have encouraged QPR supporters, although two draws against Sunderland and Aston Villa is not enough given the London club's predicament. In Wigan, QPR face another team in relegation trouble, with Roberto Martínez's side having only taken three points from their last five games. Declan Olley

Since meeting last season both of these clubs have undergone managerial changes, with both so far proving to be roaring successes. Michael Laudrup's Swansea are in the midst of a six-game unbeaten run which has seen them climb to seventh, and in Michu they have a genuine goal threat – his battle with Sébastien Bassong should be one to watch. Norwich are also in the midst of a long unbeaten run and their manager, Chris Hughton, will feel his side have the organisational strength to keep the swashbuckling Swans at bay. Declan Olley

Considering Fulham's impressive home record against Newcastle, Martin Jol may well see the visit of Alan Pardew's side as a timely one given his side's recent poor form. Fulham have found goals hard to come by of late and with the news that Bryan Ruiz will be out until the new year, Jol is relying heavily on Dimitar Berbatov and Mladen Petric to score for them. Newcastle, despite a 3-0 win over Wigan on Monday, have not been in great form either and travel to Craven Cottage still looking for their first away win this season. Declan Olley

Such has been West Bromwich Albion's excellent start to the season that their defeat at Swansea on Wednesday came as something of a surprise, despite the Liberty Stadium being a ground where Chelsea and Liverpool have failed to win recently. The setback provides Steve Clarke with a chance to see the resolve of his high-flying squad and they will certainly not get an easy ride against Stoke, who are unbeaten in four games but without Peter Crouch after he broke three teeth in a clash with Newcastle's Fabricio Coloccini in midweek. Sachin Nakrani

It is a measure either of Swansea's success, or of Arsenal's decline, that Michael Laudrup's side arrive at the Emirates on Saturday just one point and one place behind their hosts. Laudrup would surely prefer the former description, with Wednesday's 3-1 defeat of high-flying West Bromwich Albion confirming that the Dane has maintained the attacking vibrancy Swansea had under Brendan Rodgers last season. After two hard-fought away draws, Arsène Wenger promises Arsenal will thrive in December. A win on Saturday would be the ideal start. Paul Chronnell

Harry Redknapp will get a rousing reception from QPR supporters desperate for a saviour. Attempts to win their first match of the season against fellow relegation worriers Reading and Southampton, at home under Mark Hughes, ended badly, and the hosts can ill afford to make it third time unlucky. Aston Villa beat Reading in midweek but have not won successive Premier League matches for over a year. Neither team is scoring freely and by the end, it will be interesting to see who has the greater need for Darren Bent. Amy Lawrence

Trips to the Boleyn Ground have represented easy pickings for Chelsea in recent times, with only two points shed in their last six visits. Perhaps that was why Sam Allardyce sounded a note of caution ahead of this derby despite the fact the visitors arrive without a win in six league games and with fans still deeply unsettled by the arrival of Rafael Benítez. "Rafa has already sorted out what was a problem under Roberto [Di Matteo]," said Allardyce, reflecting upon Chelsea's successive goalless draws under the Spaniard. Benítez will continue to juggle his resources, and may rest Oscar as he seeks a win to ease the tension. Dominic Fifield

It will be a meeting of many old friends at Craven Cottage with Mousa Dembélé and Clint Dempsey returning to face the club they left for Tottenham in the summer, while Fulham's Martin Jol and Dimitar Berbatov will spark a few fond memories among those in the away end. Despite a fine – if largely unnoticed – display against Chelsea in midweek, the Cottagers are at their lowest ebb of the season so far in terms of league position and they will find it tough against a visiting side looking to extend their winning run to three games. John Ashdown

There have been four top-flight games between these sides and Reading can take heart from the draws they have achieved on two of those occasions. Less heartening, however, is the Royals' current league position – they are 19th having won only once all season and now come up against a Manchester United side who lead the division despite not having clicked into high gear. Sir Alex Ferguson will expect three points before resting his big guns for Wednesday's Champions League dead rubber against CFR Cluj. Jamie Jackson

Martin O'Neill celebrates his first year in charge at Sunderland on Monday and would dearly love a victory over Norwich at Carrow Road to commemorate the anniversary. His side are in the midst of a black period, having collected just 13 points from 13 games, and are playing with a severe lack of imagination and incisiveness. It does not help their cause that they are coming up against opponents who are undefeated in their past seven league games, although Chris Hughton's side also lack a genuine cutting edge. Sachin Nakrani

After four successive defeats Newcastle United could do with an ego-repairing win at the start of a busy week, during which Alan Pardew's side also visit Bordeaux in the Europa League on Thursday. Wigan have never won a Premier League game at St James' Park but little has gone right for Pardew since he signed an eight-year contract in September. No Newcastle side have ever lost five successive Premier League fixtures but the visitors will hope to capitalise on the absence of Hatem Ben Arfa, Yohan Cabaye and Steven Taylor from an injury-hit home squad. Louise Taylor

Given Southampton's manager, Nigel Adkins, and their top-scorer, Rickie Lambert, are self-confessed Liverpool supporters it is fair to say this is a fixture with significant meaning for leading figures among the visitors' ranks. Their focus, however, is on securing a fifth match without defeat and clambering out of the relegation zone. Much is at stake for the hosts, too, whose own unbeaten run was ended at White Hart Lane in midweek. Home spirits should be lifted, however, by the return of Lucas Leiva from a long-term thigh injury. Sachin Nakrani

Manchester City have already passed the first test of champions hoping to retain their title: that of staying among the leaders as Christmas approaches despite failing to hit top form. In fact, Roberto Mancini's team are only a point behind Manchester United with a goal difference that is better by two ahead of Everton's arrival at the Etihad Stadium on Saturday. David Moyes's side have defeated Mancini's City on five of the six occasions they have met and the Toffees should once again prove to be a tricky proposition for the home side. Jamie Jackson

Fulham's surprise collapse against Sunderland last week means Martin Jol will be demanding a strong response from his players. But it will not be easy – while the visitors' goal haul is second only to Manchester United, away from home they have leaked goals in every match. With Stoke holding the best defensive home record in the league, it could be a tough ask for Dimitar Berbatov to inspire Fulham's depleted squad. Stoke have their own injury concern – Andy Wilkinson may miss out after limping off at West Ham on Monday with a back problem. Rob Clyne

Arsenal's injury list has lessened slightly after the nadir of last week's north london derby with Tottenham, a match that Arsène Wenger's side would certainly have found a much tougher assignment were it not for Emmanuel Adebayor's moment of madness. Althout the visitors are still without Theo Walcott and Abou Diaby among others, they should still have enough about them to provide a severe test for Paul Lambert's floundering side, who are themselves coming off the back of the morale-shredding 5-0 drubbing at Manchester City last week. Rich Flower

While QPR have spared their new manager a game against one of the Manchester giants, there's no such luck for Rafa Benítez. In his first game in charge he welcomes the champions to Stamford Bridge, a team who finished fifth last time he managed a Premier League side back in 2009-10 – coincidentally the last time City got an away win at Chelsea. Both sides will be looking to get over their Champions League disappointment, with only a four-point gap between them, despite all the talk of a crisis at Roman Abramovich's Chelsea. Toby Moses

Emmanuel Adebayor's sending-off during last week's north London derby undeniably skewed the outcome of a match Arsenal went on to win 5-2, but the reality for Tottenham is that they have lost four of their last five league games and are performing like a team short of belief and purpose. That is in contrast to West Ham, whose spirits are high following a good start to their first season back among the elite, although that is sure to be tested by the tough set of seven fixtures to come. This could prove the easiest of the lot. Sachin Nakrani

Brendan Rodgers returns to the Liberty Stadium for the first time since swapping Swansea for Liverpool. A glance at the table would suggest he made the wrong move – Swansea are one place and one point ahead of the Merseysiders – but Rodgers remains optimistic about his current club's prospects, and perhaps should be given they are undefeated in seven league games and have the division's top scorer in Luis Suárez. It was the hosts, however, who won 3-1 when these sides met in the Capital One Cup last month. Sachin Nakrani

Sir Alex Ferguson has seen Queens Park Rangers remove Mark Hughes on the eve of their trip to Old Trafford and now believes even more that a win against the bottom club should be regulation, especially as there is not yet a Harry Redknapp or any other permanent successor to provide the 'bounce' factor that can often lift players after a managerial sacking. Instead, Mark Bowen and Eddie Niedzwiecki, Hughes' long-term lieutenants, take charge against United, who have lost their last two in all competitions. This all points to a home rout. Jamie Jackson

David Moyes has several injury concerns plus a one-match ban for Marouane Fellaini to contend with against an in-form Norwich team that has not conceded a goal in three matches or lost in six, an impressive sequence that includes wins over Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United. The Everton manager was incensed with last week's defeat at Reading – "we abused an opportunity," as he put it – and his team badly need to rediscover their early season momentum. Norwich keeper John Ruddy is expected to recover from a knee injury suffered in the United win in time to face his former club. Andy Hunter

Such was the brio of Southampton's performance at Queens Park Rangers last week, in a match where their manager's job was said to be in jeopardy, that Nigel Adkins's team go into this game as slight favourites. Newcastle are stuttering and have several key first-team players unavailable through injury while Southampton are playing with a swagger, especially at home. Newcastle should at least provide a home defence that is still to keep a clean sheet with a stiffer test than QPR did, but Southampton look capable of scoring more. Paul Doyle

Jason Roberts, who was one of the scorers in a Wigan victory over Reading that secured their promotion to the Premier League in May 2005, returns to pie-land with a Royals team who claimed their first win of the season against Everton last week, and are now unbeaten in their last four. They could be unchanged, while the Latics lost Gary Caldwell with a hamstring problem as well as Ben Watson with a broken leg in last Saturday's defeat at Liverpool. Ryo Miyaichi and Franco di Santo are also doubtful for the visitors. Andy Wilson

Martin O'Neill and Steve Clarke sat alongside each other at Upton Park on Monday night watching West Ham draw with Stoke and they will be back in close proximity on Saturday. While Clarke's slick counter-attacking visitors aim to enhance an unlikely European challenge, Sunderland could do with building on last Sunday's restorative win at Fulham. With Albion's Shane Long, currently challenging Luis Suárez's mantle as the division's hottest striker, O'Neill must trust his own centre-forward, Steven Fletcher, is in the mood to remind everyone precisely why he cost £12m. Louise Taylor

West Ham aim to consolidate their place in the top six, which would set them fair for a tilt at European football. This was not part of the script upon the London club's promotion but they have thrived as one of the season's surprise packages. Sam Allardyce's signings have been astute, individual form and confidence are positive and expectations have been readjusted, although not within the squad; they always believed they would shine. Stoke, however, are past masters at jolting opponents to earth and the captain Ryan Shawcross is buoyed by becoming a full England international. David Hytner

Given Roberto Di Matteo is facing the club that sacked him and Steve Clarke coming up against one he used to play for and coach at, it is no surprise that the respective managers, who also happen to be former Stamford Bridge team-mates, took centre stage ahead of this match. Yet the real intrigue lies in the form of both teams, with Chelsea arriving at The Hawthorns having failed to win any of their past three league games and the hosts looking to win their third match in a row and subsequently move within a point of the European champions. Sachin Nakrani

Roberto Mancini breezed into his Friday press conference wearing a David Platt mask to poke fun at himself and illustrate a lighter mood after recent travails during which he sent his assistant to speak with the media. Manchester City's manager protects the Premier League's only unbeaten record against a team defeated 4-1 in the corresponding fixture last season, though Aston Villa's recent form has them a place above the drop zone. After Maicon helped inspire Sunday's 3-2 win over Tottenham when entering as a substitute the Brazilian may start, while Mario Balotelli, dropped from the squad for that game due to attitude issues, will hope for a return. Jamie Jackson

Norwich should probably not get too excited if they take the lead against Manchester United, Sir Alex Ferguson's side having come from behind to win numerous times this season. Aston Villa felt United's powers of recovery last week, letting a two-goal lead slip, but perhaps Norwich, unbeaten in their past five matches, are made of sterner stuff. Much will depend on how Chris Hughton's improving side handle the in-form Javier Hernández, who is expected to be handed a rare Premier League start after scoring seven goals in his past five games. Jacob Steinberg

Newcastle may have exceeded expectations by finishing fifth last season, but aspire to more than their current position of 10th. However, Sunday's home defeat to West Ham has ruffled Magpie feathers and the continued absence of the suspended Fabricio Coloccini is compounded todayon Saturday by Yohan Cabaye missing out through injury. Their squad depth is being tested. Swansea would be happy to end up where they are now – 11th – and Michael Laudrup's improving side will hope to take advantage of any home uncertainty. Paul Chronnell

The stakes are high in a clash that has been dubbed "El Sackico" and Nigel Adkins is entitled to approach it with more confidence that Mark Hughes even if Southampton have yet to win away this season. At least his team has shown cohesion and attacking menace, whereas QPR have struggled to score and only intermittently suggested they are playing to a plan. Having said that, both teams have an alarming propensity to sabotage themselves with mistakes so the result is difficult to predict. A draw would be no surprise. Paul Doyle

Martin O'Neill arrives at Craven Cottage yearning for a change in fortunes. His side have won only once in the Premier League since March, Sunderland having lost their last three games in all competitions and with confidence clearly fragile. "We need to win some football matches and the sooner we do that, the better," said the manager. "We have to look at points on the board now at this stage and start galvanising ourselves." A confrontation with an expansive Fulham side, inspired by Dimitar Berbatov and the ever improving Bryan Ruiz, feels daunting – only Manchester United have scored more often than Martin Jol's team. O'Neill's luck may have to be in. Dominic Fifield

Reading's manager Brian McDermott has had his say after his side were booed off by their own supporters at the end of last Saturday's goalless draw with Norwich, but the message from impatient terraces and boardroom alike is clear: a first league win of the season is overdue. Can it come at the 12th time of asking? Everton are aiming to maintain an impressive start that sees them in fourth place and, while they will be without Kevin Mirallas on Saturday, they are finding goals easy to come by. Reading's wait may go on. Paul Chronnell

it is not uncommon for a derby to be characterised by tension but this meeting of north London's most prominent clubs has a particularly fraught feel to it. The hosts have made their worst start to a league campaign under Arsène Wenger's management and confidence is fragile within a team that has blown a two-goal lead in their last two games. Tottenham, too, have their difficulties, having lost their last two league games and, like Arsenal, their defence continues to appear vulnerable. Goals are practically guaranteed. Sachin Nakrani

They are both 39-years-old, both previously managed Swansea and, although only one is actually from Spain, both speak fluent Spanish. Brendan Rodgers and Roberto Martínez have much in common; these two football purists were the leading candidates to succeed Kenny Dalglish at Anfield last summer. In the end Martínez stayed put at Wigan, leaving Rodgers striving to reprise Liverpool's former glories. With the Merseysiders stuck in 13th place, Saturday promises to be tricky; Wigan won at Anfield last season and once again much may hinge on Luis Suárez. Louise Taylor

Southampton are in desperate need of a win to ease some of the pressure on Nigel Adkins, and the visit of Swansea presents a good opportunity to collect three points for only the second time this season. The Saints manager has denied reports he was issued with an ultimatum this week by the chairman but a fifth successive defeat in all competitions would still be disastrous. Michael Laudrup has told his players to be wary of a motivated side keen to save their manager, although he will be quietly confident of a good performance following his team's impressive 1-1 draw against Chelsea last weekend. Jack Cork should be fit to make his first appearance of the season, and Southampton fans can welcome the record signing Gastón Ramírez to St Mary's after he returned from injury to face West Bromwich Albion on Monday. Five of Southampton's next seven fixtures are at home, the highest placed of these opponents being Newcastle in 10th. Southampton's fate will most likely be decided over the next few weeks; a win on Saturday would be the perfect way to kickstart their season. Alex Keble

Alan Pardew has fuelled the fire before Sunday's visit of West Ham by declaring his intention to sign Andy Carroll when his loan deal expires. The fixture was already set to be a lively affair, with both Pardew and Sam Allardyce facing their former employers. Allardyce will be keen to seek revenge following his dismissal in 2008, his opposite number being the man Mike Ashley lined up to replace him. Both sides are struggling defensively, which could mean plenty of goals at St James' Park. West Ham wait on fitness tests for James Collins and James Tomkins, while Newcastle are without the suspended duo of Fabricio Coloccini and Cheik Tioté, Newcastle's two key defensive players. Their absence gives a boost to the visitors' physical approach, which has not been particularly successful away from home; a 2-1 victory at QPR is their only away success to date. Up against a depleted Newcastle recovering from a midweek trip to Belgium, Allardyce could rectify West Ham's away form, and make a victorious return. Alex Keble

Since a 3-1 victory over Sir Alex Ferguson's kids 17 years ago, Villa have crumbled when United visit. Paul Lambert's revolution is making slow but steady progress, his young side's three-match unbeaten run putting a relatively comfortable four-point buffer between themselves and the relegation zone. Villa are boosted by the return after suspension of Karim El Ahmadi, whose crisp passing has brought some vital composure to an otherwise inexperienced midfield; Villa have held the majority of possession on only two occasions this season. The hosts will need significantly higher ball retention than in recent weeks if they are to stunt a visiting side that seem to be steadily growing in confidence as the season progresses. United have won four successive league games since the shock 3-2 defeat by Tottenham, and with a relatively straight forward run of games until the Manchester derby in early December, Ferguson will be keen to ensure his team do not drop points against sides as depleted as Villa. Alex Keble

Tony Pulis could be forgiven for feeling pretty grateful to Mark Hughes. QPR's winless campaign, coupled with the struggles of Southampton and Reading, have meant that Stoke's own slow start has gone largely unnoticed. Pulis's Potters have won only one in 10 thus far and have scored six goals fewer than rock-bottom Southampton. "The disappointing thing is we've players who have goals in them," said Pulis. "The one thing I didn't think we'd have a problem with this season is scoring goals. But things like this happen so you have to make sure everybody stays nice and calm, keeps the belief, keeps the faith." Archie Smith

Albion's Steve Clarke has been making an early bid for manager of the season, but he is determined to keep his feet on the ground. "People ask about Europe but it is too early for that," he said. "It is a dangerous league. If we hadn't won the other night against Southampton, we would be stuck in mid-table." Wigan are looking to complete a hat-trick of wins, after victories against West Ham and, particularly impressively, at Tottenham last weekend. But Roberto Martínez also struck a cautious note, describing this fixture as "arguably one of the toughest this season". Archie Smith

"For us, there are no easy matches – irrespective of the opposition, we have to be on top of our game," said the Norwich manager, Chris Hughton, ahead of his side's trip to 18th-placed Reading. The Royals manager, Brian McDermott, insisted this week that "every single person at the club is going in the same direction" and there does seem to be plenty of positivity at the Madejski, despite the club still being in search of their first league win. "The win is coming, everyone knows it," said the Reading midfielder Jem Karacan. John Ashdown

Four successive draws have put the brakes on Everton's uncharacteristically rip-roaring start to the season, and with Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester City on the fixture list between now and Christmas, David Moyes's side could do with getting back to winning ways.
