United have won six of their last seven meetings with Arsenal at Old Trafford in all competitions, conceding just two goals, and were rampant in the second half against Tottenham on Monday night. Kevin McCarra

Doing the double over Bolton was one of the few highlights of Roy Hodgson's brief, tortuous time at Anfield, although successive Liverpool managers have rarely been troubled by the Trotters. Bolton have lost their last nine matches to Liverpool and you would have to go back to 1954 to find their last league victory at Anfield. Both sides are suffering the after-effects of midweek Carling Cup wins. Kenny Dalglish will be without Raul Meireles, who suffered a collarbone injury at Exeter, while Owen Coyle saw Marcos Alonso join Bolton's growing casualty list with a fractured metatarsal. Tim Rich

Each club had sweeping victories in their opening fixtures in the Premier League. That seems to promise an exciting yet close contest, but it will be interesting to see whether Manchester City continue in so expansive a manner – Roberto Mancini will certainly appreciate that Bolton are very different opponents from the fragile Swansea side his team thumped 4-0 on Monday night. He also has to decide how much involvement there is for the £38m Argentinian, Sergio Agüero, a devastating substitute against the Welsh club. Kevin McCarra

Swansea never expected to beat Manchester City, but Wigan at home is the sort of fixture from which they need maximum points if they are to stay up. Off the pitch, Brendan Rodgers is calling for a warm welcome for the former Swans manager Roberto Martínez. On it, he is looking for the return of captain Garry Monk and left-back Neil Taylor to stabilise a defence that shipped four on Monday. Wigan are unsure about the fitness of Steve Gohouri, Hugo Rodallega and James McCarthy, but Antolin Alcaraz is in line to return. Joe Lovejoy

Of all the football joints, in all the towns, in all the world, Queens Park Rangers would have to walk into Bill Kenwright's. Having detailed the club's financial problems and his desperate, fruitless search for new investment, albeit unwittingly, the Everton chairman welcomes a club who spent the past 15 years outside the Premier League yet have still attracted four wealthy owners recently – Bernie Ecclestone, Flavio Briatore, Lakshmi Mittal and now Tony Fernandes. One pertinent point about the game remains, however – no one at Everton would exchange David Moyes' squad for Neil Warnock's. Andy Hunter

Opening-day draws for Norwich at Wigan and for Stoke at home to Chelsea may not have entirely displeased either of these clubs, but given Stoke's poor away record last season, the Canaries will fancy their chances of taking all three points at Carrow Road. Imagine for a moment, however, that Tony Pulis does manage to sort out Stoke's away form this season – a top-10 finish would be the least of their ambitions. An injury to centre-half Zak Whitbread means the former Liverpool defender Daniel Ayala, for whom Norwich paid £800,000 this week, could make his debut. Richard Rae

Alex McLeish's first home game as Aston Villa manager should be an ideal opportunity to also pick up his first win. Blackburn lost 2-1 at home against Wolves last weekend and have the look of a team that could be in for long season. Steve Kean hopes to give a debut to Radosav Petrovic, the Serbia midfielder who joined from Partizan Belgrade earlier this month, and should also welcome back experienced defenders Ryan Nelsen and Christopher Samba. McLeish has a full-strength squad to pick from with the exception of Carlos Cuéllar. Stuart James

The focus has switched firmly towards squad strengthening at Stamford Bridge as the transfer deadline approaches, though Chelsea's current crop must slip seamlessly into winning ways to inject momentum into their early season title challenge. André Villas-Boas' first home game in charge offers an opportunity – the Baggies, then under the current Chelsea assistant manager Roberto Di Matteo, were defeated 6-0 in south-west London last term – which cannot be passed up. Roy Hodgson's team, with Peter Odemwingie secured on new terms but still unfit, are much improved these days but still face an awkward afternoon. Dominic Fifield

Wolves fans should not get too excited – after an opening-day win over Stoke last season, they languished in 19th place in early October. A season-long fight against relegation was eased dramatically only on the last day of the campaign, when events elsewhere conspired in their favour despite a 3-2 defeat by Blackburn. It was Rovers who they beat 2-1 at Ewood Park last weekend. Battle-hardened Fulham have already completed the best part of 25% of a Premier League season, with seven of their eight matches in the tortuous Europa League qualification process that started in June. In that octet of fixtures, they have conceded just one goal. Russell Kempson

Kenny Dalglish's Liverpool provided one of the horror moments of last season for Arsenal when they equalised in the 102nd minute at the Emirates, and they might not get a better chance to inflict more pain. Arsène Wenger is under siege, with his problems taking in a clutch of injuries and suspensions, Samir Nasri, and the difficulties in making signings. With confidence fragile, it is a time for stout hearts. Liverpool, flat in the second half against Sunderland, also operate under extremes of pressure but it feels as if Arsenal have more to lose. David Hytner

Two clubs, two managers, two very different outlooks. "I don't look forward to any games now, to be honest. It's hard," says Steve Bruce. "I have a great job, the best in the world – until Saturday afternoon comes along." Alan Pardew disagrees. "I quite enjoy the games," he counters. "It's the Monday to Friday bit, the putting out of fires, I don't like. It's a genuine relief to be beside the pitch." On it, expect to see Lee Cattermole and Joey Barton wind each other up and opposing strikers Asamoah Gyan and Shola Ameobi vie for hero status. Louise Taylor

The loss of two experienced centre-backs would be a blow to most clubs but the absence through injury of Nemanja Vidic and Rio Ferdinand should provide a good opportunity for Phil Jones, Manchester United's summer signing from Blackburn. Despite the challenge ahead, Tottenham will at least feel rested after a 5-0 amble against Hearts in the Europa League on Thursday. It remains to be seen whether Luka Modric, if fit after injury, will take part, considering the speculation about a possible move to Chelsea. Kevin McCarra

Having finished a point apart last season, these sides have undergone transitional summers. Martin Jol will include Bobby Zamora, who sustained a broken hand in the Europa League a fortnight ago, for his first league match in charge of Fulham, though Zamora will wear a cast. Yet Cameron Jerome will not partner him in attack after Fulham refused to improve on their £3m midweek offer for the Birmingham striker. For Villa fans outraged at the appointment of Alex McLeish and dismayed at the loss of Stewart Downing and Ashley Young, debuts for Charles N'Zogbia and Shay Given will provide some cheer. Jonny Weeks

It might be a little early in the season to bill this match as a crucial relegation encounter but in the battle for survival in the Premier League every point must be fought for. Wolves stayed up by a single point last season. They have recruited Roger Johnson from relegated Birmingham and brought back last season's Tottenham loanee, Jamie O'Hara, on a permanent deal. Such reinforcements may prove crucial against a Blackburn side that could be shorn of both of its first-choice central defenders through injury. Rich Flower

This represents a daunting start for Swansea in their first Premier League season, even though Roberto Mancini says neither Sergio Agüero nor Carlos Tevez will be fit enough to start. The Welsh team kept 21 clean sheets in the Championship last season and will need that defensive solidity against a side that, once again, has had considerable investment over the summer, with £50m spent and counting. Swansea's own recruitment has been altogether more modest, with Danny Graham their most expensive signing at £3.5m, and it is difficult to imagine they sympathise too much with Mancini when it comes to his complaints about the FA Cup winners not signing enough players. Daniel Taylor

Manchester United's title defence begins at The Hawthorns, one of only five away grounds where they won in the Premier League last season. Lady luck was smiling on them on that occasion. Gary Neville should have been sent off and Peter Odemwingie missed a penalty for Albion. Despite United's impressive comeback against Manchester City last Sunday, which was inspired by younger legs, Sir Alex Ferguson is likely to put his faith in an experienced line-up here. Albion may give a debut to new signing Shane Long, with Odemwingie struggling to be fit. Stuart James

Liverpool have lost an opening-day home fixture only twice since 1962, and having spent £54m since bidding farewell to the most topsy-turvy season on record there is justifiable expectation on Kenny Dalglish's team to gain early momentum against this summer's other reconstruction work. Both sides need time to settle but, with 10 additions to a squad that underwhelmed last season, Steve Bruce's task appears harder. Sunderland's swollen ex-Manchester United contingent and Jordan Henderson provide the subplots but the midfield contest between Blackpool old boys Charlie Adam and David Vaughan should not be overlooked. Andy Hunter

A team facing a period of transition cannot have wished for a trip to the Britannia Stadium in the first weekend of the season. The visitors take on last season's FA Cup finalists and the new Chelsea manager, Andre Villas-Boas, faces a particularly British sort of occasion. The larger issue for the visitors is the further regeneration of an ageing squad that is starting to creak a little. Stoke, for their part, are ready and settled – Tony Pulis's team beat Hajduk Split 1-0 both home and away in the Europa League qualifiers. Kevin McCarra

If QPR are to stay up they will need to win home games against mainstream Premier League opposition of this sort on a regular basis. Bolton won only two away league fixtures last season and with Tuncay Sanli's attacking talents awaiting a work permit will be hoping that the arrival of Nigel Reo-Coker stiffens their midfield. Neil Warnock will look to Danny Gabbidon and Kieron Dyer to provide some wrinkles at the higher level while hoping his defence maintains last season's discipline and organisation. The attacking qualities of both teams should produce an entertaining fixture. David Lacey

As the Premier League enters its 20th campaign, it is easy to forget Norwich, top in early April 1993, could have been its inaugural champions. After competing in only one of its last 16 campaigns the Canaries have returned with a flourish, courtesy of back-to-back promotions. Manager Paul Lambert has been busy and must decide which of his new signings merit debuts on Saturday while Wigan's Roberto Martínez, another former Motherwell midfielder, may be without James McCarthy. But for Hugo Rodallega's winner at Stoke in May, these two clubs could have traded places over the summer. Richard Jolly

Arsène Wenger's mood, hardly mellowed by painfully slow goodbyes from Cesc Fábregas and Samir Nasri, has been further darkened by logistical disruptions. When the Arsenal manager discovered his team's intended hotel on Tyneside was hosting a Geordie wedding party he switched the booking to a less conveniently situated property in Durham City. While Wenger wonders whether Alan Pardew will select Joey Barton, Cheik Tioté dreams of emulating his wonder volley which earned Newcastle a 4-4 draw after being 4-0 down in last season's equivalent fixture. Much may hinge on Yohan Cabaye's input in Pardew's midfield. Louise Taylor

Of the five clubs in danger of being relegated, Wolves and Blackburn Rovers kick-off looking the most likely to retain their Premier League status. The only way both can be relegated is if they draw and Birmingham, Blackpool and Wigan all win, which seems highly unlikely. Wolves will be full of confidence after back-to-back victories in which Steven Fletcher has continued his excellent form. Blackburn have also had a recent revival, collecting five points from three games, including one against Manchester United last Saturday. Stuart James

The battle for seventh is not one the hype-merchants have been getting excited about, but it means a lot to Mark Hughes. Beat Arsenal and Fulham could leapfrog Everton and equal their highest ever Premier League finish, thereby enabling Hughes to prove that he has successfully replaced Roy Hodgson. In addition, Hughes has introduced a spirit of adventure into Fulham's play that was not always there under his predecessor, which means this match could be one of the most entertaining of the weekend, especially as Arsenal will be looking to win in order to climb back above Manchester City and avoid the Champions League qualifying-round next season. Paul Doyle

Roberto Martínez likened the pulsating win over West Ham last Sunday to giving birth – 'As if he'd know,' mothers cry – but one more push is needed. Wigan have been pleasing on the eye yet vulnerable in defence all season, particularly at set-pieces, and Stoke is not the place to take such weaknesses. In Charles N'Zogbia, however, they possess a cutting edge to compensate and will hope to encounter a Stoke side bruised from two defeats to Manchester City but slapping themselves on the back for a campaign well done.Not that Tony Pulis will countenance any self-congratulation until the final whistle. Andy Hunter

For a while, back when their form was blistering, Chelsea and Carlo Ancelotti had hoped this fixture might become their coronation. As it is, it is likely to prove a swansong. The Italian expects to speak with the club's chief executive, Ron Gourlay, next week and will discover whether or not his time at Stamford Bridge is up. This would be an awkward way to go out: Ancelotti has not beaten Everton since coming to England, and Avram Grant was in charge the last time Chelsea defeated the Merseysiders in the league. David Moyes will have his own issues to address over the summer, but will be happier to do so should his team maintain seventh place. Dominic Fifield

The focus will be on whether Liverpool can obtain the Europa League place that seemed impossible for them at the start of the year. However, Aston Villa also have a desire to win – three points could plausibly take them as high as ninth. Gérard Houllier, still recuperating from his health scare, is unable to face the club with whom he won six trophies at the start of the century and, given Liverpool have not lost at Villa Park in their last 12 visits, they will be hopeful of pipping Tottenham, who face Birmingham, to fifth place. William Unwin

Relegated to the Championship and having seen their end-of-season dinner descend into a brawl, West Ham will hope to at least salvage some dignity from this fixture. Kevin Keen is in charge of the team following Avram Grant's sacking amid the anger and anguish at the DW Stadium last Sunday and the former Hammers midfielder has already expressed a desire to keep the job on a long-term basis. He could not have asked for a better audition, with Sunderland arriving in east London bereft of playing staff and morale. Sachin Nakrani

Back in August, Roy Hodgson was settling into a new job at Liverpool, Alan Pardew was heading for the sack at Southampton and Chris Hughton and Roberto Di Matteo offered Newcastle and West Brom hope for the future. Who could have guessed the season's final day would see Pardew welcome Hodgson to St James' Park? Tynesiders, who may see Shola Ameobi's younger brother Sammy make a home debut in attack, will be hoping this does not prove to be José Enrique's final game ahead of a widely mooted move to Anfield. Louise Taylor

Manchester United, the champions, host a Blackpool side scrapping for survival. The hosts are aiming to go through the entire season unbeaten at home, while the visitors are looking to pick up their first victory at Old Trafford in 49 years. It hardly helps their cause that Sir Alex Ferguson has said he will field a strong team, but Ian Holloway's men could still lose and stay up – and therefore play in the Premier League for a second successive season – should Birmingham, away at Tottenham, lose by a bigger margin. Tom Moore

Bolton's season effectively ended after their FA Cup semi-final thrashing to Stoke. Manchester City, meanwhile, are coming off two wins in four days against Tony Pulis's side, the first of which ended 35 trophy-less years for them. But the club's owners are also looking to secure qualification for next season's Champions League group stages, which victory at the Reebok Stadium will guarantee for Roberto Mancini's men. City are clear favourites against a team whose eyes are firmly focused on their summer holidays, however much the Bolton manager, Owen Coyle, likes to think otherwise. William Unwin

The drab final between victors Porto and Braga in Dublin did nothing to improve the allure of the Europa League, but Tottenham Hotspur should still strive for the win that will ensure qualification for it. After all, this is the one achievement within reach. Birmingham's motivation must be even more intense since the Carling Cup winners continue to be at some risk of relegation following last weekend's loss to Fulham, although pursuing Blackpool and Wigan also have away matches, with the former's at Old Trafford. Kevin McCarra

Manchester City face a Stoke City side who will surely make them uneasy as they try to win their first major trophy since the League Cup in 1976. Roberto Mancini has built a careful City team whose scoring record is not remarkable considering the vast sums spent on constructing the squad. The clubs drew 1-1 in their only league encounter of the season so far, in November, and it may be hard to separate them. Tony Pulis has given Stoke status by taking them into the top half of the Premier League. Kevin McCarra

The team who wish the season was just starting are at home against the one for whom it cannot end quickly enough. Liverpool, with 10 wins and three draws from Kenny Dalglish's first 16 Premier League games, have Andy Carroll available after knee trouble as they seek to deny Tottenham fifth place and qualification for the Europa League. Spurs, with one win in their last 13 in all competitions, have Ledley King fit again for the first time since mid-October and standing by to replace William Gallas, who has a calf injury. Joe Lovejoy

Birmingham's disappointing run of two wins in their last 11 matches, including three defeats in the last four, has left them hovering close to the relegation zone. Playing at home will be an advantage, however, and there is the added motivation for the Blues of winning their 50th league match under Alex McLeish. However, Fulham have looked rejuvenated in the second half of the season, despite the recent hammering to Liverpool, and are aiming to secure a top-10 finish between now and the end of the season. Subhankar Mondal

Arsenal's players will hold the traditional lap of appreciation after this, their final home match, and all eyes will be on the number of fans who stay for it and their reaction. The diehards will surely drown out the dissenting minority but the situation could be complicated if the team fail to beat Aston Villa. Although Arsène Wenger still hopes to overhaul Chelsea in second place, he has to be wary of Manchester City on his shoulder. The manager does not want a troublesome Champions League qualifier to negotiate. Villa plan to end a dismal season proudly. David Hytner

The result of this match may be irrelevant in the greater scheme of things, but while West Bromwich Albion fans will be in the mood to celebrate safety in their final home game of the season, Everton supporters may still be fretting. This is David Moyes's 350th Premier League match as their manager and there are some who fear that after seven years working on a restricted budget, the Scot would find a summer approach from a club with more money, and arguably more ambition, such as Aston Villa perhaps, hard to resist. Richard Rae

Steve Bruce wanted the two final games of this season to mean something, and although the greater significance may not be from a Sunderland perspective, he has been granted his wish. After hosting fourth-from-bottom Wolves, who are without a win on Wearside in seven visits spanning 18 years, his side go to West Ham. "Those two clubs are fighting for their lives, but we want to end on a high," said Bruce. Mick McCarthy and Premier League wins were not bed-fellows during his time in charge of Sunderland, but one on his return will go a long way to securing a third straight season of top-flight football at Molineux. Jason Mellor

For Blackpool to have any chance of extending their Premier League adventure into a second season, they must surely defeat Bolton at Bloomfield Road. Fail, and Ian Holloway's side would have to go Manchester United on the final day of the campaign and hope to beat the champions-elect while also wishing for other results to go their way. Bolton are suffering a late-term dip that has handed Owen Coyle's men reverses in their last three outings, so they should not be in the mood to allow the Seasiders any favours. Jamie Jackson

Manchester United stand one point from a 19th league title and history, but Sir Alex Ferguson is likely to begin Champions League final preparations early by resting Edwin van der Sar. That decision appears risk-free against the team with the fewest Premier League goals in 2011 and, while Darren Fletcher hopes to press his claims for Wembley, a strong side is expected for the task of sealing the championship a fortnight before the date with Barcelona. Not that Blackburn represent a foregone conclusion – they are playing for survival and will not want a final day decider at Molineux. Andy Hunter

The temptation will be for those present at Stamford Bridge on Sunday to treat this as a farewell. Carlo Ancelotti will wave to the crowd after his team's final home game of term and, even with the league title likely to have been surrendered by then, will surely command a fine reception. The Italian may want to see out his contract at Chelsea, but there is something of the Claudio Ranieri about his position. "I don't want to think about it being my last game," he said. "But I will say thank you to the fans". Newcastle prevailed here in the Carling Cup and will look to register an equally startling result, though, if this is to be a swansong, the hosts will seek to send their manager out on a high. Dominic Fifield

None of the West Ham board made the last away trip to Manchester City, but they have paid for 34 coaches to ferry supporters north for a fight to the death. The stakes are giddyingly high. Only a win will stave off relegation for Avram Grant's side while the Wigan manager, Roberto Martínez, who has overseen 15 draws this season, argues that another point will be not nearly enough. Form is no real guide. Wigan have not lost at home since February but have been beaten in four of their last five encounters with West Ham. Tim Rich

This promises to be a lively affair. Black Country derbies have plenty of edge to them but Sunday's match carries extra spice because Wolves are desperate to pick up the three points that would give their survival hopes a shot in the arm. The form guide, however, favours Albion, who have picked up 16 points from their last nine games. Peter Odemwingie has been particularly impressive in recent weeks and goes into this fixture attempting to become the first player to score in five successive Premier League games this season. Stuart James

Wigan should take comfort from having never lost a league game at Villa Park as they edge towards the end of this gripping relegation battle. Victory on Saturday afternoon would make the fight to stay alive more thrilling still, as it would suddenly pull Aston Villa back into danger. The hosts remain inconsistent – they have won, drawn and lost their last three matches – and, under the caretaker charge of the inexperienced Gary McAllister, would fret were they to find themselves within range of the bottom three with two games left to play. Sachin Nakrani

Two teams who were among the hardest to beat at the start of the season have become rather too prone to defeats for their liking, with Bolton losing five of the last seven and Sunderland nine in 11. Injuries have taken their toll, with Bolton still without a right-back and Sunderland lacking a specialist striker. Indeed, Steve Bruce's problems are multiplying, with the midfielders Lee Cattermole and Jordan Henderson the latest doubts. Owen Coyle at least has the option of recalling Jussi Jaaskelainen and Lee Chung-yong, both rested for last week's setback to Blackburn. Richard Jolly

Having fallen out with City for the way in which they took Joleon Lescott from Goodison Park, David Moyes has exacted a deep revenge. The three subsequent matches against them have all been won, extending Everton's sequence to six victories in their last seven encounters. Several weeks ago, this match and Tuesday's much-anticipated showdown with Tottenham would have been seen as formidable obstacles to Champions League qualification. However, Manchester City require just four points to achieve their pre-season goal, a situation that should be beyond even their historic capacity for cock-ups. Tim Rich

Chelsea will never give thanks for elimination from the Champions League, but they have at least had a period of rest recently. United, on the other hand, showed the first symptoms of fatigue when losing on away goals to Bayern Munich after taking the lead last season. There is a test here for Sir Alex Ferguson to come up with a line-up that has sufficient vigour while also containing the essential experience for a game that could go far towards determining the outcome of the 2010-11 Premier League title. Kevin McCarra

Prepare To Meet Thy Doom. Hard to escape a sense of foreboding at Upton Park today for a match which neither side can afford to lose, least of all West Ham. Blackburn might be happy with a draw but a failure to win would leave the home team, already anchored to the bottom following five straight defeats, facing life in the Championship without several leading players likely to leave. Avram Grant has surely only three games left as manager whatever happens. At least a West Ham win would send shudders up the table. David Lacey

Liverpool arrive on the banks of the Thames having spanked Birmingham and Newcastle in their last two games to thrust them into contention for Europa League qualification, and with the clamour for confirmation that Kenny Dalglish is to oversee the continued renaissance at fever pitch. That will surely come given the galvanising effect he has had, though the visit to Fulham represents an awkward occasion. Mark Hughes has challenged his players to secure their highest ever points tally in the top flight by winning their final three games, securing a top-10 finish en route. The Cottagers have lost only three league games since new year's day and, even without Damien Duff, will test the Dalglish inspired revival. Dominic Fifield

The sight of Tottenham may revive fading memories for Blackpool, whose last win was against the same opposition at Bloomfield Road in February. That and the urgency of their fight for survival could give them a mental edge over Spurs, who have been on an iffy run themselves and may be ambivalent about the prospect of qualifying for the Europa League. The scoreless draw with Stoke last week suggests Blackpool may finally be sorting out their defensive problems but it is still difficult to envisage them returning from White Hart Lane with more than a draw. Paul Doyle

Arsenal, their hopes downgraded to a runners-up finish, are without two major players in Cesc Fábregas and Samir Nasri and will give fitness tests to Johan Djourou and Gaël Clichy, with Thomas Vermaelen, greatly missed since August, standing by to replace Djourou in central defence. Stoke have one eye on the FA Cup final but remain keen to secure a top-ten finish. Danny Higginbotham, Matthew Etherington and Ricardo Fuller are all absent injured, but Andy Wilkinson and John Carew are fit to resume. A subplot sees Aaron Ramsey up against Ryan Shawcross, whose challenge broke the Welshman's leg last season. Joe Lovejoy

Nothing if not adventurous, Birmingham are planning a post-season jaunt to Tanzania. They intend to land at Dar es Salaam as a Premier League side and hope lingering relegation fears will be banished on Saturday afternoon. "There's no chance we'll take our foot off the pedal," said Alex McLeish. While much may depend on the midfield duel between Birmingham's Newcastle old boy Lee Bowyer and Cheik Tioté, Mike Williamson's broken arm offers Steven Taylor a rare start. "Steven's got the technical ability to be an England player," said Alan Pardew. "But he's flattened out." Louise Taylor

"Am I scared of any of them? No. Am I looking forward to it? Yes," Ian Holloway said on Friday of the sides his Blackpool team must face in the run-in. Despite his bullish attitude, Holloway must surely believe that with visits to Tottenham and Manchester United either side of entertaining Bolton to come, Saturday's meeting with Stoke represents the best chance of picking up a precious victory. The visitors could be forgiven for being distracted by the FA Cup final, but it would be naive to expect a team managed by Tony Pulis to be a soft touch. Rich Flower

West Ham's situation is beginning to look critical, with their co-owner David Sullivan saying this week they have only a "25 to 30%" chance of staying up. They are also facing a side they have beaten only once in their 11 attempts. City's win at Blackburn has strengthened their hopes of qualifying for the Champions League and Joe Hart needs only one more clean sheet to equal the club record of 26 in a single season, set by Nicky Weaver in 1998-99. Hart's form means the fit-again Shay Given will leave the club in the summer and Arsenal are monitoring his availability despite passing up the opportunity in the last two transfer windows. Daniel Taylor

Wolves are running out of time to turn plaudits into points. The team has been admired this season for their regular endeavour and occasional guile, but sat in 19th place and having claimed just one point from a possible 12, relegation will be their fate unless a couple of wins are secured before the season's end. St Andrew's would be a decent place to start, particularly given Birmingham are fellow candidates for the drop, but the visitors travel to the home of their local rivals having not won a top-flight match there since November 1981. Sachin Nakrani

There is little love lost between Steve Bruce and Mark Hughes. Indeed these former Manchester United team-mates turned frosty Premier League rivals will both want to put one over on the other. Bruce's cause is hampered by injuries which have left him without a recognised striker. This means the 5ft 7in Benin international midfielder Stéphane Sessègnon will be pressed into emergency striking duties with fellow midfielder Steed Malbranque occupying 'the hole'. No matter; after observing this new double act in training Sunderland's players have already dubbed Sessègnon – likely to be marked by Fulham's 6ft 4in Brede Hangeland – "The new Drogba." Louise Taylor

These two clubs are linked by Sam Allardyce, whose final game as Blackburn manager was a 2-1 defeat to Bolton in December. His former employers are headed in different directions, however, with Wanderers on course for their highest finish since Allardyce's time in charge while Rovers' 10-year spell in the Premier League might be nearing an end. Both sides may be without the strikers they borrowed in January but, as Bolton's Daniel Sturridge has seven goals and Blackburn's Roque Santa Cruz none, that looks less of a loss to Steve Kean's side. Richard Jolly

A sense of calm continues to characterise Roberto Martínez but the Wigan manager knows that for all his team's stylistic virtues, now is the time for them to get ugly. They simply cannot replicate last week's crumble at Sunderland if relegation is to be avoided and against an Everton side in the midst of its usual end-of-season flourish, the hosts must dominate from the outset. It helps Wigan that Maynor Figueroa is available again after suspension, although the visitors may be bolstered themselves by the return of Mikel Arteta. Sachin Nakrani

With both teams reaching 40 points this would normally be an end-of-season mid-table encounter of little consequence, but this time nobody can afford to relax and the game should be the better for it. With Darren Bent finding his finishing touch, Villa – who have recalled Barry Bannan from his loan spell at Leeds – will be confident of getting something from the afternoon. But Albion, beaten once in nine games, are thriving under Roy Hodgson and it says something for their revival that anything other than a home win will be a disappointment. David Lacey

Europa League qualification appears a strange incentive for a club that was hardly fixated with the competition this season but it is a mark of Liverpool's transformation under Kenny Dalglish that it is within their sights. Liverpool remain three points adrift of Tottenham, having played a game more, but face a less daunting run-in commencing with this fixture against a Newcastle team that has lost its way on the road of late. Newcastle have won as many away games as Manchester United – five – but only one of their last seven. They have not won at Anfield in the Premier League since 1994. Andy Hunter

Chelsea require victory to narrow the gap on Manchester United to three points ahead of the leaders visit to Arsenal on Sunday, while Tottenham know failure to win allows Manchester City a four point lead and a game advantage in the challenge for a Champions League berth. Last Saturday, Fernando Torres replaced Didier Drogba against West Ham and the £50m man finally opened his account in his 14th Chelsea appearance. Carlo Ancelotti claims he may consider pairing the strikers against Spurs despite the strategy not working so far. Jamie Jackson

Arsenal could have been in contention for the title, but their main hope of making an impression this weekend will lie in hindering Manchester United's progress towards the prize. If the Champions League victory over Schalke in Gelsenkirchen is any indication, Sir Alex Ferguson's side is getting sharper in away matches. For Arsenal, the target is to deliver a rare win over these visitors that will allow supporters a happy afternoon in a spell where their side has otherwise lost all impetus after a string of disappointing results. Kevin McCarra

Arsenal have won only one of their last eight matches and cannot afford any more slip-ups if they are to revive their title chances. They will be up against demoralised opponents, with Bolton still reeling from their 5-0 thrashing against Stoke in last weekend's FA Cup semi-final. A goal for Robin van Persie will see him set a Premier League record for scoring in seven away games on the run. Arsenal, however, have other ambitions and anything but a victory will almost certainly condemn the club to another year without a trophy. Daniel Taylor

Chelsea's recent Premier League record may be impressive, with six wins in seven, but, realistically, Carlo Ancelotti's side cannot afford to shed another point this season if they are to make the title "dream" of which the manager has spoken a reality. West Ham have not claimed victory across the capital in nine years and will arrive desperate to ease their considerable relegation fears by surprising the hosts. Yet Avram Grant's team will privately be pining for their last three games, which appear less daunting than their next two. Dominic Fifield

This game had more than enough riding on it without Karl Henry, the Wolves captain, reminding Danny Murphy that he "should worry about his team and no one else's". Murphy had implied Wolves were "too pumped up" in the wake of Henry breaking Bobby Zamora's leg at Craven Cottage in September. The Fulham midfielder seems certain to get a hostile reception at Molineux on an afternoon when Wolves will be desperate to pick up three points to revive their survival hopes. Fulham are not yet safe but one more win should be enough. Stuart James

This could be a tricky one for Tottenham. West Brom's seven-match record under Roy Hodgson (3-3-1) is better than Spurs' last six league games (1-4-1) and in September Albion won at Arsenal under Roberto Di Matteo. Harry Redknapp will want his side to show the powers of recovery that they demonstrated in Wednesday's thrilling 3-3 with Arsenal but would prefer it if they did not dig themselves a hole in the first place. Another home draw would raise serious doubts about Spurs again finishing in the top four. David Lacey

Two of the season's more unexpected winners of silverware meet as Carling Cup holders Birmingham encounter newly-crowned PFA Fans' Player of the Year, Raul Meireles, but while Alex McLeish's men have secured a place in Europe, the prize they really crave is another season in the top flight. Martin Jiranek should be fit to return to Birmingham's defence while Liverpool could be without both Jamie Carragher and Andy Carroll, should they fail fitness tests. Teenagers John Flanagan and Jack Robinson are likely to be the full-backs. Richard Jolly

In the unfortunate absence due to ill health of Aston Villa manager Gérard Houllier, attention turns to his assistant Gary McAllister, a man whose managerial record at Coventry City and Leeds United was average to say the least. Stoke should still be on a high after securing the club's first FA Cup final appearance in real style last weekend with their 5-0 win over Bolton, and given a win for either side would end any lingering relegation concern, this is not a match in which end-of-season lassitude is likely to be a factor. Richard Rae

Both sides need a result, with Manchester City requiring points to hold off Tottenham's challenge for the fourth and final Champions League place and Blackburn hoping to halt their alarming slump in form which has not seen them win in 10 games. That run has left Rovers just two points outside the relegation zone. The manager Steve Kean will hope to welcome back his young striker Junior Hoilett after a hamstring strain, but Keith Andrews is still injured, while City are without their top scorer Carlos Tevez. Toby Moses

A home match against a mid-table side is attractive to any team in sight of the title, but this fixture might not be as simple an exercise as it appears for Manchester United. Everton have not lost a Premier League match since mid-February and that form has taken them to seventh place. With matches against Arsenal and Chelsea to come, this is a critical phase for Sir Alex Ferguson's side, who cannot afford any more of the drabness seen in the goalless draw at Newcastle United if they are to secure a 19th league title. Kevin McCarra

Bottom of the table a week ago, Wigan know victory will lift them to within a point of struggling Sunderland. Steve Bruce, Roberto Martínez's predecessor at the DW Stadium, has seen his side lose eight and draw one of their past nine games. He needs a strong performance from captain Lee Cattermole – also once of Wigan – but must be mindful of the threat posed by Charles N'Zogbia, Martínez's outstanding individual. "You've got to show your teeth, come out fighting and hope people around you have the same kind of bollocks," said Bruce. Louise Taylor

Blackpool have been handed a double boost with the return of David Vaughan from injury and the news that Charlie Adam's suspected broken foot was just bruising. Newcastle have no fresh concerns following their draw with Manchester United, which lifted them to the magic 40-point mark. Ian Holloway's side need seven more points to join them, and he's shown them a video of past victories to lift the team – "we've got to look back at the times we've played and scored and won games that people never believed we could do." Toby Moses

The West Ham manager, Avram Grant, will hope that Scott Parker is able to shake off an achilles problem that has troubled him all season. Parker is key to his side's chances of a victory that would take them to within two points of Aston Villa while defeat could see them drop below Wolves on goal difference. Carlton Cole is likely to start for the hosts despite his recent escapades on Twitter while Gerárd Houllier has a full Villa squad to choose from and will have no excuses if his team find themselves deeper in the mire after this match. Richard Flower

Arsène Wenger thinks that Arsenal have exceeded many people's expectations simply by remaining in the top four, but the larger truth is that they could easily be competing hard for the title if it were not for some very avoidable lapses, which include three defeats at home. This weekend, victory over Liverpool would take them to within four points of leaders Manchester United, who have a game to come at the Emirates. Liverpool possess in Andy Carroll exactly the sort of centre-forward who could cause havoc in Arsenal's defence. Kevin McCarra

The Birmingham manager Alex McLeish wants to see "bottle" from his players now that safety beckons, while Sunderland's Steve Bruce wishes he could "bottle confidence" and get his players to down a few pints. The visitors have gone eight games without a win and conceded 21 goals in that time; they travel to St Andrew's without the injured defenders Anton Ferdinand, John Mensah and Titus Bramble. The pressure will be on Asamoah Gyan to get back to scoring, though Birmingham should have defender Roger Johnson available after a concussion. Nikola Zigic is likely to be fit enough for the bench. Georgina Turner

While Ian Holloway relaxes by tending chickens, Roberto Martínez switches off from the pressures at Wigan by watching 12 to 15 European and South American matches a week on television. 'All that football is not always good for my relationship with my wife but it's my way of finding inner peace,' said the Spaniard. Equally desperate to avoid Championship football, Holloway trusts serenity will prove elusive for Martínez at Bloomfield Road on Saturday. The Blackpool manager must cope without his influential midfielder David Vaughan, whose hip injury may prove season ending. Louise Taylor

Blackburn are lacking experience in the dugout as they slip towards trouble, and now in defence with Ryan Nelsen ruled out for the rest of the season following knee surgery. A run of nine matches without a win under Steve Kean has left them three points clear of the relegation zone and although their last away trip yielded a spirited draw at Arsenal, they face a demanding run-in. It continues against an Everton team who are stacking up the points as well as the injuries, and have not lost at home in the league since November. Andy Hunter

The manager who can do no wrong versus the man who cannot get it right. West Bromwich Albion, unbeaten in their last seven, are up to 10th under Roy Hodgson, despite the continuing absence of last season's top scorer, Graham Dorrans. Chelsea, who can now win nothing after going out of the Champions League, have Carlo Ancelotti admitting he was wrong to prefer Torres to Drogba in midweek – a mistake he cannot afford to repeat. He is without Alex and Ramires, both with thigh injuries, but David Luiz is available again. Joe Lovejoy

Arsenal travel to the seaside with their title aspirations all washed up. Last week's stalemate with Blackburn means the Gunners are seven points adrift of leaders Manchester United with little in their form suggesting they can make up the difference. The injuries also continue to mount up, with Alex Song now out with a knee strain. Aaron Ramsey, is expected to replace the Cameroon midfielder and face a Blackpool side who, ahead of kick-off, could find themselves in the bottom three for the first time this season. Sachin Nakrani

Back in October 1892 Sunderland, then English Champions and known as "the team of all the talents", thrashed West Bromwich Albion 8-1 on Wearside. How times change. After failing to win for seven games and collecting a single point in the process, Steve Bruce's side cannot expect the score to be similarly one-sided in this relegation tussle, especially as Roy Hodgson's team have gone six matches unbeaten and the home players have not scored a single goal in their past four fixtures. Sunderland's apparently burnt-out England Under-21 midfielder Jordan Henderson will be given a long overdue rest. Louise Taylor

With Wayne Rooney's potty mouth ruling him out of contention for two matches, Sir Alex Ferguson is likely call on Dimitar Berbatov and Javier Hernández to lead Manchester United's attack against Fulham. The London club's manager, Mark Hughes, will hope his former team are preoccupied by thoughts of their Champions League return game with Chelsea to come as he looks to become the first man, Ferguson aside, to lead a club to victory at Old Trafford this season. "We are playing well, so why not have a go? If their eye is off the ball, then maybe we can exploit that," Hughes said. Tom Clarke

If West Ham survive, it will be their record away from Upton Park that keeps them up. They have not lost any of their last four away games, but with the manager, Avram Grant, serving a touchline ban, they will be pushed to make it five. Their last seven fixtures against Bolton have all ended in defeat and they have never won at the Reebok Stadium, scraping together a solitary victory in this corner of Greater Manchester since 1958. Zat Knight and Mark Davies return to the Bolton squad after spells out injured. Tim Rich

Roberto Martínez may have gleaned a satisfying point from the visit of Tottenham Hotspur last week, but he and his squad may tremble at the prospect of confronting Chelsea. Last year's visit to Stamford Bridge, on the season's final afternoon, ended in an 8-0 spanking, while the London club prevailed 6-0 in the north-west back in August. The Latics will take heart from their hosts' current striker toils, but they will need to repeat the resilience on show last week, and some, to enhance their prospects of survival this afternoon. Dominic Fifield

Following this fixture two seasons ago the home side secured a place in the top six while Newcastle were relegated. How times have changed. Gérard Houllier wants Aston Villa to accrue 10 points from their remaining seven games, a target he feels will ensure they stay in the Premier League. "Excuses are not an option. We want results and points," the Frenchman said. Newcastle are all but safe after last week's 4-1 win over Wolves. They are now looking for the victories which could yet secure them a top-six finish of their own. Tom Clarke

There is now a chasm between Liverpool and Champions League qualification following last week's defeat at Roy Hodgson's West Bromwich Albion but having defeated Chelsea and Manchester United since taking charge, Kenny Dalglish must summon another response against the club whose wealth has helped shove Anfield outside the European elite. City were rampant in their last outing against Sunderland – when Gareth Barry, James Milner and Edin Dzeko were all rested – but, with United to follow in the FA Cup semi-final, a depleted Liverpool will hope Roberto Mancini's men have their minds elsewhere. Andy Hunter

Last weekend's 4-1 defeat at Newcastle was one of the season's low points for Mick McCarthy's side, but they are a different prospect at home, where Manchester United, Manchester City and Chelsea have all been beaten. After Everton, Fulham, West Brom and Blackburn all have to visit Molineux before the end of the season – three wins should be the target. Tomorrow would be a fine time to start but Everton, unbeaten in five matches, have the chance to finish above Liverpool and maybe qualify for the Europa League again. John Ashdown

Harry Redknapp did not mention the 'bare bones', but it is clear he believes his Tottenham squad are feeling the physical effects of a long season spent fighting on more than one front. After the battering at Real Madrid he will patch his players up and send them out for the final push, but a Stoke team he admires would not be the opponents he would chose, even if Tony Pulis's men are getting the credit for being more than mere powerhouses. In the battle for fourth, Tottenham know they must win here. David Hytner

These clubs could figure prominently in Arsenal's end-of-season inquest. Blackburn may effectively have ended the Gunners' title challenge last week while Birmingham beat them in the Carling Cup final. Both, however, are endangered, with their respective Glaswegian managers, Steve Kean and Alex McLeish, looking to plot a path to safety. Blackburn can recall Gaël Givet and Morten Gamst Pedersen from suspension and illness respectively, while Alexander Hleb is available for Birmingham after two months out injured. Richard Jolly

Both sides have problems with strikers. For City, Roberto Mancini says Carlos Tevez's form has regressed lately, Edin Dzeko is struggling to get in the team and Mario Balotelli has been, well, Mario Balotelli. "His behaviour must improve," Mancini said of a player who seems to have a magnetic attraction to controversy. Sunderland's issue is goals, with only seven different scorers in league, the lowest in the division. They have not scored in the past three games, taking only one point from the last six, although Asamoah Gyan will relish renewing acquaintances with Joleon Lescott after eluding him for Ghana's equaliser against England on Tuesday. Daniel Taylor

Blackpool have won only twice in 2011, but the scalps of Liverpool and Tottenham prove that they can beat the best – they just have to beat some of the rest in order to earn a second season in the Premier League. Fulham, though, are in good form at Craven Cottage in the league over the same period, with four wins and a draw out of five. They could be without Aaron Hughes, who dislocated a shoulder on Northern Ireland duty, while DJ Campbell completes a three match suspension for Blackpool. Nick Szczepanik

This is a huge game for the troubled Gérard Houllier and one that the Aston Villa manager needs to take at least a point from to gain some respite. Everton have improved of late but they have failed to beat Villa in nine Premier League games and will be missing their leading scorer Louis Saha through injury and have doubts about several other key players. Richard Dunne and James Collins are set to return to the centre of Villa's defence for the first time since they turned a team-building exercise into a drunken row. Stuart James

Harry Redknapp insists he "can't even look at Tuesday", when the first leg of Tottenham's most prestigious European tie for more than a quarter of a century takes place in the splendour of the Bernabéu. But Gareth Bale will have at least one eye on Madrid, as he rests his hamstring injury. Spurs, who excel when bare bones are exposed, have ground to recover in their bid for the top-four finish that would guarantee consecutive Champions League seasons. Relegation-threatened Wigan should recall fit-again top scorer Hugo Rodallega, whose goal inflicted the London club's only home league defeat this season. Richard Gibson

It is not so much the two wins from their past nine league games as the fact they have scored just 14 goals in their last 17 that lead many people to include Birmingham City among their predicted three to be relegated to the Championship. Bolton Wanderers themselves have hardly sparkled away from home this season, but Owen Coyle's team do not get beaten by sides in the bottom half of the table, and having won here in the FA Cup three weeks ago, a point will be the least of their expectations. Richard Rae

Arsenal have taken a single victory from their past six matches in all competitions, but they have a chance to show that their situation can work to their advantage. Unlike their rivals they now have the league as their sole objective and players such as Cesc Fábregas and Theo Walcott are returning to fitness. Blackburn still have hope because Arsenal so often thwart themselves, but the form of Steve Kean's team is troubling. While their scoring record in away matches is their defensive record on the road is the worst in the division. Kevin McCarra

Sir Alex Ferguson's record at Upton Park is passable but the Manchester United manager may associate the stadium with the death of title campaigns. His comment about already relegated West Ham's "obscene effort" in 1992 has entered folklore and so has his team's failure to win on the final day in 1995. United have shed points away from home this season and another two or three here might spark feelings of deja vu. The margins for error are tight for both clubs although West Ham are not playing like a relegation team. David Hytner

Stoke will feel two more wins would guarantee top-flight survival and allow them to concentrate on their FA Cup semi-final, but for Chelsea, a run of wins now will thrust them back into the defence of their league title. This trip feels awkward on paper, but Chelsea have won the past three meetings between the sides 11-0 on aggregate and have not dropped league points to Stoke since 1984. They are expected to prefer Didier Drogba's brawn up front. Fernando Torres's wait for a first Chelsea goal may be prolonged. Dominic Fifield

Some will see this as Roy Hodgson's chance to get back at his previous employers but the West Brom manager will be more concerned with seeing his side take enough from the game to stay out of the bottom three in a relegation situation which is becoming too tight to call. While Albion have not lost in five matches four of those have been draws and this time nobody is likely to find salvation a point at a time. Kenny Dalglish will want all three today and a repeat of Liverpool's performance at Sunderland should be enough. David Lacey

As an ex-Sunderland manager Mick McCarthy expects a hot reception on Tyneside. Undeterred, he trusts that, despite lacking the injured Kevin Doyle – a striker integral to Wolves's strategy – his side can drag Newcastle into relegation waters. Aware Alan Pardew's team have won one of their past 10 games, McCarthy said: "Newcastle have 36 points but, if we beat them they're in it, no question." In contrast, a win would place the hosts, for whom Stephen Ireland should make his debut, within touching distance of safety. "It would put seven points between us," said McCarthy. "That would make catching Newcastle hard." Louise Taylor

Manchester United have dropped only two points at home all season, whereas Bolton have not won away in the league since November, but Sir Alex Ferguson could be excused for feeling a little uncomfortable as he begins his five-match touchline ban. United's injury problems are considerable and, if Jonny Evans is not passed fit, it may be that a midfielder, Darren Fletcher or Michael Carrick, has to play instead of Wes Brown at right-back. Add to that Paul Scholes starting a two-match ban for accumulating ten yellow cards and Bolton, potential FA Cup final opponents, can believe they have at least a chance of ending a run of seven successive defeats at Old Trafford. Daniel Taylor

Gérard Houllier marked his first Premier League game in charge of Aston Villa with a win over Wolves in September but little has gone right since. Villa have won only five of their subsequent 23 league games and there has been an endless stream of problems off the field, the latest being a team-bonding session that turned into a drunken row. With Villa's defence ravaged by injury, Wolves will view this as the ideal opportunity to defeat their neighbours for the first time in 31 years and drag them deeper into relegation trouble. Stuart James

With convincing wins against Liverpool and Stoke behind them, West Ham's form in the Premier League compares favourably with that of Tottenham following their trials at Blackpool and Wolves. Spurs lost to a goal from Frédéric Piquionne at Upton Park in September so West Ham supporters will turn up with a sense of anticipation added to the usual feelings of rivalry. Spurs may need to take a higher proportion of their chances to overcome opponents whose scoring rate is improving, and West Ham could have the edge in midfield. David Lacey

Arsène Wenger insists the Premier League is a two-horse race, and if it is to remain that way Arsenal have to win games like this. In need of a lift after elimination from the FA Cup and Champions League, they have Nicklas Bendtner available again, but Cesc Fábregas (hamstring), Alex Song (knee) and Theo Walcott (ankle) are all injured. Albion, unbeaten in their last four, and on the road to recovery under Roy Hodgson, are without the influential Graham Dorrans, but hope to have Youssouf Mulumbu fit after hamstring trouble. Joe Lovejoy

There are hoodoos and there is Fulham at Goodison Park – the Cottagers have lost their last 17 league matches at Everton. It was perhaps appropriate that they should have been David Moyes's first opponents as Everton manager and they return amid rather downbeat celebrations for his ninth anniversary. This will be a match of makeshift midfields. Fulham are without Dickson Etuhu and Steve Sidwell while Everton are missing Marouane Fellaini, Mikel Arteta and possibly Tim Cahill, although Phil Neville is likely to shake off a hamstring injury. Tim Rich

Having hit out at "lazy" journalists for describing his team as overly physical, the Stoke City chairman, Peter Coates, will be glad to know that no such suggestion is to be made here. Instead the focus is on Stoke's home record, which since the turn of the year has been impeccable. Tony Pulis's men are unbeaten at the Britannia Stadium in 2011, with their most recent win there being the FA Cup triumph over West Ham. Newcastle arrive in the Potteries having won only one of their last nine games in all competitions. Sachin Nakrani

Fourteenth hosts 15th in a battle of clubs that have been sucked into the relegation battle and who stand only a point above the drop zone. Steve Kean's Blackburn side have not won since late January as rumours grow that despite the new owner's assurances, he could be sacked in the summer if Premier League status is not maintained. For Blackpool, since mid-January their league return stands at only four points from a possible 27 which has, rather sadly, put Ian Holloway's early season success story into freefall. Each team requires a win. Jamie Jackson

Even the elements appear to be conspiring against bottom club Wigan – their warm-weather break in La Manga this week turned out to be gloomier than the atmosphere they left behind – and an improved Premier League outlook will depend on winning matches like this. Roberto Martínez will feel the portents for victory are good: fellow strugglers West Bromwich, Wolves and Blackburn all succumbed at the DW Stadium. Meanwhile, f

As Dynamo Kyiv eliminated Manchester City from the Europa League, there was a laborious tone to Roberto Mancini's side that was not explained entirely by the red card for Mario Balotelli. They have scored significantly fewer Premier League goals than any of the other clubs in the top four. Chelsea drew a blank at Stamford Bridge against Copenhagen, but had virtually won that Champions League tie in the first leg. Carlo Ancelotti's side has lost just one of its past dozen games and looks equipped to continue the recent rise. Kevin McCarra

Asamoah Gyan v Luis "hand of God" Suárez, Steve Bruce v Kenny Dalglish and Andy Carroll v Titus Bramble represent just three reasons why Sunderland's first home game in five weeks is a sell-out. Bruce's side stand eighth, two places and four points behind Dalglish's but his aim remains to reverse the positions. "We haven't given up hope of catching Liverpool," said the Sunderland manager. "If we win on Sunday we stand a chance of overhauling them by May." The Merseysiders though are desperate to somehow revive their fading dreams of European qualification. Louise Taylor

Manchester City will be in their first FA Cup semi-final for 30 years if they can overcome Reading, but Everton will be able to testify that the Championship's eighth-placed side cannot be underestimated. Reading, quarter-finalists for a second successive year after their 1-0 win at Goodison Park in the fifth round, can be encouraged by the fact City come into this match on the back of a gruelling trip to Ukraine for a Europa League tie that saw the team arrive back in Manchester at almost 5am today. Roberto Mancini will hope the grass at Eastlands is kinder to Mario Balotelli as the club aim to reach Wembley for the first time since the third-tier play-offs in 1999. Daniel Taylor

These two clubs meet eight days after West Ham defeated Stoke 3-0 at Upton Park in the Premier League. That result provided further evidence of West Ham's renaissance and the growing influence of Demba Ba and Thomas Hitzlsperger. Ba failed a medical at Stoke in January and could well feature up front alongside the fit-again Robbie Keane as Avram Grant, having allowed Kieron Dyer to join his former club Ipswich on loan for a month, enjoys the luxury of picking from a full-strength squad. Matthew Etherington is set to return for Stoke against his former club. Stuart James

Bolton will fancy this one. Birmingham already have a trophy and with seven first-team players doubtful, among them Lee Bowyer and Craig Gardner, will be more concerned about staying up than making a quick return to Wembley. By contrast, Owen Coyle feels winning the FA Cup would be a fitting tribute to the late Nat Lofthouse, and to judge by Bolton's away displays in the competition his players are of a similar mind. Birmingham have held the opposition at the Reebok this season but for Alex McLeish a replay would be an unwanted chore. David Lacey

These are clubs in need of therapy at least as much as a place in the FA Cup semi-finals. Manchester United have lost two games in a row and Arsenal were knocked out of Europe. Both sides, though, are also competing for the Premier League title and any success in deepening the other's gloom would be welcomed. Arsenal's last victory at Old Trafford came in September 2006. Arsène Wenger's team will also have to shake off the despondency of Cesc Fábregas being sidelined by a recurrence of his hamstring injury. Kevin McCarra

Mick McCarthy will be hoping that the absence of Jamie O'Hara does not have an adverse effect on his resurgent Wolves side. O'Hara is unable to play against his parent club, who continue to find themselves in a battle with Chelsea to secure the fourth Champions League qualifying place. The home team's concerns are very different – they have been out of the bottom three only twice in the last 20 games. Both sides will use this match to remember Dean Richards, the former Wolves and Spurs defender who died on Saturday. Tom Sheen

There may never be a good time to meet sock-it-to-'em Stoke, but for West Ham now seems as good as any. Amid a clutter of cup ties Avram Grant's side have lost only once in five league matches while Tony Pulis's team have won one in five. West Ham forced a 1-1 draw at the Britannia Stadium in September and their goalscorer that day, Scott Parker, remains their best hope of avoiding relegation. West Ham's defence is looking more resilient but will need its ARP hats to counter the visitor's usual aerial bombardment. David Lacey

The classic 'six-pointer'. Birmingham will be on a high after winning the Carling Cup at Arsenal's expense while West Bromwich will hope to catch them still in celebratory mood and off guard. Nobody in the league has scored fewer than the Blues' 25 goals in 26 games. The Baggies have been undermined at the other end, only Wigan conceding more than their 53 in 28. After three successive draws, they are close to full strength. For Birmingham, Roger Johnson is expected to shake off his calf injury but Barry Ferguson and Craig Gardner are doubtful. Joe Lovejoy

Prioritising the Premier League is nothing new, but Gérard Houllier's decision to rest the majority of the Aston Villa first-team for their defeat to Manchester City in the FA Cup means this game acquires an added importance for the Frenchman. More intrigue surrounds Houllier's selection than Owen Coyle's, but Bolton could reach Europe via either of two routes. Sixth place, where Villa finished last season, would be their reward for victory and the in-form Daniel Sturridge pursues a fifth goal in as many games against a defence without the injured Richard Dunne. Richard Jolly

Viewed by some as an upstart in managerial circles, Steve Kean would be forgiven for practising his post-match handshake ahead of Blackburn Rovers' trip to Fulham. Mark Hughes's apparent need for validation from his peers – he clashed with Roberto Mancini in last weekend's draw with Manchester City – does his side no credit as they creep up the table. Blackburn, who could give a debut to the former Barcelona B forward Rubén Rochina, were ninth on New Year's Day but are now heading in the wrong direction. James Callow

After their trauma at Wembley last Sunday, this now feels like a pivotal weekend for Arsenal's title aspirations. Manchester United were beaten in midweek and must travel to Anfield, meaning Arsène Wenger's side could potentially end the weekend a point behind the leaders with a game in hand. The management will plead for focus with the trip to the Camp Nou to come on Tuesday, Wenger claiming that beating Sunderland had become his "obsession". The visitors are on a downturn, eighth in the table but beaten in their last four fixtures. Their last league win at Arsenal came in 1983. An awkward afternoon awaits. Dominic Fifield

The win over Manchester United in midweek has just about kept Chelsea in the title race, but Carlo Ancelotti knows his team can ill afford any more slip-ups. Fernando Torres will be hoping the most porous defence in the league allows him to open his account for the Blues. Blackpool have been in free-fall of late, having picked up only seven points in their last 11 games, and with two of their most influential players, Charlie Adam and DJ Campbell, missing through suspension Chelsea will expect to collect three points at Bloomfield Road. Tom Sheen

Arsenal, Manchester City and Tottenham Hotspur have all taken more points from away matches in the Premier League than Manchester United. That record, which includes the recent 2-1 defeat at Chelsea, adds to the stress of the trip to Anfield, where Sir Alex Ferguson's side has been beaten on its last two visits. The joy of disrupting United's bid for a record 19th league title would be memorable for Liverpool, who need time to develop their squad before they can expect to compete for major trophies themselves. Kevin McCarra

Manchester City will be pleased Vincent Kompany is fit enough to return to the side given Kolo Touré's suspension for failing a drugs test. Indifferent league form has allowed Manchester United and Arsenal to pull away from the hosts at the top of the table while Chelsea are now also breathing down City's neck. Despite an encouraging opening 20 minutes against United last week, Wigan collapsed and now look in serious danger of being relegated. The bottom-placed team have the second-worst attack in the league and need to start scoring if they are to survive. Tom Sheen

At the end of a week in which he received a six-figure out of court settlement from Newcastle, Victor Anichebe makes a first return to St James' Park since a two-footed tackle by Kevin Nolan seriously damaged his knee in 2009. The Everton striker, on a highly incentivised contract, sued for loss of earnings after requiring two operations. Newcastle's Shola Ameobi, another Nigerian-born forward, has undergone facial surgery on a fractured cheekbone but could feature wearing a protective mask specially made and fitted in the United States last week. Meanwhile, Alan Pardew's troubled midfield talents, Stephen Ireland and Joey Barton, require late fitness tests. Louise Taylor

Cup finals are meant to be enjoyable occasions but this one provides Arsenal with sizeable stress as they face the challenge of claiming a first trophy in six years. Arsène Wenger's team will be expected to flourish against opponents they humbled 3-0 on New Year's Day, even though their captain, Cesc Fábregas, and Theo Walcott are missing through injury. Birmingham, fresh from reaching the FA Cup quarter-finals, may just feel they can cause a shock and win the League Cup for the first time in almost half a century. Sachin Nakrani

Manchester City won the corresponding fixture 4-1 in November and Mark Hughes could be in for a difficult time given his former club have won seven home games on the bounce. With 24 goals scored in the process, Roberto Mancini is removing the suspicion that he may be too restrained in his tactics, with Mario Balotelli, Carlos Tevez and Edin Dzeko all starting the win over Aris Thessaloniki on Thursday. Bobby Zamora's hopes of a first start for Fulham for five months are in the balance after he twisted his ankle in training. Daniel Taylor

When it comes to Merseyside, Everton instil far more fear in Sunderland hearts than Liverpool. In the last 30 years they have won only once at Goodison Park – and that when a former Evertonian, Peter Reid, was at the helm. After three straight defeats, Steve Bruce is likely to freshen up his midfield by replacing Steed Malbranque with Ahmed Elmohamady. Having salvaged their season with the FA Cup penalty shoot-out win at Stamford Bridge last week, Everton are likely to welcome Louis Saha back into their attack. Tim Rich

West Ham might have been contesting the Carling Cup final but, instead, have a timely opportunity to move out of the relegation zone. Avram Grant's team have been horribly inconsistent in the league but must now build on their unlikely recovery at The Hawthorns in their last outing, together with the FA Cup thrashing inflicted on Burnley, to inject real momentum into their campaign. Liverpool have lost only once at Upton Park since 1999 and could move within three points of fifth-placed Chelsea with victory. Unbeaten in eight, they represent an awkward obstacle to the Londoners' aspirations. Dominic Fifield

Newcastle have not won a home Premier League game with a 3pm Saturday kick-off since 23 August 2008, when Bolton were beaten 1-0. By further coincidence, Kevin Nolan, now the Newcastle captain, had a penalty saved for the visitors that afternoon before Michael Owen secured a home win. Newcastle are out for revenge following their 5-1 thrashing by Bolton last November, which came two weeks before Chris Hughton's dismissal as manager. His successor, Alan Pardew, has rewarded Cheik Tioté with a new contract. Louise Taylor

Tony Pulis nearly pulled off a draw at the Emirates Stadium last Wednesday when his Stoke side came close to totally smothering the skills of Arsenal. On Monday he hopes to record a vital win that would take his team's points tally to within four of the magic safety number of 40. Roy Hodgson's single game so far in charge of West Bromwich Albion saw them salvage a late draw against Wolves, so no doubt he will remind his troops of how far spirit and unity can take a team that is only one place above the drop zone. Jamie Jackson

Could it be 13th time lucky for Wigan? Current form says absolutely not. The Latics have faced United 12 times since being promoted to the top flight in 2005 (11 in the Premier League, once in the League Cup) and lost every one, conceding 37 goals and scoring just four in the process. On paper, Sir Alex Ferguson could not wish for a better start to three consecutive away games that will shape his team's title challenge, with Stamford Bridge and Anfield awaiting next week. But this is where Wayne Rooney and Dimitar Berbatov must respond to their manager's call to improve outside of Old Trafford. Andy Hunter

This is the type of game from which Wolves need maximum points if they are to stay up; unfortunately for them it is also the sort of fixture Blackpool specialise in winning. Ian Holloway's cheap and cheerful cavaliers have won at Wigan, Newcastle, Liverpool, Stoke and Sunderland already, and demonstrated a timely return to form by beating Tottenham 3-1 in midweek. Wolves, typically, defeated Liverpool and Chelsea, then lost their next four before beating Manchester United. Consistent only in their inconsistency. Joe Lovejoy

Gérard Houllier made six changes when Aston Villa met Blackburn in the FA Cup a month ago, including a number of youngsters as well as the wise old head of Robert Pires,and saw his team win 3-1. He will field a more recognisable side today as Villa, still deeply embroiled among the strugglers, seek what would be only their third league win of the year. Blackburn may lie in mid-table but they are just two points ahead of today's opponents, so a tighter encounter is in prospect with possibly one goal deciding it. David Lacey

Roy Hodgson is about to take charge of his first game for West Bromwich Albion, but there can be little he needs to know. He watched the side draw 3-3 with West Ham after they had led 3-0. They have scored as many league goals at home as Manchester City and ought to stay in the top flight, but they have also conceded more than anyone else in the Premier League. This match does appear promising for Albion since Wolves have struggled on their travels and have so far collected just four points away from home. Kevin McCarra

After four matches unbeaten in all competitions, including a creditable draw with Manchester City, and with a Carling Cup final appearance secured and a vital away win snared against West Ham last time out, Birmingham's fortunes appear to have turned. New arrival Obafemi Martins, having resolved his visa tangle, offers Alex McLeish extra options up front, too. Stoke continue to be uncomfortable on the eye but at least their top-flight status seems to be assured. They have yet to concede more than two goals in any league game this season, a resilience that Birmingham may struggle to break down. Russell Kempson

Arsène Wenger will certainly not forgo the traditional handshake with Mick McCarthy, after Wolves's win over Manchester United lifted the Frenchman and his shell-shocked side out of their sizeable depression following their Newcastle meltdown. Wenger has one eye on Wednesday's visit of Barcelona but has indicated he will play his strongest side, assuming Johan Djourou and Alex Song are passed fit. McCarthy will persist with the XI that surprised United, the on-loan Spurs midfielder Jamie O'Hara keeping his place. Paul Chronnell

This time last week, Chelsea were crowing after spending £76.5m to sign David Luiz and Fernando Torres from Benfica and Liverpool respectively. Then came last Sunday's visit of Liverpool, a 1-0 home defeat and a horrendous debut for Torres against his old club – proof, perhaps, that accommodating the Spaniard alongside Didier Drogba and Nicolas Anelka in the starting lineup will not be easy for Chelsea's manager. With Fulham enjoying a fine run of form, Ancelotti must discover a solution sooner rather than later. Jacob Steinberg

Whether it was on opposite sides in the 1992 Scottish League Cup semi-final, entering management early, or thriving on modest resources in Lancashire, Owen Coyle and David Moyes have followed the same career path for decades. Now the two fortysomething Glaswegian friends meet in desperate need of consistency and three points. Bolton's impressive start to the season has been undermined by a run of one win in seven games while Everton have not recorded back-to-back league victories since October. The loss of the in-form Louis Saha and Jack Rodwell is a severe blow to the visitors. Andy Hunter

Yet another six-pointer for West Ham, on the bottom once more after losing at home to Birmingham last Sunday. Albion, on the other hand, have yet to occupy a place in the last three and briefly lay fourth back in October, since when a plunge down the table has cost Roberto Di Matteo his job as manager. The caretaker, Michael Appleton, will hope for a repetition of last month's performance which saw off Blackpool while Avram Grant awaits fitness tests on several of his players plus the usual questions about his future should West Ham lose again. David Lacey

Newcastle's record at Ewood Park is not promising, and they have not beaten Blackburn anywhere in four years – though they will be less daunted by such figures since their remarkable comeback against Arsenal. Blackburn have lost three of their last four matches; the manager, Steve Kean, has focused on finishing after seeing his side score five goals from more than 50 attempts in that time, and welcomes Roque Santa Cruz back from a groin injury. Newcastle's new recruit Shefki Kuqi could feature against the only one of his former clubs he has yet to face. Georgina Turner

Oh, to be a fly on wall in the Bloomfield Road dugouts. Blackpool manager Ian Holloway insists "I never hold any grudges" but his unsavoury response to Gérard Houllier's January pursuit of Charlie Adam adds piquancy to a game with a myriad of subplots. Along the touchline will be Sian Massey, on her Premier League return, while two England goalscorers, Darren Bent and Ashley Young, line up for a Villa side finally settling under Houllier. In contrast, Holloway has been tinkering with personnel during a slide of five straight defeats. Richard Gibson

Steve Bruce describes Tottenham's football as "a breath of fresh air" but Sunderland's manager may not be quite so complimentary about Harry Redknapp should his Spurs counterpart make a widely predicted bid for Kieran Richardson this summer. Hugely versatile, Richardson is vying with Phil Bardsley to be player of the season at the Stadium of Light and will be particularly keen to impress here. While Bruce's players are aiming for Europa League qualification, Spurs may well have Tuesday's trip to San Siro for the Champions League knockout date with Milan on their minds. Louise Taylor

United are unbeaten in their last five league matches with City, but circumstances are awkward this time since injuries have severely affected their defence. That difficulty is particularly problematic since it follows their first Premier League defeat of the season, at Wolves. It remains to be seen whether City have the boldness to exploit the situation, although they have been more expansive in the last couple of games, a 2-2 draw at Birmingham and a 3-0 win over West Bromwich Albion. Victory for United would leave Arsenal as their one plausible rival for the title. Kevin McCarra

Five straight wins is a sign of a team in the groove. Liverpool achieved the sequence three times when finishing second in 2009 and will do it again under Kenny Dalglish should they overcome Wigan, a club who have never won at Anfield. Both sides will have players coming back from slight injuries that prevented them from appearing internationally in midweek – Steven Gerrard and Martin Skrtel for Liverpool and James McCarthy for Wigan.
