If he is to save his job then his side will have to reverse a terrible run of results that has left them a point adrift of safety. Despite a 3-1 home defeat to Wigan last week, Burnley have made an encouraging start to the season, recording wins over Manchester United and Everton. Their manager, Owen Coyle, has expressed support for Brown but will still be hoping for a win that could consign his former captain to unemployment. Chris Bell

Expect damage limitation from Blackburn as they seek to avoid a fifth straight away defeat in the league. Any hopes of exploiting a depleted United back line have been dented by the loss of Jason Roberts to swine flu while Christopher Samba is still not fully recovered from the illness. Pascal Chimbonda and David Dunn should make a welcome return, but they face a daunting task to prevent the home side reasserting itself after last week's poor performance at Anfield. Allardyce will hope that United plumb similar depths in this match. Alex Derber

Not a day for Birmingham City fans to be boasting about their riches. The £40m that Carson Yeung has pledged to make available to Alex McLeish in January is a drop in the ocean compared to the sums that Manchester City's owners have spent. City, however, have stuttered of late, with their last three league matches all ending as draws. Birmingham will also take encouragement from their much-needed victory over Sunderland last Saturday and the defensive lapses that have seen City fail to keep a clean sheet since the end of August. Stuart James

Chelsea cannot flirt with complacency against the side they demolished in the Carling Cup. Wednesday's 4-0 win was the third successive rout at Stamford Bridge, with 13 goals scored and none conceded, but Carlo Ancelotti's last two journeys north brought defeat at Wigan and Aston Villa. Bolton, despite their meagre cup offering, should provide a truer test of Chelsea's conviction than recent home form. They are unbeaten in four at home and Gary Megson's fortunes were rising until he gave fringe players a chance they failed to take. Andy Hunter

Following victory at Tottenham last week, Tony Pulis has complained that Stoke are still not accepted as a true Premier League team. Wolves will nonetheless expect to trouble the home defence after themselves stretching Villa last week. Mick McCarthy should name a starting 11 unchanged from that game, and will have Austrian striker Stefan Maierhofer and Chelsea loanee Michael Mancienne back on the bench. Thomas Sorensen, returning from illness, is expected to regain his place in the Stoke goal and Tuncay may also start as the home side try to put Tuesday's Carling Cup drubbing behind them. Alex Derber

Liverpool's Carling Cup defeat at Arsenal has done little to dilute the feel-good factor generated by their victory over Manchester United. Rafael Benítez's team scrap well when seemingly hemmed in but they ought not to need the stimulus of crisis. There is a determination to build on the United triumph and much will be read into their showing at Craven Cottage,not least because it presages another drama – the Champions League tie at Lyon. Fulham feel their results have not reflected their performances and are keen to make a statement. David Hytner

The simplistic take on the Premier League is that it consists of two species – the Big Four and the rest – but in the past couple of seasons these two clubs have formed a demilitarised zone. Finishing fifth and sixth suggested they were betwixt and between – too good for the rest, not good enough for the best – but now that status is under threat from Manchester City and Tottenham. Credit to Everton, though – despite their training ground resembling a hospital they occupy the same position after nine games as they did last season and are only two points worse off. Mikey Stafford

This is a fixture consumed by off-field distractions. Portsmouth have this week been placed under a transfer embargo while Wigan have had to deal with the twin issues of an apologetic manager and a jailed striker. There will be relief, then, when play finally starts this afternoon. For Portsmouth, the aim is to secure a first home league victory of the season and they can take hope from the visitors' injuries in defence – both Chris Kirkland and Maynor Figueroa are likely to be unavailable to Roberto Martínez. Paul Hart, the Portsmouth manager, is himself likely to be without Papa Bouba Diop. Sachin Nakrani

Gianfranco Zola will look to build on last weekend's point against Arsenal when he takes his side to the Stadium of Light. Without a victory since the opening day of the season, West Ham find themselves in the bottom three as the off-pitch troubles that have dogged them since last year continue to unsettle the club. Steve Bruce's return to Birmingham ended in disappointment for the Sunderland manager and he will be hoping that Darren Bent, who missed the Carling Cup exit in midweek, will return as they go in search of a fifth consecutive home win. Chris Bell

Robbie Keane's belief that Tottenham have a squad that is at least the equal of Arsenal's smacked of boldness if not delusion. In their most recent trip to meet one of the Champions League clubs, his team were beaten 3-0 by Chelsea. Tottenham have not defeated Arsenal in almost a decade, a run of 19 matches without a win over their north London rivals. The clubs, however, are now adjacent in the table and an attacker such as Keane must believe he can exploit weaknesses in Arsène Wenger's line-up . Kevin McCarra

Aston Villa have made their best start to a season for 10 years and make the short trip to Molineux in confident mood following last Saturday's win over Chelsea. Wolves have failed to beat their neighbours in 14 matches, dating back to 1980, but Mick McCarthy's side can take comfort from the fact that both of Villa's defeats in the league this season have come against teams in the bottom half. Villa are likely to be unchanged, while McCarthy is expected to bring back Michael Mancienne, who has recovered from a virus. Stuart James

It is a measure of the serenity of Arsenal's progress that perhaps the biggest issue for Arsène Wenger is whether to persist with Vito Mannone in goal, or recall the now virus-free Manuel Almunia, who has stewed on the bench for the past two games. Mannone has had both excellent and erratic moments and Wenger is keen not only to accelerate his development but to reassure other players that they, too, can force their way in. What West Ham would give for such trifling worries. Another fraught afternoon beckons for them. David Hytner

The lasting strength of Tottenham's claim to a finish in the top four will be decided by how well Harry Redknapp's squad stand up to the rigours of winter, especially at the back with its recurrent aches and strains. Going forward Spurs have more options and Stoke's away form does not suggest they will be able to deny the opposition a win to stay in third place. However, Tony Pulis's side are nothing if not stubborn and Redknapp may need the lofty presence of Peter Crouch at some time or other to break them down. David Lacey

Mark Hughes will have half an eye on events at Anfield when his side welcome Fulham to Eastlands. City are within touching distance of the Premier League summit and Liverpool's recent poor form will have reinforced their self-belief. Fulham were the last team to beat City at home in the league and under Roy Hodgson's stewardship have looked to improve again this term. Denied victory over Roma in the last minute on Thursday night, Fulham will be out to dampen the City fans' early-season optimism. Chris Bell

Despite a planned protest against the owners before the match, there will be a show of unity and determination at Anfield tomorrow once the game begins. Inside the stadium the fans' efforts will be directed solely against Manchester United. Liverpool did beat these opponents twice in the league last season, but the club looks to be in a decline steepened by injuries. United, in contrast, should be able to field a stronger line-up than the one that beat CSKA Moscow in Russia on Wednesday. Kevin McCarra

The 'crisis' at Anfield is put into stark perspective as soon as the plights of Hull City and Portsmouth are examined. Despite rousing victories for both clubs in recent weeks, they remain fixed in serious relegation trouble and defeat for either at the KC Stadium could precede a truly miserable Christmas. Indeed, Hull's manager, Phil Brown, may not even last that long in his post – after this fixture his side face potentially make-or-break games against Burnley, Stoke City and West Ham United. Sachin Nakrani

Chelsea's dismantling of Atlético Madrid cost the Spaniards' manager, Abel Resino, his job, though a more stringent test of their resilience awaits. Rovers will seek to exploit the hosts' vulnerability in the air and prosper where Stoke, Wigan and Aston Villa have reaped rewards recently. Chelsea were without their manager Carlo Ancelotti in their preparations for this game, after he returned to Italy to be with his father who was taken ill on Wednesday night. Ancelotti expects to be back in time for kick-off but Ray Wilkins stands by. Dominic Fifield

Both managers are new to the Premier League and it says much for Wigan under Roberto Martínez that they were disappointed last Sunday not to add Manchester City's scalp to Chelsea's. A point, Martínez felt, did not reflect their domination but he hopes to "take the good things" into this game, such as the competitiveness of Hendry Thomas and Mohamed Diame, both in the league's top five tacklers. Those two games, though, were at home. Owen Coyle's Burnley have a 100% record at Turf Moor, thriving on high tempo. Jeremy Alexander

Bolton, who finished 13th last season, are again your typical mid-table team, with two wins, two draws and two defeats from their last six games. That said, they would have drawn at Old Trafford last Saturday had not Gary Cahill spurned a sitter in added time. In Kevin Davies they have a striker good enough to trouble any defence. Everton's 5-0 loss to Benfica was a red herring, given the absence of so many regulars, but draws at home to Stoke and Wolves and a negative goal difference does not augur well. Joe Lovejoy

Steve Bruce returns to St Andrew's with a Sunderland side in buoyant mood after victory over Liverpool. Bruce hopes to prove a point to his former club after his acrimonious departure in 2007, and with Darren Bent in sparkling form atop the division's scoring charts, stands every chance of gaining a second win over the Blues this term. In the first home game since Carson Yeung's arrival as Birmingham president, he will be watching from the stands as Alex McLeish seeks to heal their defensive frailty and keep their first clean sheet since August. Chris Bell

Mark Hughes may have spent £120m in the summer but the Manchester City manager has been left fretting about the size of his squad going into Sunday's match, with 11 players either out or struggling because of injury problems. Wigan beat Chelsea in their last match and Roberto Martínez could be forgiven for sensing that City might be vulnerable to another upset given the list of possible absentees, including Robinho, Kolo Touré and the in-form Craig Bellamy. The most pressing concern for Hughes is that all four of his first-choice defenders are having treatment. Daniel Taylor

The last time these two clubs met Eduardo suffered a broken leg and dislocated ankle, William Gallas staged a sit-down protest and Arsenal's season imploded. One can only imagine this will be a more sedate affair. The portents are not promising for Birmingham. Arsenal have won their previous six matches and scored four or more in each of their last four home fixtures. Birmingham, on the other hand, have lost four of their last five in the Premier League and not won at Arsenal since 1957. Carson Yeung, Birmingham's new president, was not even born then. Stuart James

Burnley's results on the road in the Premier League so far; 0-2, 0-3, 0-4, 0-5. The consequences of that miserable sequence continuing at Ewood Park do not bear thinking about. Strip away the raw emotion of the east Lancashire derby, a tall order admittedly, and Owen Coyle's clear priority is to inject some Turf Moor resilience into a Burnley team beset by injuries to key players. Opposite number Sam Allardyce simply wants a repeat of Blackburn's last home game; a 10-man victory over Aston Villa he has labelled "one of the biggest results I've ever had as a Premier League manager". Andy Hunter

Unbeaten in six matches in all competitions, the mood is buoyant at Everton these days. Bar the opening day 6-1 thumping by Arsenal, David Moyes's team are based on a tight defence, and in Louis Saha he has one of the division's most potent strikers. They will expect nothing but a win. For Mick McCarthy there are only problems. His team have won only one away game and he will need the strikers to start firing soon if they are not to get stuck in a relegation scrap. Patrick Curry

With Fulham having already played 14 games this season, and now facing a midweek visit to Roma, Roy Hodgson will have been glad of the rest the international break provided for some of his squad. Phil Brown's first ever top-flight victory came over Fulham, but a lot has changed since then. Despite a much-needed victory over Wigan, Hull still sit in the bottom three and will need to shore up the worst defensive record in the Premier League if they are to avoid the relegation worries that engulfed them last season. Patrick Curry

The story of Michael Owen's first two months at Old Trafford is that he appears to be reserved exclusively for Lancashire derbies. His first league start was at Burnley and Wayne Rooney's calf injury has ensured that his second will be against Bolton. His only goal has been the winner against Manchester City, when Alan Wiley's timekeeping rather than his fitness was the chief source of comment. Sir Alex Ferguson will await Dimitar Berbatov's return from Bulgaria after the birth of his child to assess how ready he is to play. Tim Rich

The international break has not been kind to Rafael Benítez. Liverpool have lost Steven Gerrard and Fernando Torres to injury since their 2-0 defeat to Chelsea two weeks ago and may have to field Lucas Leiva and Javier Mascherano at the Stadium of Light despite the pair having returned late from their World Cup exploits in South America. The Merseysiders have not lost consecutive league games since December 2007, but Sunderland, who must feel grateful that Fabio Capello continues to overlook Darren Bent, will fancy their chances after giving Manchester United a scare last time out. John Ashdown

For Gianfranco Zola it's a question of when does a bad run become a crisis? The West Ham manager has not seen his side win in the league since the opening day and witnessed them keep only two clean sheets so far this campaign. The Italian has plenty to ponder, then, as he travels to the Potteries. Stoke, meanwhile, are comfortably ensconced in mid-table and will look to exploiting any uncertainty in the Hammers defence. They, however, will have to be wary of Carlton Cole, who has already scored four times this season. Patrick Curry

Jermain Defoe, Peter Crouch and Niko Kranjcar join Harry Redknapp and his coaching staffin what is likely to be a fractious reunion on the south coast. The hosts, buoyed by their latest takeover and their first points of the season, could conceivably hoist themselves from the foot with a win, but Spurs are third and potent even on their travels these days. The corresponding fixture was won courtesy of goals from Defoe and Crouch last season. Pompey must ensure that scenario is not repeated if they are to leave Redknapp defeated and deflated. Dominic Fifield

Chelsea's victory at Villa Park in February was their first at the ground since 2000. Tomorrow's fixture ought to be demanding for Carlo Ancelotti's team, who were beaten 3-1 at Wigan in their last away game in the league. Villa led the expensively assembled Manchester City 1-0 earlier this month in the eventual draw. Containing the visitors will be difficult, particularly because of the outstanding form for Chelsea of Didier Drogba, who also scored last weekend to confirm Ivory Coast's place at the 2010 World Cup. Kevin McCarra

A visit to Turf Moor is a daunting prospect, particularly for a Birmingham side who have struggled for goals and been ravaged by injury problems all season. The visitors' task may be made even tougher by the return of Burnley's captain Steven Caldwell, who missed the start of the season with a groin complaint. It is not all good news for the manager Owen Coyle, however, as Jay Rodriguez has joined Chris McCann and Martin Paterson on the long-term injury list after fracturing an ankle in training. Richard Flower

The managers of these clubs might have been in an unwitting contest to decide who was the more irascible. Rafael Benítez had an advantage since his rage was stoked by Liverpool's defeat in Fiorentina. Given that he was handicapped by a win, away to Apoel Nicosia, Carlo Ancelotti did well to deplore the Chelsea display with such feeling. There is no doubting which man is in the greater difficulty – a loss for the visitors would be a third in a mere eight league fixtures. Chelsea, though, have the challenge of regaining form if they are to win. Kevin McCarra

Molineux welcomes a club in complete and utter crisis. Bottom of the league with zero points, so impoverished that they cannot even pay wages to their players and now having to deal with their owner, Sulaiman al-Fahim, being in hospital, Portsmouth's supporters must be wondering when the misery will end. They can take hope, however, from their side's showing in last week's 1-0 defeat to Everton, when they deserved to win, as well as from Wolves' porous defending during their 5-2 defeat at Sunderland last Sunday. Sachin Nakrani

Steve Bruce has had an encouraging start to his new job as Sunderland manager but his team face a side today who are looking for a ninth successive win in all competitions. Manchester United have gone to the top of the table and the portents are not good for Sunderland, given that they have not won at Old Trafford in more than 40 years. Bruce has a terrible record against Sir Alex Ferguson as a manager and Sunderland are likely to miss the combative Lee Cattermole if the midfielder does not recover from a shoulder injury. Daniel Taylor

It is never too early to start worrying, as your mother might say, and despite both of these teams feeling that they are playing well enough, results have left them peering up at most of the table. Although not one of London's high-profile derbies there is sure to be tension as three points are sought, especially within West Ham's ranks, as they have lost all of their home fixtures. Both managers have strict ball-playing principles which they will not desert, pointing towards a pleasing 90 minutes ,but goals have been in short supply. David Hytner

Peter Reid returns to Everton as the enemy. The former Goodison Park midfielder has swapped coaching Thailand for assisting Tony Pulis and will hope to find his old team suitably jet-lagged. Indeed Stoke are probably the last side David Moyes's side would have wanted to meet after a Europa League trip to Belarus and a hard-fought Thursday night win in Minsk. Stoke's former Everton centre-forward James Beattie will be aiming to jog a few memories with a goal or two but with Yakubu finally fit Moyes is, for once, not lacking in attacking options. Louise Taylor

Phil Brown desperately requires a win, having managed one this season, leaving Hull second-bottom on four points from seven games and looking in danger of suffering second season syndrome. Liverpool's 6-1 hammering of them last Saturday was hardly the loss-with-honour the usually effervescent Brown could have drawn sustenance from ahead of Wigan's visit. Roberto Martínez, meanwhile, has the fillip of guiding the Latics to a first ever triumph over a big four club – Chelsea's deserved 3-1 defeat – last time out. He may also note Hull's worrying goal difference which already stands at minus 13. Jamie Jackson

Old Trafford, where they have not won since 1989, is famously one of Tottenham's great hoodoo grounds. But there is another part of Greater Manchester where Spurs come regularly and spectacularly to grief – the Reebok, where they have never won in the Premier League. Jermain Defoe's broken hand, sustained in the 5-0 rout of Burnley last Saturday, could force Harry Redknapp to play Peter Crouch up front, although given Bolton's physical game, the Tottenham manager might have done that anyway. His counterpart, Gary Megson, will be without Johan Elmander but buoyed by four games without defeat. Tim Rich

Aston Villa face quite a challenge to repeat last season's top-six finish since clubs such as Tottenham and, in particular, Manchester City have upgraded their squads. Martin O'Neill's side had been looking quite effective in the league, winning three matches in a row while keeping a clean sheet, but doubts about their defence were reawakened by the 2-1 loss to Blackburn. Villa, at home, still ought to present a test of City's credentials. Mark Hughes's team can at least be bolstered by Emmanuel Adebayor, who has completed his suspension. Kevin McCarra

Sam Allardyce is unlikely to make the same mistake he did last season, when Blackburn were uncharacteristically timid and let Arsenal pick them off. With the Gunners averaging three goals per game in the Premier League the Emirates crowd can expect a more abrasive resistance from Rovers of the type that so unnerved them when Allardyce was at Bolton. Patience may again be required for Wenger's men and Theo Walcott will be desperate to get in on the act for what would be his first appearance of the season. Amy Lawrence

As a Championship team, Burnley ran Tottenham close in last season's Carling Cup semi-finals when they threatened to wipe out Spurs' 4-1 lead in the return leg at Turf Moor. Given Burnley's early away form in the Premier League – no points from three matches and nine goals conceded – they may suffer a similarly heavy defeat today, this time with no second chance. Burnley's confidence cannot have been helped by Harry Redknapp's confession that he has difficulty knowing which strikers to leave out of his attack. David Lacey

When will Chelsea fail to win this season? Carlo Ancelotti's team lead the league with 18 points from six games and a goal difference of 12. Wigan, on the other hand, only have six points and a goal difference of -8. Last week, Arsenal handed Roberto Martínez's men a 4-0 hammering so a point against John Terry and company would undoubtedly be a psychological fillip for them. The visitors, though, will have Yuri Zhirkov eager to impress in what could be his second game for the club following a return from injury. Jamie Jackson

There will no motivational material for Tony Pulis to pin up on the dressing-room wall. "Stoke are going to be a force," said Sir Alex Ferguson yesterday. The Manchester United manager knows how to use flattery to help his cause but he also appreciates just how difficult it can be to get a result at the Britannia Stadium following last season's 1-0 win. The significant team news is that Ben Foster will definitely start in goal for United despite his mistakes last weekend. No prizes for guessing whom Stoke will be targeting. Stuart James

Emmanuel Adebayor is serving the last game of his three-match suspension but Roque Santa Cruz could be involved for the first time since his £17m move from Blackburn Rovers. Santa Cruz came through 45 minutes of a training-ground friendly against Wrexham on Wednesday, as did Michael Johnson, the largely forgotten midfielder who has suffered from a year-long groin problem. West Ham have won only one of their opening five league fixtures and could be vulnerable to a City attack led by Carlos Tevez, a former Hammer. Daniel Taylor

Mick McCarthy returns to the Stadium of Light once more but this time his old Ireland nemesis Roy Keane will not be occupying the home dug-out. Instead it is now filled by Steve Bruce, who has been careful to talk of his "massive admiration" for McCarthy this week. During the Wolves manager's time in charge on Wearside, Sunderland had next to no money to spend but, having seriously splashed the cash this summer, Bruce is under pressure to produce results. McCarthy and his side also have several points to prove, though. Louise Taylor

Blackburn Rovers have won once in the league this season and come into this game short of confidence following their 3-0 hammering at Everton on Sunday. Their visitors have no such problems, however, as they head to Ewood Park on the back of six straight wins. Gabriel Agbonlahor has been the focal point of that success, scoring in last four outings, while the visitors have yet to concede in any competition this month. With a trip to the Emirates to follow, Rovers have a tough fortnight ahead of them. Lee Price

Portsmouth's ongoing woes led to their manager, Paul Hart, walking out of a press conference on Thursday. Another defeat today and he may be tempted to walk out on the club altogether. These are truly desperate times for the 2008 FA Cup winners, both on and off the field, and the growing sense is that things will only get worse before they get better. Indeed, the hosts could have done without the visit of a side who have scored 11 goals without reply in their last three games and, in Louis Saha, boast a striker reborn. Sachin Nakrani

Arsenal will hope to continue their rich vein of form in front of goal this weekend, but face a tough test against Roy Hodgson's well-drilled back-line. Fulham's defensive record so far this season is better than that of the visitors, although a paltry four league goals – less than a quarter of what Arsenal have mustered – must be a real cause for concern. With Vito Mannone expected to remain in goal for Arsène Wenger's side, however, Fulham's misfiring forwards will sense an opportunity to bolster their tallies. Lee Price

Is it really only nine months since Bernand Mendy destroyed Andrea Dossena on the right wing and forced Jamie Carragher to concede the own goal that brought Hull a two-goal lead at Anfield? It must feel like another lifetime ago to Phil Brown now. The Hull manager has an inauspicious start to the five games that may decide his fate and another mauling like that suffered against Everton on Wednesday could hasten his demise. Liverpool have discovered the art of demolishing lesser sides at home so far this season. Andy Hunter

David Sullivan and Karren Brady have spent this week reminding fans of the "pretty good job" they have done as chairman and chief executive at Birmingham City and today's game marks their departure from St Andrew's. It is not likely to provide much of a send-off – the last four matches between these sides have produced six goals and just two goals have been scored in City's last three home league games. With pressure on both managers, that return is unlikely to be improved upon. Expect a tense, nervy affair. John Ashdown

Any hopes Wolverhampton Wanderers had of facing a Fulham side affected by the demands of a Thursday night fixture in Sofia were dashed when Roy Hodgson made nine changes for the 1-1 draw in Bulgaria. Hodgson has learnt his lesson after the previous European away trip, which was followed by a dismal showing at Aston Villa. Wolves, who are boosted by the return of Michael Kightly, Kevin Foley, Jody Craddock and Sylvan Ebanks-Blake, need a victory after picking up only one point from their previous three matches. Stuart James

For Rafael Benítez, the hope is that familiarity does not breed complacency. The Liverpool side he deploys at Upton Park is likely to contain three former Hammers – Javier Mascherano, Yossi Benayoun and Glen Johnson – but now is not the time for friendly reunions. Despite winning their last two matches, Liverpool's title credentials remain on shaky ground and they can ill afford another slip-up. Four days after marking a year in charge of West Ham, Gianfranco Zola will be aiming for a second victory of the season. Sachin Nakrani

We are barely into the second half of September but this has the ominous look of a relegation six-pointer. Bookmakers are not quite sure whether Phil Brown or Alex McLeish is the manager in greater peril of losing his job but the former remains manically positive and with Jimmy Bullard, now pencilled in to return to Hull's midfield from injury next month, perhaps has some reason to be. If Brown's side are weakened defensively by Michael Turner's defection to Sunderland, Birmingham huff and puff horribly in front of goal. Louise Taylor

This match now looks less like a show of Manchester City's resources than a test of their adaptability when circumstances are against them. In theory, the suspension of Emmanuel Adebayor and injuries to other attackers will limit their capacity to take the game to United. The derby still has an enhanced status not only because of the sums lavished on the visitors and the fact that Sir Alex Ferguson has disparaged them, but also because City are level with United on points despite having played one game fewer. Kevin McCarra

It is seven matches since Burnley last conceded at Turf Moor, but while defeats at Chelsea and Liverpool can hardly be taken as evidence that the Clarets' bubble has burst, there is a feeling that the arrival of a confident and much-improved Sunderland side represents an important test for Owen Coyle's team. Steve Bruce's new signings, including Darren Bent and Michael Turner, are bringing out the best in the likes of Andy Reid and Anton Ferdinand, and an attractive, open game could be on the agenda in this contest. Richard Rae

When Jermain Defoe leapt to volley Tottenham into a first-minute lead against Manchester United last weekend, the dreams of their supporters ran wild. Their flawless start to the season would add the scalp of the champions to that of Liverpool. United's subsequent comeback supplied the reality check and now comes the trip to a stadium where they have not won in 19 years and 22 matches. Spurs will attack but Chelsea, relentless and remorseless, have yet to be stopped under their latest manager, Carlo Ancelotti. David Hytner

You know Everton's season is not going to script when Lee Dixon and Martin Keown are asked whether David Moyes' team "will be all right?" – as occurred on Match of the Day last Sunday following their defeat at Fulham. Everton have yet to find solidity, balance or invention in the league, unlike Blackburn, who discovered all three in their recent defeat of Wolves. David Dunn was instrumental in that win and a reunion with their former captain Lucas Neill rests on how rusty Moyes deems his new signing to be. Andy Hunter

After picking up their first points of the season at Portsmouth last week, the Bolton manager, Gary Megson, said his players had to learn to become more physical. There could no more immediate test of that policy than Stoke. Tony Pulis's side, however, are still recovering from their heroic exertions against Chelsea. The goalkeeper Thomas Sorensen, who limped off midway through that game, should have recovered from a thigh strain in time. However, James Beattie, who burst a blood vessel in his ankle, is more doubtful. Tim Rich

Still at the bottom of the table on zero points, Portsmouth will be lucky to come away with a point from this fixture. Martin O'Neill's in-form side will give Paul Hart's men a tough match, although Portsmouth should feel more confident having England's David James back in the side. The south coast club may also take heart from alleged unrest at Villa – a reported training ground punch-up between O'Neill and Nigel Reo-Coker, who grappled on the pitch this week in a dispute about the former being left off the team-sheet. Anna Kessel

What Arsenal need is a straightforward victory without collywobbles or further injuries. They should get it today, although Wigan did begin the season by winning at Aston Villa and will be quick to punish any further lapses by Arsène Wenger's defence. Robin van Persie should be back in the Arsenal attack after a knee problem and Andrey Arshavin may be sufficiently recovered from a groin strain to play some part. But with Manuel Almunia still getting over a chest infection, the nervous Vito Mannone may keep his place in goal. David Lacey

Arsenal's trip to Eastlands combined with Tottenham's hosting of Manchester United offers Liverpool the chance to make ground on the leading pack. They will need to seize the opportunity, too, if a faltering title challenge is not to collapse completely. The anxiety of Liverpool's supporters will be raised by memories of Burnley's triumph over their side in the 2005 FA Cup but thankfully for them, Djimi Traoré no longer plays for the club. Instead, Fábio Aurélio should come in at left-back following his recovery from injury. Sachin Nakrani

A Gaël Givet header from a set piece is the sum total of Blackburn's goal tally in the Premier League so far this season and while their manager, Sam Allardyce, acknowledges that his team are never likely to be prolific, that has to change against Wolves today if they are to avoid being cut adrift so early in the season. Mick McCarthy's team will head to Ewood Park looking to exploit Blackburn's desperation for goals and will fancy their chances of adding to a creditable total of four points from four matches. Ian Bayley

Portsmouth will be hoping that a rush of last-minute signings can reverse a dreadful start to the season that has seen them lose all four of their games and score just a single goal. Bolton have also started badly and would appear to be vulnerable, having not won away in the Premier League since November last year. The former Portsmouth midfielder Sean Davis is suspended for the trip to his old club, having picked up two yellow cards and one red in three appearances since moving to the Reebok Stadium in the summer. Richard Flower

Fulham are the only club in the Premier League who can point out that their season started in July, with a Europa League qualifying tie away to Vetra, and one of the greatest challenges facing Roy Hodgson is accommodating the demands of Europe. His team looked jaded at Aston Villa two weekends ago after the long trip to play Amkar Perm in eastern Russia. The Everton manager, David Moyes, has similar worries, after his team also advanced to the Europa League group phase, but at least this is more familiar territory to his squad. David Hytner

Wigan will be doing all they can to win this match to stem the bleeding prompted by four successive defeats. Roberto Martínez is yet to win as a manager at the DW Stadium and although the Premier League is still in its infancy, a win here would stop a drama turning into a crisis. West Ham manager Gianfranco Zola will be thinking similar thoughts on his one-year anniversary in charge at Upton Park. Zola will also be hoping Carlton Cole puts in a better performance than during the dreadful visit to Blackburn a fortnight ago. Chris Brereton

Carlos Tevez will be missing for Manchester City, and probably Robinho too, but the central figure today was always going to be Emmanuel Adebayor, formerly of Arsenal and now desperate to prove a point or two to the supporters who, he claims, hounded him out. "He's on fire," says Arsène Wenger, the Arsenal manager, "and we have to put it out." Wenger's team will stand a good chance if they can reproduce their performance from their last trip to Manchester, the undeserved 2-1 defeat at Old Trafford a fortnight ago. Daniel Taylor

This game could provide another piece of evidence that the old order is fading. Liverpool have already been beaten at White Hart Lane and the Manchester United squad is not as redoubtable as it has been in previous years. The main difficulty for Tottenham will lie in showing that they now have the mentality to continue a run of wins in the Premier League. There is still a certain slackness about a team that has conceded a goal in each of the five matches it has played this season in league and Carling Cup. Kevin McCarra

Steve Bruce will give Michael Turner his Sunderland debut against his old club Hull after signing him for around £6m on deadline day. The centre-back will be replaced at the heart of the Hull defence by the Senegal international Ibrahima Sonko, who has joined on loan from Reading. Sunderland could face a crisis behind Turner as both Marton Fulop and Craig Gordon are doubts with heel and knee problems respectively. Hull will be missing Caleb Folan, who is believed to be talking to Middlesbrough about a move to the Riverside. Richard Flower

The last time these two west Midlands rivals met, at Villa Park in April 2008, Birmingham City suffered a 5-1 defeat that pushed Alex McLeish's side a step closer to relegation. It was the sort of hammering that leaves a few scars and ought to provide McLeish and his players with additional motivation tomorrow. After a slow start to the season, Aston Villa have picked up and arrive at St Andrew's on the back of three straight victories. Richard Dunne, Stephen Warnock and James Collins are all expected to make their debuts. Stuart James

Chelsea's machine gets its first outing post-Kakuta with a visit to a Stoke side strengthened by the arrivals of Tuncay Sanli and Robert Huth. Carlo Ancelotti has declared that Fifa's proposed transfer ban is not a concern so he will hope John Terry and company can underline his bullishness by recording a fifth successive victory. Tony Pulis' men stand a place outside the Champions League positions as they continue last season's admirable work. A point won before a fevered Britannia crowd would not be a total surprise. Jamie Jackson

Despite their 4-0 win over Stoke, Liverpool remain a club rocking on its heels following the departure of Xabi Alonso and a clutch of injuries that has left the squad looking bare. But after the opening day defeat at White Hart Lane, another reversal so soon into the new season is unthinkable. It helps, then, that they are facing a side that has lost its last two games and failed to score on either occasion. Aston Villa could also be without Curtis Davies after he injured his shoulder in Thursday's defeat to Rapid Vienna. Sachin Nakrani

The current league leaders step out into the feverish atmosphere generated by this fixture attempting to maintain rare momentum. It took Tottenham 10 games last season to muster the six points they boast from two fixtures this time around, and eight, seven and six matches in the three years before. The midweek thumping of Hull City sharpened Jermain Defoe up for a return to his former club though West Ham, impressive in defeating Wolves and a slick threat under Gianfranco Zola, will provide a sterner test of their mettle. Dominic Fifield

Manchester United's 1-0 defeat at Burnley on Wednesday already represents one of the more astounding results that will happen in the entire Premier League season. United, however, are unlikely to play so badly again and have an immaculate record against Wigan since their promotion to the top division. The fit-again Nemanja Vidic and Gary Neville are in line to start but Rio Ferdiand is likely to miss out. Antonio Valencia, signed from Wigan for £17m earlier this summer, will be keen to impress against his old club. Daniel Taylor

These are truly glorious times for the new and improved Manchester City. Having beaten Blackburn last week, Mark Hughes' side then overcame Barcelona at Camp Nou on the same night local rivals United were losing at Burnley. But City being City, there remains every chance they will slip-up against a newly promoted side in front of their fans. Wolves also arrive at Eastlands buoyed by their midweek win at Wigan – their first ever away victory in the Premier League. Carlos Tevez should make his full debut for the hosts. Sachin Nakrani

Any optimism generated by Hull's narrow defeat at Chelsea in their opening fixture was quickly dissipated by the manner in which Phil Brown's side was dismantled by Spurs in midweek. Bolton also made a poor start at home to Sunderland but their new signings Sean Davis, Paul Robinson, Zat Knight and Sam Ricketts give them scope for improvement while Brown will be hoping the American striker Jozy Altidore, available after visa problems, can give his toothless Tigers some bite up front. One thing is for sure – it won't be pretty. Richard Rae

The achievements of Fulham, who came seventh last season, often go unnoticed, but they will not have escaped Chelsea. The visitors' prospects of maintaining a perfect record in these early days are now enhanced, however, by the fact that the Fulham striker Andrew Johnson suffered a collarbone injury last night against Ankar Perm. Roy Hodgson's team still has some cause to feel buoyant. Fulham have scored 10 goals while winning all four of their fixtures so far, even if three of them were Europa League qualifiers. Kevin McCarra

Turf Moor thrived on its first top-flight game for 33 years and Owen Coyle's team will be confident of continuing the momentum that stunned Manchester United. Coyle's fellow Scot, David Moyes, must hope the final hour against Sigma Olomouc in the Europa League marked a U-turn in Everton's early season form but, with the Joleon Lescott saga ongoing, Phil Neville required as an emergency central defender and still no reinforcements in place, the visitors face an arduous task to recover from their Arsenal humbling. Andy Hunter

If Birmingham are to stay in the Premier League for more than their usual season this is the sort of home fixture they need to win on a regular basis. Stoke can be sticky opponents but their away record was poor last season and even a point at St Andrew's today would be a small triumph. With Grégory Vignal and Cameron Jerome carrying knocks Alex McLeish may have to make changes, one of which would mean a start up front for record-signing Christian Benítez. Lee Bowyer is set to play in midfield after completing a suspension. David Lacey

Peter Storrie says he has a mystery new backer who will fund a rescue act at Portsmouth. The club would then, presumably, be in a position to meet its scheduled loan repayment of £24-36m by Monday week, meaning it would not have to sell more players and the only way would be up. Excellent. The pessimistic reading as push comes to shove at Fratton Park is somewhat darker. Thank goodness then for respite today, with 90 minutes against a struggling team, whose confidence has been shot to piece by the naysayers. Hang on a minute... David Hytner

As a former Newcastle United manager, Blackburn's Sam Allardyce can expect a hot reception. Steve Bruce, meanwhile, anticipates a somewhat gruelling afternoon. "Sam is very, very well organised and his teams play to a system which is not always easy on the eye but is very effective," said Sunderland's manager. "But these are the games we are going to be judged on." This is the home side's third match in a week and, with injuries mounting, it will be intriguing to see if Bruce offers fit crowd favourite Andy Reid a start. Louise Taylor
